PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Building Materials
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit our opposition to the announced imposition of Sales Tax of 12% on basic hardware and building products by the Federal Government from July 1 1995. The petitioners note particularly that:

1. This new tax will directly affect ordinary Australians in the form of rising prices of building, maintaining and improving their home and by consequential job losses and company closures in an industry which has faced many economic pressures over recent years.
2. The new tax offers no net benefit to Australia and should be abandoned.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners request that the Senate should not pass this legislation when it is presented and/or work to prevent this taxation measure from being implemented by the current Federal Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Building Materials
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of New South Wales respectfully showeth that the tax on selected building products, proposed in the May 1995 Budget, will place an unwelcome burden on all Australians planning to build a new home or carry out alterations and additions, or repairs/maintenance to existing homes. Moreover, it is considered that the tax is iniquitous in that, when introduced, it will apply retrospectively to people currently building homes, who had entered in good faith into `fixed price' building contracts.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject the extension of proposed wholesale sales tax to building products.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Building Materials
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned citizens strongly urge the Government to accept the Democrats' proposal to drop the intended tax on essential building materials.

We believe the proposed tax—adding between $600 and $1,200 on the cost of a medium-sized home and up to $3,000 over the life of a mortgage—will make it more difficult for Australians to buy their own home, increase maintenance costs and rents on existing houses, and hinder growth in the building industry.
We call on the Government to drop the tax on essential building materials.

PETITION.TITLE: Census
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That the current practice of destroying the Census is denying future generations an invaluable and irreplaceable resource of data on medical, historical, social, scientific, and demographic factors.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:

Request the Government to review its current policy of destroying the Census; and support a proposal to retain the census forms for release for specific research purposes in either 70 or 100 years time.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

PARA.TAB: We call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Women: Pension Age
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned strongly opposes the increase in the Pension age for women from 60 to 65.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate take action to reverse this decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the Child Support Scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing in the Pacific
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned expresses the widespread community outrate throughout Australia at the decision of the French Gov to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition and convey to the French Parliament in the strongest terms Australia's opposition to this decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnamese Asylum Seekers
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate, assembled in Parliament House of the Commonwealth of Australia:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate various concerns related to Vietnamese asylum seekers in South East Asia and Hong Kong camps. These are: Firstly, that there is strong evidence that their refugee status determination (screening) by the first asylum countries under the Comprehensive Plan of Action (CPA) was flawed by widespread corruption and/or prejudice by screening and appeal panels, and procedural faults. Secondly, that the UN High Commission for Refugees is not seen to take active nor systematic steps to identify and review wrongly screened out refugees. Thirdly, all asylum seekers are now facing or will soon face forced repatriation against their will, amounting to refugee refoulement in the case of refugees among them. Fourthly, all asylum seekers have for some years now been deprived of basic needs by measures such as closing of secondary and primary schools in camps, cutting of essential medical facilities, and restricting communications with relatives outside the camps, which are seen as designed to coerce asylum seekers to repatriate against their will.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate

PARA.TAB: 1. Request the Australian government, as a signatory to the Comprehensive Plan of Action (CPA), to raise the question of whether their screening was flawed by corruption, prejudice, and procedural faults resulting in refugees being wrongly rejected as economic migrants; and to require investigative and remedial actions within the CPA.

2. Request the Australian government to follow up on the UNHCR's admission (as reported by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs Nick Bolkus to the Senate on 1st February 1995) that there has been corruption in screening in Indonesia, with the view of:

(a) ascertaining why in 1994 the UNHCR replied to Minister Bolkus that it was not aware of any corruption, while prior to that time according to its own internal documents the UNHCR should have been aware of it

(b) requesting the UNHCR to state whether it is aware of any corruption or any other reason why screening in other first asylum countries might have resulted in refugees being wrongly denied refugee status
(c) requesting the UNHCR to take corrective actions, and report same to the Australian government
3. Request the Australian government to request first asylum country governments to investigate whether there were flaws in the screening of Vietnamese refugees, and to take corrective actions
4. Request the Australian government to request the first asylum country governments to immediately stop the planning and/or execution of plans for repatriation of non-consenting asylum seekers

5. Request the Australian government to request the first asylum country governments to immediately stop restrictive measures such as closing of secondary and primary schools in camps, cutting of essential medical facilities, and restricting communications with relatives outside the camps, which are seen as designed to coerce asylum seekers to repatriate against their will

6. Request the honourable member for Blaxland, Mr Paul Keating, MP, to consider petitions signed by approximately 24,000 Australian citizens related to this topic that were submitted to his electorate office in March 1995 by the President of the Vietnamese Community in Australia and the President of the Council of Vietnamese Refugee Supporting Organisations in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TROETH

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present to the Senate the following petition, from 1,053 citizens, which is not in conformity with the standing orders as it is not in the correct form:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned, urge the Federal Minister for Primary Industry to reconsider the Federal Government's decision to exclude Central and Northern Victoria from qualifying for exceptional circumstance provision for drought relief under the Rural Adjustment Scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to make a short statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

Senator TROETH—I thank the Senate. I wish to highlight the problem that is presently being encountered by farmers affected by drought in central McEwen. Two areas in Victoria received assistance; unfortunately, the area of McEwen was not one of those. Farmers in the area of McEwen have been feeding out for the past 12 to 18 months: many have spent in excess of $40,000 on feed, the average cost to keep sheep alive is between $10 and $15 per head, and the majority of farmers have used up their cash reserves.

Although the recent rain means that the drought has broken, it is now a green drought in that there is a veneer of green but no real growth of pasture. Farmers in this area cannot understand why some wheat areas qualify for special circumstance provision because they need assistance to harvest their crops, but cattle and sheep are not regarded as a similar harvest in the sense that assistance should be granted to keep those animals alive and in good condition until a cash return can be obtained from them.

Representations have been made by the member for McEwen, Mr Cleeland, saying that the government followed the RASAC guidelines, but the petitioners would like the guidelines and recommendations to be published so that they can judge for themselves whether or not McEwen was treated fairly. Ultimately, the government can choose to accept or not accept the recommendations. The people who have signed this petition hope that the government would wish to consider McEwen in the list of areas to be looked at for exceptional circumstance.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present to the Senate the following petition, from 378 petitioners, which is not in conformity with the standing orders as it is not in the correct form:

PARA.TAB: Herewith the petition by the undersigned residents of Australia, and unto this Honourable Office, respectfully alleges;
1. That on July 2, 1994 Mr Pedro Lim went to the Philippines for the purpose of attending his sister's wedding;
2. That few months after his arrival, he was arrested for the murder of his sister's lawyer;
3. That he was thrown in jail without due process of law;
4. That because of such allegation he stands to lose his business interest in which he is in partnership with his sister;
5. That since the business was put up the sister wants to take over the whole venture as her own;
6. That Mr Pedro Lim by right is already well off and have no reason to kill anyone just to gain control of a business venture;
7. That the business venture is mostly financed by Mr Pedro Lim;
8. That the Philippine authorities acted solely upon the witness presented by his sister pointing to Mr Pedro Lim as the mastermind without reviewing all evidence and background information;

Whereof, in view of all the foregoing, it is respectfully prayed that this office intercede so that Mr Pedro Lim can be released and be properly represented without fear of harassment and intimidation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a) congratulates the Australian under-21 netball team for the exciting victory over the New Zealand team in the first test last night in Canberra—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this not a notice of motion that is clearly out of order?
—I think not, Mr President.
—We can go through the process of listening to it and then cutting it out later, but I think it is one of those clearly agreed by all parties as being out of order.

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza—I take a point of order, Mr President. I suggest to you, Mr President, that you should listen to what he has to say and then rule whether it is in order or not, otherwise how do you know?

Senator Michael Baume—On the point of order, Mr President: I understood that the prohibition on that kind of congratulatory notice of motion related to internal sporting activities, not to national teams in international competition. In fact, as I understood it, there have been congratulatory notices of motion relating to, for example, Mr Allan Border, which I am certain were passed in this chamber, and to various other national sporting heroes in respect of their national achievements which do bear a relationship with the national parliament.

I understood that the strong view of the Senate was that, while it was inappropriate for internal championships and so on to be lauded in notices of motion, there was specifically no prohibition on notices of motion which took note of national achievements by Australian sports men and women in international arenas. Whilst the netball team only won by one point, it is still a very important one point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not discounting the importance of it. It is out of order if it has nothing to do with the national parliament. It may be that your motion refers to that later on; I might have been anticipating. Perhaps I should hear you out.

—I think perhaps you were, Mr President. I think Senator Baume made the point well. The agreement is that if it is a major national sporting team and not the Mukinbudin tiddlywinks association it is relevant. It is also linked to the national parliament, in this case through the Australian Sports Commission.

PARA.TAB: I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

PARA.TAB: I am advised by the Bureau of Resource Sciences that are carrying out this report for AQIS that they are in the final stages of completing the report, that it is not in proper form at the moment—although they are just about there to actually release, partially, the report. TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) for that guarantee that, by 1 August, he will give the report to the Senate, to Senator Coulter who I know has a particular interest in this matter and to myself.

PARA.TAB: I am concerned, as are many other senators and many other industry representatives, that the minimal risk standards that are being accepted by AQIS have the potential to allow disease into Australia. That is not only my opinion. According to a headline in today's Australian, it is also the opinion of CSIRO officers who are seeking a review of the `flawed quarantine policy'.

There is much angst out there in primary industry that we maintain a high standard of primary industry in Australia. Mr Humphreys, who is the chairman of the BRS working party, has been working on this since 1992. That is an exceptionally long period for a report to be in the working stages.

I accept the minister's proposal, but there are great concerns in the community. Australia has a virtually disease free primary industry. We must maintain at all costs the high quality health standards that have been set over the last 90 years. We do and can command a premium on our products. The reason that we can promote our products as clean and green is that we maintain—we always have maintained—a very high standard.

The report that was tabled on Monday, which could not rule out that the importation of pilchards could have caused the massive pilchard kill around Australia, has sent a shock wave through primary industry around Australia. They are now saying—the minister is aware of this; if the minister is not concerned, he should be—that the notion of minimal risk is just not acceptable. The CSIRO has said that the protocols surrounding minimal risk have to be very much tightened. I point this out to the Senate. Senator Collins has a big responsibility in this matter to maintain Australia's high standards of primary industry.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the revised explanatory memorandum to the bills, and move:

The speeches read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: ABORIGINAL LAND GRANT AND MANAGEMENT (JERVIS BAY TERRITORY) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: This bill reflects the continuing commitment of this Government to securing legitimate title to traditional lands on behalf of the Aboriginal people throughout Australia. The Bill is a result of a wide acknowledgment of the significance of Jervis Bay to the local Aboriginal people and their strong work as a community in the area.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill is modelled on the very successful and highly acclaimed Uluru National Park joint management arrangement. That arrangement recently won the prestigious award, the UNESCO Picasso Gold Medal, in recognition of the outstanding management and conservation of Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park which has been achieved with the participation and support of the traditional Aboriginal owners of the area.

This bill, once approved by Parliament, has the potential to provide opportunities for non-indigenous Australians visiting the internationally renowned Jervis Bay to learn a great deal about the vibrant indigenous culture that has cared for these lands and waters for so many generations, and will undoubtedly advance Australia's international standing through its demonstration of the Government's commitment to indigenous joint management of such heritage areas.

This bill also represents a significant step in the reconciliation process by formalising the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community's willingness to participate in an arrangement to utilise their lands and waters in the National Park as a significant and properly planned cultural tourism destination. The bill embraces the progressive views of major environmental organisations in Australia that have responded to the concept of indigenous land management in such a positive way.

Indeed, Mr President, I think it should also be pointed out that the grant of these areas and associated joint management proposals have received wide public support, particularly from the local region, as is evidenced by an editorial in the Illawarra Mercury when the Government first announced its intentions in October last year.

The bill will enable title to such areas of the Jervis Bay National Park and the Jervis Bay Botanic Gardens that are of significance to the Aboriginals who are members of the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community to be granted to the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community Council, where it is deemed appropriate.

The bill is a step in the implementation by the Commonwealth of recommendation 315 of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, which provides a comprehensive agenda for governments to address aboriginal aspirations for involvement in national parks including the negotiation of lease-back arrangements which enable title to land on which National Parks are situated to be transferred to Aboriginal owners, subject to the lease of the area to the relevant State or Commonwealth authority on payment of rent to the Aboriginal owners. The recommendation was endorsed by Commonwealth, State and Territory governments.

The bill is based on the models successfully applied to the Uluru and Kakadu national parks in the Northern Territory. Under the bill the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community Council will lease any land granted as a consequence of the amendments back to the Director of National Parks and Wildlife.

The bill includes complementary amendments to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 (the NPWC Act) under which the Jervis Bay National Park and the Jervis Bay Botanic Gardens are currently proclaimed. The NPWC Act provides for the establishment of Boards as a means to allow the joint management, with Aboriginal people, of areas of Aboriginal land that are situated wholly or partly in prescribed parks or reserves.

By amending the definition of `prescribed park or reserve' to include the Jervis Bay National Park and the Jervis Bay Botanic Gardens, the bill will enable the Minister for Environment, Sport and Territories to establish a Board for those areas, if they are declared to be Aboriginal land and if agreement is reached with the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community Council. The Board would have a majority of Aboriginal representatives and would include amongst its responsibilities, overseeing development of a plan of management for the national park.

Other amendments to the NPWC Act will change the definition of `traditional Aboriginal owners' to include the registered members of the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community Council and give the Council (and chairperson of the Council) the same status as have other Aboriginal councils in relation to relevant provisions of the Act, such as those concerning preparation of plans of management and the establishment and operation of Boards.

It may be noted that public rights and enjoyment of the national park and botanic gardens will be preserved under the joint management arrangements that shall be made possible by the proposed amendments.

As part of an agreement between the Minister for Environment Sport and Territories and the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community Council, in relation to the amendment of the Aboriginal Land Grant (Jervis Bay Territory) Act 1986, it was agreed that the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act 1973 would be extended to apply to the Jervis Bay Territory.
The amendments to the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act 1973 extend the application of that Act to all Australia's Territories.

This would allow the Commonwealth Grants Commission to report on appropriate funding for works and services in Jervis Bay as well as requiring inquiries into the financial relationships between the Commonwealth and Norfolk Island as recently recommended by the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories in its report entitled "Delivering the Goods".

The amendment will allow the Commonwealth Government to address one of its principal policy objectives for Australia's Territories which is to align conditions and standards with those of comparable communities in the rest of Australia.
There will be limited financial implications arising from this bill.
Mr President, I commend the bill to the Senate.
HAZARDOUS WASTE (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this bill is to amend the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989 to bring that act into closer conformity with Australia's obligations under international instruments relating to the control of transboundary movements of hazardous waste.

SPEECH.PARA: The principal act was passed at the time that the Basel Convention was negotiated. At that time the major concern regarding trade in hazardous waste related to hazardous waste sent to another country for what is termed final disposal, that is for incineration, landfilling or the like. As a result, the Australian enabling act regulates material which has been rejected as worthless or otherwise falls within the ordinary definition of waste. As such it generally does not cover material sent for recovery. In the years since the Convention was negotiated the emphasis in international debate has shifted to its coverage of materials which are traded for recovery operations; that is, for reclamation of metals or recovery of other useful materials.

Just as the trade in hazardous waste for final disposal led to an active process of transferring the environmental costs associated with the generation of hazardous waste from one country to another, and in particular from developed to developing countries, so the trade in hazardous waste for recovery operations can similarly lead to the transfer of environmental costs in an uncontrolled fashion. The Basel Convention was drafted to cover both kinds of processes, that is both final disposal and recovery operations, and both kinds of processes are included in the Convention definitions under the single term "disposal". The Australian act does not cover a wide range of hazardous wastes from which valuable materials are to be recovered; these hazardous wastes are not worthless or do not fall within the ordinary meaning of waste. The major purpose of amending the act is to remedy this discrepancy between our international obligations and our domestic legislation.

The Basel Convention is the primary international instrument under which trade in hazardous waste is controlled. It is the set of rules for this trade on which Australia and the rest of the world have agreed. As virtually all of Australia's trading partners are either parties to the Convention or parties to similar sets of rules established by the OECD, Australia cannot participate in this trade unless it accepts these rules. The interpretation of the Convention as expressed in the principal act and with the amendments now put forward is in line with the views of other parties to the Convention. Without these amendments, Australia would continue to be out of step with other Parties in its capacity to give domestic effect to the Convention.

In accordance with the primary intention of the bill, the object of the act is to be amended to make it clear that one of its major aims is to give domestic effect to the Basel Convention and other international instruments relating to trade in hazardous wastes.

The definition of hazardous waste now to be adopted is aligned with that in the Convention. This will ensure that in future Australia does not find itself in breach of the Convention by virtue of having adopted a definition which is at odds with the interpretation of the Convention followed by others. Nevertheless, the question of definition remains central to the operation of the act, and indeed definitional questions remain the subject of very active debate in Basel Convention meetings. In Australia, a high degree of concern has been expressed because of the uncertainty of the definitions in the Convention. The bill addresses these concerns through the establishment of a process to provide greater practical certainty regarding what is and is not a hazardous waste. The bill provides for the establishment of a Technical Group of scientific and technical experts who will advise the Minister on definitional questions. The advice of this group will be of great benefit in enabling the Minister to decide whether a material is considered to fall within the definition of hazardous waste and so is regulated.

The Minister will have the power to issue Evidentiary Certificates which will be prima facie evidence that a given material is or is not a hazardous waste; and by compiling a list of materials for which Evidentiary Certificates have been issued, the Minister will be able to provide greater certainty to those subject to regulation on what materials will be controlled and what will not. This means for example, that it will be possible to issue an Evidentiary Certificate stating that a material such as clean ferrous scrap is not a hazardous waste subject to the act and can be traded without any controls. At the same time, flexibility will be retained to respond to incremental progress in international discussions on what materials should and should not be controlled. As an example, recent international discussions suggest that the existence of internationally recognised product specifications will be influential in deciding what are and are not hazardous wastes. The Evidentiary Certificates will not be conclusive, but will be prima facie evidence; and the definitions in the act would remain as the final means of determining the definitional question. In practice, however, the advice of the Technical Group will provide the government with the capability of issuing clear guidance on definitional issues, and should satisfy the needs of those who are subject to regulation for a clear understanding of their obligations under the act.

There are many who would prefer to replace the uncertain Basel definitions with Australia's own list or set of criteria. To follow that course, however, would inevitably lead to Australia once again being at odds with the Convention and the views of trading partners on what constitutes hazardous waste under the Convention. This would risk not only breach of our international obligations but could well lead to shipments acceptable under our definitions being rejected at foreign ports, to the embarrassment, cost and inconvenience of all.

The Convention itself recognises that the hazardous criteria it establishes are in need of further development. There is provision for the development of national tests which would provide greater precision in determining whether a waste is hazardous. That provision is included in the relevant Annex to the Convention, by reference to which the bill defines hazardous waste. Over time the Technical Group will advise on national tests to establish hazard on a more certain basis, taking account of international developments.

Another key concept in the Convention now adopted into the act is the definition of "environmentally sound management". The Convention requires not only that an exporting country obtain prior informed consent from the country of import before allowing the transboundary movement to proceed, but also that the country of export require that the waste to be shipped is managed in an environmentally sound way in the country of import. The concept of environmentally sound management of hazardous waste is defined in the Convention as "taking all practicable steps" to ensure that the hazardous waste is managed to protect human health and the environment. The Technical Group will advise the Minister to assist in determination of what constitutes environmentally sound management and whether particular facilities or processes meet the definition. For that reason, it will include people with social and economic expertise.

The concept of environmentally sound management as set out in the Convention replaces the phrase in the principal act "dispose of safely". In the principal act "dispose of safely" is defined in terms of an outcome, that is hazardous waste is disposed of safely provided there is no damage to human health or environment. By contrast, "environmentally sound management" is defined by reference to a process, that is, "taking all practicable steps" to prevent damage to human health or the environment. In practice, pragmatic considerations are likely to prevail. Within the Basel Convention process detailed guidelines on what constitutes environmentally sound management have already been drafted, and these will provide the context for the Technical Group's advice to the Minister. Australia will put its efforts into ensuring that those guidelines are sound. Once again, the need to ensure that our legislation is fully in line with our international obligations is the overriding consideration in the changes set out in the bill.

Under the Convention the general rule is that Parties must not trade in hazardous waste with non-Parties. An exception to this is provided for in Article 11, whereby Parties may enter into agreements or arrangements either with other Parties or with non-Parties. These agreements or arrangements can set out controls which are different from those prescribed by the Convention itself, provided those controls do not reduce the level of environment protection intended by the Convention. The only such agreement to which Australia is currently a party is the OECD Decision on Transboundary Movement of Hazardous Waste Destined for Recovery Operations (the OECD Decision), which regulates transboundary movement of hazardous wastes among OECD countries.

The bill provides explicitly for regulations giving effect to such agreements and arrangements, and for those regulations to give domestic effect to rules different from those in the Convention. The materials covered by the agreements or arrangements may also differ to some extent from those covered by the Convention. Thus the OECD Decision covers some wastes which are not hazardous wastes under the Convention and trade in these must comply with the controls set out by the Decision; conversely, the Decision classifies some materials as non-hazardous waste (the OECD Green List) and these materials may be traded without a permit provided countries outside the OECD are not involved. The provisions are general and can be applied to any further Article 11 agreements or arrangements which Australia enters into.

The procedures by which the Minister reaches a decision on whether or not a permit should be issued for a transboundary movement have been amended, once again to bring the act more closely into line with the Convention. Among the changes are those ensuring that the prior informed consent procedures established by the Convention are followed. Another amends the existing provision that the Minister have regard to the possibility of processing hazardous waste within Australia when considering an export application. This is in accordance with Article 4(2)(d) of the Convention which requires parties to "minimise the transboundary movement of hazardous waste consistent with the environmentally sound and efficient management of hazardous waste". The intent of this Article is met by requirements that disposal in Australia must be both efficient and environmentally sound. The intent is that a local disposal facility must be more than merely an experimental or test facility, and must operate on a commercial basis. There must be some cost effectiveness factor which is brought to bear when the Minister weighs up the pros and cons of local versus overseas disposal in deciding whether or not a permit should be issued.

The principal act already provides that there must be appropriate insurance for shipments of hazardous waste before a permit is issued. A new provision in the bill allows the Minister to require bonds or guarantees in addition to, or instead of, insurance. This recognises that where there is contravention of a permit, for one reason or other an insurance policy may not be paid out, and a bond would allow the Commonwealth to ensure that there was some coverage in such a case. In other cases insurance may not be available, and a guarantee would provide the opportunity for a permit to be issued in such cases. The principal act allows the sum total of such arrangements (insurance, bonds, and guarantees) to be assessed when the Minister comes to a decision.

Other procedural amendments are aimed at ensuring that the administration of the act proceeds smoothly and efficiently, and that all Convention requirements are met. Because the Convention itself contains detailed rules, it has not been possible to simplify the administrative system beyond a certain point. That is why both the principal act and the amending bill are complex. Where possible and appropriate, provision is made for the making of regulations to set out requirements under the act, in order to ensure that its administration will be flexible and responsive to the needs of industry. A detailed set of administrative procedures is being developed in consultation with interested parties, including industry, and will be complete by the time the amendments are ready to come into force.

The act also addresses a number of aspects of the Convention which were not picked up in the original drafting process. One of the most important of these is the issue of transit permits, that is for Australian consent (or its denial) to the transiting of waste from another country on its way to a third country for disposal.

There is also explicit provision for more than one shipment of the same hazardous waste to be covered by a single permit. The Convention allows such a procedure up to a maximum of 12 months, provided that certain conditions are met and that is now reflected in the bill.

The current system for recovery of the Government's administrative costs in respect of issuing permits is unnecessarily inflexible. The bill provides for fees to be set in regulations on the basis of administrative costs of each type of permit. The Minister has discretion to reduce fees where appropriate. The fee level may not be above the fee currently prescribed in the principal act.

Penalties under the act have been increased in order to provide a deterrent to illegal traffic. Prevention of illegal traffic is specifically required by the Convention, and the value of some of the transactions involved requires that penalties be raised to ensure that companies are deterred from failing to comply with the act's requirements. A new provision is that executive officers of companies will be personally liable for contraventions by companies, with the onus of proof resting with the Commonwealth—that is, liability will not be automatic. Liability for executive officers of companies is an important step in ensuring compliance with the act, as it would be difficult for other compliance measures to be effective—for example, identification of hazardous wastes at the Customs barrier when materials leave the country would often be difficult given that hazardous waste cannot readily be distinguished from a variety of other materials.

Third party standing under the principal act is already very broad with respect to appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Standing under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 has been extended by providing standing for organisations and associations which have matters which relate to the decision under the act as part of their object or purpose. This will provide further legislative clarity to the standing rules for the purposes of the ADJR act and is an extension of the standing rules which have already been recognised in recent cases under other similar legislation.

The bill has been the subject of extensive consultations with a variety of groups both inside and outside Government. In particular, detailed consultations have been held with a Policy Reference Group made up of representatives of industry, environment groups, development and co-operation groups, and unions. State and Territory Governments have also been consulted. An exposure draft of the bill was provided to members of the Reference Group and to States and Territories, and comments have been taken into account in finalising the bill. In the course of the consultations, an issue which has stimulated more discussion than any other is Decision II/12, taken at the Second Meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Basel Convention in March 1994. This decision, known as the Ban Decision, was in favour of an immediate ban on the export of hazardous waste for final disposal from OECD to non-OECD countries; and phasing out by the end of 1997 and banning from that date the export of hazardous waste for recovery operations from OECD to non-OECD countries.

The government is yet to decide its position with respect to the Ban Decision. There are proposals on the table internationally for the Ban Decision to be incorporated into the Basel Convention as an amendment, and those proposals will be considered by the Third Meeting of the Conference of the Parties in September 1995. It has been Australian Government policy for some time, however, that the export of wastes for final disposal to developing countries is not acceptable practice and that policy is now reflected in the bill. Indeed the bill extends that policy by limiting exports for final disposal to any country to exceptional circumstances, such as where there is a direct risk to human health or environment if the waste remains in Australia, or if the wastes are being exported for research or testing. It remains firm Government policy not to export hazardous waste for final disposal to developing countries. Each permit issued under this provision of the amended act will be specified in the regulations to ensure that the application of the concept of "exceptional circumstances" is transparent and subject to scrutiny by the community.

The extension of the definition of hazardous waste from that in the principal act to that in the Convention will inevitably result in regulation of a far wider range of hazardous wastes than at present. Studies which have been carried out recently into the range of wastes covered by the Basel Convention and Australia's trade in them suggests that total trade may be somewhere between $100 million and $200 million each year. The vast majority of this takes place with OECD countries, and is therefore subject to the less rigid controls set out by the OECD Decision. The kinds of materials in which we trade with developing countries of our region include spent lead acid batteries, metal-bearing wastes such as sludges, slags and drosses and a miscellaneous range of wastes variously containing metals such as lead or arsenic. These are the kinds of materials which will be regulated under the amended act. Suggestions that clean ferrous and most clean non-ferrous scrap metal will be caught up under the Convention are mistaken. The only significant material of this kind which, it appears, must be regulated under the Convention is lead scrap, and even that may be traded without a permit with OECD countries.

In general, the amended act will not cover trade in products, mineral ores and concentrates, processed minerals and metals or uncontaminated waste paper or textiles. The distinction between wastes on the one hand, and non-wastes on the other, especially where co-products, intermediates and by-products are concerned, will be subject to consideration and advice by the Technical Group. The Technical Group will also be giving priority to assisting the Minister in determining which of the OECD green listed materials are clearly inside the scope of the act (expected to be a small number) and which are clearly outside it, with a view to the Minister's reflecting this in Evidentiary Certificates. Consultations with all interested parties will continue as regulations and supporting administrative arrangements are developed.

Bilateral discussions between Australia and our developing-country trading partners make it clear that they wish and expect Australia to abide by the rules to which so many of the countries of the world have agreed. A continued failure to do so may lead to retaliatory reaction by these countries, which could threaten trade far more seriously than the controls required by the Convention and now established by this bill. It is time for Australia to give effect to the obligations it has taken upon itself, just as the vast majority of its trading partners have done.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
TRANSPORT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1995

PARA.TAB: In my second reading speech introducing the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 1995, I said that the two new bodies to replace the Civil Aviation Authority, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) and Airservices Australia (AA), together with the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI), will constitute a tri-partite structure, each with separate and distinct functions but working together as parts of an integrated system.

SPEECH.PARA: BASI has the independent role of investigating accidents and incidents (which will include any occurrences involving CASA and AA) and promoting safety by identifying deficiencies in the aviation system. This Bill amends the Air Navigation Act 1920 to strengthen BASI's capacity to conduct more detailed, systemic investigations and analysis and to ensure, as far as practicable, air safety investigations in Australia conform to International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) standards as set out in Annex 13 to the Chicago Convention.

To reflect the fact that BASI operates independently within the Department of Transport the amendments vest the power to conduct investigations in the Director of Air Safety Investigation. The Director has the normal powers of delegation. The amendments provide that upon completion of an investigation the Secretary of the Department may publish any information in an investigation report he or she considers desirable to promote aviation safety.

The amendments identify those persons (defined as "responsible persons") who are required to report accidents, serious incidents and incidents to the Director. These are essentially persons who have some involvement in the operation of an aircraft. Officers of CASA and AA who become aware of an accident, serious incident or incident are also required to report to the Director.

The amendments provide that the purpose of an investigation is to prevent the occurrence of other accidents, serious incidents and incidents and not to assign blame or liability. This reflects the statement of the objective of an investigation in Annex 13 of the Chicago Convention. Many of the operative provisions of the amendments pick up definitions and standards from Annex 13.

The Director has the power to require persons to answer questions and produce documents, aircraft components or other things. However, the amendments provide that the answer, to a question or the production of documents or aircraft components cannot be used in evidence against the person in criminal proceedings. The amendments make clear that BASI investigators have a limited right to enter onto an accident site to secure wreckage and for the purposes of investigation. BASI investigators are also authorised to exercise investigation powers on private property if a Magistrate issues a warrant. These powers of entry are tied to the production of formal identification.

The amendments also provide limited protection from disclosure for those classes of records (defined as "air safety records") that ICAO has identified as requiring protection for air safety investigation purposes. These records are not to be disclosed in civil proceedings unless a court determines that it is in the interests of justice to order disclosure having regard to the adverse domestic and international impact such action may have on that or any future investigations. This essentially mirrors the test contained in Annex 13 to the Chicago Convention and is consistent with the practice adopted in other jurisdictions such as Canada, the UK and the USA.
The Government considers that by enhancing BASI's powers of investigation these amendments will significantly assist in ensuring the integrity and safety of Australia's civil aviation system.

The Bill also amends the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1992 (the SRC Act) by removing the section which establishes the Seafarers Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Authority (the Authority) as a separate statutory authority.

As the Authority will no longer be a legal entity separate from the Commonwealth, it is inappropriate that money be appropriated to it. Consequently, the finance provisions of the SRC Act are also being repealed.

The Authority will be a separate budget-funded agency, similar to the International Air Services Commission, within the Department of Transport. As indicated in the Second Reading Speech when the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill was introduced in 1992, the Authority has been serviced by the Department of Transport. That arrangement will continue. The amendments will have no effect on Commonwealth revenue or expenditure.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 28 June 1995
ATTORNEY-GENERAL'S TABLING STATEMENT

In the short time available I have had relevant inquiries made of those Departments which may have in their possession documents caught by the motion moved by Senator Vanstone. As a result of those inquiries, I table certain documents.

Some of the documents caught by this motion I have not tabled, on the basis that they are subject to legal professional privilege or public interest immunity or both. The documents which are caught by the motion which I have not tabled include:

PARA.TAB: requests by the Attorney-General for advice from his Department;
the advice provided by his Department;
documents, including this advice, and advice from the Department of Finance, which formed the basis of Cabinet ministerial and consideration of these matters;
correspondence between solicitors in relation to the contemplated litigation subsequent to the Cabinet decision.

SPEECH.PARA: These documents clearly fall within the accepted boundaries of legal professional privilege and public interest immunity. The Senate has traditionally recognised such claims.
Further the issues raised by Dr Lawrence's challenge will, I understand, be shortly before the courts. It would also be inappropriate for these documents to be publicly disclosed at this time.
However I do make the following comments. The funding of Dr Lawrence by the Commonwealth is fully justified, and the processes whereby that funding was determined was wholly appropriate.

It should be remembered, however, that it was the Court Government of Western Australia which established this Royal Commission and it is the Court Government which should bear the responsibility for its cost, including the costs of Dr Lawrence.
If that responsibility is not met then the Commonwealth has a duty to ensure that Dr Lawrence is appropriately represented.

The process which the Government has adopted, which is designed to ensure that Dr Lawrence is not bankrupted by defending herself in this blatantly political attack on her fitness to be a Commonwealth Minister, is neither unusual nor without precedent.
The Hon. Nick Young MP received legal funding assistance from the Commonwealth in relation to the Hope Royal Commission.

The Groom Liberal Government agreed to meet the legal expenses of former Premier Gray in relation to his appearance before the Rouse Bribery Royal Commission. This included his Supreme Court challenge to the Royal Commissions.

The Fahey Coalition Government agreed to meet the costs of former Premier Nick Greiner's appearance before the Independent Commission Against Corruption and the subsequent Supreme Court challenge by Mr Greiner against the finding that he was corrupt.

There was also the Fahey Government's decision to fund the current Leader of the Opposition, Peter Collins', appearance before the Independent Commission Against Corruption in relation to the decision of the NSW Department of Health not to pursue a costs order made against Mr Collins as a result of a failed private defamation action.

The Opposition's State colleagues thought that the provision of legal assistance was appropriate in cases where corruption or maladministration was being alleged. Yet they now have the hypocrisy to claim that the Government should not fund Dr Lawrence's legal costs when no such allegation is before the WA Royal Commission.

It is right and proper in these circumstances that Cabinet determine whether a Minister is entitled to legal assistance on a case by case basis. This process has been followed in relation to Dr Lawrence. The Cabinet considered the issues, took its own legal advice, and decided to provide assistance. Dr Lawrence quite properly excluded herself from those deliberations.

It would be totally inappropriate for the Government's legal advice or the terms of the Cabinet deliberations to now be disclosed. We all know the track record of Liberals from South Australia in getting hold of documents to be used in legal proceedings involving the Commonwealth and giving it to the other side.

It remains patently clear that the decision to offer legal funding to Dr Lawrence was wholly justified. The sole purpose of the Royal Commission is to impugn Dr Lawrence in her capacity as a Commonwealth Minister. If Dr Lawrence were not a Commonwealth minister there would be no Royal Commission. In these circumstances it is entirely appropriate for the Commonwealth Government to provide Dr Lawrence with assistance.

In addition, the establishment of the Royal Commission offends one of the most basic principles of parliamentary democracy. The Bill of Rights of 1688 states that the proceedings of Parliament are not to be questioned in any place out of Parliament. This provision is embodied in section 16 of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Privileges Act 1986.

The Royal Commission has been specifically established to inquire into and question proceedings of parliament, and as such it is a direct attack by the executive on notions of Parliamentary privilege. As such, the establishment of this Royal Commission should be of concern to all Australian Parliaments and indeed all Australian Parliamentarians, including the Senators in this Chamber.
It is the equivalent of the Government establishing a Royal Commission, with coercive powers, into why this motion has been moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present report No. 337 entitled A focus on accountability: review of Auditor-General's reports, 1992-93. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard my tabling speech.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: It gives me pleasure today to table on behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts the results of the Committee's review of 1992-93 audit reports titled: Report 337—A Focus On Accountability.

Report 337 reviews 37 reports of the Auditor-General which were tabled in the financial year 1992-93, and is prepared in accordance with section 8(1)(ab) of the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951, requiring the Committee to examine all reports of the Auditor-General.

In reviewing these reports the Committee has not canvassed in detail all of the issues raised by the Auditor-General, but instead has focused on the key recommendations in his reports. The Committee's review has shown that in the vast majority of cases, agencies have responded positively and promptly to the Auditor-General's recommendations. In some cases, however, it is clear that agencies have disagreed with the recommendations, or have not taken appropriate or effective remedial action. It is these cases which are commented upon in Report 337.
Report 337 contains 15 recommendations for further action by the Government.
The Committee's recommendations address various matters, including:
.the need for the Department of Employment, Education and Training to take further steps to reduce the levels of debt associated with the AUSTUDY program, which amounted to $60.3m in early 1993-94;

.the need for the Health Insurance Commission to continue to develop and implement strategies aimed at identifying and discouraging Medicare fraud and over-servicing, which have the potential to be a significant drain on Commonwealth resources; and

.the need for the Joint Coal Board and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to clarify the method of valuing the Coal Board's future liability for workers' compensation insurance, which is in the order of $225m

The Committee has also made a series of recommendations about the management by the Department of Defence of the new submarine project. This project was the subject of critical comment by the Auditor-General in Audit Report No. 22, 1992-93, Efficiency Audit, Department of Defence, New Submarine Project.

The Committee has taken a forward looking approach in commenting on the submarine project. We have not reviewed in detail the nature of the contract for the construction of the submarines, nor have we commented on the rather colourful debates that took place around the time the audit report was tabled. Instead we have focused on some of the risks facing the project and have considered whether steps can be taken to improve the management of these risks for the remainder of the submarine project and for future defence projects.

In taking this approach the Committee acknowledges that the Department of Defence has managed many of the risks successfully. For example, evidence to date indicates that the Project Office has taken all reasonable steps to ensure that the submarine construction and performance standards will be satisfied.

However, there are areas where project management improvements can be made. Some of the audit findings in relation to financial and scheduling risks, for example, warrant close attention by the Department.
The Committee has for example, noted:
.that a considerable proportion of the contract price has been paid before some of the most significant project risks have been overcome;
.that there is sufficient reason to be concerned about the financial guarantees available to the Commonwealth; and
.that the Commonwealth appears to be bearing a disproportionate amount of the financial risk associated with the project.

The main theme running through the Committee's consideration of the submarine project is the need for the Department of Defence to exercise more commercially astute management of major acquisitions projects, particularly in relation to the timing of cash payments.

The Committee has made what I believe are a series of constructive recommendations which, if implemented, will help ensure that the submarine project and future Defence projects of similar size are managed in an effective and cost-efficient manner.

Mr President, Report 337 is confirmation that the Public Accounts Committee is committed to ensuring that the reports of the Auditor-General receive close parliamentary attention. By reviewing each audit report that is tabled the Parliament signals to government agencies that the process of accountability and scrutiny is continuous and proceeds beyond the tabling of an audit report.
I commend the Report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings, I present the report of the committee on radio and television broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings, together with submissions, transcript of proceedings and minutes of evidence. On behalf of the President, and with the agreement of the Senate, I incorporate in Hansard the President's statement on the report.
The statement read as follows—

PROCTEXT.PARA: Statement by the President
Tabling of a report of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings
I table the report of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings on its inquiry into the radio and television broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings.
The context in which the inquiry was undertaken included-.

PARA.TAB: the relatively poor appreciation the community has of Australia's system of government;
the significant investment the Parliament has made in the production of broadcast quality radio and television signals of the Houses and their committees,
the current inadequate coverage of proceedings on the electronic media, and
the emergence of new technologies which should enable an enhanced coverage of proceedings.

PROCTEXT.PARA: With this background in mind, the committee has sought in its report to make recommendations that will give the Parliament a more strategic view of the future of parliamentary broadcasting. It has recognised that these strategies may not have an immediate impact.

The committee has recommended that a new bill covering parliamentary broadcasting be introduced into the Parliament. The new act would consolidate arrangements for electronic broadcasting of Parliament and increase the role of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings. In addition to its current role, the Joint Committee would undertake a more strategic role on behalf of the Parliament in:

PARA.TAB: regularly reviewing and advising on arrangements for radio and television broadcasting; and
advising on the application of new technologies to the public dissemination of parliamentary proceedings.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The committee wishes to see an increase in the radio and television coverage of proceedings. One way to achieve this would be to have a service similar to the C-span service in the United States established in Australia. Such a service would provide dedicated coverage of parliamentary proceedings. The committee will monitor developments in pay television with a view to obtaining capacity for the coverage of parliamentary proceedings at the earliest opportunity.
Other approaches recommended by the committee to increase coverage of parliamentary proceedings include:-

PARA.TAB: encouraging and funding the development of packages of parliamentary material for broadcasting; and
examining the provision of the audio and audio-visual productions of proceedings to not-for-profit broadcasters.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I commend the report to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

The Bill will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects. It includes measures announced in the Treasurer's Superannuation Policy statement of 28 June 1994. In that statement the Treasurer outlined several major initiatives to enhance the Government's retirement incomes policy and to alleviate the small amounts problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the measures in the Bill, such as the employee share scheme provisions, are new and largely self-contained. These have been drafted in the new tax law improvement style. Other measures in the Bill either amend existing provisions of the law or inter-relate with concepts already contained in other parts of the law (for example, the late lodgment penalty and interest provisions). For these reasons it has not been possible to fully adopt the new drafting style as this would entail changes to a much broader range of provisions. The tax law improvement project will be redrafting the tax law over the next three years.
Employee share schemes

The Bill will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to provide a new income tax regime for the taxation of employee share schemes. The new regime will generally apply from 6pm in the ACT (and the equivalent time elsewhere) on 28 March 1995.

Transitional arrangements will apply so that in certain circumstances the existing provisions of the income tax law will continue to apply to shares or rights to shares acquired after the date of commencement of the amendments.

The Government is making these changes to reduce the exploitation of the existing legislation and to ensure that the tax concessions that are available under the new arrangements are directed at share schemes which encourage employees to own shares in the company in which they are employed or a holding company of the employer. The measures will increase the taxation benefits available to employees under these schemes.

The amount to be included in a taxpayer's assessable income in respect of the shares and rights acquired will be the difference between the value of the share or right and any amount paid by the taxpayer to acquire the share or right. Generally, the amount is to be included in assessable income in the year that the share or right is acquired.

However, in certain circumstances a deferral of taxation of up to 5 years without any upper limit on amount will be available. Conditions have to be satisfied before a share or right qualifies for the deferral concession. The share or right must be acquired under an employee share scheme. At the time the share or right is acquired, or at an earlier time, each permanent employee should have been entitled to acquire shares or rights of the employer or holding company of the employer. The shares or rights should be ordinary shares or rights of the employer or holding company. The employee should also not hold more than 5% of shares or voting rights of the employer company or holding company.

An exemption concession will apply for certain shares or rights that are issued to employees under a scheme operated on a non-discriminatory basis. The employee can elect that the discount received be included in his or her assessable income in the income year in which the shares or rights are acquired. Where this election is made, benefits up to a limit of $500 for an income year will be exempt from tax.

If the exemption concession applies, the provider of the benefit will be entitled to a tax deduction for up to $500 of benefits provided to each employee. This deduction will apply if the deduction is not allowable under the other provisions of the tax law.
The Bill will also amend the capital gains provisions and the fringe benefits tax law to ensure that there is no double taxation of share or right benefits.
The nature of these measures is such that a reliable estimate of the revenue impact cannot be provided.
Capital gains tax—roll-over relief for merging superannuation funds

The Bill will amend the capital gains tax (CGT) provisions to allow certain superannuation funds which merge to defer any CGT gains or losses that would be realised at the time of the merger on the assets transferred.
Although the Government remains of the view that CGT should, in general, be payable on assets realised when entities merge, it considers that special circumstances exist that justify this concession.

For example, the Government recognises that the new member protection rules may put greater pressure on superannuation funds to merge to improve their economies of operation. It also realises that current CGT rules may affect the short term liquidity of such superannuation funds.
This temporary relief will improve the efficiency and performance of the industry.
The amendments will apply to superannuation funds that merge on or after 1 July 1994 and before 1 July 1997.

The notional cost to the revenue from the proposal is estimated to be $50 million for each of the 3 years of its operation. The actual cost to the revenue will be less because many funds would not merge if roll-over relief was not available.
Superannuation guarantee—jurisdiction of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission

The Bill clarifies the jurisdiction of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC). It is generally accepted that the operation of the superannuation guarantee legislation has not affected the jurisdiction, powers, or functions of the AIRC. However, there is no express statement in the superannuation guarantee legislation or the Industrial Relations Act 1988 to this effect.

For this reason, and because there has been doubt expressed in some quarters concerning the power of the AIRC to continue to arbitrate on superannuation, the amendment makes it clear that the superannuation guarantee legislation does not alter in any way the substantive jurisdiction, functions and powers of the AIRC.
The amendment will apply from the commencement of the superannuation guarantee law on 1 July 1992.
The amendment has no impact on the revenue.
Superannuation guarantee—flat dollar contributions

The Bill also amends the superannuation guarantee law to ensure that the percentage level of superannuation support actually provided for an employee for flat dollar contributions is calculated based on actual contributions, rather than the amount specified in the award. The current provision causes problems where contributions differ from the award amount. The effect of the amendment will be to make it easier for some employers to satisfy their superannuation guarantee requirements.
The amendments will take effect from 1 July 1994.
There is no cost to the revenue from the change.
Superannuation guarantee—local government councillors

The Bill proposes to generally exempt from the superannuation guarantee law the payments received by local government councillors in the course of their duties. The payments will not be regarded as salary and wages for superannuation guarantee purposes, enabling councillors to claim deductions under the income tax legislation for any personal superannuation contributions. The exemption will not apply to payments from certain local government bodies.

Local government councillors will retain their status as employees for the purposes of the superannuation industry supervisory legislation to prevent some funds which have councillors as members from being treated as public offer funds which entails higher compliance costs.
The amendments will apply from 1 July 1993.
Cost to the revenue in the 1994-95 and subsequent years will be less than $500 000 per annum.
Superannuation—various amendments to the income tax law

Following the Security in Retirement statement of 30 June 1992 the Government has introduced a number of changes to the income tax law to encourage superannuation pensions and annuities and to ensure that superannuation moneys are kept within the superannuation system until withdrawal. This Bill makes some minor adjustments to some of these changes to clarify their operation and further ease administrative requirements.

In addition, the Bill changes the income tax law to ensure that superannuation pension and roll-over annuity recipients who started receiving a pension or annuity before 1 July 1994 will be able to change providers without losing tax concessions. This change will allow pensioners and annuitants to move their investment without being disadvantaged by a different tax treatment.

The Bill also amends the income tax law to ensure that tax concessions for employer superannuation contributions are restricted to superannuation funds established primarily for the benefit of employees.
The amendments are not expected to have any significant impact on the revenue.
Superannuation—miscellaneous amendments
The Bill also makes a small number of miscellaneous amendments to superannuation law administered by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner.

The two main amendments allow the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to undertake statistical surveys of the superannuation industry and change the method of collection of the superannuation supervisory levy. As a result, the manner in which the late payment penalty for the levy is calculated is also changed.
The Bill also makes some other, more technical, amendments.
No overall impact on revenue is expected to result from these amendments.
State and Territory bodies

Amendments in the Bill will create broad new exemptions from income tax and sales tax for certain State and Territory bodies. These amendments arise from an agreement reached at the 1994 Premiers' Conference, which aims to promote efficiency and competitive neutrality in markets in which State and Territory trading enterprises operate. One aspect of this is removing the tax advantage enjoyed by State and Territory trading enterprises over private businesses.

It was agreed that the tax advantage could be eliminated if the States and Territories imposed tax equivalent regimes on their trading enterprises. A tax equivalent regime is basically equivalent to Commonwealth income tax and sales tax in its principles and the rates imposed.

Before tax equivalent regimes are introduced, the States and Territories need to be certain that their trading enterprises will be exempt from Commonwealth income tax and sales tax. Certain State and Territory bodies will therefore be made clearly exempt. Some bodies will be specifically excluded from the exemption, including bodies prescribed by regulations.

These amendments will not change the tax status of many of these bodies. For the 1994-95 year, the bodies which were taxable at the time of the 1994 Premiers' Conference will remain taxable. These bodies will in most cases become exempt from 1 July 1995.
The amendments are expected to be revenue neutral.
Late lodgment penalty

The Bill introduces a new penalty regime for late lodgment of income tax returns. The penalties will apply to 1994-95 and later year returns where the due date for lodgment occurs after the later of 30 June 1995 or 60 days after the date of Royal Assent of the Bill.
Companies, superannuation funds and certain trusts will be liable for a flat rate penalty of $25 for each week that a return remains outstanding, up to a maximum of $500.

All other taxpayers who are late in lodging an income tax return will be liable for additional tax of 8% per annum on the amount of net tax payable for the year of income. In addition they will also be liable for interest on the net tax payable at the same rate that applies to underpayments and late payments of income tax. That interest rate is currently 10.8% per annum. The additional tax and the interest will be calculated from the due date for lodgment until the return is lodged.
A reliable estimate of the impact on the revenue cannot be provided.
Refunds of tax file number amounts deducted in error

The Bill will also amend the income tax law in a number of respects to ease compliance costs encountered by investment bodies when they are required to refund tax incorrectly deducted by them because of a mistake concerning an investor's tax file number.

One amendment limits the refunds to be made by investment bodies to requests for refunds received on or before 15 July following the year of income in which the incorrect deduction of tax file number amounts occurred. This will reduce investment body tax compliance costs associated with refunds that they are presently required to make in respect of amounts deducted in earlier years.

Any incorrectly deducted amounts not refunded by the investment body within the 15 July time frame would normally be allowed as a credit to the investor upon assessment of the investor's tax return for the relevant income year. However, where it is not reasonably appropriate for an investor to wait until an assessment has issued, the Commissioner of Taxation will be required to make refunds directly to an investor. This will ensure that an avenue for a refund is always available to an investor.

A further amendment will provide for investment bodies to choose to offset any amounts that they refund against other amounts they deduct during the same year. This will also reduce compliance costs for investment bodies.
These amendments will have no impact on the revenue.
Pensions, allowances and benefits

When the mature age partner allowance was introduced, it was exempted from income tax. This is inconsistent with the treatment of the mature age allowance which is taxable. The Bill ensures that, as from 1 July 1995, the mature age partner allowance will be taxable. Recipients of the allowance will generally be eligible for the pensioner rebate which will offset the tax on the allowance, subject to any other income received.
The financial impact of this measure is a negligible gain to the revenue.
The Bill also makes a number of minor technical amendments of tax provisions related to social welfare matters which have no impact on the revenue.
Sales tax—new credit ground for unregistered exemption users

Under the existing sales tax law an assessable dealing is taxable unless an exemption applies. An exemption applies when a quotation is made or the goods in question are always exempt goods. The law requires that a quote for a dealing be made at or before the time of the dealing for it to be effective.

If a person does not quote for a taxable dealing, then the dealing is taxable. A credit ground currently exists to enable a registered person to obtain a credit of tax paid on a dealing for which they had borne tax even though they were entitled to quote a registration number.

The bill proposes to insert a similar credit ground to enable unregistered persons to obtain a credit of tax paid on a dealing for which they had borne tax even though they were entitled to quote an exemption declaration.
The effect of this amendment on the revenue will be negligible.
Sales tax—exemption for UHF transmitters

The bill proposes a limited extension to the operation of an earlier exemption from sales tax, for certain UHF transmitters, for use in commercial television broadcasting to cover the period 1 January 1994 to 31 December 1995.

The new exemption will apply to transmitters for use in connection with the equalisation program which aims to provide services in regional areas comparable to those in capital cities. The Government considers that the extension is appropriate because the equalisation program is not yet completed in Tasmania.
The total cost to the revenue for the period of the exemption is likely to be about $2 million.
Minor amendments
The Bill also makes a number of minor technical amendments which have no impact on the revenue.
Full details of the amendments are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable senators. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Employment, Education and Training References Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —on behalf of Senator Tierney, I present the report of the Employment, Education and Training References Committee on its inquiry into matters relating to Austudy, together with the submissions received by the committee and the transcript of evidence.
