PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I have great pleasure in speaking to the report of the Employment, Education and Training References Committee on Austudy. The Senate committee's inquiry into Austudy was prompted by a 1993-94 report of the Commonwealth Ombudsman which revealed many difficulties with the Austudy scheme and its administration. The main difficulties were: delays and errors in the processing of applications; delays in the determination of eligibility; provision of incorrect and ambiguous advice, exacerbated by lack of written records and oral advice; and inconsistencies between DEET and DSS with respect to various income support eligibility criteria.

PARA.TAB: Austudy has been the focus of several reports and reviews over the last few years, and the committee was concerned that the apparent level of dissatisfaction with the scheme had not been diminished. As well, new initiatives, such as the supplementary loans scheme by which students can trade in part of their Austudy grant for a loan twice the amount, had experienced a mixed reception in the student community. Student indebtedness was raised in many quarters as we carried out our inquiry. Publicity has also been given to the findings of a research project which suggest that the student assistance scheme was being manipulated by relatively wealthy families who have arranged their income and assets so that their children might be deemed to be eligible for Austudy support.

It was in this somewhat clouded environment that the Senate committee sought to test the credibility of some of these claims and to examine possible changes to Austudy which might benefit all parties. The issues which emerged most forcefully during these hearings related to eligibility criteria for and consistency between Austudy and DSS income support arrangements, student debt and debt recovery procedures, and the quality of advice and support given to Austudy applicants.

There currently exists between DEET and Department of Social Security offices a joint working party which examines issues related to the overlap and eligibility criteria when it comes to transition between Austudy and jobsearch and vice versa. The committee has identified a number of areas which this committee should investigate further. These include examining the agencies' statistics with a view to determining the extent of the flow of students from Austudy to DSS benefits and the circumstances under which such a transfer occurs. We simply do not know the degree to which people are opting out of full-time study and Austudy to move to part-time study on jobsearch because of the perceived additional benefits that they gain with the latter scheme.

There are inconsistencies between DEET and DSS in relation to the definition of `full-time' and `part-time' study which need to be resolved. We want DEET and DSS working groups to identify those policy areas which create blocks to the simple transition of eligible students between income support schemes and to prepare advice aimed at rectifying these matters.

A major problem also exists with incorrect or misunderstood advice being given to applicants, especially by staff in CES offices, who are not trained properly to deal with the complexities of Austudy. Over 180,000 new debts were due in the Austudy default system in 1993-94, and many of these stemmed from poor advice to students, so we have recommended that the training in Austudy for CES officers be substantially upgraded.

Student assistance centres must be funded to provide to all CES officers outreach training services, including training in the use of the new STEPS computer system, which is supposed to make Austudy applications and processing significantly less error prone. Such training should be accessible by DSS officers on request. As an interim measure, we have recommended that CES officers use special `recording of advice' forms to keep track of their contacts for Austudy applicants.

We have also recommended that DEET, in consultation with the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and the relevant student advisory networks, develop a proposal for the training and support of university student welfare officers as on-campus Austudy advisers. To help with the problem of students not advising DEET of changes in their enrolment status and thereby incurring overpayment debts which have to be repaid later, we want DEET and the AVCC to jointly develop a mechanism for the enhancement of advice to student assistance centres concerning enrolment variations of students.

Students have been encouraged to take up the Austudy supplementary loans, but there is some resistance to trading in grants for loans of twice the size which have to be paid back after graduation. Already, the average loan is nearly $5,000 per loan, and the average level of student indebtedness is growing sharply.

We have recommended that DEET be more detailed in its promotional material so that students are well aware of what they are letting themselves in for and what the debt recovery mechanisms are. We have also recommended that the National Union of Students do some work in providing consumer advice for students about these loans.

Debt recovery is a big issue for students. DEET can currently recover debts by withholding up to 30 per cent of ongoing student payments. We argue that this should be reduced to no more than 14 per cent to bring it into line with other government debt recovery practices. There is a whole host of other anomalies, as I have said, which need to be sorted out if Austudy is to work satisfactorily in an environment where many other variations of income support apply.

Studying today is a very expensive business with photocopying, rapidly out-of-date textbooks, computers and software purchases and so on. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) has made it clear that Austudy is a targeted income support mechanism, which assumes that students will supplement their income with part-time work and so on. But that work is getting harder to get and, for many students, Austudy is their only form of income. It is extremely hard to live on Austudy even if one is on the highest level of benefit, which only a small proportion of students are receiving.

With the move to mass tertiary education, demands for increased expenditure on Austudy have naturally emerged. In trying to tighten up the system to ensure that the limited amount of money gets distributed to those students most in need, Austudy risks being not a lot of use to many students. The complexities of the scheme are compounding the situation and perhaps the government needs to take a long, hard look at the way in which it goes about student support.

I believe our report will go some way towards improving Austudy as it exists at the moment, but that is not to say that at some point not too far down the track we may have to revise completely the way that we support students in an equitable and needs-based way. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the motion to take note of the report of the Employment, Education and Training References Committee, and in supporting the chair's recommendation that the report be commended, I would like to say that I found my participation in this inquiry into Austudy to be interesting and illuminating, both from the point of view of a lay person's interest in finding out the effects of Austudy on Australia as a whole and because many of the assertions which had been raised by way of myths, suggestions and perhaps even unsubstantiated innuendo that had been delivered about Austudy over the years were substantiated in the gathering of the evidence by the committee.

PARA.TAB: This committee travelled extensively and heard from a broad range of Australians who were affected by Austudy. We found there to be great consistency in the evidence presented to us by students from different circumstances and by parents of students who are trying to assist their children in their pursuit of further education. There was a consistency of evidence from university administrations, TAFE administrations and school administrations, as well as from community groups and specialist commentators. The consistency was along the lines that the system as it is is not adequate in being able to deliver equitable support for further study for Australian students.

One particular matter which I pursued during the inquiry involved asking a great number of the witnesses in different places the question, `What is a student, how do we define a student in Australia, and what support should be offered to a person engaging in study?' I found it very interesting that, as a society, we are still grappling with our definition of a student. The Department of Social Security, the Department of Employment, Education and Training and tertiary institutions all define full-time students or part-time students in different ways and this is where a lot of the problem has occurred. A person may believe that he is studying full time and in accordance with the guidelines of the institution at which he is studying, but he can be confronted by a government department which says, `You are not, and therefore we can only pay you a certain amount of money' or `We can only recognise a certain aspect of your studies'.

That confuses the person and, perhaps, disadvantages him. Senator Tierney mentioned inconsistencies and I know that this is what he had in mind. There are inconsistencies in interpretation between departments and between tertiary institutions. I am pleased to endorse the recommendation of the committee that those inconsistencies ought to be resolved.

The committee was able to determine that people who engage in studies were attempting to improve their qualification skills: in other words, their contribution to the nation as a whole. These people had a feeling of not being supported in a full sense by the community. This is an intangibility which is a little difficult to nail down, but it is a feeling which permeated the hearings.

When I persisted in asking the witnesses how they felt students should be supported the answers, although varied, were consistent in that they believed that the present support was not full and was not an expression of community support, but was rather convoluted, difficult, inconsistent and begrudging. Young people who were engaged in the development of their skills for the benefit of the nation as well as themselves felt as if they did not have the full support of the nation. This is a poor state of affairs and one which I am sure nobody in this chamber would wish to continue.

The committee recommended an increase in the flexibility and capacity of DEET to recognise the human situations in which people find themselves when seeking support of the nation. The committee recommended that DEET act accordingly to provide support to our young people who are seeking to further their qualifications.

The committee had some difficulty in addressing some of the myths or suggestions that the system is being rorted by those who tailor their taxable incomes to qualify for Austudy. Accusations of this nature are abundant but the committee found it difficult to obtain hard evidence demonstrating how incomes were being tailored to suit applications for Austudy.

The committee determined that reliance on taxable income as a measure to determine who should and should not receive Austudy is not appropriate. Whilst that reliance exists there is the possibility that people will tailor their taxable incomes to enable them to qualify for the assistance of Austudy.

The committee determined that there should be a more sophisticated method. The committee determined that if it is to be a targeted system rather than a universal system of support the targeting device should be more sophisticated and that it ought to be a little smarter.

We also wrestled with the definition of what is an independent person. We found that that definition was not as sophisticated as it could or should be. The committee was at pains to ensure that such questions were dealt with in a very comprehensive manner, perhaps even more comprehensive than they had been in the establishment of this very complicated and bureaucratically driven scheme.

In conclusion, the demonstration of how complicated and inefficient it is can be illustrated by what the chairman said a few minutes ago—that if 186,000 new debts could be incurred in the period 1993-94 by Austudy recipients, something must be wrong. Either the system of advice by recipients to the bureaucracy is not efficient enough or the way that such advice is processed is not efficient enough. Either way, the system which enables such a huge number of new debts to be incurred is one which should withstand further investigation. I think the committee treated this matter seriously, it was comprehensive and it was most enlightening to those involved. I too commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw Sen M.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add a few words to this debate. I particularly note that there are a number of recommendations within the report of the Employment, Education and Training References Committee that go to bringing into alignment or looking at a closer relationship with respect to Austudy and payments paid through the social security system. It is apparent to the committee that there are a variety of interpretations abroad as to what Austudy actually is. This, in turn, has led to a variety of expectations about the financial dimensions of Austudy and the range of additional benefits or concessions which should apply to those who receive it.

PARA.TAB: Whilst we have made a number of recommendations—for instance, recommendation 1, where we recommend that the age of eligibility for Austudy and JSA rates at 21 be brought into line—it is nevertheless important for us to keep in mind that we are dealing with two quite distinct concepts. One is the provision of assistance to students who are engaged in full-time study and the other is the responsibility of society to provide income support to persons who may be unemployed, who may be sole parents or who may fit into a whole range of other categories where the social security system provides assistance. I have stressed throughout our deliberations that we need to bear that distinction in mind. There were quite a number of submissions from students and other groups who argued that there should be parity in respect of, for instance, Austudy and the jobsearch allowance in all regards.

It must be remembered that we in this country recognise the need to support students, both financially and by providing a vast education infrastructure and resources—be it teachers, books, libraries, laboratories and so on—because education is a primary objective of our country in terms of maintaining its development. Austudy students do not get it easy. Anyone who has been a student knows that. As I said, I think we will run into trouble if we focus too heavily on trying to make Austudy and the jobsearch allowance virtually indistinguishable. Arguments were put to us that the age of independence, whereby Austudy could be available to students, should be at the same age as the jobsearch allowance—that is, 18 years of age. We have not accepted that because it would clearly skew badly the income support resources across the range of young people.

If one was to take this issue further, one would probably come to the conclusion that the only way to provide a simple arrangement across the board would be to develop some kind of guaranteed minimum income policy for Australia as a whole. That of course is to look way beyond Austudy to a whole new income support ball game, something that our committee was conscious not to get too far into.

Rather, what we have tried to do in our report, as Senator Tierney and Senator Bell have stated, is to identify the main shortcomings in the way that Austudy operates at the moment, and to look also at the way in which other forms of income support payment are made—and I particularly mention the jobsearch allowance. The committee also wanted to look at alternative ways of dealing with some of the problems that were brought to our attention and to try, as far as possible, to get a better interface between Austudy payments and Austudy procedures on the one hand, and DSS procedures on the other.

SPEECH.PARA: For instance, our attention was brought to the constant difficulties that students may come across in moving into an education system, moving out of that system and seeking to get into the job market; and the issues that arise when they earn income during the year whilst they are also studying. We are dealing with many hundreds of thousands of students and there are many thousands of different situations that can arise that have to be addressed.

PARA.TAB: When we asked our witnesses about the major features of Austudy, whilst it was certainly pointed out to us that there were a range of procedural difficulties and administrative problems—there were also submissions to us about the level of payments and so on—it was, nevertheless, agreed fairly widely that it was at the margins of the scheme that the problems really emerged. It was at the margins where the anomalies showed up, quite often because of wrong advice or misunderstanding leading to those difficulties.

Circumstances do change for students throughout the years they may be involved in study. They change courses or the load level of the course; they may move from a full-time to a part-time study arrangement or defer their study for some time. All these changes in circumstances can cause problems and misunderstandings which may not be addressed until some time after the situation has occurred.

Ideally, all young people up to the age of 21 or 22 should be involved in some kind of education and training. It is clearly to their personal benefit; it is to society's benefit; and the costs of that education and training should be shared by both. That is not to say that individuals and society at large should contribute equally in an up-front financial sense. In any event, the money for our education system ultimately comes first from the taxpayer.

We must operate in a policy framework within a set of attitudes that reflect a distinction between participating in education and training and doing something which may be other than that. That means continuing to have income support systems which differentiate between those two states of affairs. I must pay a particular compliment to the staff of the secretariat for their work in conducting the proceedings and in the preparation of this report. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak to the Austudy report. In my opinion, the introduction of the Austudy scheme in 1986-87 was a great step forward from its immediate predecessor, TEAS, in improving assistance to eligible secondary and tertiary students. I suppose the problems that students have encountered with Austudy stem from an expectation that has been erroneously built over time; that is, the introduction of Austudy was, and probably still is, perceived as being built upon the principles and objectives of TEAS that were in circulation in the 1970s. Therefore, in my view, it is incumbent that student bodies, DEET, and all of those other organisations and individuals who have a role related to Austudy push for the objectives and principles of Austudy to be clearly defined. To that end, a level of certainty has to be reached in the administration and delivery of the scheme.

PARA.TAB: At the coalface—for example, the institutions—any changes to the scheme need to be clearly made to the students. Therefore, the recommendation that DEET, in consultation with other relevant bodies, develop a proposal for training and support of university students and a welfare officer on campus to advise the students about their rights, to my mind, is paramount.

In many ways, the difficulties that I heard students were experiencing were related to the failure to communicate. In this day and age, there should not be that failure, particularly with the information technology streams that are coming into high schools and tertiary colleges. Those sorts of things should be available for students to access information and, therefore, communication ought not be the problem that it is.

One of the good outcomes that I discovered from the hearings is the significant changes that have been accomplished by DEET and the DSS working party. The fact that a body is in place and working constantly on improvement is encouraging, but it has to be ongoing. I am, therefore, very confident that in a short period of time the current difficulties experienced, for example, by the full-time/part-time student dilemma will be addressed and resolved.I believe it must be made clear to the students that the onus is upon them to understand fully the Austudy scheme and, with good qualified advice available on campus, many of the complaints currently received will, I hope, be resolved in time.

As recommended, any information about this scheme must be comprehensive and should set out proceedings for debt recovery and garnisheeing of bank accounts. I, too, want to pay a compliment to the secretariat for their work. I also commend the report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (BUDGET MEASURES) BILL 1995INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 20 June, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the coalition to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Budget Measures) Bill 1995 and the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill 1995—the purpose of which is to increase the income tax rate from 33 to 36 per cent. This will provide additional income for the government in the next financial year of $320-odd million, and in the following three years between $1 billion and $1 1/2 billion or something of that order.

PARA.TAB: This legislation comes before the Senate as a testament to the hypocrisy and fiscal treachery of the Labor government. The legislation demonstrates the high or, perhaps more correctly, the low point of this government's deceit of the Australian people. It reinforces how out of touch is this government, which, all Australians will remember, was responsible for driving this nation into deep recession just four years ago.

Government members, together with their leader, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), just do not understand, or refuse to acknowledge, what is happening to Australians who are seeking to make a living from business. They do not recognise that the last thing Australian businesses need now is for the government to grab an extra three per cent of any profit they may be able to make.

This is a nine per cent tax increase, while inflation is one-third of that amount. The legislation is a blunt fiscal instrument designed to attack all Australian businesses as a result of the success of a few. It is important to recognise that since the recession of 1990 all Australian businesses have sought to rationalise their overheads and operating expenses and become more internationally and domestically competitive.

If we were to listen to this government, we would have to believe that all businesses in Australia were flourishing. We would have to believe that all Australian businesses were so flush with cash that they could give up three per cent of their profits without altering their behaviour in any way. We would have to believe that taking this money from companies would not have any effect on employment. We would have to believe that taking this money from companies would have no effect on investment. Plainly, we would have to believe in an economic model without any sense of reality. The Treasurer (Mr Willis) clearly believes in these scenarios. In his budget speech he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Now that the economy is growing strongly it is appropriate that the corporate sector make a contribution to the tightening of fiscal policy.

Let us examine the Treasurer's statement in detail. He claims that the economy is growing strongly. For the past month we have all heard from the government's economic ministers statements proclaiming how Australia's economic growth is slowing—no fear of inflation; no fear of rising interest rates; the new level of interest rates, whatever that may be, will be sustainable. Whatever `sustainable' might mean—and I add that Treasury officials during estimates this week have been reluctant to define what `economically sustainable' is—
the clear and undeniable fact is that economic growth, the level of activity in the community, is slowing. The real question is: by how much?

PARA.TAB: The government currently estimates that GDP will grow by 3.75 per cent over the next financial year. However, recent forecasts by the OECD suggest the Treasury figures may be on the high side, given the forecast of economic growth in our region and for our major trading partners. In addition, the private sector is forecasting a rate of growth significantly less than the figure forecast by Treasury. A Reuters survey released last week estimated growth of 3.2 per cent. Australia's most successful bank, NAB, estimates growth of 2.8 per cent.

Since the budget was handed down the US and Japanese economies have exhibited significant structural problems that almost certainly will lead to lower industrial production over the next 12 months. Slow or negative economic growth in these economies can only lead to slower than estimated economic growth in Australia. Our enormous foreign debt and the largest current account deficit in the OECD world could lead to higher costs of funds for all businesses and individuals in the future.

This uncertainty in financial markets, together with our anti-competitive labour market, provide causes for real concern as to how Australian businesses will perform over the next 12 months and in the longer term. The most recent Yellow Pages Small Business Index indicates that the profitability of small business operators surveyed by it has declined over the last five quarters. Of course, expectation amongst those operators is still for things to get better. Those small business operators are the backbone of this economy. They have no choice but to be optimistic. But to be a pessimist with this government is to be a realist.

Even the Treasury itself has noted that company profits are on the decline and that the level of profitability is patchy. So much for the Treasurer's justification for this tax increase. The claim that the economy is growing strongly and business can sustain the tax rise is a false and misleading generality. I remind the Senate of the words of the Treasurer on 30 November last year. When commenting upon the reduction in the company tax rate to 33 per cent he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It was also done with an eye to structural change, and that is to provide some longer term encouragement to investment.
In November 1994, the Treasurer also said:
You can't say now the economy is growing well we can rip all that away.
Yet in May 1995, this year, the Treasurer now says:
The economy is growing strongly. It is appropriate that the corporate sector makes a contribution to the tightening of fiscal policy.

Is it really possible to miss the contradiction in these statements? I think not. But what is really clear from the words and actions of the Treasurer is this: the Labor government does not understand what is happening to business, particularly to small business, in Australia today.

PARA.TAB: No matter how many times the Prime Minister may say so, this Labor government is not committed to any real structural change in the Australian economy as it affects people conducting businesses. When it comes to the crunch, the government would rather impose an additional tax than take the hard decisions regarding its own expenditure.

This government is a spending addict. They know they cannot afford to spend any more money, but they would rather use credit or take money from someone else than make a saving or institute a cut-back. Let the rest of Australia have less but not this government. I remind the Senate and the community that since 1991-92 Commonwealth outlays have increased by 20 per cent.

Reintroducing this tax two years after removing it may be viewed by some as just expedience. The fact is that this decision will hurt all businesses alike regardless of their long-term profitability and it raises no sympathy with the government. The fact that this decision will send the wrong message altogether to international and domestic investors is a matter of trivia, apparently, for this government.

What makes this a tax of deceit is the fact that it has been reintroduced by the government without removing the accelerated payment arrangements which the government said previously went hand in hand with the tax reduction in 1993.

I might add that the international moves for lower company tax rates have basically been driven by the difficulty of picking up company taxes. We live in a corporate financial world and it is difficult to tie taxes and profits to particular countries. We have to recognise that fact; it is a long-term trend.

I remind other non-government senators that the reduction in the company tax rate in 1993 was allied with a move by the government to accelerate company tax payments. What Paul giveth Paul taketh away. The revenue foregone by the government equalled the revenue gained by the government in 1993—a nice way of balancing the books.

As the Senate will note, there is no proposal to return the company tax payments structure to the way it was prior to the 1993 amendments. From the government's perspective, there is no need to do so as the revenue benefits have all been garnered from this measure.

Just two years ago, the Assistant Treasurer championed the measure as one which would act as a stimulus to business investment. As the lower tax it would increase the level of retained company profits that could be used to finance expansion and future investment—and also improve the attractiveness of Australia for both domestic and foreign investors. He further claimed that the measures would provide Australian industry with `a most competitive and supportive business tax environment'.

The Prime Minister claimed the 33 per cent tax rate would be comparable to Singapore and that increases in the rate would only hinder investment. If the government seriously believed that in 1993, why then is it turning 180 degrees two years later?

I ask all senators to consider if they will what this measure may do to Australian business and to Australia generally. Firstly, it will make all business tax arrangements less competitive compared with our international partners, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region. It will require business people to reconsider investment in Australia—and this is at a time when statistics already show a foreign exodus from the Australian equities market.

This measure will hurt Australian investors as share prices are lowered and dividend returns are reduced. Most significantly, higher taxes will force business to review cost structures. The likely consequence will be either higher prices of goods for which consumers have to pay and, with that, increased inflation, reduced employment and lower business investment. What alternatives does business have?

I ask non-Labor senators to trust their own instincts in respect of the economy. They should think about the state of business, particularly small businesses, in their home state. They should think about how many businesses can afford to pay higher taxes at this very time. In doing so, I ask them to carefully compare the circumstances of those major corporates with high profiles with the circumstances of the vast majority of small and medium businesses. Please do not make this a Pyrrhic victory. Do not punish the majority of businesses for the sake of short-term vengeance against a few. The tax increase should not be seen as an only option.

We have all heard how the government is seeking to blame this chamber once again for the government's economic mismanagement. No member of the public and no member of the press gallery should be fooled by this charade.

If this tax grab and others contained in the budget were defeated, the government would be forced to take a genuine look at its spending priorities. It may be forced to even seriously consider the recommendations of its central agencies, such as Finance and Treasury, for expenditure control. While the Senate continues to ratify the cheques for the government's expenditure machine, policy and program evaluation will never occur and waste will continue. We cannot complain that the government ignores the issue of expenditure priority while we continue to provide the mechanism for avoiding the issue. The coalition opposes the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill 1995.

The second bill we are debating is Taxation Laws Amendment (Budget Measures) Bill 1995. I will briefly outline the coalition's position on this bill, although I will have some more to say in the committee stage. We are opposing some parts of the bill and will vote against them in the committee stage. We do not oppose the other parts.

Firstly, schedule 1 of this bill makes consequential amendments in relation to the rise of company tax rates. The amendments are designed to ensure that the increasing company tax rate will not apply to the concessional rates of tax for recognised medium and large credit unions for the next two years. The coalition wants to see these concessions retained and will support schedule 1. Should we have thought that the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill would be defeated, we would have opposed this path. Should other non-Labor senators like to prove me wrong on this matter, I will be delighted to hear them and alter the coalition's position. Assuming, however, that the tax increase will be passed, the coalition will not oppose schedule 1.

Similarly, schedule 2 of the bill amends the income tax law to freeze the rate of tax imposed on the eligible insurance business of friendly societies and other registered organisations at 33 per cent for the next two years. In addition, the rebate applying to taxable bonuses paid on life insurance policies issued by friendly societies will increase to 33 per cent from 1 July this year as scheduled, and it will be maintained at that level for the next year.

The government has decided to introduce this tax freeze to enable a review of the taxing arrangements that apply to the life insurance business of friendly societies and life assurance companies. The review has been under way since 1989. The legislation does not remove the legislated rise in the tax rate to 39 per cent in 1997-98 and later years. The coalition opposed the increase in tax on friendly societies and other registered organisations in 1993. Therefore, the coalition will not oppose the freeze.

Reluctantly, we will not oppose the consequential amendments included in this bill in request of the government's proposal to return the sales tax rate on motor vehicles to that which existed prior to the last election. The increase on the tax on motor vehicles was a most cynical and callous tax grab. It deserves to be condemned not only for its hypocrisy but also for its likely consequences for the Australian motor vehicle industry. Nevertheless, as the Senate has already agreed to this tax rise, the coalition will not oppose these consequential amendments.

The coalition will oppose the attempts of the government to prevent a common law action for unjust enrichment in the case of sales tax. This is big brother legislation aimed at limiting the rights of citizens to those rights which the government declares a citizen will have. This is dangerous legislation and will be vigorously opposed.

The opposition will support the amendments to limit the tax advantaged computer program concession. Since 1 January 1993 taxpayers have enjoyed a concessional taxable value on a wide range of goods such as computers, mobile phones and white goods which contain computer programs housed in reprogrammable microchips. The government has alleged that the exemption has allowed unexpected and large deductions in relation to sales tax. The government maintains that the concession was intended to encourage innovation, but instead it has encouraged wastefulness as manufacturers added non-permanent microchips to their goods in order to qualify for the concession.

When supporting this proposal originally, the coalition indicated that it did so with some reluctance. The government claims an anomaly has occurred and, to the extent that this measure seeks to merely rectify that situation, again we will not oppose the measure. We do note, however, that it is possible that unintended consequences may come to light as a result of this amendment. In this era of new technology it will always be the case that it is not possible to foresee the entire spectrum of technological possibilities. I would urge the government to closely and thoroughly monitor the effects of the exemption and consider any claims that are made by Australian industry in this context.

The coalition will also be moving an amendment in respect of the provisional uplift factor. The government has set the rate at eight per cent for next financial year. The coalition believes that all economic evidence suggests that this figure is too high and proposes that the rate be set at six per cent. I know the government will oppose this amendment. However, I will listen most carefully to the arguments that the government puts forward to justify the eight per cent. Given the most recent economic data, the coalition's proposed rate may even be on the high side. So how an eight per cent rate can be justified is hard to see.

In summary, the coalition stands firm on its commitments to oppose electoral fraud in this country. It is one matter to be forced to amend an electoral commitment in light of serious economic changes which were clearly unforeseen at the time of the commitment; but quite another to make a commitment, be warned of its consequences and then proceed to renege on that commitment, later saying that things are worse than first thought.

In opposing the increases in taxes in this budget, the coalition does not seek to be negative, as sections of the media would portray; rather, it seeks to enforce the positive responsibility of government to be honest, responsible and an effective manager. The tax measures in this bill are dishonest, irresponsible and negligent management. They are testament to a tired, complacent and arrogant government. The measures deserve to be defeated as they merely repeat and highlight the fraud of 1993.

We have heard all the excuses before from this government, and the coalition will not support its continuing litany of deception. An economic sunset has begun in Australia, and our five minutes of brief economic sunshine is over. Let those responsible take their medicine.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I know you love debating tax bills all day, every day, but it is hard to make them interesting for 24 hours at a time. What we are talking about is really important. The bills we are talking about this morning are important because they are an important part of this government's deficit reduction strategy. I acknowledge that. They include the key measure to increase the company tax rate from 33 per cent to 36 per cent, by which the government will raise $320 million in 1995-96 and $1,590 million in 1996-97. The bills also contain some of the key base protection measures on sales tax. These measures, collectively, are worth about $150 million.

PARA.TAB: In our discussions with the government we requested that the bill setting the provisional tax uplift factor for small business for 1995-96 be brought forward. We thank the government for agreeing to do that. The government's resolve to set the uplift factor for 1995-96 at eight per cent, which is two per cent higher than the estimated growth in per capita national income, means the government will raise an extra $170 million in 1995-96 by setting the uplift factor at this rate. That is money that will have to be paid back to small business with interest as a refund in 1996-97.

The Democrats will be supporting the increase in company tax and will reluctantly support the base protection measures. We will be seeking to reduce the uplift factor. We will also be moving a number of amendments to the company tax collection arrangements for small businesses to lessen the impact of the company tax rise on them.

We asked for the provisional tax uplift factor to be debated cognately with the company tax in order to use the forum to highlight the problems with small business taxation, not just under company tax but also under provisional tax. About 80 per cent of small businesses are unincorporated and therefore fall under the provisional tax system. In October of last year, after the opposition failed to support the Democrats' move to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor to five per cent—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's because we are more responsible.

—I don't know about that. You are prepared to do it this year. We need to debate it to test your credentials this year. You said, `We cannot do it now; we will do it next year. We put the government on notice.' Well, here we are.

PARA.TAB: Because we were not able to achieve that last year, we said, `Let's have a look at the whole issue of taxation of small business.' I moved to establish a Senate inquiry and that inquiry reported yesterday. It received 68 submissions and the evidence was pretty overwhelming that small business remains concerned that tax is so often collected before the income is earned and that the timing of tax payments upon the cash flow of small businesses can significantly effect both their initial and ongoing viability.

The issue of most concern to small business operators was the unfairness of the provisional tax uplift factor. With that factor being set at eight per cent for next year—which, as we have said, is more than twice the inflation rate—the government gets $300 million worth of tax. While it is tax that will be refunded, it is the timing of the payment of that tax that creates the cash flow problem.

The Taxation Office submission to the inquiry highlighted just how much money the government is making out of provisional tax. In the three years from 1991 to 1993 the government collected an average of $367 million more in provisional tax than you could argue it was entitled to because of an excessive uplift factor. The uplift factor was set at 10 per cent when the inflation rate was nudging eight per cent. Inflation has fallen by six per cent but the uplift factor has only fallen by two per cent. That means that small business is forced to pay provisional tax on income deemed to be eight per cent higher than the income for the previous year. That is a lot higher than the average growth in provisional taxable income.

At the committee stage, along with the opposition, we will be seeking to reduce the uplift factor to six per cent. That takes into account the change in incomes because of inflation and general economic growth. According to Treasury and ABS projections, over the next four years GDP income per capita is expected to grow at a rate slightly above or slightly below six per cent. To provide certainty for small business, we will also be seeking to abolish the default rate of ten per cent and replace it with six per cent, which represents a reasonable income growth rate over the next four years, the years for which government projections are available.

We also indicated to the government that we would be seeking to lessen the impact of the company tax rise on small business. When the company tax rate was dropped in 1983, the government partly compensated the cost of it by bringing forward company tax payment times. Small companies balancing in June had until 15 February to finalise their tax; after 1993, this was brought forward to 1 December. Medium companies were required to pay 85 per cent by 28 September, following a June balance, with the rest due by 15 February. After 1994, 25 per cent was brought forward to 1 June, with a further 25 per cent due on 1 September, 1 December and 1 February. I thought that was a very clever way of paying for reductions in tax. Unfortunately, it has caught up with the government, so it has got to lift the overall rate again. But it worked.

Now that the company tax cut from 1993 has been cut in half, I think it is appropriate to partly revise these payment times; and we propose that the payment time for small companies be put back to 1 February and that the quarterly payments for small companies commence on 30 June rather than 1 June. That might seem a technicality, but finding the money means a big difference for business.

The amendments do not reduce the amount of tax payable; they just give small business a little more time to get their often understandably chaotic affairs in order. I will be moving amendments in this regard in the committee stage, and I will also be moving to increase the threshold for small businesses from a tax liability of $8,000 to a liability of $10,000.

The history of this is that, following the One Nation statement, this cut-off was set at $20,000, and the reduction to $8,000 was part of the bringing forward of repayment times needed to pay for the tax rate cut. The higher tax rate will mean that, if the $8,000 figure is not changed, 5,000 small businesses will find themselves without an increase in income—pushed up from small companies category to the medium category—and those things make a difference.

With respect to the company tax increase, we are disappointed that the government did not look more seriously at our suggestion for an alternative minimum company tax. Based on the performance of the tax in the United States, a minimum tax could have raised close to the same amount of money as the three per cent increase without penalising any honest tax paying company. I said at the time that I would have preferred the government to have gone for the fair hit rather than the king hit, because alternative minimum company tax is designed to make sure that companies are not able to use a wide variety of tax planning advice to eliminate their tax responsibility.

Many of us still have vivid memories of the 2c in the dollar tax rates that the Bond Corporation and Skase's Qintex were able to achieve. While the situation has improved—I would say noticeably; I would not say brilliantly, because I have heard people from the Business Council and others say, `But we pay at least 14 per cent now'—there are still plenty of major corporations with tax rates less than 10 per cent. You can easily find out who they are. Some in the top 100 companies still include News Corporation, FAI Life Insurance, QBE Insurance, James Hardie Industries and ERG Australia. A minimum company tax would require these companies to pay 20c in the dollar on a broader definition of `income', close to the ordinary statement of income provided to the stock exchange.

This tax is a Ronald Reagan initiative; it is hardly radical. It does not make it wrong either—I saw you look, Senator McMullan—which might have been my initial reaction. In the United States, this tax raised overall company tax collections by eight per cent, and that would represent about a billion dollars here. By cracking down on tax minimisation, the government could have sought to maintain a highly competitive headline company tax rate. As the Pender and Ross EPAC paper earlier this year showed—and as I have heard others say this morning—this tax rate is very important in making Australia a good place in which to invest.

We do not believe that a company tax rate of 36 per cent is unsustainable. We can see that it will move Australia's corporate tax rate from the lower end of the field to the middle of the field, and a company tax rate of 36 per cent is not unreasonable if you compare it to some other countries—40 per cent in Canada, 50 per cent in Germany, 56 per cent in Japan.

When I spoke with a lot of companies they were very philosophical about this increase saying that they could see it coming. They did not like the fact that it was three per cent; they thought two per cent would have been fairer given the circumstances, but there certainly was not the huge outcry that may have been predicted by others. In some respects I was a little surprised by that myself.

Finally, I wish to mention the issue of tax advantage computer software for which we take some responsibility, and I acknowledge that. I remember in 1992 I moved an amendment to expand the exemption for TACPs to cover software contained on reprogrammable microchips, the old EPROMs, and I never want to hear the word again. We did it to assist Australian-made software producers and to ensure that the Australian software industry was not disadvantaged by the taxation system. The emphasis was on Australian ownership, Australian employment and Australian export opportunities. I thought that was a sound position, but I guess I had not taken into account the Australian accountants' culture of seeking to find every little loophole to exploit where they can.

It was meant to be a limited exemption, but it is being used, I acknowledge, for a wide range of unintended consequences. So we have seen claims lodged for the software components of whitegoods such as microwave ovens, the software contained in motor vehicles, in photocopiers and so forth—all potentially under this exemption. We saw the exemption claimed by goods where the software was produced entirely overseas, which must be the ultimate contradiction in what was intended. We considered limiting the exemption to goods where software was a substantial part of the good or where the software was wholly produced in Australia, but we have reluctantly conceded that any formulation is likely to be too difficult.

So I regard the law as it stands post this amendment as unsatisfactory. We are prepared to agree to rescind the exemption for reprogrammable chips if for no other reason than to beat the accountants. I still have grave doubts that it will, because it remains possible for a company selling a good with a substantial software component to sell the software separately on a floppy disk, later mounted on the good after the sale, and in that way to avoid the tax. I really hope we are not replacing one leaky law with another one.

I really do not like the culture in this country of accountants and large accountancy firms touting for business and seeking to erode the revenue base with no thought for the consequences. We will see this again when we later debate the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

My office has raised with Senator Cook's office the problem that Australian software producers have come to rely on this exemption for their economic survival. That may be a good or a bad thing. I do not actually believe in level playing fields; I do not think it is wrong to pick some winners for some totally justifiable criteria. We have sought assurances that some form of transitional assistance will be made available to these firms, particularly in the mobile phone industry, and we have been assured by Senator Cook's office that the government is committed to ensuring that these firms survive and that an appropriate assistance plan is being developed.

I make it clear that my support for this exemption depends on that progress on the traditional assistance being made. If the Australian software producers in our vitally important telecommunications industry look like going under, then I will be beating on Senator Cook's door wanting to know why we should not again raise this tax measure and any other form of reasonable assistance to ensure that we do our best to retain a domestic telecommunications software industry. Those are the main areas of the bills we are currently debating that the Democrats want to canvass. The rest of it will be covered in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Budget Measures) Bill and the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill and acknowledge that my colleague Senator Gibson has put the coalition's position with regard to the tax measures involved. I want to speak about the provisional tax uplift factor and the effect that is having on small business and taxpayers.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Kernot rightly said, yesterday the Senate Economics Committee produced a report in which the provisional tax uplift factor was canvassed. I note that this year the government has chosen an eight per cent uplift factor. We have stated that a six per cent uplift factor is reasonable and justifiable—if it is possible to justify any set figure for the uplift factor. We are aware that it is necessary to make a responsible change and a responsible recommendation that is not going to have too great an effect on the government's anticipated revenue.

It is important and necessary to bear in mind that the provisional tax uplift factor is essentially a method of bringing forward anticipated tax receipts. It is therefore a timing device. It is all to do with timing. It is not a particular impost. The amount of tax for which provisional taxpayers are liable will not be affected in dollar terms by the provisional tax uplift factor, regardless of its quantum or form. What will be affected is when that money will be paid.

The provisional tax uplift factor was introduced at 7.5 per cent and it rose to 12 per cent before it became installed in the section of the income tax acts at a default rate of 10 per cent subject to parliamentary discretion. That is really what we are talking about today. The government has set the uplift factor at eight per cent for the two previous financial years and this year the government is again proposing that it will be eight per cent.

Should a provisional taxpayer consider that his or her taxable income will not increase by the amount predicted in the uplift factor, or that their income will decline during the remainder of the forthcoming year, they have the option of lodging a variation of their provisional tax. This adds compliance cost, which is an additional cost to small business. But there is also the problem that if the variation understates actual income by more than 15 per cent, the onus is on the taxpayer to make a case as to why the underestimation occurred; otherwise they may be subject to penalties, including the culpability factor.

During the course of the inquiry one of the issues we looked at was that of the culpability factor and whether it was fair on taxpayers. The fact that we only have that small window of 15 per cent in which to lodge a variation and have it assessed deters some people from putting in a variation because they are not sure, with the fluctuations in their incomes, that it is possible for them to accurately predict that they can fit into that window.

In its report the committee proposed that the culpability factor be removed and, instead, that underpaid taxation should be penalised at a levy which is at the highest commercial bank interest rate. Having to pay the highest commercial bank interest rate is penalty enough in itself. There is no advantage in understating income because the taxpayer will be penalised at the highest commercial rate for the amount understated. That penalty is all that is warranted.
The joint submission by the Taxation Office and the Treasury to the inquiry dealt with the provisional tax uplift factor. The submission said:

SPEECH.PARA: The level of aggregate income that should be subject to provisional tax is difficult to predict with accuracy.

The tax office is telling us that it is difficult to predict it with accuracy; yet we have this eight per cent being proposed by the government. By the Treasury's own admission outcomes have not matched predictions. As the submission says, if you look at the actual data you will find that in a lot of cases the provisional tax uplift factor, compared with what actually happened, varies quite a lot. The tax office itself is saying that the record is not good. However, this year the government is recommending an eight per cent uplift factor for provisional tax.

PARA.TAB: If we look at the actual data that is supplied by Treasury, it reveals little, if any, correlation between the uplift factor and the actual annual changes in taxable income for all provisional income earners. The committee acknowledges the thoroughness that is employed by the Treasury in attempting to take into account the widest range of relevant considerations when formulating a provisional tax uplift factor. It even pointed out that the subjectiveness of the process was evidenced by the need to utilise indicators such as long-range weather forecasting.

This was particularly in relation to the primary industry sector, where it is talking about projections of drought easing successively over the next couple of years. Volume growth should be exceptionally strong. When the Treasury has to start looking at the long-range weather forecast to see at what rate the uplift factor should be applied to certain areas of the economy, that defies all explanation. If we were to go to any academic and say, `One of the issues that we will have to take into account is whether it will rain or not' and try to predict that accurately, it would be stretching things a bit too far.

The recommended remedy for provisional taxpayers whose growth of income is expected to be less than the eight per cent that the government wants to put in place is to lodge a request to vary their provisional tax instalments. The committee received a considerable amount of evidence concerning the usefulness of this facility and has found it to be deficient in its current form. Having taken into account all of the evidence that we possibly could, we found that the facility of varying provisional tax is deficient in its current form. That is partly because many provisional taxpayers have fluctuating incomes which are very difficult to predict for more than a few weeks ahead, let alone most of the year, particularly if a taxpayer wishes to lodge a variation very early in the accounting period.

Consequently, as pointed out in a number of submissions and in evidence, many provisional taxpayers would not be in a position to lodge a request to vary until the final quarter of their accounting period because the 15 per cent margin of understatement allowed under the legislation is far too narrow for these taxpayers. It could create considerable hardship for taxpayers who suffer reductions of income, as their provisional tax assessment may be based on what may well be much higher levels of income from a previous year.

It is interesting to note that about 12 per cent of provisional taxpayers lodge variations, although in many cases by doing so they are faced with additional compliance costs in the form of additional accountancy fees. This places an extra burden on the taxpayers, who are already likely to be in far tighter financial circumstances because of the reduction of their income.

Let us look at some of the consequences of a high provisional tax uplift factor, assuming that the tax uplift factor is high, which is what we are saying in this debate. The Taxation Office acknowledges that the reality is that at an individual taxpayer level there will probably be a greater number who will be below that average and far fewer who will be in excess of it. In other words, the rates at which the provisional tax uplift factor have been set since 1991 have resulted in the tax office never having lost any net provisional tax revenue—in fact, considerably exceeding what was required to be remitted in advance by provisional taxpayers in some of those years since 1991. Thus, the tax office has had a considerable benefit from the uplift factor being, on average in the past three years, far too high.

The imposition of any factor which attempts to express an average rise in projected income upon this numerically very large disparate and volatile section of the business is clearly inappropriate. There are a number of alternatives, some of which are not very palatable, either to the government or to people who are trying to predict into the future. One would be to abolish the uplift factor altogether. While this would undoubtedly be very popular with provisional taxpayers, it is fair to say that the deferral of over half a billion dollars of revenue would probably rule this out as a possibility either in the short term or even in the medium term.

Almost all of the submissions and evidence received during the committee hearings from the private sector—and one of the three submissions received from the public sector—opposed the current level of the provisional tax uplift factor. The most frequently stated reason was that the provisional tax uplift factor was far in excess of inflation. Those who did not advocate its abolition—and there were many who did—generally recommended that the provisional tax uplift factor be fixed at either the current or projected inflation rate.

It is fair to say that in the report that was brought down yesterday in this chamber, the economics committee recommended that the provisional tax uplift factor be set at a level no higher than the current or projected annual movement of the CPI. In making that recommendation, which we would like the government to consider, we realise that if that method was to come in immediately and be taken as a proposition for the coming year, it would have a severe impact on government revenue. In order for it to be put into place there needs to be some time allowed for the rate to move to the CPI. For that reason, the coalition responsibly has decided that it will support a six per cent uplift factor for this year.

There is some justification for us doing that. Last year, when the uplift factor was an issue in October, as Senator Kernot mentioned, the Democrats moved for the provisional tax uplift factor to be reduced. The reason we opposed the Democrats position was that we felt the government needed some time to allow for the impact on revenue that move would have. However, at that time, the coalition put the government on notice that it was considering its position with regard to the provisional tax uplift factor and since that time the government has made no move to change from the eight per cent that it had last year.

There is no justification for eight per cent. It is very difficult in some cases to justify an uplift factor at all because it presumes, averaging over all businesses, that a business is likely to make a greater income next year than it did this year; and a greater income the following year than in the previous year. It simply is not the case, because there are so many factors that need to be taken into consideration when determining whether a business has been successful and its income is rising. It varies between professions. Yet this one factor is arbitrarily rated at eight per cent by the government. It says it has taken a lot of factors into account. One I mentioned was the weather.

We apply an average over a whole range of businesses and then say to them, `If you are not doing so well this year put in a variation to your provisional tax.' What we are doing at that stage is placing additional burdens on businesses, in many cases small businesses, which are already feeling the pinch. It is putting extra pressure on those small businesses when they can least afford for it to happen. If a small business needs to vary its provisional tax downward, it is because its income has dropped; yet we have a standard rate of provisional tax uplift factor which is very difficult to justify in any case. Certainly, if there is to be an uplift factor—and because there has been one in place for a considerable time, I concede that it cannot be taken away immediately because of the impact on revenue—at least the rate at which it is going to be applied should be considered in the current economic climate.

With that in mind, I support totally the coalition's proposed amendment that for this year the uplift factor be six per cent. We think that if it is at six per cent, business communities, particularly the small business community which it will affect most of all, will at least have some acceptance that we are trying to do something to get the provisional tax uplift factor down to what they would consider to be an acceptable level.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment (Budget Measures) Bill 1995 is a complex bill. The major issues in this bill for the Greens relate to provisional tax and tax refunds. The bill includes consequential amendments relating to luxury cars, but we do not have any issue with that section.

PARA.TAB: Provisional tax is paid for the year in advance and affects anyone who is self-employed. This is actually a large portion of small business, where business profit is taken as personal income rather than paid at the company tax rate. Provisional tax is paid on the year ahead, although payment is not due until significantly after that date; that is, nine months after, so that payment can largely be based on real returns. Provisional tax calculates that there will normally be an increase in income each year above the increase in consumer prices and GDP growth. It says that this increase is taken to be 10 per cent. This figure, the provisional uplift factor, may be adjusted by parliament if there is an annual exception or an adjustment to the base figure.

The government is proposing to set the tax at eight per cent this year. The coalition is proposing to change the rate from eight per cent to six per cent this year. The Democrats are proposing to change the normal factor from 10 per cent to six per cent. We think this is probably a more reasonable figure and a way to go about it. The Democrats are also moving an amendment to protect small businesses that have been incorporated as companies from the consequences of changes.

The first measure is to adjust the classification of small business so that the increase in company tax does not result in their being reclassified without any real increase in income. This is a consequence of the classification which divides companies on the basis of tax liability. There are a number of anomalies in relation to this classification, since profit—and, hence, liability—can be adjusted somewhat. If you change the rate from 33 per cent upwards, it will be a bit like a tax net—more companies will fall into that net without there being any change in what they actually earn or the size of their business. We are going to support these two measures.

The second measure is to change the date by which claims must be filed. These were brought forward and there have apparently been a number of problems with this. They will now partially be put back. This is less clear in relation to where we should fall—one side or the other—so we will be listening carefully to the arguments to make a decision on these particular issues.

The final issue is tax refunds. The coalition is suggesting they should be struck out. Tax collected under the tax regimes is collected by wholesalers, but they are not obliged to pay government until 28 days after the bill receives royal assent. Tax may also be collected or paid wrongly; for example, when a business applies a wrong rate of tax to an item. This can occur as classifications are not always obvious.

In that case, they are entitled to a refund but, under sales tax laws, can obtain it only if they can prove they have not charged their customers or they can show they have returned the overpayment. The latter is unlikely to occur and the former is very difficult to prove, since sales price is simply a price and not a price plus X amount of tax. Companies can argue that they absorb the tax out of profit, but this is hard to prove, since profit levels are also not separable or established.

Companies are unlikely to admit they have overcharged or go to the time, expense and trouble of finding and refunding overpayments and then apply to the tax office for a refund, when they can only get a refund on the tax returned by them. Therefore, they make no money from a process which is embarrassing and costs money. The only time it would occur would be if they were caught by customers and could not deny overpayment and were so embarrassed they needed to act. In other words, refunds are unlikely.

The only other option is a common law claim. If a claim is made and is successful, it is evidence of overcharging, and retailers have a case to make similar claims against the wholesalers on the same common law ground. If they win, the customers could claim against them. All this is difficult and complex. The customers have little understanding of their options. The Greens will therefore be putting forward amendments to require customer information to be advanced in relation to sales tax changes. We certainly want this to be part of legislation so that it actually becomes a normal part of the way bills are presented in relation to sales tax so that people and businesses know their rights and obligations. This is the least we can do to help sort out the confusion that arises as a result of any such changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not speak for long on these measures because of the time constraints under which we are unfortunately working in this last day and a half of these sittings. This legislation deals with a number of matters. It specifically deals with the company tax rate change. Senator Gibson made some very important points about that matter. Not only individual voters but also the companies in this country, which are, in large part, the employers of those voters, are entitled to certainty. Undertakings were given by the government prior to the last election. We saw, as has been pointed out, various excuses being made as to why this particular tax should be adjusted one way or the other—downwards if there is an election looming. Now we have an election looming and it is being proposed that it should go upwards.

PARA.TAB: The other matter relates to the taxation of friendly societies and other registered organisations. If the prior matter to which I have referred is defeated, then that provision is not necessary anyhow. The bill also deals with tax advantaged computer programs, consequential changes and the uplift factor. It also deals with the question of sales tax refunds, to which Senator Margetts has just adverted. It is on that matter that I want to say a couple of choice words. This whole question is a very great matter of principle for parliament. This legislation is attempting to entrench a narrow base for refunds of moneys paid to the Taxation Office in respect of sales tax. The Taxation Office is unlawfully retaining that money. That is the issue that is involved here. The money has been paid to the Taxation Office and it is unlawfully retaining that money.

There can be a whole host of arguments put forward by the government, and it has done so on this matter. It has also been dealt with by other speakers—Senator Gibson, Senator Kernot and Senator Margetts. I do not want to go into the detail but I want to address the question of the Taxation Office holding moneys that are unlawfully obtained. This is a fundamental question about the purpose of parliament. I refer to the proposal in this legislation to strip people of their common law rights to recover sales tax that is unlawfully demanded by the Commissioner of Taxation.

It has been more than 300 years since the revolution of 1688 and the Bill of Rights which declared that taxation could not be levied except according to law. It is even longer since King Charles I asserted the right to take money by royal prerogative and lost the Crown as a result. I do not claim to have known King Charles I, though my ancestors on the Harradine side lived in the surrounds of London—rather poorly, I must say. They looked to the parliament, of course, to be their protector.

The outcome of those great struggles between Crown and parliament was firmly established in the principle of the rule of law. As Dicey enunciated in his monumental Law of the Constitution the principle of the rule of law is the firm rock upon which our constitutional arrangements rest. The Queen is not above the law. The Governor-General is not above the law. The Prime Minister is not above the law. None of us is above the law, nor is the Commissioner of Taxation above the law. This principle is enunciated in the Judiciary Act which provides that where the Commonwealth is a litigant with a private party it is generally to be in the same position as any other litigant.

Against this background—particularly having regard to the actions of the House of Commons and the various disputes that occurred between the Commons and the Crown—I find it extraordinary that the House of Representatives should have so forgotten that history as to have presented us with a bill which allows the Commissioner of Taxation to retain moneys unlawfully taken.

I am here to represent the people of Tasmania. The people who put me here are entitled to have certain expectations of me. They are entitled to expect that I will defend their rights to their lives, their liberty and their property. It is my duty as a legislator to ensure, so far as is within my power, that the law is equal for all—that its protection extends from the wealthiest to the poorest, from the famous to the most obscure, to the newest arrival equally with the native born. That is why I have stood up for the rights of the poorest refugee, the rights of the disabled and the dying, the rights of the unborn and why I now stand up to denounce this bill.

If law is to mean anything, it must command the respect of the governed. If it is to command the respect of the governed, then it must be, and it must be seen to be, fundamentally just. The High Court of Australia has held that it is unjust enrichment that the Commissioner of Taxation should be able to retain moneys which he was not lawfully entitled to demand. He has no more right to retain such moneys than a common thief.

I am astonished that ministers and their Public Service advisers have in their arrogance so far forgotten the first principles of constitutional government that they have dared to bring forward this proposal. I know that they will not be slow—and have not been slow—to justify it with sophistries but I ask them to remember who they serve. I ask them to remember the principles that I have repeated and that have long since been foundations of justice and equality before the law.

We did not abolish absolute monarchy in order to replace it with the absolute despotism of ministers and the executive government. If the House of Representatives does not play its part as its predecessors have done in the past and as the House of Commons did during those famous struggles with the Crown, it is for this Senate, this House of review, to uphold the rights of the ordinary people against the executive by utilising the power it has to review legislation of this nature.
Prime Minister William Pitt remarked that absolute power is apt to corrupt the minds of those who possess it. The bringing forward of this bill is a sad confirmation of the truth of that judgment.

I might add that this attempt to escape the principle of equality of the law would face further scrutiny even if we in this chamber were to fail our duty and allow this part of this law to pass. I do not see how the taking of money without lawful authority can be other than an acquisition of property on unjust terms and therefore constitutionally invalid. It is by definition not a law with respect to taxation to allow a tax officer to demand and retain payment of an unlawful tax. I must admit to my colleagues that this is merely offered as an indication. I have not studied it, but it seems to me that it is not a law with respect to taxation to allow a tax officer to demand and retain payment of an unlawful tax. That is what we are being asked to do here. I ask the minister to table any advice he has on the constitutional validity of the proposal to strip people of their rights to recover money unlawfully taken from them. I cannot support this bill as it stands.
In conclusion, let me express the hope that the House of Representatives will in future continue its position and not present us with this type of unprincipled legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the Taxation Laws Amendment (Budget Measures) Bill 1995. This bill is an omnibus bill that will cover a wide range of amendments to the taxation law to implement the government's budget proposals. I wish to confine my remarks to two particular issues that this bill covers.

PARA.TAB: I want to deal with schedule 3. I certainly welcome the presence of the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) in the chamber, because this is a very important bill that needs his consideration for the continued existence of the very small telecommunications industry in Australia. When I say very small, I am referring to the people who design and manufacture hand-held phones in Australia.

Firstly, I am strongly opposed to the amendments to the Sales Tax Assessment Act, which seek to remove the concessional treatment given to products that contain computer programs embodied in the non-permanent microchip. I note all the arguments put forward by the minister. The concession has encouraged manufacturers to use non-permanent microchips simply to get at the tax concession, resulting in a miscalculation of resources. The concession has led to a loss of sales revenue, promoted inequities in the marketplace and created anomalies for taxpayers. That may well have been the result.

As Senator Kernot said, this amendment was supported by the coalition and the Democrats in 1992. In our opinion, it advances technology and locally produced telecommunications equipment. For that reason, we put it through. As will happen in such cases, everyone wants to get in on the bandwagon. As Senator Kernot also said, it has been extended to many other industries, such as cars and whitegoods. I would have thought it was a simple matter to put through an amendment which would restrict the taxation concession to the telecommunications industry, as was originally intended.

The central proposition advanced by the minister that business has sought to utilise non-permanent microchips simply to avail itself of the sales tax exemption could be right, but in the telecommunications industry it is absurd. Non-permanent microchips are increasingly used as a consequence of technological advancement in product development. The use of non-permanent microchips allows newly developed programs to be downloaded into the product as they are developed.
