This could be used as a means of product differentiation from products using permanent microchips which must be totally replaced when new programs are developed. The government's amendments will act to penalise technological advancement in the rapidly changing field of software development and encourage the continued use of antiquated technology.

Senator Cook rightly says—he reminds us almost ad nauseam at question time—that Australia has to be at the cutting edge of technology. He promotes that as Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. That is great. We on this side of the parliament support him. Here is an advanced method of technology, and the minister is going to put 13 pounds of lead in the saddle and pull it wide on a wet track. He is going to hurt the small, hand-held components section of the telecommunications industry.

It makes no sense to discriminate in this fashion between manufacturers of computer programs. It is particularly illogical to give the advantage to manufacturers who are utilising outmoded practices involving floppy disk against manufacturers at the forefront of new technology who, because of the nature of their product, as is the case with cellular phones, are compelled to download the software into microchips. It is foreseeable that, far from removing sales tax avoidance practices by manufacturers of computer programs, these amendments could simply give rise to a different method of tax avoidance. For example, as the legislation levies a tax advantage for computer programs that have not been embodied in microchips, manufacturers of computer programs could possibly avoid sales tax by selling the program separately from the device in which the program is to be used—in other words, by means of selling a floppy disk and the actual product and then downloading the floppy disk into the product.

Practices such as these will result in their own miscalculation of resources which, in all likelihood, would be greater than any alleged miscalculation of resources by computer program manufacturers using non-permanent microchips to escape sales tax under the present arrangements. There would also be a misallocation of Taxation Office resources as tax bureaucrats would have to police whether the program was removed before or after the point of sale. Removal of the sales tax concession would repudiate key provisions in the Radiocommunications Act 1992 which is described as designed to provide a regulatory environment to maximise opportunities for the Australian communications industry in domestic and international markets. That is part of Senator Cook's policy on technological advancement in the telecommunications industry.

Removing one of the few benefits that local industry currently has over overseas competitors, which hold such market power, allows them to subsidise the sale of phones at a low cost. I am not sure whether they are subsidised or they are dumped but one thing I am sure of is that it would be impossible to retail phones at such low prices in the market at the moment without their being either dumped or heavily subsidised.

Giving advantages to the imported games and entertainment cartridge industry makes absolutely no sense. You are putting a handicap on an industry that is worth billions of dollars around the world while allowing computer games to go through without a similar tax. You are taxing the technology of the phone industry while allowing computer games a free kick.

The government's assessment of the loss of sales tax revenue following on the alleged practice of manufacturers of computer programs of using reprogrammable microchips—or EPROMs, as we know them here—instead of permanent microchips in order to gain a tax benefit, is greatly overstated in the telecommunications industry. According to the minister, the removal of this concession will raise $10 million in 1994-95, $150 million for 1995-96, and $185 million by 1998-99. Those figures are illusionary.

The telecommunications market is presently dominated by the major carriers of Telecom and Optus, and those two companies engage in the practice of substantially subsidising the sales of cellular mobile phones to get the people who buy those phones to connect to their networks. They are not selling phones; they are subsidising phones to get people to connect to their networks.

As a result, phones are being purchased by the retail dealers at very nominal prices from the two major carriers, which are buying in bulk and distributing the phones to retail distributors at very nominal prices. So sales tax, in the vast majority of the telecommunications market, is derived from a very small base. This is causing severe damage to the industry.

The only remaining Australian designers and manufacturers of cellular phones are NEC and Voxson, and they are finding it difficult to afford to subsidise their phones in this way. The sales tax yield is therefore derived from the sales of these manufacturers, which is a very low base.

Until now, the concession has lessened the blow suffered by the local manufacturers trying to compete with the companies subsidising their phone sales. In particular, the concession has enabled one of the two local manufacturers, Voxson, to develop the GSM telephone, which is the latest technology in the industry. Voxson is the only company developing GSM within Australia. While I have the minister's ear, I want to tell him that there are billions of dollars of sales of the new GSM technology throughout the world but Australia will miss the bus if something is not done about these two remaining companies.

This development and others are now jeopardised by the government's change in policies. The revenue forgone from exempting imported entertainment and educational cartridges far exceeds the increase in revenue to be gained from the Australian telecommunications industry as a result of the government's amendments. In view of the critical anomalies raised and the fact that the likely effect of the removal of this concession will severely disadvantage the Australian telecommunications industry, I strongly urge the government to reconsider the amendments. I can strongly urge it as much as I like, and I know that I am not going to win there, but I ask Senator Cook to come up with some alternative form of assistance to an industry that can provide Australia with billions of dollars of export sales if it is allowed to get on the front foot.

I turn to schedule 10 of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Budget Measures) Bill, another important issue, which amends the Income Tax Assessment Act to set the provisional tax uplift factor at eight per cent for 1995-96, as foreshadowed in this budget. The provisional tax uplift factor—the amount by which the previous year's taxable income of an unincorporated business increased in order to calculate provisional tax in that business's current year of income—impinges very heavily on the small business sector.

At eight per cent, the uplift factor is double the growth rate and three times the inflation rate. Small business—or what is remaining of small business after the high interest regime in the 1980s—is really going to feel the pinch and is being used as a milking cow for the government's budget surplus, or its attempt to get a budget surplus.

The government introduced the uplift factor in its current form at 10 per cent. The taxation laws amendment bill and a joint Treasury and Australian Taxation Office submission to the Senate inquiry into the taxation treatment of small business provided no clear explanation of the rationalisation for the level of the uplift. The explanatory memorandum states:

The level of the uplift factor is intended to be a reasonable reflection of the growth in income of provisional taxpayers. The level cannot be predicted with accuracy so it is preferable not to place undue emphasis on a specific forecast or estimate in setting the factor. Matters such as inflation effects are taken into account.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasury and Australian Tax Office joint submission, included in the preliminary issues paper released by the Senate Economics References Committee, stated that the level of aggregate income that should be subject to provisional tax is difficult to predict with accuracy. We agree with that. But this year and for the past three years the uplift factor has been set by the government at eight per cent, despite the fact that the 1995-96 forecasts for growth and inflation were 3.75 per cent and 3.5 per cent respectively.

PARA.TAB: The forecasts for growth and inflation for 1994-95 are 5.75 per cent and three per cent. Growth for 1993-94 was 4.3 per cent and the inflation rate was 1.8 per cent. Yet the uplift factor has remained at eight per cent. In 1992-93, the growth was three per cent and inflation was one per cent, but we still had the uplift factor at eight per cent. Even at the height of the recession, in 1991-92, with growth at almost minus figures—0.8 per cent—and inflation at a minimum of 1.9 per cent, the uplift factor was retained at 10 per cent. There is no excuse for an uplift factor to be set at 10 per cent and actually charged at eight per cent. I am finding it very hard to support the uplift factor at even six per cent. The legislated uplift factor of 10 per cent and charged at eight per cent is an arbitrary figure, and it is almost just plucked out of the air.

The small business sector has sought an uplift factor that is more in line with the inflation rate and the growth figures of around two or three per cent. Treasury figures indicate that every one per cent of the uplift factor translates into $100 million in tax revenue for the government. So the government is extracting from the small business sector something like $600 million a year that it does not deserve and cannot reasonably claim.

This huge slug is to be taken out of the small business sector, out of the economy, to boost the government's coffers so it can run around and say that it has a budget surplus. Senator Schacht, the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, should be in the cabinet. I do not know who represents him in the cabinet; maybe it is Senator Cook, who has just raised his hand. If Senator Cook does represent him, then I have to say that he has done a damned lousy job on this issue. I would ask him to lift his game if he is to continue to represent small business in the cabinet.

The issue of the uplift factor has been extensively canvassed. It is one of the key references of the Senate Economics References Committee inquiry into the tax treatment of small business. I think that report was tabled yesterday, although it may have been tabled this morning as I heard Senator Ferguson speaking on that issue. The reference dealing with the uplift factor considered the appropriateness of the quantum and current form of the uplift factor. Cited in the small business issues paper released by the committee in March were 63 submissions received from individual and peak industry bodies. Every single one opposed the provisional tax uplift factor and every one advocated its reduction or complete removal.

This view was also supported by a recent survey undertaken by the Institute of Chartered Accountants which showed that almost 96 per cent of the 1,000 respondents believed that an eight per cent uplift factor was unreasonable for the 1995-96 financial year. Over half of the respondents stated that the uplift factor should be pegged at the inflation rate, and that that would be a reasonable assessment.

I welcome the committee's findings on small business in relation to taxation and the uplift factor. In conclusion, let me say that small business has suffered probably more than any other sector of the market, apart from the rural sector. About 70,000 small businesses have gone into receivership over the last four years. Setting the uplift factor at eight per cent will only increase the demise of what remains of Australia's small business sector. Let me say this in the final minute of my speech: regional and rural small businesses suffered more than any others. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment (Budget Measures) Bill 1995 and the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill 1995. This is the second package of tax bills that have come before the Senate as a consequence of the 9 May 1995 Australian budget for 1995-96.

PARA.TAB: As I said last night—and I do not intend to repeat all the things I said last night but I will make a few relevant points following the debate by honourable senators in this chamber, particularly with regard to the views put by the coalition, the Australian Democrats and the Greens—the important thing to remember about this year's budget is that it is historic and important. It sets the macro-economic parameters for the management of the Australian economy, which is economic code for saying that it puts the right fundamentals in place. A lot of the debate that we have heard thus far on these bills, if I may characterise it this way, has been nitpicking about details that are necessary in order to deliver the fundamentals. With the greatest respect for the contributors, there has been a lot of crocodile tears shed about small business.

The fundamental truth is that if you get the fundamentals wrong in the economy, and if you undermine the macro settings that we have put in place in this budget for the economy, small business will be the most massive disbeneficiaries. They will pay the price, and they will pay the price in a way unlike anything that you are concerned about here. You are delivering populist and appealing arguments to small business but they cannot be seen outside of the macro context because if you fail on the macro fundamentals you will fail small business across the board in a much more devastating way.

This budget is historic because it puts the budget of the Commonwealth of Australia into surplus. This year it goes into surplus by $718 million. That is a surplus achieved by fiscal tightening. We have reduced Commonwealth expenditure, we have also imposed some revenue measures and we have budgeted for asset sales. This year, if this budget is unmaligned, we are in surplus. Next year we are in surplus to the tune of $3.4 billion without any asset sales to prop up the surplus. The following year we are in surplus in excess of $7 billion. Those are structural surpluses.

It is vitally important for the Australian economy that we achieve surplus. It is vitally important, too, that we deliver on our program for a massive medium-term national savings plan which this budget puts in place through the provisions we have made for superannuation. Superannuation works in two important ways. It means that almost all Australians will have superannuation provision made for them to which the government will contribute, to which they will contribute, and to which their employers will contribute. They will be able to look forward to retirement with some dignity and at income levels above that of the aged pension. That is a sensible thing to benefit ordinary Australians.

The pool of funds that the national superannuation provisions provides is a massive pool of investment owned by Australians to invest in the Australian economy and ensure that there is less foreign ownership or less reliance on investment by foreigners in the Australian economy. They are positive moves.

The net effect of this budget is to put downward pressure—I believe quite significant downward pressure—on interest rates. This budget is a massive signal to the market that this government is responsible; it manages its economy properly and there is pressure downward on interest rates. You fiddle with this budget; you play a quasi-populist game to save a few cents here or a few dollars there and you remove that downward pressure on interest rates and interest rates remain higher, or go up, and as a result no small business operator in Australia will thank you. Small business operators will blame you and it will be your responsibility, not ours. We have said that quite clearly and quite strongly.

We need to repeat that message. The downward pressure that this budget puts on interest rates is significant. Australian home buyers want to see interest rates fall. You tamper with that downward pressure and interest rates remain constant, or rise, and that is your gift to the Australian community.

I asked the Senate last night to pause. Pause again before you go over the brink and commit yourself to this. Last night you did not pause; you went over the brink and you cut revenue measures of the Commonwealth which have reduced the amount of the surplus and have eased, at this stage, some of the downward pressure on interest rates that our budget has put in place. You have done that so far.

We have a number of measures here where you are, as I listened to the speakers, proposing to do it again. We have the Senate taking the downward pressure off interest rates. You are easing that pressure back. Once again I say to the Senate: pause before you cross that bridge because business and taxpayers in Australia want to see an economy in which their long-term retirement aspirations can be addressed. Australians want proper access to education for themselves and for their children; they want proper provision for health services within the Commonwealth; and they want a proper safety net for social security. All those things need to be met out of this budget—and are—and we in the Labor government have not tampered with those other than to make the targeting of them more effective.

We have found savings within that structure and we now find that the opposition wants to cancel out some of the savings in outlays that we have found and impose higher costs on the taxpayers by returning those savings. The opposition also wants to cancel out some of the tax changes that we are making, principally in the business area, so that there is less income. So it wants to spend more money, but reduce the income and lower the surplus. It says that it is economically responsible.

It does not matter how many doorstops the shadow Treasurer, Mr Peter Costello, does around this place attacking the federal government, he will not escape the fact that what the commentators—the informed economic critics—and the people of Australia will see is an opposition that wants to spend more, raise less, put the budget back into deficit and lift the downward pressure that we have applied to interest rates. That is exactly what is happening here. People around Australia are watching it and the economic commentators are analysing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —And what did the dollar do last night? Nothing, because they can see through you.

—Senator, this is an incubating problem. One night does not make a winter. When this message is out and it is understood—increasingly it is—the electorate will turn to those who are responsible and reject those who are irresponsible.

PARA.TAB: We have built our period in government on the proposal that good economics is good politics. That means you face the hard questions, you deal with them honestly and you tell the people what you are doing. That pays dividends because living standards are made more secure and rise. What we have in the Senate at the moment is an opposition which thinks playing populist politics, irrespective of the economic impact, is good. Populist politics and a short term, weak-kneed, jelly-backed approach to being responsible about the fundamentals always comes home to bite you. When it comes home to bite you, it does in a huge way. As I said, I believe that that will be the case.

A number of honourable senators in this debate have raised some specific issues to which I should address myself before I resume my seat. Nothing that I will now say should undercut the weight of the remarks I have made thus far. In this debate it has been foreshadowed that there will be a number of changes to the new company taxation instalment system that the government proposes to introduce. For the importance of the record, I will read into it a number of points that the government would wish to make. The tax issue of greatest concern to small business has been the subject of inquiry by the Senate Economics References Committee. The reference was `improving the tax treatment of small business'. The government is committed to responding to that report. We will respond to it and, therefore, it is appropriate to consider the committee's findings before deciding on any further amendments to taxation on small business. The Senate has conducted a report and we will respond to it. Do not move before that opportunity has been created.

If the intention of the proposed amendments is to relieve small business of some of the costs of doing business, the proposed rescheduling may not be the best method of achieving that objective. Small business, small companies and companies paying small amounts of tax are discernibly different groups. Indeed, most small businesses, particularly those at the lower end of the total business income scale, are not incorporated and therefore would not benefit from special treatment for taxpaying companies. Furthermore, companies with small income tax liabilities may not be small businesses in terms of their accounting profit, assets or number of employees. Any change to the instalment arrangements for small or medium taxpaying companies would be likely to provide an undeserved benefit to subsidiaries of large corporate groups. It might also encourage—I think this is an important point—artificial manipulation of subsidiaries in order to capture the associated tax benefit.

The new company tax instalment system was designed both to improve the equity of the scheduling of income tax payments for companies vis-a-vis other taxpayers, particularly unincorporated businesses, and reduce the lumpiness of the previous scheduling of payments. Under the previous system, unincorporated businesses generally paid tax earlier than incorporated businesses whose income tax liabilities became due considerably after that income was derived. This difference is diminished by the new instalment regime. I therefore ask honourable senators to consider that and act accordingly by not proceeding with their proposed amendments.

Senator Boswell's and Senator Kernot's remarks raised the question of the microchip tax provision and referred to the impact that may have on some Australian telecommunications companies. I can, for the sake of the record, put more explicitly what it is that the government proposes to do to assist Australian telecommunications companies to become more competitive both within Australia and internationally.

The original industry development arrangement scheme to promote—and there is some jargon in this—CPE products in Australia is due to expire on 30 June 1996. `CPE products' is bureaucratic code for customer premised equipment—I have as much difficulty with all this jargon as, I am sure, ordinary people do. This equipment includes portable phones, the PABX system or the first phones when that equipment, owned by Telecom, Optus or someone else, is in the customer's premises.

Just to reiterate, the original industry development arrangement scheme to promote certain customer premised equipment products in Australia is due to expire on 30 June 1996. The government believes it timely to consider a strategy for the CPE industry within the wider industry development arrangements for the telecommunications industry. The government is committed to developing a national strategy for the communications industry. A key part of that strategy is industry development.

Tonight, my portfolio colleague, Senator Schacht, the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, is leaving Australia to lead a telecommunications industry trade mission throughout South-East Asia. The trade mission will be travelling to Japan, Vietnam and the Philippines. He will be accompanied by a whole raft of Australian telecommunications companies as part of this promotional push to encourage the export of Australia's telecommunications excellence to the world.

The government is committed to developing a national strategy for the communications industry and a key part of that strategy is industry development. A strategy for CPE is being jointly developed by the Department of Communications and the Arts with my department, Industry Science and Technology. The strategy will be an input into the post-1997 telecommunications review, which is already looking at the wider industry development issues arising from telecommunications reform. This will be part of the package looking at technical regulation issues which will be considered separately after the principal post-1997 considerations. The broadband services export group recommended that the government should require cable network operators involved in broadband service provision to implement development plans for the telecommunications supply industry. This recommendation will be considered as part of a post-1997 review.

The anticipated growth in telecommunications will provide many opportunities for Australian industry. The ministers—and I speak for Minister Lee and me in this—are committed to ensuring that a strategy is in place so that Australia is well placed to capture the emerging opportunities. A key element of that strategy will be working with Australian-owned companies to improve their quality and the applicability of their technology, and to encourage their ability to find niches and broader markets for their products. I say that because of the anxiety raised by Senator Kernot and Senator Boswell. I trust that, with those commitments and reassurances, we can look afresh at the tax measure that is before the chamber.

We have had a long discussion on this matter. Many of the words that have been spoken have been said before. I do not wish to repeat them, but these are important bills. They go to the efficacy of the budget. Once again, I request senators to have regard to the fundamentals of the economy and our bottom line, put aside their previously pronounced positions and sensibly adopt the proposals brought forward by the government. I commend the bills to the Senate.
Question put:
That these bills be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
Debate interrupted.
Debate resumed from 28 June, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —When debate on this matter concluded last night I was in continuation. I have left my notes in my office as I was unaware that this was to proceed now.
—It hasn't troubled you before.

—As Senator Ferguson said, it has not worried me before. Last night, I pointed out that a number of my colleagues speaking in this debate—Senator Tambling, Senator Calvert and Senator Panizza—have long and distinguished careers and records in local government. Senator Calvert reminded me afterwards that I forgot to mention myself. Of course, it is not for me to say that I had a distinguished career in local government, but I was an elected member of the Burdekin Shire Council for 11 years. So I do understand what local government is all about.

PARA.TAB: I mentioned that a number of our candidates who will become members of parliament after the next election are people who currently serve their local communities on local councils. As well, I indicated that the Australian Local Government Association also has a very proud record of looking after the interests of local councils and, through them, ratepayers by its work with the federal government.

As I concluded, or as I was interrupted by the bell last night, I was saying that that organisation has generally been very responsible and mature. It did go through a period just before the last election when it was headed by a person who, I might say, is not a bad friend of mine, a nice fellow, councillor Peter Wood, who is obviously very much to the left of the political spectrum. Unfortunately, in that period the ALGA became a fraction political because of the influence of Peter Wood and his close association, first of all, with Mr David Simmons and, subsequently, with the current minister, Mr Howe.

I was emphasising the fact that prior to the last election, the Australian Labor Party had gone around in the mode of deceit that it was in at that time saying, `We're going to have a separate ministry for local government following the election.' Of course, following the election local government disappeared off the portfolio names and now has become a very small part of one of the mega-departments. So that is roughly where I had got to last night.

The bill we are debating is one that, generally speaking, local government supports, although it did have some specific objections to the bill as it was before then. Without my notes, which I have been unable to get, I will not be as specific in this matter as I had intended. But local government was very concerned at its lack of involvement. Promises that had been made to local government in the lead-up to this bill were simply ignored by the government. Perhaps in the committee stage when I have more details of that I will discuss that further. One of the definite promises made to local government on the determination of national principles was not taken up.

I am aware that Senator Tambling intended moving a number of amendments to overcome the problems that local government saw in these matters. As a result of the opposition's proposed amendments, I understand that the government has picked up most of them. So, fortuitously through the activities of Senator Tambling and others on our side and the points they have made, the government has agreed to rectify most of the problems.

I congratulate the ALGA and the various state organisations that represent local government on the activities they continue to perform each month of every year in support of their particular constituents who are ratepayers.

I want to make a couple of specific points. I will not keep the Senate long. The local government associations generally were very concerned about the procedures for establishing national principles to guide the allocation of grants amongst councils. Commitments had been made. They were not dealt with in the bill as it was originally drafted. Subsequently, the government has picked up Senator Tambling's amendments and moved them as its own. The associations were also concerned about section 16, which required annual reports to be presented to parliament, and section 3, which sets out the intended objects of the legislation.

I am also aware that Senator Tambling has gone through them in some detail. Local government was concerned that the national principles should be formulated in consultation with state ministers and the Australian Local Government Association and should take the form of disallowable instruments. Again, the bill as it was originally drafted was a typical Labor Party bill. The Labor Party makes these arrangements, consults and then ignores them completely. The commitments it made were ignored in the first draft of the bill. Fortunately, through Senator Tambling's amendments, the government has picked them up and is now moving the amendments itself.

The state associations of local government—WAMA in Western Australia, the Local Government Association of South Australia, the MAV in Victoria, the Tasmanian local government association, the Local Government Association of New South Wales and the Shires Association of New South Wales, the association in the Northern Territory and the Local Government Association of Queensland—are all very professional bodies that do tremendous work for the councils they represent and, ultimately, the ratepayers. It is a pleasure to be involved in this area of government activity and to work with people who are so professional in the way that they go about things, the research they do and the commitment they give.

My state of Queensland is a very decentralised state. Local government has a huge influence in all parts of Queensland. As I mentioned at the beginning of my speech, it is the sphere of government that is the closest to the people. In my state of Queensland, it is a very well-respected, well understood and very much needed part of the government system in the country. I fear the day when the Labor Party achieves its ultimate aim of getting rid of the states and local government as we now know it. Any number of senior Labor Party figures have said that they want to get rid of the states and local government and replace them.

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one in the Labor Party has said that, you buffoon.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Calvert

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I ask the minister to withdraw that remark.

INTERJECT.PARA: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—Withdraw that unparliamentary remark please, Senator Schacht.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw.

—I thank Senator Calvert, but it was not necessary. Nobody takes any notice of the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht). Having him call me names is like getting hit with a feather. I was absolutely shattered by someone of Senator Schacht's standing—
—Tell the truth for a change about the Labor Party.
—What do you want me to say? The Labor Party lied its way through the last election. Is that the truth you want me to tell?
—Order! Senator Macdonald, address the chair and continue with the debate.

—It is the long-term Labor Party aim to get rid of the states. Does Senator Schacht deny that? If it gets rid of the states, it gets rid of local government, because local government is a creature of state government. The government's long-term aim—it is showing in this regional development organisation—is to set up—
—You are opposed to regional development, are you?

—I am not opposed to regional development. I am the shadow minister for regional development. Therefore, I support regional development to the very greatest extent that I can. I do not like the Labor Party's centralist approach to regional development. The government went to Port Augusta and told regional development people there that they would get $160 million every year for the next four years. It tried to deliberately mislead them. Anyone who can read the budget knows that it is $150 million over the next four years. They are the government's thoughts on regional development. Labor Party members tell people what they can in order to try to make them believe whatever words come tumbling out of their mouth.

PARA.TAB: As I said in another debate yesterday, fortunately the people of Australia have woken up to this lot and, whatever they say now, they take absolutely no notice. They know that your Prime Minister—I do not like to call him the Prime Minister—the leader of the Labor Party, will simply say or do anything to try to stay in government. So there we are; the Labor Party approach is to have 45 regional governments around Australia replacing the states and local government as we now know them—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did you get the 45 from?

—That is the number of regional development organisations the minister is setting up. Senator Schacht would not be aware of that. Could I suggest to Senator Schacht that he helps himself by keeping quiet and by not making a bigger fool of himself than he has already in these debates. If Senator Schacht would read the Hansard, he would see where the department has said that it is its aim to set up 40 to 45 regional governments around Australia. The Labor Party's aim is to set up these regional development organisations—45 around Australia—
—That was Whitlam's idea.
—It was Whitlam's idea, that is right. It was Whitlam and the other fellow.
—It has always been Labor Party policy.

—Yes, Labor Party policy was to get rid of the states, get rid of local governments and set up these 45 regional governments around Australia. They will then be totally directed, totally dependent upon, totally funded by a centralised government in Australia. It is part of the Labor Party's centralist plan—part of the old socialist centralist thing. Even the old socialist countries are now giving all that sort of centralised control away but not this mob over here; that is what it is after. It wants to control every aspect of Australian life. It does not want the checks and balances that the states give. It does not like local government as it presently is, because it is that sphere of government closest to the people and that is part of its long-term aim. I support local government as it stands. I support the states. Local government does a tremendous job. It is pleasing to see that, with Senator Tambling's urging, at last the government has picked up the amendments we have proposed, which are simply putting into effect the agreements that the Labor Party had made with local government but had tried to get around. So on that basis, we will obviously be supporting the bill.

—It is a great pity that the government has waited to debate this Local Government (Financial Assistance) Bill 1995 until everyone is in a state of total exhaustion. It is very poor planning from a legislative and accountability perspective, although it might be clever if the objective is to sneak things through. I am certain that it will not get the debate it deserves.

PARA.TAB: The Greens (WA) have always had a strong interest in local government. We have indicated that we have concerns that federal grants should be distributed equitably, that needs arising from the specific situations of councils should be recognised, and that local governments should use the grants in ways that are accountable to each local community. This bill seeks to address several of these issues, and that is a good thing. The reporting requirements are a good thing, especially the ministerial report to parliament. However, it is strange that there is a requirement to report to federal parliament but not to report to the council of local government ministers or to local governments themselves. I am sure that it is the intention of parliament and the minister that they should get copies, and I thought we should say so. I have indicated this in an amendment.

As I have said, this bill will probably not get the debate it deserves and has probably not had the attention and scrutiny it deserves. I think this is because it is basically a measure to assure some distributive equity for local government grants. However, while I salute the purpose as far as I can determine it, I have a few reservations and I have raised them with the minister and the department. I think there are some problems with the method by which the objectives are sought. The new arrangement this bill introduces seems a bit top down to me.

At this point, I would like to mention that last night the duty minister, Senator Crowley, sniped at me on behalf of the advisers. The snipe was: `Why did you not tell us what your problems were?' I was really tired at that stage and I did not come back originally. I now clearly recall that in that meeting it was mentioned to us that there would be such things as benchmarking by the state and federal governments together on such things as waste management.

Perhaps the advisers remember that. We mentioned our horror in regard to areas like waste management, which are about as far away from the gambit of state and federal governments as it is possible to get. If there is anything that local governments have the expertise in, it is waste management. The suggestion was that state and federal governments get together on benchmarking for these kinds of areas. Perhaps the advisers who felt it necessary to get the minister to snipe at me—or perhaps she did it on her own volition—might remember those serious concerns and might get back in their advisers box.

The requirement to report is all upward, to the federal level. In some sense, this bill overrides state government. That, in itself, is not a problem where it is in the interest of local government. I have no illusions that state governments are responsive and decentralist bodies. They are not. They are often worse and more centralist than federal government, and I think this bill seeks to overcome state decisions that occur at the expense of equity between local areas.

That said, for the perspective of the Greens (WA), we would like to have a much more democratic process embodied here. We would like to see a lot more of the power explicitly put in the collective hands of local government. I am not naive enough to think that local government always acts in the best interests of the community or the environment, but I do think that, when it comes together collectively, it can come up with relatively fair and equitable criteria.

Another concern that I have is that, in clause 6, the principles governing allocation of grants is decided by the federal minister. He or she is supposed to consult the state ministers. There is nothing here about consulting local government or its representative bodies. This is a very top-down situation akin to the way the boundaries of regional economic development organisations in Western Australia were decided. This occurred in a meeting between federal and state ministers without reference to the community, local government or existing regional development organisations. This is regional based development—I bet!

For that reason, we have put forward another amendment to state that not only should the federal minister consult with local government but also the minister should actively seek the assistance of local government in formulating the national principles. Now, if it is about local government, I should darn well think so! National principles concerning local government should not be made by a cabal of ministers with ultimate autonomous power resting with the federal minister.

I note that the coalition has also recognised some of the problem, particularly the problem of parliament setting up autonomous instrumentalities to wield federal power over state and local government without needing to refer to federal parliament. Originally, the coalition had proposed an amendment to ensure that this would happen, that instruments affecting the federal policy should be tabled in parliament, that any revocation or variation of such instruments made by the minister should also come before parliament and that such instruments should be disallowable by parliament. I note this is no longer listed as a coalition amendment. The government has put it up. I hope this is a sign of government recognition of the problem.

The Greens (WA) have no difficulty with this amendment, as it is likely that only a measure that seemed contrary to the interests of local government would be disallowed. I may be wrong about the parliament on that, but I hope not. The Greens (WA) will support this amendment, but wonder that Senator Tambling had no similar worries about the competition policy bill, which creates even more centralised executive power. Under clause 7 of the competition principles agreement, the parties agreed to apply the agreement to local government. The opposition knocked back our amendment that would have assured some consideration by the competition minister, or competition commission of any state-federal or state-federal-local agreement relating to local government funding. In fact, the opposition supported government amendments to explicitly exclude any considerations of such amendments. So, we might look after local government in relation to the minister for regional development, but that minister is always more likely to be receptive to local government than the competition commission and its minister, and that commission and minister have been given the power to trample on this agreement and whatever the parliament does in relation to it.

That outlines our concerns. Basically, the bill is reasonable in its objectives, but it should have and could have embodied real participation and powers of determination with local governments themselves. It does not, and instead, we have one of those peculiar autonomous organisations, with quasi-legislative powers, which seeks to redefine the relationship of the three tiers of government. It is a far better organisation than some of the others—for instance, the competition commission—but it is still a top-down organisation.

We have therefore put up three amendments—and will support those of the government—which were put by the opposition in the House of Representatives. Our first amendment would ensure that the minister, in making principles to follow, would have to actively engage local government. The second would include environmental considerations in the reports. This recognises the crucial role and high degree of expertise that many local government agencies have on environmental issues and the crucial role they play in sustainability.

I will say here that local government handles waste, recycling, zoning and often sewerage and other such issues. Whilst some councils may do a poor job, collectively local government is often way out in front of other tiers of government on waste management, water management and other areas of natural resource management. It is the level of government that sees the problem and usually the one that has direct responsibility to act. Our third amendment addresses concerns of local government that it should also receive a copy of the report that is tabled in federal parliament.

Finally, before any minister or acting minister snipes at the Greens about our ability to produce amendments earlier, I would like to point out that all of the budget bills and all of the other bills in this parliament are being handled for the Greens by two senators with very small staff. So before the government starts sniping about our ability to get amendments to it quickly, it should work out first of all when its amendments come to us and what resources two senators are expected to apply in order to act exactly like government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure for me, as the spokesperson for the shadow minister for Commonwealth-state relations, to speak on the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Bill 1995. I endorse the remarks that my colleagues have made regarding local government. As we all would know, this bill replaces the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1986, under which existing financial assistance grants, known as FAGs, are made to local government. In 1995-96, FAGs to councils will total $1.165 billion, comprising $807.2 million in general purpose grants and $358.1 million in funding which, while nominally identified as local road funding, is untied.

PARA.TAB: The coalition has a longstanding record in relation to its support for local government. We believe that local government must be treated as the vital third tier of government which it is. My colleague Senator Ian Macdonald has already identified quite a number of my colleagues on this side that have had local government experience. I too had a fair amount of experience in local government before I came to this place. The commitment that the coalition has stands in stark contrast to the record of the Labor government.

The fact is that the federal general purpose grants for local government councils in 1995-96 will be three per cent less in real terms than when the Labor party come to office. When I was the warden of the then Clarence municipality, now known as Clarence City, we experienced at first hand the different funding ways the government used to fund councils. At the end of the day, in most cases, in real terms we used to get funding cuts. This was so right across Australia and the 1995-96 general purpose grants to the local councils will be three per cent less in real terms than when Labor came to office.

Whilst this in itself is bad enough, the hypocrisy of Labor senators who come into this place and pretend to champion local government is further demonstrated by the fact that this government, in the time in which it has reduced funding to local government in real terms by three per cent, has raised total tax revenues by a staggering 49 per cent. Although the government has foreshadowed that it intends maintaining a real terms per capita funding level commencing in 1997-98, such a move is long overdue and mirrors the position which the coalition has repeatedly taken ever since this Labor government assumed office.

Furthermore, anyone who has watched this government's neglect of local government cannot help being very concerned by the fact that the government is not prepared to enshrine such a commitment in the bill. Knowing this government as we all do, I have not the slightest doubt that, if it does not suit the Labor Party at the time, the Labor Party is quite capable of changing its mind. We have only to cast our minds back to the tax cuts promised before the last election, which were supposed to be enshrined in l-a-w law but ended up being one big l-i-e. No doubt, this aspect would be worthy of debate as an amendment if it were not for the fact that we will obviously have a coalition at the time, which will no doubt honour any commitments which it makes to local government.

I have received a number of representations on this bill from local government in Tasmania. One of the principal concerns which was put to me was that this bill did not require the federal government to consult with local councils before deciding the formula by which federal local road funds would be allocated between local councils. Understandably, councils were angry that the government had failed to give them input into the new distribution arrangements which could lead to major changes in the allocation of funds.

This position adopted by the government was also clearly at odds with the agreements which were reached at conferences of local government ministers in October 1994 and April 1995. What had been agreed was that any new national principles would be formulated in consultation with state ministers and with the ALGA. It took the coalition to remind the government of this previous undertaking. I am glad that the government eventually saw fit to adopt our amendments in the other place.

What remains a concern is that the government has until now refused to ensure that the funding distribution is subject to full accountability before the parliament. As a result, we were left with legislation where it was possible for the minister to vary the principles on a whim. The coalition has always maintained that this is not good enough and I am sure that local government considers that this is not good enough also. Although we now have an amendment which at long last is to be included by the government, I am sure that local government will remember that it had to bring the Labor government to this final position kicking and screaming.

It is essential during the debate on this bill that we also acknowledge that section 16(2)(c) goes far beyond what was agreed to in relation to reporting requirements. Once again we have the government breaking an undertaking which quite obviously local government believes was made to it previously by this government.

At this stage, I would like to quote from a letter which I received from Sue Smith who is the President of the Local Government Association of Tasmania. It is in a very similar vein to a letter that my colleague Senator Panizza quoted from the Local Government Association of Western Australia. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: State Ministers and ALGA took the view that reporting on the performance of Councils should be to the Local Government Ministers Conference, not Parliament. There has been no agreement as yet on the form which such reports should take, and the issue is to be subject of further investigation by officials and advice to Ministers next year.
The provisions of the bill are therefore at best premature.

Quite clearly, the government has broken a firm commitment to local government. I only hope that this is the last commitment that this government is able to break with local government before it is removed from office by the ratepayers of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Local government has also identified significant problems in relation to the objects clause as it relates to council efficiency. It is felt that—and I would certainly agree, if the purpose of these grants is to improve the capacity of councils to provide their services to ratepayers in a more equitable manner—decisions as to how these funds are to be spent must remain a matter for each individual council.

It is also a matter of further concern that, at the Local Government Ministers Conference in April this year, it was agreed that arrangements would be put in place to ensure that the states and territories, state local government associations and the Commonwealth would work together towards providing council services to Aboriginal communities. I remember Senator Tambling commenting on this yesterday.

Local government had an agreement with the government which it considered was both equitable and reasonable; however, the government either has a bad memory or it has simply chosen to throw an undertaking out the window. Let me again quote from the letter I had from the President of the Local Government Association of Tasmania. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of ATSIC communities, it was agreed that one of the national principles would refer to their particular needs. To go further and make the improvement of services a specific object of the Bill can only raise unsustainable expectations that such improvements will occur. This is a dangerous and potentially divisive course of action, especially given that the Bill does not and cannot provide any special funding for that purpose.
The letter continues:

Our underlying concern is that once this Act refers to one particular group with special needs, others will inevitably seek similar treatment. Local Government has broad social justice responsibilities and it is wrong to focus so strongly on just one section of the population, albeit arguably the most disadvantaged.

What the government has failed to appreciate is that the problems faced by our Aboriginal communities require a combined approach rather than an isolated approach. What I fear, and no doubt what concerns local government, is that what the Labor government is attempting to do is to embroil local government in attempting to resolve the failings of the federal government in providing adequate services for those who live in Aboriginal communities. Should this occur, we will have a situation in which local government is forced to assume far too great a responsibility for what is essentially a federal Labor government failing.

PARA.TAB: I know that local government associations from around the country wrote to the minister seeking amendments to address these concerns; but obviously, and not surprisingly, these representations fell on deaf ears. This is a government which likes to pretend that it has a genuine interest in local government but, looking at the facts and the manner in which its representations are ignored or only included reluctantly at the last minute, we can see that we have a government which only pays lip-service to the genuine concerns of local government.

No doubt the resignation of former Deputy Prime Minister Brian Howe will further downgrade the level of recognition afforded local government by the Labor Party. But there is light at the end of the tunnel, Mr Acting Deputy President. That light comes in the form of the forthcoming election, when I am sure the coalition will take over the Treasury benches and will give local government the fair go it has been looking for for quite some time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding, I want to make just a couple of brief comments. We do not accept the amendments of Senator Margetts. She made some reasonable points in philosophical terms about local government, but we do not accept the amendments. We believe our own amendment quite adequately covers the points that she was trying to deal with. Of course, we support the government's amendment. We believe it deals with the issues that both Senator Margetts and opposition senators have raised, and we are pleased to put it forward.

PARA.TAB: Senator Calvert in his speech laid great emphasis on the claim that in terms of the percentage of GDP we had reduced grants to local government, and he quoted $1.16 billion for the untied assistance grants. That was his calculation. He conveniently failed to mention that we have also provided $350 million to the local capital works program and $54 million over four years for the new local government development program. When those figures are put together, Senator Calvert's criticism does not stand up. The government has maintained good funding arrangements for local government.

I came into the chamber as Senator Ian Macdonald was in full cry. He was not speaking to the bill at all, Mr Acting Deputy President; it was more his clearing his chest about what he thought of the evils of the Labor Party generally. He made some extraordinary assertions, which I could not restrain myself from responding to. He claimed that the Labor Party is in favour of the abolition of state and local government, and he said there are numbers of Labor people who have said that. I would like him to list them; in particular, those who have said that about local government.

Only a couple of years ago I heard John Howard say that if we were redesigning the federation of Australia we would not have the structure we now have. Even John Howard, the ultimate conservative, says that if we were starting with what we know now, we would not have the present structure; so I think it ill behoves Senator Macdonald to rant and rave that this is some socialist, centralist plot.

This government has given a bigger boost to local government and local communities to bring them into the mainstream than any previous government. I am very proud of the fact that this is a continuation of the work of the Whitlam government, and of Tom Uren as Minister for Urban and Regional Development in that government. When the opposition has been in government it has done nothing for local government—absolutely nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, yes, they did. They gave them a guaranteed share of tax income, which is more than you have ever done.

—When we listen, as I did, to the remarks of Senator Macdonald and Senator Calvert, we see no vision for local government, no vision about the future of what role it can play for the local community. We just see negative, carping, political criticism. In view of Senator Macdonald's remarks that we want to abolish local government, I did not hear him make any remark about what Mr Kennett did in Victoria in the last two years where he abolished 218 councils, down to 70, where there was mayhem in the local community about the way he went about it.

PARA.TAB: But let me put on record, as an observer from another state, as a minister for small business who has visited, as part of my portfolio duties, many of the areas of Victoria where these local government changes have taken place, that, though I may disagree with the Kennett method of doing it, I fully support and congratulate the Kennett government on making local government a much stronger body to deliver services, to empower the local community to have adequate resources and budgets to do things in their local area. Now I know that it may come as a surprise to some opposite that I would congratulate the Kennett government, as I say, not on the process, but certainly on the outcome.

Victoria is going to be very advantaged by having this structure of local government where there are councils with a minimum of 70,000 to 100,000 in most areas, with budgets running into many tens of millions of dollars. The councils will make decisions for the economic development of their own areas and be involved in that. As a minister in the industry portfolio, I already had chief executives of local government in Victoria approaching direct the federal government to be involved in programs in their area to help economic development. That is a good example of where local government can empower the local community. Senator Macdonald made no comment about the Kennett reforms in Victoria, but he accuses us as the ones abolishing local government. It is the Victorian Liberal government that abolished some 150 local councils. So 150 local councils were abolished in Victoria under Kennett and not a word from Senator Macdonald—

TALK.START.PARA: —And Queensland.

—Senator Parer makes a comment about Queensland. Again I congratulate the Goss government on creating bigger councils, creating a super council by merging the Gold coast and Albert Shire, Mulgrave and Cairns, Toowoomba and Moreton, creating big councils—
—Whoops, Ipswich and Moreton.

—Ipswich and Moreton, sorry. That creates much larger councils, with large populations and with access to large budgets that they control to make the best use of those resources. The Greater Gold Coast Council now has a population of 300,000 people, 12 councillors and a budget of half a billion dollars. With the present growth rate of the population, that council with 12 councillors, Senator Calvert, may actually be bigger than Tasmania within 10 to 15 years.
—Not in area it's not.

—Not in area, but in population and in economic size. Now I have not heard any complaints, subsequent to the election of the new council up there, that the people of the Greater Gold Coast believe that they have less representation. I think that those changes by the Goss government are excellent, and they empower local communities by having a better and more efficient structure for local government. The government commends the bill, with the amendment, to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRANSPORT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995TRANSPORT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate on Transport Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 resumed from 8 March, and debate on Transport Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 resumed from 29 March, on motions by Senator Sherry and Senator Crowley:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Transport Legislation Amendment Bill and the Transport Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) would enact a series of amendments to a number of transport related acts. The first bill would amend ten acts, including the Australian Maritime Safety Authority Act, the Federal Airports Corporation Act and the Motor Vehicle Standards Act.

PARA.TAB: The Transport Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) would implement a number of important changes to the Air Navigation Act relating to aviation safety. The bill would insert a new part dealing with aviation safety issues into the act. The new part would be largely the same as part XVIA of the Air Navigation Regulations but would impose penalties that were more in line with the gravity of aviation security offences.

The most important sections of the two bills are those that would implement the government's undertaking to reform the liability and insurance arrangements that apply to air operators. I am talking about the air operators' liability for the passengers that they carry and the responsibility they bear for compensation in the event of death or injury to the passengers. The personal injury liability of air carriers is set out in the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act 1959. The act implements a series of international agreements that are known collectively as the Warsaw Convention.

The Warsaw Convention was signed in 1929, when aviation was very much in its infancy. The state-of-the-art aircraft in 1929 was the Lockheed Vega, an aircraft that carried only six passengers and a pilot. But it was still apparent that international air travel would increase dramatically. With this predicted increase in air travel loomed the possibility of increased airline crashes. There were concerns that if an aeroplane did crash, there would be no limit on liability and the large damages claims could wipe out the airline concerned.

Therefore, the Warsaw Convention was drafted to impose a degree of uniformity on international aviation law. The most important sections of the Warsaw Convention are those that regulate civil aviation carrier liability. Article 17 provides that a carrier is liable for damages with respect to passenger death or injury. Carriers are liable if the accident took place on board an aircraft or in the course of boarding, embarkation or disembarkation. Article 22 limits a carriers' liability to 125,000 Poincare gold francs for each passenger except where there is a different contract existing between the parties. The Poincare gold franc was a world currency standard that ceased to exist in the 1970s.

But there is a trade-off in the Warsaw Convention regarding aviation liability. The limit on a carriers' liability does not apply if the damage results from his or her wilful misconduct. This, and other articles, were changed by the Hague protocol of 1955. The 1955 Hague protocol amended the Warsaw Convention and entered into force on 1 August 1963. The protocol doubled the liability limit to 250,000 gold francs and tightened the conditions under which carriers could be held absolutely liable.

There was a further attempt to amend the liability limits in the Montreal protocols, which were debated in the 1970s. The Montreal protocols were deemed necessary due to the inflation of the 1970s and the demise of the gold standard. The Montreal protocols proposed to limit the carriers' liability to 100,000 special drawing rights. The Montreal protocols proposed to lift the international liability ceiling to $US75,000, but the protocols would have made that ceiling unbreakable. Accident victims could not recover more than the limit, even if the airline was guilty of wilful misconduct. Instead, passengers could fund their compensation by paying a surcharge on their airline tickets.

This unbreakable ceiling and the funding shift from airlines to passengers became the stumbling blocks to approval of the Montreal protocols. The Transport Legislation Amendment Bill would increase the liability of domestic carriers to a minimum of $500,000 per passenger. It would increase the liability of Australian international carriers to a minimum of 260,000 SDRs per passenger, and 260,000 SDRs is approximately $500,000.

But what about foreign international carriers serving Australia? Australia cannot impose its own liability regime on airlines that are based in countries that are signatories to the Warsaw Convention. I understand the government has asked them to increase their limits voluntarily, but it cannot require them to do so. However, the government can use some coercion and does have some weapons. One of them is the mandatory insurance requirement that would be enacted in the Transport Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) which I will discuss shortly.

The government's other weapon is the threat of notice requirements for foreign carriers which do not raise their liability limits. That would mean on flights to or from Australia such carriers could be made to notify passengers that the limits are lower. Essentially, the notification would state, `If we crash, your life is worth less than if you were flying Qantas or Ansett,' or any other airline that had agreed to the limit.

The Transport Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) would insert a new part into the Civil Aviation (Carriers Liability) Act which could require all carriers, including foreign carriers, to hold personal injury liability insurance of at least $500,000 for a domestic carrier, or 260,000 SDRs for any other carrier, such as an Australian international carrier or a foreign carrier. To be acceptable under the bill, an insurance contract would have to provide that the insurance company's liability was not affected by any breach of safety related requirements by the carrier or by its financial position.

I have had a few complaints from some small carriers who complained, firstly, that they were having difficulty getting coverage by the underwriters and, secondly, that they were concerned about the fact that the premiums would go up. On both occasions I have been satisfied by the responses I got. The first one was that when the liability increased last year to $500,000 premiums went up. Underwriters have advised me they do not expect the premiums to go up further because of the requirement that insurance covers would be paid irrespective of any breaches of safety. Carriers would be prohibited from carrying passengers unless they have suitable insurance cover. The penalty for a breach of the act would be up to two years imprisonment.

These proposed changes to the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act come about as a result of a tragic air accident that occurred outside Young on a dark night in June 1993. On 11 June 1993 a Monarch Piper Chieftain aeroplane slammed into a rocky hill near the Young aerodrome. All of the seven people aboard were killed, although one passenger, a little girl, survived with shocking injuries for another 10 hours. The investigation into the Monarch crash revealed the inadequacies of the arrangements regarding aviation liability and insurance. It became very obvious that our arrangements regarding carrier liability insurance were not good enough.

The amendments to the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act significantly increase the maximum payout that would be given to the victim of an air crash or to his or her family. Nonetheless, there is still a degree of inequity in the system. People who are involved in land accidents often receive huge compensation payouts. People who are made paraplegics as a result of accidents have received several million dollars in compensation. A recent example of such a case was when an Australian man who was a cancer victim was made a paraplegic because of a needle being incorrectly injected. That man received a record $6 million in compensation.

Some people argue that we should abandon the framework of the Warsaw Convention and move towards an unlimited liability regime and that such a system would be much fairer for the victims of air accidents. But the Warsaw Convention framework benefits the travelling public as well as the airlines. In the event of an air accident, the passengers or their families do not have to prove fault on the part of the carrier. That is the key part of the legislation. What is more, the multilateral system eliminates many jurisdictional difficulties. It also means that payments would be made in a much quicker way than under the existing system where legal cases can go on year after year.

We need to strike a balance between the need to adequately compensate the victims of air accidents and the need for Australia to remain firmly within the Warsaw Convention regime. The modifications to the carriers liability system have resulted in a substantial increase in insurance premiums paid by the carriers. The $180,000 liability limit that applied until last year was entirely unacceptable. It was an insult to the pain and terror experienced by people involved in air accidents, such as the seven people who died on that rocky hillside near Young on a dark night in June. The coalition supports the bills.
