DEBATE.TITLE: PUBLIC SERVICE (ABOLITION OF COMPULSORY RETIREMENT AGE) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 7 June, on motion by Senator Patterson:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I endorse the motives behind this legislation which was introduced in this place by Senator Patterson. I would expect this particular piece of legislation to be supported by the government because the government is able to see the sense of including in the Industrial Relations Act a measure to remove discrimination in employment on the grounds of age.

PARA.TAB: I had thought that the provisions of that act would be applied in the Australian Public Service, and in particular in the Commonwealth Electoral Office. I was disappointed, however, to find that refuge was sought by the Commonwealth in the Public Service Act, which it was claimed overrode any provisions of the Industrial Relations Act. This I found to be frustrating, but I find that what Senator Patterson is proposing today is anything but a frustration. It would be a relief to see these measures applied across all employment, because that would bring about the very intention of the amendment which the Democrats moved to the industrial relations legislation.

Our support for this legislation is thorough and we welcome the proposition. I would hope to see a speedy passage of this legislation, and I would hope to see a retreat from the government's position of trying to find reasons why it cannot implement its own industrial relations legislation in this area. For the sake also of those people who are able to make a valuable contribution to the nation regardless of their age, I would hope for a speedy passage of this legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Public Service (Abolition of Compulsory Retirement Age) Amendment Bill 1995 I will be brief, because I know Senator Patterson will want to make some closing remarks. The government does not oppose the removal of compulsory age retirement in the APS, but the government believes that any change needs to be sensitively managed, especially in the context of the potential additional cost of workers compensation if the retirement age is removed. The government does not, therefore, support the private member's bill.

PARA.TAB: In considering this issue, the government believes the following points need to be borne in mind. Although the Public Service Act retires APS staff at the age of 65, departmental secretaries do have the discretion to retain the services of staff beyond this age if this is in the interests of the service. The number of staff affected also needs to be kept in perspective. Less than two per cent of public servants continue to work past the age of 60 and, as at June 1994, only about 300 people out of 143,000 were still in the APS work force at the age of 64. Thus the evidence suggests that most public servants choose to retire before reaching maximum retirement age.

The potential cost impact of removing the retirement age could, however, be enormous, particularly in relation to workers compensation. If the compulsory retirement age is removed, it is possible that a long-term compensation claimant could be compensated not just until the age of 65 but forever. The cost of this could run into tens of millions of dollars. The government is, however, considering options for the design of workers compensation arrangements so that the compulsory retirement age issue can be addressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—This has to be one of the most disappointing days in this parliament. The government has had innumerable opportunities to lift the compulsory retirement age for public servants. A similar bill was brought into this house by me, and a similar bill was brought into the House of Representatives by Mr Connolly, during the last parliament, nearly three years ago. The same old tawdry, tired arguments were brought up then by the government, that it could not afford the workers compensation.

PARA.TAB: If the government had wanted to do it, it would have found a way. Where there is a will there is a way. There is no will on the part of this government to enable those people in the Public Service who are still capable, who are still able and who still wish to, to continue working beyond the age of 65.

Only the other day one of the attendants in this building said to me, `You have got 18 months, Senator, to get this bill through, because I want to keep working. I am fit, I am well and I would like to keep working.' He is one of that two per cent over 60 who wants to keep working. That is not so for everyone—of course not for everyone. It goes against the government's argument to say that only two per cent of people in the Public Service are over 60. In fact, it reduces the government's argument almost to nothing. Of course there are not hordes of people in the Public Service who want to stay on beyond 65, but there are some who wish to, who are capable and who should be able to.

Many of the states have found it possible to adjust their legislation to enable people in their Public Service departments to work beyond 65 and they cope with the compensation. The federal government is unable to address the compensation issue. It cannot organise itself at a federal level when, in fact, many of the states have been able to do it. This is a most disappointing response from the government. It has had three years to address the issue. It knew it was coming up; it came up with the same argument last time.

I appreciate the Democrats' support for this bill. We will introduce this bill over and over again. I hope the Australian public is aware that this government says that 65-year-old people have reached their use-by date; it chooses to put these people on the shelf as worthless. The government would rather have these people on the pension than working and contributing to Australia. This government is saying to those people who want to stay on, `Go on the pension or take out superannuation, if there is any.'

Some of these people, if they have been in the Public Service for a short while, may have to be on a part pension. The government is saying to them, `Go on the public purse; don't make a contribution; we don't need you; you have passed your use-by date.' The message from this government to every person over 65 is: you are useless; the government does not need you; you have nothing to contribute. That is the message that the government has given today not only to all public servants but also to all Australians. It is reflected in its attitude.

I asked the minister the other day: what is the government doing about counteracting ageism in the Australian society? She could not answer me; she had to get a brief. When she came back with the answer a week later, it was hopeless. There was nothing about what the government was doing to counteract ageism in advertising; there was nothing about counteracting ageism in the work force; there was nothing to counteract advertising in government literature; there was nothing to counteract ageism in children's literature. If it had been an issue about indigenous people or an issue about homosexuals, the government would have been making an effort.

People over 65 have passed their use-by date; they are not worth anything to this government. The treatment of pensioners and the treatment of unrealised capital gains on shares is another example of the government's attitude to older Australians. Time after time this government keeps demonstrating to us and to the Australian community its attitude to older Australians. It was demonstrated by its previous leader Mr Hawke, when he called a pensioner a `silly old bugger', and this attitude is demonstrated in the way the government deals with legislation. The government has opposed this private member's bill. It is a very sad day. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask: why did you claim in the Senate on Monday that General Mantiri's remarks of July 1992 that the Dili massacre was `quite proper' was a single response and that there is nothing to suggest that they represent a more substantial position than he has adopted, when he had, in fact, repeated those comments almost a full year later in May of 1993, when he again described the actions of the Indonesian military in East Timor as `quite proper'? Secondly, I repeat my question of yesterday. What action did you personally take to raise the insensitivity of the general's appointment as Indonesia's Australian ambassador before the formal decision to seek his approval was made? Thirdly, as you have now told the Indonesians that you expect the general to express regret for his comments upon his arrival, haven't you now placed Australia in a difficult position in the event that he declines to do so?

—Mr Downer, as quoted in one newspaper story this morning, seems to be believing that the government response is quite on target so far as this particular matter is concerned, for which, of course, I am pathetically grateful, given Mr Downer's inability hitherto to adopt a bipartisan position on anything in recent weeks. It is interesting to see that others in the opposition still seem to think there is some political mileage from making even more difficult in the national interest an issue which is already of some difficulty and sensitivity, as I have been at pains to point out.

PARA.TAB: When I referred on Monday, as I think it was, to the article in 1992, that was the information that was before me and that was my recollection, that there was only one substantial breach. Certainly, that was the only one that had been drawn to my attention in a way that produced the response that I have described, that is to say, to go back to Indonesia, as we did at the time, and to express our deep regret about the fact that the remarks were made.

The fact that they may have been made at some later stage does not alter the basic nub of the answer I gave. It was given inadvertently. To the extent that it may have been repeated, that is again unfortunate, but it does not alter the nub of what I was saying. And to the extent that there is any explanation in cultural terms of the kind that I gave, well, then, it is equally applicable to the second expression as it was to the first. As I also drew attention to later in the week, there was a second, a further, journal interview given by General Mantiri earlier this year in which he was at pains to acknowledge that there were some—I have not got the quote in front of me—bad elements within the Indonesian military and that that fact ought to be acknowledged.

So we have someone who, as I said, has a reputation for competence, who has a reputation for personability, who has a reputation for a strong knowledge of Australia, who has a reputation for being a reformer within the Indonesian system and who was clearly the choice of the Indonesian president. The choice of that particular person, from all points of view, would be an admirable one were it not for this very considerable blot on the record. That blot demands some attention; otherwise it will obviously be the case that there will be a considerable degree of ongoing discomfort and embarrassment for the Indonesian government in Australia. That is something that is much to be avoided, if it possibly can be.

As to my own role in all of this, I did have discussions in the latter part of last year about the impending appointment, during the course of which some markers were laid down. There were subsequent direct exchanges on the subject between officials here in Canberra and also in Jakarta.

I do not want to go any further into the details of those exchanges, but they were certainly sufficient to signal the Australian government's concern about the implications of this appointment, although, I repeat, General Mantiri is, apart from this, very highly respected.

The nomination was actually received in the department back on 24 April. That was when we were confronted with the situation that I have described—the difficult situation of deciding whether or not to knock the appointment back, given the background of a lot of unwillingness over the years for governments to do that. There is only one precedent anyone in my department can think of in the last 20 years or so—and I am getting this further checked as to the earlier history—and that was a very extreme case indeed of alleged criminal behaviour in an earlier incarnation. It is against that background that the decision is as I have described it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a delegation from the Senate of Colombia. On behalf of honourable senators, I welcome you and hope your stay will be both informative and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. The United States and Japan have announced that they have reached an agreement relating to automotive trade. In the past you have expressed concerns that any agreement should not disadvantage the Australian automotive industry, and specifically Australia's export of components to Japan. Can you, therefore, advise of the implications of the agreement for the Australian automotive industry?

—The Australian government welcomes the settlement of the automobile dispute. In principle, it seems to have been a satisfactory settlement, particularly as an alternative to the prospect of unilateral retaliation. The dispute covered three areas: replacement parts market, dealerships in Japan for new automobiles and original equipment parts. The Australian interest has always been mainly in the outcome in the area of original equipment parts, for which Australia is a very big supplier.

PARA.TAB: We should look at this outcome as more than merely the avoidance of a serious problem, which it is, but as the creation of a significant opportunity because the plans that we were advised the five Japanese automobile companies would release would propose the increased purchase of foreign parts for production of autos in Japan, to the value of about $6 billion. This creates a window of opportunity for the Australian automobile parts manufacturers. We already have a significant share of that market. We export a lot of automobile components to Japan.

We have consistently sought to ensure that the outcome of this matter was not discriminatory against third party interests, of course Australia's interests in particular; but not just for the proper and obvious priority that it defends the interests of our industry, but for the broader interest that it defends the multilateral trading rules which are very important to a free trading country like Australia. That was why we exercised our so-called third party rights. We participated in the World Trade Organisations consultations and made a small increment of contribution to the process and certainly put ourselves in a good position to defend Australia's interests as the further detail of this issue unravelled.

Because of our concern that any outcome might be discriminatory, we very much welcome the comment by Mr Hashimoto, made at the joint press conference with USTR Kantor, `I would like to assure you on this occasion that all the agreements between the two countries is applicable to all the trading partners we have on a MFN basis.' That is a very important statement by Minister Hashimoto. We have been told confidentially by both the United States and Japan that the deal will be MFN and the outcome does not and will not disadvantage Australia.

The government and the industry in Australia will be examining closely the fine print of the agreement to make sure there is nothing in the detail or in its implementation that might disadvantage Australia, because there is a downside and a potential benefit to Australia which we wish to make sure we do not miss out on. Australia has put itself in a strong legal position because of the initiatives we have taken. If anything should arise which causes us concern, we are very well placed to take the opportunity to pursue our interests in the World Trade Organisation.

The Australian industry has given us its initial assessment of the agreement. It is welcomed. Both the Chamber of Automotive Industries and the Federation of Automotive Products Manufacturers referred to the potential pluses and the need to keep a close watch on these matters. I am delighted to say the Federation of Automotive Products Manufacturers also correctly expressed its support for the prominent role Australia had played in it. Together with my colleague Senator Cook, who is going to Japan on a matter which particularly relates to this—and I will subsequently be doing the same in Washington—I will be keeping in close contact with the industry as the agreement unfolds.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, since Ms Isabelle Lidden-Vallin, your former French teacher, joined your staff as European adviser, what advice has she given on Australia's bilateral relationship with France or in relation to French territories in the Pacific? How long has Ms Lidden-Vallin been in Australia? Is she still a French citizen? Given your willingness to provide the Senate with a great volume of detail on your recent scholarly scribblings, would you please table in the Senate this week a detailed list of the activities undertaken by Ms Lidden-Vallin since she joined your staff?

—Mr President, I thought we had reached some depths yesterday with Senator Vanstone's sally into the area, but this is really beyond the pale. Ms Isabelle Lidden-Vallin is someone who was working last year and, indeed, for the year or two before, as a tutor in the Department of Foreign Affairs in the area of languages, which is the context in which I met her. She is extremely well academically qualified, with three degrees—two undergraduate, one postgraduate—from the Sorbonne and is presently doing a doctorate in Australia.
—What, in French diplomacy?

—No, as it turns out, in English language and literature and French history, as I understand the background. She is also qualified with the agregation, which is a particular qualification for tertiary teaching in France, and a qualification obtained by very few people. She has reviewed books on a number of occasions for the Canberra Times and is an extremely well qualified all-rounder.

PARA.TAB: Perfectly understandably, she was bored with her job as a French teacher, no doubt undernourished by some of her pupils—I readily concede that—and indicated an interest in a job in Parliament House. She had, in fact, applied on a couple of occasions around about that time to other ministerial offices for particular jobs. When a position came up on my staff which involved a combination of speech writing responsibilities, speech coordination and also, potentially, with some reshuffling, a combination of other areas in which she had expertise—namely, contemporary Europe, plus Central Asia, the Middle East, as well as Africa—

TALK.START.PARA: —So what qualification did she have for any of that?

—As much qualification as any adviser ever has in the system. Her qualifications were, of course, scrutinised by the interdepartmental merit panel—which considers all appointments at and above adviser level—in March 1995 and the appointment was approved in the normal way through that particular system.
—What, you don't have any say in who works for you?

—She was advising on bilateral French issues. The French nuclear issue was not within her particular area of responsibility because it went to disarmament. It is in the disarmament, arms control, United Nations area of my office, with a completely different adviser. When that issue came up, and because of the concern there might have been, I quarantined that source of advice and said, `I'm going to deal purely within the office with the adviser that deals on the UN-disarmament side.' It was in everybody's interest that that quarantine be maintained and it has been maintained strictly throughout.

PARA.TAB: Ms Lidden-Vallin is married to an Australian citizen. She is an Australian by choice. She has Australian citizenship, which she took out in 1993. She has been in Australia since, I think, 1991. All round, it is a pretty comprehensively disgusting piece of innuendo that I have had from the other side. You, Senator Ferguson, should join the ranks of the apologist, Senator Vanstone, who has been spectacularly silent on the subject, notwithstanding her little effort yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Can the minister inform the Senate of the expected impact on national savings of the superannuation measures announced in the budget? Could the minister also detail the expected impact of these measures on the current account?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Burns for his question. I know that he has had a long interest in superannuation. Senators are aware that this year's budget is aimed squarely at boosting the level of national savings in Australia. In the short term, national savings are boosted by a return of the budget to surplus, with surpluses not only this year but in the out years—next financial year and the financial year after that. Over the medium term, the government's latest superannuation initiative, Saving for our Future, will have a substantial impact on national savings as well as providing Australians with higher standards of living in their retirement.

PARA.TAB: Since 1983, the government and the ACTU have cooperated, in what is an historic partnership, to transform superannuation from a privileged form of tax advantage saving, mainly by the higher paid, to an almost universal entitlement for working men and women in this country. It is therefore fitting that the Saving for our Future program has been endorsed as part of Accord Mark VIII announced last week.

The measures announced in Saving for our Future are expected to add around one per cent of GDP to national savings by the middle of the next decade, rising to 1.7 per cent of GDP by the year 2020. Combined with the government's earlier award and superannuation guarantee initiatives, the new measures are expected to increase national savings by two per cent of GDP by the year 2000, growing to four per cent of GDP by 2020. In today's dollars, that is equivalent to an extra $9 billion of saving each year by 2000, growing to around $18 billion of additional savings by the year 2020.

Since the beginning of the 1980s, the current account deficit, which reflects the gap between national savings and investment, has averaged 4 1/2 per cent of GDP. The boost to national savings coming from the government's superannuation initiatives will therefore be instrumental in bridging the gap between national savings and investment. In turn, this will see a substantial reduction in the current account deficit over the medium to the long term.

I note that, in its most recent review of Australia, Moody's, the international credit rating organisation, endorsed the government's strategy of boosting national savings in order to reduce Australia's reliance on foreign capital without destructive cuts to investment. I would like to quote what Moody's said in extolling the strengths of our policy direction. It said:

ANSWER.PARA: The higher the level of savings, the more remains for investment. The higher the level of investment, the greater the potential for future economic growth. In Australia's case there is an added benefit. Since Australia has traditionally relied heavily on foreign savings to fund an important portion of its domestic investment, a higher level of national savings will help satisfy the demand for investment funds which otherwise would have to have come from foreign sources. Higher national savings translates into less foreign borrowings.

The superannuation initiative that we have supported for the length of our term in government, and which is encoded again in this budget, will produce major structural change in Australia's national savings performance. It will produce retirement incomes with dignity for working Australians, both men and women. It is part of the visionary agenda, opposed at every point by the opposition, that we have put together brick by brick to lift the retirement standards of living of Australians as well as to develop a major pool of national savings from which we can draw investment in developing Australian industry and Australian competitiveness in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, what would be the impact of freezing the superannuation guarantee charge and not proceeding with the measures announced in Saving for our Future?

—If that happened, the impact on national savings would be very significant—a reduction of around 2 1/4 per cent of GDP by the year 2003, which is $11 billion less in savings in today's dollars. The impact on the stock of superannuation savings would be particularly severe: by 2003, just eight years away, about $45 billion of superannuation savings would be lost.

PARA.TAB: Individuals earning average weekly earnings and working for a large employer would stand to lose 62 per cent of their superannuation entitlement—that is a loss of $288,000 to an individual in today's dollars. The loss of retirement benefits for a similar individual working for a small employer would be 69 per cent, or $318,500 in today's dollars. I am talking about the opposition's proposals on superannuation. If those proposals came into being, workers would be worse off, according to the employers they work for, by between 64 per cent and 69 per cent of their retirement incomes. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. What contracts do Australian uranium mining companies have with the French government-owned nuclear cycle company Cogema or with Saarberg Interuran or Urangesselschaft, both substantially owned by Cogema, or with EDF? What are the quantities involved, and when were the contracts entered into? At the time these contracts were entered into did they contravene ALP policy, and do they now contravene ALP policy? If not, why not? Finally, how much Australian uranium is enriched in Cogema's plant for both France and other countries, and is the same plant used for the enrichment of weapons-grade uranium?

—In relation to the first part of Senator Coulter's question, the precise details of the contracts are commercial-in-confidence between the company, of course, as the supplier and its customer. Senator Coulter may wish to take that matter up directly with the company. It is well known in the industry, and it has appeared in print just recently, that ERA is supplying quite a small amount of uranium—I think around 270 or 300 tonnes a year—and it is also well known, because these are long-term contracts, that the French are currently paying 50 to 60 per cent above the world spot price for that product.

PARA.TAB: The company is in fact ERA. WMC does not sell uranium to France. I understand, however, that ERA sells to EDF, which of course is the government-owned generating authority in France, the French producing about 70 per cent of their entire electricity supply by nuclear energy. To put that in context, from memory I think the total demand in the French system is for around 11,000 tonnes of this product per year. The contracts are with EDF, not Cogema or its affiliates.

As to the second part of the question, I wish to emphasise that exports of Australian uranium to France are actually restricted under current government policy because of the French nuclear testing, which seems to have been lost in the debate. No new contracts have been permitted since February 1988 and, under the current policy, none will be until France permanently ceases testing and becomes a party to the comprehensive test ban treaty. That is the reason the restrictions were introduced—because of the French tests.

The current contracts with France were negotiated in 1987. Because of this policy, Australian exports of uranium to France supply, as I have just indicated, something less than three per cent of France's uranium requirements for nuclear power generation.

In relation to the third part of the question, Australian uranium exports to France, as with all other markets, are subject to stringent and effective safeguard arrangements, including coverage by the International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards, to ensure the uranium is only used for peaceful purposes. Exports to France are governed by the provisions of the bilateral agreement concerning nuclear transfers between Australia and France which entered into force in September 1981. The Australian Safeguards Office administers an accounting system which follows the precise quantities of uranium from the time it is packed for export to the time it is stored as nuclear waste to ensure that there is no diversion from the civil nuclear power generation program.

I want to conclude by restating what this government has said again and again. The decision by the French government to resume testing is a bad decision. It is a bad decision because it completely ignores the views of the people of the South Pacific and because it sets back the cause of French participation in this region of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. There is just one part of the question the minister did not answer. Is it a fact that the Cogema plant, which is used to enrich uranium, is used also to enrich Australian uranium for other countries, so the amount of Australian uranium passing through that plant is much more than the three per cent? Secondly, is not this the same plant which is used to enrich uranium for weapons?

—I am sorry, I thought that was well known. I am sure Senator Coulter will acknowledge that it is well known. It is an old argument. It gets back to whether you accept this policy of equivalence or not. Senator Coulter clearly does not. He has said that over the years and he is entitled to say it in here. My understanding is that, in terms of the actual atoms coming from a particular place, it is all relevant to the total world supply of uranium.

PARA.TAB: This argument would be relevant if uranium was the rare metal that it was once thought to be. But it is not. Particularly since the break-up of the Soviet Union it is in abundant supply around the world. It is a fact that if we suspended uranium sales to France—and they are currently restricted because of the French testing program, and have been since the time I indicated—it would simply give the French government a let-off that it would otherwise not get and allow it to purchase this uranium for about 40 per cent of the price that it is currently paying for it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Defence Force: Contracts with French Companies

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. What is the value of contracts between the French company Thomson Sintra Pacific Pty Ltd and the ADF for the provision of sonars for the Collins class submarine and Anzac frigate projects, and what other large contracts is the minister aware of involving the ADF and French companies? Given that the government's response to French nuclear testing has involved only the freezing of defence contracts with French companies at existing levels, why did the government not undertake a comprehensive review of contracts involving French companies and consider the cancellation of existing contracts, which would have sent a much stronger message to the French government which has a financial interest in many of these companies? Why is the minister so keen to defend French defence industry interests in this regard?

—Senator Margetts's mention in her question of the freezing of defence contracts is a misreading of anything that I have put out. It was `contacts' not `contracts'. Nevertheless, I will move on to the substance of the question.

PARA.TAB: Senator Margetts asks about Thomson Sintra's contracts on sonar. They are not contracts with the Australian government. In the case of submarines, the company has a contract with Rockwells, which in turn has a contract with Australian Submarine Corporation. That is a commercial arrangement between those companies and not with the government. In the case of the frigates, it is a contract between Thomson Sintra and Transfield Defence Systems, and again that is not a direct contract with the government.

Senator Margetts asked why we do not cancel current defence contracts with French firms. There are a variety of reasons not to do so. The first reason is that we would thereby be found in any court, I think, in breach of contract and litigated against. It would therefore mean that we would be paying French firms money for work that they did not even do. I cannot really understand what sort of punishment that would be to France.

Secondly, Senator Margetts has used Thomson Sintra as a classic example. Thomson Sintra has set up an Australian subsidiary. As a result, the net effect of cancelling contracts would mean that Australians working for those companies in Australia would be put out of work. Again, that does not seem to be a direct punishment of France, but of Australians.

Thirdly, these firms are engaged under contract to supply equipment to larger projects. Cancelling the contracts in that regard would mean that those projects could not go ahead until replacement suppliers had been found. That would put Australian defence projects back by some months—in some cases years—and that again punishes Australia and not France.

Finally, by taking French firms out of these contracts we would allow other companies from other countries to make bids at extravagant prices because they have no competition. The two areas where we have reservations in regard to defence contracts of equipment nature with France are: firstly, any direct procurement deal with the French government is suspended for the entire duration of the tests; and secondly, where any French firm is a prime, it has to be referred to me on a case by case basis. The reason for that is that it is not always easy to establish who is the prime. Let us take the example of the Eurocopter, which is a French-German-Italian helicopter. Who is the prime in that case? I would have to investigate that and make a decision.

The last part of Senator Margetts's question asked why I was so keen to defend these contracts. I have shown no keenness at all to defend them. That is in Senator Margetts's mind and imagination. What my department has done in terms of the cabinet submission and the announcement made last Friday morning is more than every other department put together. We have totally changed our defence relationship with France. We have banned ship visits, we have banned plane visits, we have banned bilateral exercises, and we have banned senior officers' visits. We have not recalled our defence attache for consultation; we have recalled him full stop.

On a whole range of areas we have taken effective bilateral action against our defence relationship with France, and we have done it in such a way as to target those measures so that it is France, if possible, that bears the burden of it, not our Pacific island neighbours and not our own defence forces. The only exception we have made on plane visits is medivac and search and rescue, which I do not think anyone in this chamber would dispute we should stay involved in. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to check a point that the minister made. The minister mentioned that there are private companies involved that are not necessarily directly involved with the French government. In reality, in Australia we have been moving towards private and semi-private arms procurement and defence procurement. Does that mean that any statement that Australia makes in relation to government policy for our defence procurement does not apply if private companies are involved? Where do you then put Australian Defence Industries? Do we say, `That is a government business enterprise and not government' or is it government when it is sold off? What control, therefore, will government have over defence procurement policies that may impact on Australia once you have reached this level of privatisation in defence procurement?

—It would take me an hour to untangle the logic of that question, but I will assume what it means, rather than what Senator Margetts said. I reiterate the three basic things in our approach to defence procurement with France. Firstly, no procurement directly with the French government will occur while these tests are on. Secondly, where a French company is the prime that has the overall responsibility for the contract, that will be on a case by case basis with myself. Where it is involved in systems or minor equipment or part of another project, there is no prohibition.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The minister would be aware of today's official release of the report of the so-called Wran committee, which was commissioned by the federal government to examine ways in which the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory governments might foster the development of Darwin and its immediate region as Australia's northern link to east Asia. Given the importance of primary industry to the region, can the minister advise the Senate as to any recommendations which have flowed from the committee's report?
—Build the train line, Bob.

—I thank Senator Schacht for his interjection. In fact, the report, as Neville Wran pointed out today, is the first report for 100 years to make a positive recommendation about the construction of the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link.

PARA.TAB: The report of the committee on Darwin was officially released today by its chairman, Neville Wran, and it does recognise the vital importance of both mining and agriculture to the ongoing development of Darwin and the Darwin region. The report is a realistic blueprint for the future development of Darwin, in particular, and the Northern Territory in general. The report recognises that it is in the national interest that Darwin's potential to become an important regional city in east Asia is recognised.

In terms of a positive endorsement for my city of Darwin, of which I am very proud, the report actually finds that Darwin is the best positioned city in Australia to forge closer links with the east ASEAN region. The committee considers that new opportunities for Darwin and the territory are strongest in the service industries—these include education and training, research and health—whilst at the same time it places emphasis on the continuing industries of mining, tourism and agriculture.

I was particularly pleased to see the committee recommend a movement beyond the export of live cattle to the production of good quality beef for the expanding middle class markets of east Asia and continued development of the horticultural industry. In all, the committee has made in the report 77 recommendations. They are designed to bring about significant, yet realistic, change and many of them complement existing Commonwealth government policies to populate, develop and defend the north of Australia.

I must make the obvious comparison: this report stands in stark contrast to the utterly delinquent approach that the coalition adopted for the development of northern Australia, which I thought was very well summed up by the front page of the Townsville Bulletin last week, which was headlined—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Townsville Bulletin!

—Don't laugh, Senator Hill; don't sneer at Townsville—that is where your colleague Senator Macdonald, the shadow minister for regional development, lives. The front page of the Townsville Bulletin, right in his backyard, headlined his policies as `Liberal vision exposed as mirage'. It referred to the alternative to the proposal for northern Australia commissioned by this government. The bottom line of the coalition's policies is the idea that you can feed them anything in the bush and they will believe you. Promise them the Alice Springs to Darwin railway; promise them a new dam; promise to turn the rivers inland—I love that one; promise to rejuvenate the Murray-Darling Basin Commission, but do not actually do any of it. They are Senator Macdonald's personal notes. I will leave Territorians and others in northern Australia to compare the two documents and see which one has the most credibility. In conclusion, this report—
—Are you going to table it?

—Yes. This report is to the Treasurer who is represented in this chamber by my colleague Senator Cook. Because of my obvious interest in this issue, Senator Cook has graciously allowed me to table the report; and I do so now.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the minister to requests for amendment made by the Senate last night to the government's sales tax bills. As he would be aware, the Senate has rejected the government's attempts to tax the family home and has indicated that these bills will never pass the Senate while they include taxes on nails, screws, plaster, timber, taps and so on. Can the minister inform the Senate what steps the government is taking to ensure that there is no uncertainty for business with respect to collection of this tax? Will the Australian Taxation Office be issuing a statement on this matter to clarify the legal position of wholesalers as of this Saturday?

—The first thing that has to be said is that the opposition has run around this building saying, at any number of doorstops, that expenditure should be cut but, at the same time, trying to increase expenditure in this budget. We have cut it; you are wanting to increase it. We are saying that revenue needs to be increased to get into surplus; you are trying to chop that out. You are trying to unmake this budget.

PARA.TAB: In this area of legislation you succeeded last night in taking some revenue items from the government. This means the surplus we have in this budget will now be reduced and the downward pressure this budget puts on interest rates for Australian home owners—and this is where my answer is directly relevant to the question—will be removed to some extent. This means that if interest rates do not fall, or if interest rates rise, it is the damage you have done to our budget settings that has brought that about. You in the opposition and those who have conspired with you will have to take the rap for that. If interest rates rise one per cent, the housing affordability rate will go up and the cost to house owners will increase—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order as to relevance. Senator Gibson asked whether the minister can inform the Senate what steps the government is taking to ensure there is no uncertainty for business in respect of collection; and will the Australian tax office be issuing a statement? The minister's answer has no relevance, so far, to what Senator Gibson asked.
—Mr President, I am relating it to what Senator Gibson asked. Given a few more minutes, I will do so.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Let me continue relating my answer to what Senator Gibson asked, before I come to the detail of what he asked. If interest rates rise one per cent in Australia, you will be imposing over $9,000—

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The question had absolutely nothing to do with interest rates. This government wants to peddle lies about the Senate putting interest rates up, when the Australian people know that this is the government of the highest interest rates in Australia's history. The question was: what is the tax office going to do about the shambles of this government's budget? What advice is it going to give taxpayers? It had nothing to do with interest rates. Mr President, I direct you to ask the minister to respond to the question, not peddle more government lies about interest rates.

—You are not directing me to do anything. The point is—and I have made it clear many times—that I am not in a position to direct ministers how they answer questions, provided they are generally relevant within the area, and that is so.

—Just to prove that, Mr President, I have a quote from David Murray on the AM program. David Murray, for the information of honourable senators, is the Chief Executive Officer of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. What did he say?

—Mr President, I take the same point of order. The minister is answering a question he might have wished he had received, but the one he received concerned the administrative consequences that flowed from the Senate's decision last night and what action the government is taking to clarify those matters. It is a very simple question. Perhaps it is a little hard to answer, but at least he ought to make an effort to answer the question as asked, not the question that he is inventing.

—Mr President, speaking to the point of order: Senator Cook is perfectly in order to point out the implications of the question. If the questioner did not understand his question, it is not Senator Cook's fault. He is pointing out the clear and obvious implications of the outrageous decision the opposition made last night, which it is trying to deny. It is not his fault that he has to point out the implications to the senator who was silly enough to ask the question.
—I made a ruling just a few seconds ago, and I am not about to change it now.

—I am just making the point, because it has been raised by honourable senators in here several times, about the government being wrong in terms of the impact of fiddling with the government's bottom line on the budget.

PARA.TAB: I have what the Chief Executive Officer of the Commonwealth Bank said—and I will not read the whole quote, because I want to come to your answer directly, Senator Gibson. He clearly says that the Senate is out of order and that the budget bottom line is important. That is a strong signal to the market about downward pressure on interest rates. If you fiddle with that, you do risk passing up an interest rate reduction or, in fact, you risk lifting interest rates. Every Australian should know that, if that happens, that has been brought about courtesy of Mr John Howard and Mr Peter Costello.

The question I am asked was about the way in which the tax office will go about advising people on the basis of what the schedule will be here. Of course, Senator Gibson would know that the Senate has knocked back a measure from the House of Representatives. That measure has gone back on request from the Senate to the House of Representatives.

I can say on behalf of this government, as I said in the debate, that we are still fighting for the integrity of this budget. We are not going to give up that fight. That is a resolute battle by us. This legislation will come back here, and the Senate will have a chance to do the right thing. The opposition will have a chance to remove the opprobrium that now besets it because of its budget fiddling and because of the threat to home loan interest rates.

The answer to your question, Senator Gibson, is: you will have a chance to rectify the situation. Meanwhile, on the broad schedule, the tax office has had quite extensive consultations with people in this industry to construct a schedule which is understandable and workable, and it has done that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. Minister, last Thursday in answering my question relating to the reduction in funding for the emergency relief program, you indicated that the government was funding a study by ACOSS to determine `who the people are that are using emergency relief'. I ask: is the minister aware of a 1992 government funded study conducted by the Salvation Army into emergency relief, part of which detailed the people who are using emergency relief? Is the minister aware that this study showed that less than 50 per cent of people requesting emergency relief were unemployed? Why does the government need to fund another study when such data is already available? If the government still believes a study is necessary, will the government restore funding to its previous level for the period of the ACOSS study, given evidence from many of the agencies who distribute emergency relief that the demand for assistance has not dropped?

—I am unaware of that study. I have not had any advice that can confirm Senator Woodley's information. I am certainly seeking that and I will be following it up as soon as possible. I have no reason to doubt what Senator Woodley is saying; I just cannot confirm it.

PARA.TAB: It is also true that it is important we get national data across a number of agencies—in fact, across as many agencies as we can—that are providing assistance and emergency relief for people. It does not change, as much as I can tell, the terms of reference that we have set for this piece of research. In particular, we want to be sure, for example, not just who is getting emergency relief but whether those people come back again and again and what might be the reasons that are encouraging people to go through the emergency relief route into support rather than through the system of social security payments, let alone any state assistance that they might get.

The point that Senator Woodley raises is essentially a matter of continuing concern about the people in our community who make use of emergency relief. The evidence from the people who provide that relief is that there is still a considerable level of concern in the community. Certainly, that is a matter of concern for me. But as the formula for that funding, as I said last time, is based in part on the number of unemployed people and those numbers have fallen dramatically, so has our allocation for emergency relief.

I think it is still very important that we assist people through emergency relief to get into our mainstream assistance, to get to where family payments, support on behalf of children, ongoing income support and back-up are provided for them in an ongoing way, so that fewer and fewer families need to depend on emergency relief. I will note your point, Senator. I am certainly pursuing it and you can be assured of my concern about this matter. But until we have the data from that further study, I am not minded to change the formula.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would it be helpful to the minister if I brought a copy of the Salvation Army study to her?
—In answer to your supplementary question, yes.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. As the government has agreed to fund the legal costs of Dr Carmen Lawrence to challenge the validity of the Western Australian royal commission into the Penny Easton tragedy—an event which took place prior to Dr Lawrence's election to federal parliament—will your government now fund the legal and settlement costs, if any, of the member for Kalgoorlie, Graeme Campbell, who is currently defending a libel case brought against him by the Director of Public Prosecutions in the course of his duties as a serving member of parliament?
—I am not aware of that case. I will need to take the question on notice.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the minister to the continuing tension between Vietnam, China and the Philippines over claims to the Spratly Islands. Is the minister aware of recent incidents which have increased tension in the area? These incidents include naval confrontation between China and the Philippines, the arrest of Chinese fishermen and the blowing up of Chinese markers on reefs claimed by the Philippines. As the Spratly Islands are spread across major international shipping lanes in the region, what diplomatic measures has the government taken to try and achieve a peaceful resolution of this dispute?

—As is well known, the South China Sea is potentially one of the most volatile areas in the whole Asia-Pacific region. Obviously, the Australian government and I have been concerned at the increase in tension in the area since the discovery earlier this year of Chinese structures on Mischief Reef, which is also claimed by the Philippines.

PARA.TAB: In February this year, in response to the Mischief Reef incident, I clearly and publicly expressed Australia's concern at any action in the South China Sea that increased tension between claimant states. I emphasised the need for discussion of the general South China Sea issue in multilateral forums such as the new ASEAN Regional Forum, the ARF, which we established last year. In various bilateral discussions at that time, Australia encouraged ASEAN members to adopt a common position in response to the Mischief Reef issue, which they did in the form of a joint statement on 18 March.

More recently, following the annual Australia-US ministerial, or Ausmin, talks in Washington in April, I specifically expressed Australia's concern about recent Chinese activities in the area and encouraged the US to make clear its strong interest in the South China Sea.

I note that following that, Secretary of State Christopher, announced at our joint press conference after that meeting that he had urged China's foreign minister in the strongest terms against any additional construction and that the dispute should not be resolved by force. The US also issued a formal written statement on 10 May emphasising its abiding interest in the peace and stability of the area, especially in relation to freedom of navigation.Australia has also made direct representations in Beijing. Generally, Australia supports the kind of approach set out in ASEAN's 1992 declaration and 1995 statement on the South China Sea, both of which urge the peaceful resolution of competing claims.

To make progress towards a long-term solution in the Spratlys it is very important that all claimants commit themselves to a serious, multilateral, diplomatic negotiating exercise rather than seek to resolve claims through the threat or use of force or military might in any way. It is crucial that they agree to explore cooperative solutions to what is manifestly a multilateral dispute. As a starting point, Australia has been urging mutual recognition of the existence of competing sovereignty claims.

In the case of the Mischief Reef dispute, it is too early, I think, in the development of the ASEAN Regional Forum as an institution for it to operate itself as a dispute resolution body by way of direct intervention. But the second meeting of that forum in August in Brunei will certainly be the occasion for the issue to be discussed as an example at least of the kind of situation we should collectively be able to defuse better in the future.

A substantive but non-confrontational discussion on the South China Sea did occur at the ARF senior officials meeting in Brunei on 22-24 May with Australia's active support. It is important that claimants continue their discussions on areas of practical cooperation in the South China Sea through the Indonesian sponsored workshops which have been running on this subject now as a preventative diplomacy exercise for the last five years or so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer the minister to his decision, as reflected in the budget forward estimates for 1996-97, which see funding to sports and recreation slashed by $34.3 million, a more than 30 per cent cut. Do you agree that this decision has already caused angst and uncertainty amongst sporting organisation and athletes? Will you reverse this decision or will you guarantee that the estimates will stand as printed in the budget?

—I do not agree with any of the assertions that Senator Campbell makes. The government's sports policy and its programs work on a four-year cycle, which is also linked to the Olympic cycle. We are now entering the fourth year of the maintain the momentum program which, of course, will lead Australian sport up until the Atlanta Olympics.

PARA.TAB: Australian sport does recognise that our approach to four-year cycles has been one of the most significant advances in sports management that has ever taken place in this country. It has allowed Australian sport to plan with a far greater degree of certainty than has ever been the case before. It allows Australian sport to commit itself to longer term strategies and to longer term programs.

I have already commenced a process of consultation with sports on our new sports policy to replace the maintain the momentum program. Indeed, I recently met with representatives of the Confederation of Australian Sport to obtain views on their priorities for the four-year program. I also recently addressed the annual general meeting of the Australian Olympic Committee. I had the opportunity to hear their views on the structure of our programs and our policies in the lead-up to the next four-year program.

I have met with the presidents and the executive directors of many of our national sporting organisations in Australia, either on a one-to-one basis in my office or through a series of round tables that have been held in capital cities. In recent weeks I have held round tables in both Sydney and Melbourne.

The board of the Australian Sports Commission, under the chairmanship of Mike Fitzpatrick, has also initiated internal reviews of many of our major programs to ensure that they remain effective and well-targeted. These reviews will build on the highly complimentary report of Coopers and Lybrand, which I commissioned last year to undertake a full evaluation of the Australian Sports Commission.

In all the meetings I have had with sports officials, I have assured them of the government's ongoing commitment to sport. It is well accepted that that commitment is not in question. There is no doubt that the issue of our next four-year program will be addressed in the context of next year's budget.

It is fair to say that it is accepted right around this nation that the commitment this government has to sport is greater than anything ever seen before by a federal government in this country. We can see a record level of funding to Australian sport and a record level of support from national sporting organisations for what this government is able to achieve. Senator Campbell could do little more than try to copy what we have been achieving, in the unlikely event that—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The only thing that is a record of this government in sport in this budget is that there has been a more than 30 per cent decrease in the forward estimates for 1996-97. Senator Faulkner may have spoken to lots of sporting organisations in the last few months, as I have. The reason I ask this question is that, when they open the budget at page 133, they see a $34.3 million drop. They want some certainty. They want to ensure that they can plan for the future. When they open the budget, they cannot see the $34 million. They want a commitment. The government has to make a commitment to either spend that money or stand by its estimates. I ask the minister to adjust the forward estimates. Either his promise is bodgie or the budget is bodgie. Tell us which one it is.
—I will continue my commitment to consult with the national sporting organisations and other groups that have an interest in the future of Australian sport.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question had nothing to do with whether the minister will give a commitment to talk to people. The question was whether he will adjust the budget forward estimates if he has not written off that money. It is a very simple question. Mr President, you can rule on relevance. No-one is asking you to direct him on how to answer the question. You are simply being asked to decide on the question of relevance. You heard him start his answer by saying something else entirely unrelated to the question.
—There is no point of order.

—Senator Campbell should know that Australian sports policy and programs work on a four-year cycle. If he does not know that, he might have learned something in this question time. We will be a lot more impressed with Senator Campbell in the unlikely event that, some time over the next few months, he produces a sports policy on behalf of the opposition. All we have is the opposition's record. When this government came into office, the Liberal Party had committed less than $15 million to sport in this country. It is now over $140 million. We have a great record. The opposition has no policies, and everyone in the Australian sports community knows it.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. As I understand it, the government's new parenting allowance, which provides a significant benefit to low income families, comes into operation next week. Can the minister advise the Senate on progress in implementing that new parenting allowance.

—I thank Senator Neal for her question. This, as many senators know, is a year of 50th anniversaries. One of the anniversaries that may have been overlooked—and I am pleased to announce it publicly today—is the 50th anniversary of the Unemployment and Sickness Benefits Act 1944, the 50th anniversary of the Commonwealth unemployment benefits that came into effect in July 1945.

PARA.TAB: We will be marking this anniversary in the most practical way possible, by making the most sweeping changes in the social security system for 50 years. Chief among those changes is the new parenting allowance. That is, over 100,000 low income families will gain up to $211 per fortnight additional income, with an average gain of about $117 per fortnight. The first payments will be made on Thursday, 6 July.

The income test on allowances, particularly jobsearch and newstart allowances, will be reformed to remove poverty traps. As a result, all unemployed people will now always gain financially from accepting additional work, either part time or full time. These initiatives have been warmly welcomed by the welfare sector. They are not the only changes that come into effect, though, next week. The bank deeming rate will be increased to five per cent to ensure that all pensioners have a reasonable return on their bank account deposits. The indexation of pension income and assets test thresholds will also occur. Unlike the opposition, the government is committed to indexation of the pension system.

We have also, in those 50 years, seen a move away from those notions of women as dependent and payments only coming to them because of their state of dependency, to significant changes in the social security legislation as a result of which women will move more and more to entitlements in their own right.

The implementation of these measures is well under way. People who are affected have been advised by a number of mail-outs from the department. A majority of those expected to gain from the parenting allowance over the full year in fact will do so from the first pay of 6 July. The computer changes are in place. The administrative terms, which is the most critical part of the whole process, are in place and ready to come into effect.

The department has everything ready for these changes as of 1 July. I believe it is very important to recognise just how significant this raft of social security reforms is and what an excellent 50th anniversary it is with the introduction of that legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, you mentioned in your answer that the pension income and assets test threshold would be indexed. What is the new level and how will it benefit pensioners?

—That is also very important for people to know and very good news. The income test free area for all pensioners will rise from $90 to $94 per fortnight for a single pensioner and from $78 to $82 per fortnight for each member of a pensioner couple.

PARA.TAB: Senators should also remember that the tax rebate ensures that pensioners whose incomes are within this free area also pay no income tax. As a result, part-rate pensions, which now also include pensioner concession cards, will now be paid on income up to the equivalent of $19,671 per annum for a single pensioner and $32,822 for a pensioner couple. These are the sorts of changes that this government has introduced.

There are other figures which we can provide, but, most importantly, this legislation gives commitment to indexation of all pensions and benefits—a commitment not shared by the opposition. When the first budget of the present Leader of the Opposition was introduced when he was Treasurer, he denied pensioners indexation. He denied them the equivalent of one whole week's pension.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 June Senator Harradine asked me a question without notice concerning productivity gains by government GBEs being, as EPAC says, passed on to the government and, presumably, not to consumers. I took part of that question on notice at the time.

PARA.TAB: The Treasurer, whom I was representing in answering this question, has now provided me with additional information. It occupies almost 1 1/2 pages. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Cook—On 22 June 1995 (Hansard page 1.1)
Senator Harradine asked Senator Cook a question without notice concerning:

PARA.TAB: Could the Minister in his response also attend to the other question that the productivity gains have been, as EPAC says, passed on to government and presumably not to consumers?
The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

Senator Harradine's question without notice asks about productivity gains by public utilities and the extent to which these gains have been passed on to governments in the form of increased dividends. In this regard he refers to a statement attributed to EPAC.
It appears that the EPAC statement to which Senator Harradine refers was a media release of 26 July 1994 captioned `Microeconomic Reform Paying off for Government Business Enterprises'.

The EPAC release reported on substantial productivity increases in the government business enterprises sector, far exceeding those estimated for the private sector. As mentioned by Senator Harradine, the EPAC material notes that many of the benefits of increased productivity have been passed on to governments and taxpayers in the form of increased dividends and also comments that the level of competition faced by a GBE has a significant impact on the respective degrees to which customers and owners of the enterprise benefit from macroeconomic reform.

In regard to the latter point, one of the main features of the national competition policy reforms is to enhance the competitive environment within which GBEs operate. More competition should lead to further improvements in productivity and efficiency but with a greater likelihood of benefits being passed on to consumers in terms of lower prices and improved products.

The higher dividends being paid by certain GBEs should, however, be considered against the very poor returns many have delivered to their shareholder governments. In the past, the costs to governments of the funds employed in GBEs have frequently exceeded the returns earned from those investments. With the reforms to GBEs in recent years at both Commonwealth and State levels, profitability has increased and dividends to governments have been improved. These developments are appropriate; taxpayers are entitled to a reasonable return on the capital employed in GBES.
Except when there are identified community service obligations it is to the community's benefit to discourage GBEs from making investments which do not produce a commercial return.

It is also worth noting that increased dividends from GBEs can reduce the pressure on governments to increase taxes or levels of government debt. In an environment of budget deficits, any given level of government expenditure must be financed by a combination of taxes, borrowings and other receipts (including GBE dividends). In that sense, it is not correct to suggest that the public at large does not benefit from increased GBE dividends.

Notwithstanding the preceding points the question focuses on the important issue of whether there is an appropriate balance in the distribution of productivity gains from enhanced GBE performance as between employees, consumers and owner governments. In this respect the EPAC estimates indicate that governments have not been the only beneficiaries of microeconomic reforms. Moreover the EPAC estimates are only one of a number of sources of data dealing with this issue. It is clear that consumers as well as governments have substantially benefited from macroeconomic reforms.

The process of commercialising and corporatising GBEs has involved replacing many of the day-to-day controls on GBEs with new planning and accountability mechanisms, including requirements to pay all Government taxes and charges. These GBE reforms have led to a considerable improvement in GBE efficiency. Since 1989-90, GBE total factor productivity has, according to EPAC, increased by over 6 per cent per annum.

Consistent with the objective of placing GBEs on a more commercial footing, the Commonwealth has instituted a dividend payout policy which requires GBEs to pay out dividends at a rate similar to levels in the private sector. This, combined with higher productivity, has resulted in dividend payments to the Commonwealth from public trading enterprises increasing over recent years from $69m in 1988-89 to an estimated $949m in 1994-95.

This increase in productivity has also allowed a significant reduction in the prices of services offered. For example, according to the Steering Committee on National Performance Monitoring (NPM) of Government Trading Enterprises, since 1989-90 the real price of sending a standard letter through Australia Post has remained constant. Furthermore, Austel figures show that in 1993-94 the price of Telstra's international calls fell by 8.7 per cent, prices of Telstra's domestic long distance calls fell by 5.5 per cent and those of Telstra's mobile calls fell by 7.1 per cent. Telstra price increases have been subject to a CPI minus X regime since 1992 with X equal to 5.5 per cent. As a result, reform of GBEs has enabled both lower real prices and increased dividends.

The most recent publication by the NPM Steering Committee also concludes that both governments and consumers have benefited from corporatisation and increased competition—prices for the 59 largest Commonwealth and State Government Trading Enterprises fell by an average 3 per cent in real terms between 1989-90 and 1993-94. In addition, the publication concludes that service quality levels have improved in the electricity, water and sewerage, urban transport and railways industries.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to the answer I gave yesterday to that rather squalid little question from Senator Vanstone, there are some further matters I would like to add for the public record. First of all, I have contacted Professor Andrew Mack, who is presently at the University of Western Australia, to confirm my recollections of the sequence of events relating to the article as I described them in the Senate yesterday. I can now advise the Senate that he did confirm the account I gave in all relevant respects, adding the further point that he, in fact, disagreed with a number of the positions I had taken in that article. To that extent, he would have been a little embarrassed if he had been attributed a significant role in its preparation. He also, I might add, shared my disgust at the position taken on this matter by the opposition.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, for clarification, there does seem to have been some doubt by some of the people who have sought information on this subject as to the status of this Grawemeyer award and the moneys receivable under it. The Grawemeyer award for improving ideas on world order, given annually by the University of Louisville, is worth $US150,000, payable in five annual instalments of $US30,000 each. I can assure the Senate that I will not be spending any of that money for personal enjoyment. The money will be paid into a government trust account and spent on a number of projects, scholarships, prizes and the like—options for which I am still consulting on and about which I have yet to decide; the intention being that it be in the area of UN reform, peace and security issues of one kind or another. If the opposition has any constructive suggestions rather than just vulgar abuse—again, while we are on the subject—I would be willing to receive them.

The question arose yesterday, as it has on and off over the years, about my authorship not only of the article which was the subject of the question yesterday but also of the book Cooperating for Peace—the blue book, so called, which was also, as well as the article for Foreign Policy, the basis for the Grawemeyer award and the book Australia's Foreign Relations which I co-authored with Bruce Grant, the first edition of which was in 1991, the second edition of which appeared earlier this year.

In particular, imputations continue to be made that my authorship role in both cases was really quite limited and not such as to justify my name appearing on the cover. To put this canard to rest once and for all, may I take this opportunity to table, as I did yesterday, my hand written manuscript, the first draft that I wrote of the article for Foreign Policy, just as I tabled my own draft of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not table the first draft he gave you.

—You can see exactly from that, Senator Vanstone, what was the contribution in the typewritten stuff that came from the draft. Just as I did with the article yesterday, I propose now to table the equivalent material for each of the other major publications in which I have been involved. For each of these books my role was to conceive of the idea for the book; to plan it in meticulous detail, to the extent that specific research was required that went beyond that research which had previously been done in the preparation of speeches and so on; to commission that research from various people in my department and outside it—all of which is acknowledged in the prefaces. In each one of these cases I did an enormous amount of original writing as well as relying on that particular research and, in some cases, the drafting of others.

PARA.TAB: I think the best way to demonstrate the extent of my personal contribution will be to table these, which I now do. The first is Cooperating for Peace, the manuscript which I prepared in the first instance.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does this prove?

—You can go through it and see what proportion of this represents cut and paste material from other sources, draft speeches and so on that have been prepared—other books that have been written. You can see for yourself how much basically is in own my hand writing. Firstly, I table the manuscript which I prepared for the book Cooperating for Peace in 1991. Secondly, I table the similar manuscript for the 19-chapters—

—Mr President, I thought the minister was indicating that he was not undertaking a personal explanation but a further answer to Senator Vanstone's question. If that is what the minister is doing, he has to be relevant to the question that was asked. He was asked about one article and one book, not this whole library with alleged contributions made by the minister. It is clearly irrelevant. Mr President, with respect, if you allow him to keep on like this, he could table the essays he wrote in grade six as some sort of proof. This is absolutely irrelevant to the question Senator Vanstone asked.
—Order! It is highly relevant, in my opinion, and the minister has the right to table documents at any time he likes.

—I understand the opposition's embarrassment about this matter and let them wallow in it. The second bundle of material I seek to table is the manuscript from which was done the first complete typescript of the 19-chapter book, Australia's Foreign Relations, which was written with Bruce Grant in 1991.
—Mr President, is it proper, under standing orders, for a member of this Senate, let alone a minister, to use the forms of this parliament to promote his book?

—Mr President, on the point of order: I have nothing but respect for Senator Harradine but there are very few things that could be worse than the accusation made against Senator Evans yesterday. It is obviously a matter of great seriousness to the minister. He has clearly done a lot of work to get this material here and it is understandable that he would be so upset. Senator Harradine, on reflection, would see that his remark—a facetious remark, a comic remark, a joking remark; we understand all that—was not an apt remark to make in this context. Senator Harradine made a very clever, very smart and, in normal circumstances very understandable remark, but not in this context.
—Order! That is exactly why I ruled in the way I did before.

—Mr President, I am indebted to you and to Senator Cooney. For the third time, I table the manuscript for the first edition of this book written in 1991. It involves a lot of typescript, which was prepared by my co-author, Bruce Grant, together with an enormous amount of handwritten intervention, recutting, repasting, additions and variations from me. You can cheerfully and to your hearts' content sort out who wrote what but you will see that there is a very substantial personal contribution there from me.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I table the relevant manuscript material from the second edition of this particular book, which was prepared during the course of last year. Again, if you are at all fair-minded, you will see an enormously substantial contribution in writing from me.

I would have appreciated it if some of the scribes who are presently absent but who decided to write about this particular exchange yesterday could have done me the courtesy of having regard to the manuscript that I tabled yesterday. If they had done so, I think they would have been a little more fair-minded in acknowledging the reality of the point I was making rather than giving any currency or space at all to Senator Vanstone. That concludes that answer.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

PARA.TAB: Question No. 2096 was also forwarded to the minister yesterday, as was question No. 2134. Senator Woodley gave me the courtesy of raising this with me yesterday in terms of chasing it up. I gave an undertaking that I would ensure that action was taken to expedite the delivery. What appears to have happened is just that.
