SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer, and I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: I did put three questions on notice, and I thank the minister for his efforts in trying to get answers. They were directed to Senator Collins because he represents the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton), and two of these were submitted over two months ago.

PARA.TAB: One question deals with issues relating to aircraft used in the construction of the Kuranda skyrail in Far North Queensland and the other deals with matters relating to the Brisbane airport. My question in this area concerns the possibility of extension of the cross runway at Brisbane airport to accommodate larger aircraft as well as the possibility of a curfew at the airport.

Perhaps it is appropriate that the Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, has been very slow in providing responses to my questions. Those residents of Brisbane who have been affected by the major increases in aircraft noise ever since the new Brisbane airport opened in 1988 have also been asking questions of the transport department. They are also waiting for answers.

Prior to the opening of the new airport, most of the aircraft movement was over Moreton Bay. Since 1988 most air traffic has travelled over suburban areas of Brisbane. This is contrary to the government's indications at the time the airport opened. This planning blunder has never been acknowledged and is therefore continually compounded as air traffic increases. The amount of air traffic into Brisbane airport is likely to increase significantly as we move towards the end of the decade. The impact of aircraft noise on the residents of Brisbane will only worsen unless real steps are taken very soon to address this.

The Democrats believe it is time the government listened to the community instead of fobbing them off and hoping that they will either give up or go away. Of course they cannot go away and, as in Sydney, many people have moved to escape the noise and its impact on their quality of life. The government's woeful record with the Sydney airport and its noise problems is shaping up to be repeated in Brisbane. In Sydney, we have seen deception, indecision and inadequate piecemeal planning which has been driven by short-term commercial factors. These take the place of a coherent, long-term policy which considers the interests of the local people. The people of Brisbane do not want to relive that experience. The option of constructing a cross runway has been repeatedly put forward as the solution to aircraft noise. Indeed, the Labor member for Moreton, Mr Gibson, called for this as long ago as 1991. He repeated that call in 1993. Like the pleas of the residents of the area, his pleas have fallen on deaf ears. If the transport minister's tardy response to my questions is any guide it seems he is no more interested in assisting the members of this parliament than he is the average person in suburban Australia. However, having said all that, I eagerly await his answers.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On a matter of privilege, I shall now read a statement by the President:

INTERJECT.PARA: By letter dated 28 June 1995, Senator Chapman has raised with me a matter of privilege pursuant to standing order 81.

I am required to determine whether a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee should have precedence, and in making that determination I am required to have regard to criteria laid down by the Senate. In previous rulings my predecessor and I have indicated the manner in which we apply those criteria.
Senator Chapman indicates that there has been an unauthorised disclosure of documents and private deliberations of the Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive Waste, of which he is the chair.

His evidence for the unauthorised disclosure is a press release by the Minister for Justice the contents of which, Senator Chapman states, could only have come from documents and private deliberations of the committee. Senator Chapman indicates that this unauthorised disclosure has been damaging to the committee's work.

Senator Chapman indicates that he is not raising the conduct of the Minister for Justice, who, as a member of the House of Representatives, may not properly be subject to any inquiry by the Senate, but is raising the unauthorised disclosure of the committee's document and deliberations which must have preceded the minister's press release. This case is therefore different from one raised by Senator Vanstone in September 1994, in which it was clear that it was a member of the House of Representatives who, as a member of a joint committee, was accused of making unauthorised disclosures. In that case I declined to give precedence to a motion because any inquiry by the Privileges Committee would be an inquiry into the conduct of that member of the House. In relation to the matter raised by Senator Chapman, it is clear that the Privileges Committee may inquire into the unauthorised disclosure without investigating the conduct of the minister.

As I indicated in the 1994 determination, unauthorised disclosure of committee proceedings are declared by the Privilege Resolutions of the Senate to be contempts, and as such are taken very seriously. Supported allegations of unauthorised disclosures meet the criteria which I am required to consider, and therefore a motion to refer such a matter to the Privileges Committee should be given precedence.
I therefore determine that a motion may have precedence to refer to the Privileges Committee the matter raised by Senator Chapman.
I table the letter from Senator Chapman and the accompanying documents.

Whether there was an unauthorised disclosure of the documents or private deliberations of the Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive Waste, and, if so, whether any contempt was committed by that unauthorised disclosure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Gibson this day, relating to the administrative effects of requests for amendments passed by the Senate on 28 June 1995 to sales tax legislation concerning proposed taxation on building materials.

SPEECH.PARA: I asked Senator Cook a question today about the administrative effects of the sales tax requests concerning building materials that were passed by the Senate last night. Those matters have now moved back to the other place. There have been a lot of concerns in the public arena, particularly on the part of wholesalers and retailers of hardware, about what is going to happen on Saturday. Through the media the government has indicated that it is going to give in on this particular tax. That is why I asked the question.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook took the opportunity to try to blame the opposition for alleged increases in interest rates. What absolute humbug! This is a big-taxing, big-spending government. I remind the Senate and the community that since this government has been in power it has increased total tax revenue from $100 billion in its first budget to a projected $124 billion next year. That is a huge increase in tax revenue taken from the Australian people. It is money that the people will no longer have in their pockets to spend.

The private sector and most state and territory governments have reduced expenditure over the last few years, particularly since the recession. What has this government done? It has kept spending taxpayers' funds. I remind the Senate and the community that in the budget next year and in its forward projections for the following year the following tax increases will take place: fuel tax, $5 billion; personal income tax, $5 billion; sales tax, $5.2 billion; company tax, $1.9 billion; Medicare levy, $450 million; fringe benefits tax, $930 million; tobacco excise, $950 million; light fuel oil excise, $300 million; company registration fees, $140 million; bank license fees, $380 million; migration application fees, $40 million; and departure tax, $130 million.

This is a big-taxing, big-spending government and the poor Australian community is worse off for it. To suggest that the sales tax on building materials, which was scheduled to reap $250 million next financial year, would have a significant impact on the finances of the government and on the budget deficit is absolute nonsense. It is $215 million in a $124 billion take from the community. It is absolutely irrelevant. As Senator Short said the other day, the Qantas float looks like coming in about $500 million short of what the government was originally expecting. Instead of increasing taxes on the people the government should cut its expenditure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to quickly discuss this furphy that the government, including Senator Cook, Mr Beazley, Mr Willis, the Treasurer, and the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, are trying to get through to the Australian people that the Senate, by a vote last night, will somehow—to use Senator Cook's cute and quaint words—reduce the downwards pressure on interest rates imposed by this budget by opposing a new 12 per cent hidden Keating consumption tax on nails and screws and building products generally. It is an absolute furphy, as Terry McGrann says in today's edition of the Herald-Sun, which states:

PARA.TAB: Finally, and most absurdly is the, again near-hysterical, claims by Mr Keating, Mr Willis, new-boy deputy PM Kim Beazley and assorted others, that the Senate's action will cause interest rates to go up or at least prevent them falling.
Now that is hypocrisy on a major scale.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on to explain why. It is because this government already has an $8.5 billion deficit built into its own budget, hidden by asset sales and other fiddles. Terry McGrann points straight to the problem, as our shadow Treasurer Peter Costello describes it, as the current account deficit. Mr Costello says that the $215 million or thereabouts that the building tax is supposed to bring in is like a little tiny bucket of sand in this whole economic equation and the current account deficit is like a great big massive roller rolling against the beach. Today Senator Cook is saying, `Watch out, there's the opposition and the Democrats running away with a little bucket of sand.' Behind Senator Cook is this massive great tidal wave called the current account deficit. We will see just how big that wave is tomorrow and what damage that will do to the beach of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The point I wanted to make—and I will be as quick as I can—relates to this government's repeated deceit and Senator Cook's repeated deceit in this chamber about this government's history and performance on interest rates. Senator Gibson asked him a question a couple of weeks ago and Senator Cook had the audacity to say that the Labor Party's record on interest rates was better than that of the former Liberal government. Senator Cook and the Australian people should know—because I will repeat it until I go hoarse—that under the former Liberal government real interest rates were half what they have been during the term of this government. Real prime lending rates, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, were 4.08 per cent, on average, during the term of the Fraser coalition government. Under the Hawke and Keating governments, where Mr Keating has had control of the economic levers for the last 12 years, average prime real interest rates—that is, the real rate, not the nominal rate or what you see in the papers, but what the people really pay—have been 8.81 per cent.

Since I mentioned those figures last week—Senator Cook refused to admit it—I pulled out some figures on real interest rates for Australia in comparison with other OECD nations going right back to 1976. It is interesting to note that my assumption was correct. This government is the highest interest rate government in Australia's history. It has maintained on Australian people, small businesses and home buyers the highest interest rates for the most sustained period in the history of this great nation. In 1976 Australia ranked seventh in terms of real prime lending rates in the OECD, around about average. In 1981 we were about tenth—about average—in real prime lending rates. In 1986, when the Keating policies started to take a bite, we jumped up to third in the international rankings, and in 1991 we were first. We had the highest real interest rates in the world. In June 1995, guess where we are? We are number one again. We have the highest real prime lending rates in the OECD.

This minister and this government would have us believe that because the Democrats and the coalition block a building tax, we might have something to do about interest rates. These guys are the experts on interest rates. They know how to make interest rates high and they know how to keep them high. When they want to blame someone for interest rates, they look at the bloke sitting at the head of the cabinet table and his economic ministers—Mr Keating, Mr Willis and Mr Beazley. They are Mr Interest Rates, Mr Interest Rates and Mr Interest Rates—the people of big interest rates in this country's history.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter this day, relating to the trade in, and processing of uranium.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to put on the record the close links Cogema and a number of other companies—including Energy Resources of Australia in the Northern Territory, which is mining Australian uranium—have with several other uranium deposits in Australia. There are also links with other countries in relation to the enrichment of Australian uranium.

PARA.TAB: Before I do that I want to point out that Minister Collins, in his reply, again ran two furphies. One was that Australia sells France only about three per cent of its requirements—he mentioned a figure of 11,000 tonnes. Australia sells something like 500 tonnes of uranium a year to France. But he ignored the other important consideration; that is, the amount of Australian uranium that goes through that enrichment plant in France and then goes on to other countries. A great deal more Australian uranium actually goes to France and through that plant.

The other furphy that Minister Collins mentioned was that I was talking about swapping an atom of uranium that might go into a bomb with an atom of uranium that might be used for civil purposes. The fact is we showed that waste uranium, which was still labelled as such, was swapped for highly enriched uranium. There was a very significant diversion of Australian uranium into weapons. We showed that as long ago as 1988.

It was not just an equivalent amount of uranium; it was uranium that could not be used for another purpose. It had its labels swapped and, as a result, the French were able to acquire highly enriched uranium which was then used for military purposes. This is something which could not have happened had the Australian uranium not been there and had there not been the possibility of flag swapping, as we called it, or label swapping, which I called it yesterday.

Turning to ERA and the Cogema connection, Cogema is wholly owned by the French Commissariat de L'Energie Atomique which, through its military applications section, is also responsible for weapons tests. Cogema, in turn, owns the world's largest reprocessing plant at La-Hague. It is through the reprocessing that the plutonium is extracted. That plutonium can either go back into nuclear power stations, particularly breeder reactors, or it can be used—and this is its principal use at the moment—in weapons.

Its subsidiaries Comurhex and Eurodiff convert and enrich uranium. Cogema has major interests in uranium mining, with shares in mining operations in France, Gabon, Niger, Canada, the US and Australia. In Australia, Cogema owns the Koongarra uranium deposit and the Ben Lomond deposit. These, perhaps, are significant reasons why the Australian government is not prepared to move on the matter of exporting uranium to France. Cogema also has a share, as I said earlier, in ERA, both directly and via its subsidiaries Urangesselschaft and Saarberg Interuran, which I mentioned in my question. These companies operate in Germany. It is through these connections that a great deal more Australian uranium finishes up going to France than the three per cent to which the government was referring.

The representative of the B class shares on the ERA board is Mr Yves Coupin, who is deputy director of Cogema's uranium division and President of Cogema Australia. So there are very close links between the French company, entirely owned by the French government; the enrichment of uranium which goes into nuclear weapons; the reprocessing of uranium which goes into weapons; and Australian uranium going through those plants and into other countries. Those links need to be put fairly and squarely on the public record. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) this day, relating to the appointment of Lieutenant General Herman Mantiri as Indonesian Ambassador to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that the question of East Timor is perhaps the greatest problem Australia has in its relations with Indonesia. I believe it was the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade which came to that conclusion when in 1993 it handed down its report on Indonesia.

PARA.TAB: What we have here is a person who has stated that the Dili massacre was `quite proper'. He said that in July 1992. In May 1993, the same person again stated that the actions of the Indonesian military were `quite proper'. Bearing in mind the population of East Timorese in Australia, Australia's commitment to human rights and the democratic free society that we enjoy in this country, those comments are entirely out of order. When any person is to come to this country as an ambassador of another country, I believe it is most important that we scrutinise their background and attitude to such things as human rights and human freedom.

It is with this in mind that the parliamentarians for East Timor are writing to Senator Evans to remind him of this, stressing that, whilst that body strongly endorses the direction of Australian foreign policy in developing a close and friendly relationship with Indonesia, it still has to stress as strongly as possible that the appointment by Indonesia of such a man as ambassador to Australia is entirely inappropriate and that any withdrawal of those comments by General Mantiri, or any disavowal by him of his previous stance, is just not appropriate.

Senator Evans mentioned a precedent involving criminal conduct when Australia, I believe, had refused the credentials of a person who had been appointed as ambassador to this country. I believe this instance is of a similar magnitude, because in this case this person has expressed, in quite strong terms, a denial of the massacre that took place, a denial of the human rights problem which exists on our border. In fact, East Timor is somewhat in the region of 400 kilometres from our northern borders.

I believe it behoves Australia to scrutinise human rights in the region and to make a stand, but I do not say that it should do that at the cost of its foreign policy or its national interest. I believe strong ties can be maintained with Indonesia, whilst maintaining a strong stance on the human rights question in East Timor.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about their respect for our sensitivity on the matter?

—I think that is a very good interjection. I believe if the boot were on the other foot the situation might be somewhat different. What would happen if we proposed sending a known East Timor activist to Indonesia as our ambassador? The Indonesians, I believe, would take strong diplomatic action. I am not saying it in the sense that we should be hostile to Indonesia. To the contrary, we should use our strong relationship, our strong bond of friendship, with that country to at the same time stress in the strongest possible terms that this is just not on and that any continuation of human rights violations in East Timor is not on either.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Foreman this day, relating to the future development of Darwin.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to refer to the dorothy dix answer by Senator Collins. This was an important committee and report. It was chaired by Neville Wran, the former ALP President and Premier of New South Wales. It is a pity that many of Mr Wran's party political bias points have now become so blatantly obvious through this report.

PARA.TAB: I am disappointed that the minister, Senator Collins, who is also the senator for the Northern Territory, chose to table this report at the end of his answer; therefore, he did an unprecedented tabling in the parliament. By tabling a document in that manner during question time he avoided the process of a normal ministerial statement and scrutiny that would apply in the Senate. It also frustrates the government presenting, at a later date, an appropriate formal response to all the recommendations in the report—in this case, some 77 recommendations.

This is an important report and I am very disappointed by it. I have had the opportunity to peruse the 18 consultancies that were undertaken as part of the $4 million budget. The detail in those 18 consultancies is remarkable. Sadly, it is not reflected in the quality and content of the report that was mentioned here today by Senator Collins, and which was tabled by him. The key to the whole issue is to look at one of the appendices in which two members of the four-person committee put down their own particular comments. One of the commissioners of inquiry, Mr Geoff Stewart, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I consider that a more visionary, bold and imaginative approach towards the development of north Australia's vast trade and investment potential with East Asia is warranted.

What a damning report. Here is one of Australia's leading commercial figures who is a member of this important inquiry and who, in effect, has to be relegated to the back, to a minority report, in order to present such a view.

PARA.TAB: I have perused the 77 recommendations made by the report and I am thoroughly disappointed. There is a $20 million suggested appropriation to look at the issues over a four-year span. But when you go through them, they are all minute tokenism points of administrative detail. There is nothing in it that looks at the resources for economic investment in Australia. There is nothing that looks at the substantive area of funding each sphere of government and how it should be carried out. There is nothing in the report of a substantive nature that talks about infrastructure and maximising the efficient and equitable government service delivery that is so necessary.

The issue of constitutional development of the Northern Territory and the process to statehood is not addressed. There is scant regard to the opportunities for mining and exploration. There is a lot of waffle about social issues. There is a lot of discussion about town planning initiatives and turning Darwin into a green city or whatever. We find a recommendation that we should promote Darwin as an attractive place to live and work. What hypocrisy! It is already a very attractive place in which to live and work.

This report cost $10,000 per page. What we have got is something that falls far short of our expectations. The committee falls into its own trap. Chapter 2 of the report analyses all the reports on north Australian development since 1913; it sets them all out and explains why they have failed. What does it do? It then turns around and fails to deliver any innovative strategies or policies necessary to develop the Top End's links with East Asia. Instead, all it presents is a very feeble and politically safe document.

Yes, 77 recommendations may sound fine when you cite them in number terms, as Senator Collins drew out in a few points. But it really is not a report from which we can take any inspiration. It certainly does not live up to the challenge that the then Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, set down when he commissioned this report. He said that he wanted it to develop strategies and policies to be developed by the two governments—the Northern Territory and the Commonwealth—to take full advantage of Darwin's proximity to East Asia. It has not done that. The report fails to live up to those expectations. In the space of two years, it is very obvious that the federal government has gone cold on the whole concept of what this committee was set up to achieve. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

It concerned the government's decision to fund a challenge by Dr Carmen Lawrence, the former Premier of Western Australia, to the validity of the Western Australian royal commission into the Penny Easton tragedy—an event which took place, as I said, well before Carmen Lawrence came into federal parliament and well before she became a minister in the federal government. Whether the decision to fund that challenge has been correctly made will be the subject of another debate that Senator Vanstone will address later this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: I asked whether the member for Kalgoorlie in the other place, Graeme Campbell, would receive the same treatment defending a libel case brought against him—

TALK.START.PARA: —We would have to fund Senator Baume as well.
—If I have time, I might even come to that.
—Where do you stand on it, Senator?
—If you would listen—
—Not you, the other one. He might agree with me.

—If you listen, I will come to that. I asked whether Mr Campbell's costs would be borne by the government and whether the government would meet the settlement costs if the director of public prosecutions in Western Australia was successful. Let me explain that the DPP is pursuing the matter on a personal basis and not in the role of the DPP of WA.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the other one.
—So I presume he was not aware of the fact about Mr Campbell.
—It might surprise you that they are not close friends.

—Yes, okay. I presume I will get an answer later this afternoon. But it is still a valid question because the decision has been made to fund the legal action of Carmen Lawrence, as a plaintiff too, to challenge the validity of the Western Australian royal commission rather than to defend herself over there. In the other case you have a longstanding member of parliament who, in the course of his duties, has found himself defending a libel case. I will not enter a debate on who is right and who is wrong; the courts will decide that in due course. I am only interested in knowing whether the government will fund his case.

PARA.TAB: I am also interested to know, Senator Ray, how others will be treated. Others in this parliament are the subject of libel cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume and Senator Carr—that's two. Although one is suing the other one, aren't they?
—I do not know about that. If they have said or done something in the course of their duty as a member of parliament, and if Dr Lawrence is going to be funded, then their cases should be looked at.

PARA.TAB: Basically, that is all I wanted to say. I hope that I get an answer to my question before we leave parliament, say, tomorrow.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Panizza has raised a matter of principle, although not a direct correlation between the two. There are two things here. It has been traditional over years for the Commonwealth government to fund Commonwealth ministers in the course of their duties if some action is taken against them. Traditionally, they are supported legally if they are sued for defamation on what they have said in representing the government—but not necessarily for a settlement, as I understand it. I can drag up a lot of Liberal examples in history of that.

PARA.TAB: This case, the first case that Senator Panizza referred to, is a little different from that. But it is no doubt going to be debated for a full hour later this afternoon, so I will not traverse it. The third question that he raised is one that has never been properly considered by government before; that is, what protection is there for parliamentarians when, in doing what they regard as their public duty, they are sued for defamation? They are in a different position to people sworn into the executive council. But it raises the question of whether they have a right to protection by this parliament. That should be considered.

From what I understand—I hope that he does not mind my saying it—Senator Baume is being sued for defamation. Senator Carr is being sued for defamation from someone on the opposition side. According to Senator Panizza, Mr Campbell may be in the same position. The difficulty in drawing the line on this is that one does not want to make people foolhardy; that is, they think they have the Commonwealth budget behind them so they can go out and slag anyone. It is a point of principle that I do not think a government has ever addressed in this country. It may well be worth the government looking at this issue.

In order to foreshorten events, I will write to the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch), drawing attention to the issue that Senator Panizza has raised, and ask him to have his department look at it. Senator Vanstone can then get a return to order on it and we can get the document into the Senate, or we could hand it over.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would give up that legal advice, would you?

—I think Senator Vanstone would agree that we would need some legal advice, because it has not happened in the past. That is the way that we will handle that issue. I do not know whether Senator Panizza will get an answer today. It depends on what the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) is up to elsewhere.
