DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR HUMAN SERVICES AND HEALTH

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter we are considering today is a serious matter. It raises a very wide range of questions, but the bottom line question is this: why is this government agreeing to fund Dr Lawrence's legal costs in trying to scuttle the Western Australian royal commission?

PARA.TAB: This is not a debate about whether Dr Lawrence deserves legal funding before the commission. That is a matter for the Western Australian government to deal with. I understand the Western Australian government has written to Dr Lawrence and asked her to put an application in for what sort of legal assistance she might require before the commission. I want to make it clear at the outset that that is not what this debate is all about. This debate is about this government's decision to fund Dr Lawrence's private legal action being instituted in Western Australia, in effect, to scuttle the Western Australian royal commission, to scuttle the decision of another government.

Some would be so unkind as to say that the reason she wants to do this is to avoid appearing before the commission. Others would say that this is merely a delaying tactic to try to ensure that her appearance before the commission does not occur prior to an impending federal election. I do not want to go into any of those matters. The point that I want to concentrate on, purely and simply, is this: why is this federal government agreeing to underwrite, to simply pay, to write a blank cheque for one of its ministers to institute private legal proceedings to scuttle the action of another government.

To that end questions have been asked in this place and in a Senate estimates committee. Finally, a return to order was agreed to by the Senate to try to get some information on this matter. What information could we get that would give us some indication of why the government has come to this decision to give Dr Lawrence effectively a blank cheque. If a normal citizen finds himself or herself in trouble with the law and in trouble with the government and believes that whatever government they are in trouble with has made an error of judgment and is doing the wrong thing in persecuting them, can that ordinary Australian go to legal aid and say, `I want a blank cheque to challenge the action of this government'? Of course they cannot.

The only reason the government has written this citizen a blank cheque is because this citizen happens to be one of its mates, happens now to be a minister in this government. If Dr Lawrence had resigned and was now a private citizen—this royal commission does not relate in any way to her ministerial duties now—then this government would not give two hoots what happened to her. It would not be intervening. It would not be underwriting any private litigation she wanted to undertake in order to scuttle the commission.

She is getting this money for one simple reason: she happens now to be a Labor minister. It has nothing to do with the Commonwealth what matters are being looked at in this commission; nothing to do with anything Dr Lawrence has done or not done or might have thought about doing while she was a federal member. It pertains to matters quite outside the jurisdiction of this parliament, things that happened or did not happen, as the case may be, when Dr Lawrence was a member of the Western Australian parliament. It has nothing whatsoever to do with Commonwealth taxpayers. The only link is that Dr Lawrence is a federal Labor minister. I wonder whether the same effort would be made if she were a Labor Party backbencher. As we have already established, all Australians are equal before the law, but some are more equal. Labor ministers are; I wonder whether Labor backbenchers are.

We have put in a perfectly reasonable request. It was possible for the government to supply a suitable range of documents and to explain why some other documents were not given. What were we given? What documents were we given to give us some insight into how this situation came about? We have been given press releases—they are on the public record—media statements from other people and transcripts of Hansard. How very generous to give that sort of information! We have been given pretty well nothing else—a couple of cover sheets on facsimiles, but nothing of any substance from this government at all. Sure we got a letter from the Premier of Western Australia to Dr Lawrence inviting her to indicate what sort of assistance she might need, and we got a response, but nothing that indicates anything about how this government came to this decision.

The Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) has tabled a statement, with documents—these very useless documents—and indicated that it is not appropriate to comply with the return to order. The basic reasons he offers are these: the documents that exist are legal advice and legal professional privilege would attach to them on the basis that the Commonwealth is not only underwriting Dr Lawrence's action but is going to seek to intervene on its own behalf and has engaged Tom Hughes QC, despite the fact that at the time of engaging him Dr Lawrence's statement of claim had not been drafted—there is no pocket too deep to delve into to protect this minister; all the documents relate to and were constructed for the purpose of legal proceedings. From the minute someone put pen to paper, anywhere in the Commonwealth, somehow we knew at that time that the Commonwealth was going to be involved in litigation. That is simply beyond belief.

The Western Australian royal commission does not pertain to the Commonwealth in any way. It simply involves one of the Commonwealth's ministers. We are asked to believe that every document, every note of every telephone conversation, every memo, every piece of paper, from the minute it was created, was created for the purpose of legal proceedings. Nobody in their right mind would accept that. We certainly do not accept that.

If the Commonwealth is going to intervene in these proceedings and has had legal advice prepared, there may be a case for that advice to be kept back. Sometimes there might be a dispute about that, but you could make a reasonable claim in that respect. For there to be not one other document that this parliament can see is nothing short of a disgrace.

Does legal professional privilege attach to a simple letter from the Attorney-General to the department seeking advice? Does it attach to a memo of a telephone call from Dr Lawrence to the Attorney-General asking for help? Does legal professional privilege attach to a note of a telephone call or a discussion between Dr Lawrence and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) or between the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General on this matter, when things were at a very preliminary stage, before it had entered anybody's head that it might be possible to challenge this commission? Are we asked to believed that there is not one piece of paper in the possession of the Commonwealth, not one document that has travelled through the hands or the office of the Attorney-General, the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr), the Prime Minister or Dr Lawrence that you cannot claim legal professional privilege for? Nobody will believe that.

The second claim is public interest immunity. I noticed some obfuscation from the government on this point. No-one seems to be prepared to claim that every other document that does not have legal professional privilege is a cabinet document, because they simply cannot all be cabinet documents. You cannot ask the Australian community to accept that out of the blue—without any other documents being prepared initially, without anybody seeking advice, asking to arrange a meeting, making a note that a meeting was going to take place, making a note that a telephone call took place—there is not one document like that that is not part of a cabinet submission. You cannot be serious. You cannot really mean it. Hence we see dragged up the other broad scope behind which you want to hide, and that is public interest immunity.

I do not know whom people here are trying to kid that it is in the public interest that the public not be told something—putting aside the legal advice you might have sought—and that the public is not entitled to know something about how this government came to this decision. If this decision will stand up to scrutiny, give us the documents and let us see that it will. Let the public make an assessment about the motion we moved to get these documents and the points we make now. Let the community see whether we are grovelling around in the dirt and engaging in some scummy little exercise, which is what you claim, or let them make the assessment that you are engaging in a grubby little exercise. Only the release of these documents will tell us that.

You can keep the legal advice out of every note of every telephone conversation. It would be very easy to black out those matters that pertain to legal professional privilege or legal advice. That would be perfectly simple to do, and it has been done on plenty of occasions in the past. You are asking us to believe that one day cabinet made a decision and that every document in the Commonwealth's possession in relation to this matter is covered either by legal professional privilege or by being a part of the cabinet file—from the minute this matter started, with the purpose of the Commonwealth entering into proceedings. That simply cannot be true.

If I can phrase it this way, these proceedings are between the Western Australian royal commission and Dr Lawrence. Until the Commonwealth makes a decision to intervene there is no legal professional privilege. Yet you ask us to believe that on any occasion this has been discussed you can claim legal professional privilege or public interest immunity.I put to you that if there is a public interest here it is that the public should have some idea of how you came to this decision. If you are not suggesting that, if you are simply saying that there are no documents that do not have legal professional privilege and that there are no documents that were not in the cabinet submission, you are whistling Dixie if you think anybody will believe you. If you want to say that, you are condemning your government to the public understanding that, when you think you are on thin ice, you do not make a record; you have conversations behind doors; telephone calls that are not noted; or documents and records of such conversations and telephone calls that are later destroyed as a means of preventing any accountability.

This is just like what happened with the State Bank in my state. It went bung because it got away with off balance sheet budgeting and entering into arrangements that did not show up in the balance sheet. If it is the case that you have not made records that you should have, as a government, or you have destroyed those records of conversations, you are now asking us to accept that we can have off-the-record government. Off-the-record government is just as dangerous as off balance sheet budgeting is for companies. That is why the State Bank went down the chute. If that is the type of activity that this government is up to, you will go down the chute too, and deservedly so. If you have not made proper records of conversations and dates of correspondence between parties, you are into off-the-record government.

This decision you have made to fund the personal litigation of one of your ministers is to scuttle the action of another government. You engaged Tom Hughes QC before the statement of claim had even been drafted. I do not think that you could find anybody more expensive. You are off spending taxpayers' money to defend one of your own on a matter that does not pertain to Commonwealth government activities in any way. It is a disgrace.

You were given an opportunity to produce some documents so that we can see who first raised this matter. Did Dr Lawrence come begging for help? Did the Prime Minister go rushing to the Attorney-General and say, `Fix this or else,' or did the Attorney-General say, `I think there is a Commonwealth interest here'? If there is, why cannot he spell out the Commonwealth interest.

I make the point again: there must be some documents somewhere that are not covered by legal professional privilege and that are not part of the cabinet submission. I express deep regret that this government has chosen to respond to this call to order in this way, by basically giving us nothing.
I turn to a quote from a Mr Wiggins in a publication called Freedom or Secrecy. He makes some very good points. He writes:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the worst consequences of secrecy is the licence it confers upon deceit. Where the access to facts about government is open and unobstructed, where the sources of intelligence are numerous and unrestricted, where the official channels to authority are many, misrepresentation is perilous. The possibility of contradiction then rises as a constant threat to authority. But when there are no independent means of verifying official accounts of public transactions, an invaluable check is removed. It then becomes relatively safe for authority to publish such a version of an event as lends the most lustre to government or the least discredit.

Even where outright falsehood or deceit is not involved, less flagrant misrepresentation may occur. The temptation to sugar-coat each disaster and guild every triumph will prove almost irresistible to officials who are secure against contradiction. Government then can manage the news to its taste. It will speak with one voice and, however much that voice may err, there will be none to say it nay.
That is the position you put yourselves in with this disgraceful return to order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard Senator Vanstone speak on a number of issues and on a number of occasions but I have never heard her make such a nitpicking contribution, a contribution so based on irrelevance, lack of principle and a lack of substance, as I have heard this afternoon. It reflects the attitude the opposition is taking not just to this issue but, as we have seen during the course of this afternoon, to other issues as well.

PARA.TAB: This is an opposition without direction and without understanding of principle. Because of that, it latches on to issues like this with no consistency. Here we have someone who, for purposes of political voyeurism and nothing else, wants documents that she needs to look at. There is no addressing the issues that are the substance of this matter. There is no addressing the issues of what this process is all about.

I want to pin this process for what it really is, and the person who has pinned it best is the Deputy Premier of Western Australia, Hendy Cowan. He said that this is an exercise in politics and, for that reason, the inquiry could well be damned before it starts. He went on to say that the National Party, the partner of the government in Western Australia, does not believe that the taxpayers should pay for what is essentially an inquiry to achieve a political outcome. If Senator Vanstone were concerned about taxpayers' money, her statement should be directed at the Western Australian Premier, Richard Court, and the person who pulls his strings, Senator Crichton-Browne in this place. This process could be put to an end immediately if you picked up the phone, rang Richard Court and said, `Hey, mate, this is not on. This is just a political exercise and, like Hendy Cowan, I don't believe the taxpayers should be paying for it.'

That is the starting point. But, because you do not acknowledge that, you are ignoring the basic principles involved in this matter—principles that have always applied in this place, principles endorsed by previous Liberal Attorneys-General, Greenwood and Ellicott—namely, the public interest immunity of cabinet documents and legal professional confidentiality.

At the start of this process we made it very clear that you could move your return to order but that very few documents would be tabled because of those two basic principles of government. We made that clear to you, Senator Vanstone, both inside and outside this place, but you have chosen to ignore those principles. That is why your return to order motion is at best vacuous and at worst blatant hypocrisy. It is a disregard of the accepted principles of practice in this place. It is a disregard of accepted principles of government. You know that but, despite knowing it, you come in here with a wish list that you know any responsible government cannot meet. That is your basic starting point and your basic failure.
You come in here asking for things to be done that you know have not been done in the past and cannot be done now because of those two basic principles. As Greenwood and Ellicott said:

SPEECH.PARA: The process of Cabinet Government and the security of military information would be seriously prejudiced if all information in these matters were readily available to either a House or a committee of a House and whether in public or in camera. This, we think, is self evident.

That principle is there on both sides of the parliament but you do not want to accept it. It applies to both ministers and backbenchers. Odgers, in his work, recognises that public interest immunity applies to the relationship between a member of parliament, be it a cabinet minister or a backbencher, and a legal adviser.

PARA.TAB: There are two fundamental principles of law and administration, but what do you do? You come in here with a return to order that shows a blatant disregard for those principles. I know Senator Vanstone well enough to know that she knows and accepts these principles I am talking about. Yet she comes up with a motion that is hypocritical in its nature because it denies those principles.

We are also talking about matters that will very soon be before the court. Does Senator Vanstone want to undermine wholesale the federal government's position in this matter? Does she want the legal advice to go to the other side, which we know it would? Does she want to reveal the case? Does she want her mates in Western Australia involved in a political witch-hunt, which is all it is? That is the only motivation she could have in this exercise here today.

Such a motivation says to the people, `We do not care about the national interest. We do not care about national perspectives. We just want to help our mates in their witch-hunt in Western Australia.' It is vacuous, empty, hypocritical and, in its motivation, quite destructive to the national interest.

Cases will be before the court soon and a request that would make available the federal government's legal position—this documentation, this advice on questions asked—relates to matters that could well be before the courts. Senator Vanstone shows no responsibility to the national interest here. This is a political exercise, one in which the opposition made it very clear from the start that what is at stake is the credibility and fitness for position of a federal minister.

Do not come in here now and deny that. For weeks, the opposition—through its leader, John Howard, or its spokesperson, Michael Wooldridge—has stepped up the attack on Carmen Lawrence, someone they quite rightly fear and will continue to fear as a political powerhouse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—Let me give you some advice, Senator Patterson: this sort of attack on a person of Carmen Lawrence's character and status does not detract from her image in the community. In all my contacts with people and from all the polls I have seen, you have been exposed as viciously and spitefully attacking a person for political purposes. You want to make Carmen Lawrence bankrupt—that is Richard Court's attitude—but the public are not stupid. They can see through it, especially when Hendy Cowan says that this is a political exercise. They can see that there is no motivation of principle here.All they can see is a federal minister being unfairly targeted at the expense of the taxpayer. This is taxpayers' money going to support Richard Court in his and your vindictive attempt to take the blame for corruption away from the Western Australian Liberal Party.

PARA.TAB: Here we have a federal minister targeted because of her position. She is singled out by virtue of the public office she holds. In the process, a number of important legal issues are raised. If they were not important, you could not sustain a case in court. They are issues that go to the heart of the parliamentary process. They are issues of principle, such as whether the processes of the parliament can be questioned outside the parliament. That is a matter of importance not only to the Western Australian parliament, but wherever the Westminster system applies, particularly on a federal level.

There are also issues that go to the confidentiality of the cabinet process. If the tables were reversed, if a state Labor government were picking on a federal Liberal government, attacking those basic principles of constitutional practice, attacking cabinet solidarity and the proceedings of parliament, you would be the first ones in here screaming for intervention to ensure that the processes of the parliament were protected against such an unprincipled attack from outside. We have a responsibility to be part of this. We have a responsibility to intervene once this process is under way.

The Attorney-General made it very clear in his tabling statement today that there are precedents, and most of them originate from state Liberal governments in their processes. The precedents are there; it is just that the opposition, without principle and without a sense of proportion or parameters, comes in here and chooses to ignore them—in the same way that it chose to ignore the basic principles underlying the government's response in this matter.

This is a charade, and it should be recognised as such, because for Senator Vanstone to ask for more than what she got today would be for her to deny any knowledge of basic constitutional practices in this place—practices which go very much to professional legal privilege and very much to the processes of cabinet and cabinet confidentiality. They are processes which have been consistently acknowledged and which were last reflected in 1972 in documents prepared by former Liberal Attorneys-General Ellicott and Greenwood and are principles that this government is pursuing. As I said at the start, I have heard Senator Vanstone speak quite often, but this has to be one of her most incredulous performances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I refer to the statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) which, I believe, accompanied these documents and which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, the establishment of the Royal Commission offends one of the most basic principles of parliamentary democracy. The Bill of Rights of 1688 states that the proceedings of Parliament are not to be questioned in any place out of Parliament.

The minister is saying that the royal commission which has been called in Western Australia infringes section 16 of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Privileges Act. On looking at that section, I put it to the minister that I think he has missed the point. Section 16 talks about the protection provisions of article 9 of the Bill of Rights 1688 applying to the parliament of the Commonwealth. I put it to the Senate that the royal commission in Western Australia does not relate to proceedings in the parliament of the Commonwealth—the Senate or the House of Representatives—but relates to proceedings which took place in the state parliament and thereby is a matter quite discrete from the business conducted in both houses of the Commonwealth. Therefore, section 16 has no application at all, as the royal commission in Western Australia is dealing only with matters pertaining to the state parliament and not to the federal parliament.

PARA.TAB: I reiterate the remarks made by Senator Vanstone: in this return to order, we have seven press releases which are on the public record; we have extracts from the estimates committee and from the business in this chamber—the Hansards, of course, are freely available to senators; we have media transcripts from an interview with Carmen Lawrence and two with Hendy Cowan; and we have the advertisement for the royal commission in Western Australia giving the terms of reference, and a media statement accompanying those terms of reference. None of that is of a private nature whatsoever. The only thing of interest that I found was the guidelines from both the Legislative Council of Western Australia and the Commonwealth of this country for determining legal assistance to ministers and government officers. I will come to that shortly.

We are not saying that there should be an abrogation of legal privilege in the motion for a return to order. In the documents that were sought, we have copies of correspondence between Dr Lawrence and the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch), and that is hardly protected by legal privilege. We have sought copies of correspondence between the Attorney-General and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), and that is not in any way affecting legal privilege. We have correspondence between the Prime Minister and Dr Lawrence—again no legal privilege would attach. And we have copies of any notes, memos, briefs and documents prepared by a Commonwealth official relating to the same matter. I doubt whether that would be protected by legal privilege, either. Subsection (v) of the resolution says:

SPEECH.PARA: copies of any legal advice prepared by any Government lawyer in relation to the same matters.

I concede that there could be matters of legal privilege there. Nonetheless, the minister has said that there are matters of public interest immunity and legal privilege which restrict the minister from providing documents in this return to order. I can only assume that those documents must be voluminous because this is a matter of some weight and importance and it has been before cabinet, yet all we have been given are the documents that I have referred to. I suggest that that would be only the tip of the iceberg.

PARA.TAB: I think that what we have here is a question of accountability. I refer to Senator Bolkus's comments: this is not a question of attacking a person; it is a question of bringing the government to account for how it came to make this decision. As I understand it, Carmen Lawrence has applied to the state government of Western Australia for assistance in relation to the royal commission, and I am not aware of any decision having been made yet. I would have said to the Commonwealth Attorney-General that it would have been wise to wait to see what happened there before making any decision as to the provision of assistance to Carmen Lawrence.

This is all about accountability, and if government members were in opposition, they would be doing exactly what the coalition is doing here—that is, seeking some sort of accountability. I understand that Senator Bolkus says there is a process, but that process does not deny or shut out accountability to the taxpayer of moneys to be spent. That process is an important process, and I am the first one to acknowledge that there should be cabinet confidentiality. However, when you make decisions of this sort, there are available, beyond the protection of cabinet confidentiality, documents and procedures which are well within the purview of the Australian taxpayer. That is what we have here. We have the government overreacting to a call by the coalition simply asking: how did you arrive at this decision; what are the guidelines; what criteria do you apply? There is absolutely no harm in that. In fact, the coalition is doing its job as a responsible opposition in seeking that information on behalf of taxpayers. I think it is an area that needs clarification.

I note that Senator Ray said earlier that he was going to write to the Attorney-General in relation to representation or assistance being offered to ministers, and possibly members and officers of the Commonwealth, in various matters. I would be the first to say that you do not give members of parliament, senators, ministers or officers a blank cheque book for legal proceedings, but I do think that the government needs to address the question of how it makes ex gratia payments for legal assistance to ministers and officers of the crown. I also ask the government to address whether it would do the same for shadow ministers in this situation. I believe that it is not only ministers of the government of the day that could well be entitled to some protection; if you were to be even-handed in a democratic sense, that sort of assistance should be looked at for opposition parties.
There should be strict guidelines which state that the assistance relates only to the performance of one's duties. Guideline No. 2 of the Commonwealth's guidelines states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where a Minister becomes involved as a defendant in litigation arising out of the performance of his or her Ministerial duties, the facts of the matter should be referred to the Attorney-General for consideration as to whether it is appropriate for assistance in accordance with these guidelines to be provided at Commonwealth expense.

I suggest in the strongest possible terms that Carmen Lawrence was not a minister of this government and was not even a member of the Commonwealth parliament when all these issues arose. We are talking about a petition which was presented to the state parliament when she was a member of the state parliament. I would submit that it does not come within the Commonwealth guideline No. 2.

PARA.TAB: I think that the government has overlooked or ignored its own guideline. In this instance, the government has much to account for, and I call upon the government to answer in relation to that guideline how it would justify such a decision. I still believe that, at the end of the day, it was unwise for the Attorney-General to state that the government would assist Carmen Lawrence in the event that she did not get assistance. I think it would have been pertinent for him to have made that decision once the minister had been refused assistance from the state government in Western Australia, which I understand she has applied to.

This whole matter reeks of a lack of accountability. With respect to guideline 2, I fail to see any justification for the Commonwealth government's decision. It may well be that the government has other grounds for granting this assistance. Let us hear them. Let us see them. Lay them on the table so that the Australian people can see how this decision was arrived at.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are taking note of the voluminous documents that the government presented this morning supposedly in response to the request by this chamber for the provision of the information as to why Dr Lawrence, a minister in this government, somehow cons taxpayers' money out of this government to pay her costs to support her arguments at a royal commission about what happened while she was a member of another parliament. The minister's statement today clearly contradicts the motion that was agreed to only yesterday. The motion read:

SPEECH.PARA: (i) copies of all correspondence and other documents (whatever their form) exchanged between Dr Lawrence and the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) and/or the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) in relation to the following matters, namely, the possible or actual provision to Dr Lawrence of legal advice or financial assistance in relation to any challenge to, or involvement in, the Western Australian Royal Commission into the Penny Easton affair,

(ii) copies of all correspondence and other documents (whatever their form) exchanged between the Attorney-General and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in relation to the matters referred to in paragraph (i),
(iii) copies of all correspondence and other documents (whatever their form) exchanged between the Prime Minister and Dr Lawrence in relation to the same matters,
(iv) copies of any notes, memos, briefs and documents (whatever their form) prepared by any Commonwealth official in relation to the same matters, and
(v) copies of any legal advice prepared by any Government lawyer in relation to the same matters.

What we have been provided with today bears no relationship to that motion. Why does the government suddenly come in here today and say, `Here you are, you can have copies of press releases'? One thing that the government has given us is a media alert which says, `The Honourable Carmen Lawrence will hold a press conference in room 1R4 at 1.30 p.m. today. Contact Brenda Conroy 2277220'. There is no date on the press release, so I do not have a clue when it was.

PARA.TAB: This is the quality of the documents that have been provided to assure taxpayers that they are getting value for money. In his statement today the minister said that the documents requested in the motion fall within the accepted boundaries of legal professional privilege and public interest immunity. Why did he say that these documents would be made available when they have not been? He made the following comment: `The funding of Dr Lawrence by the Commonwealth is fully justified and the process whereby that funding was determined was wholly appropriate'.

The process by which that funding was determined as being wholly appropriate is exactly what this parliament and the people of Australia deserve to know. If it was wholly appropriate, why is the government afraid to tell us the reasons. As Senator Vanstone, Senator Panizza and Senator Ellison said: if it is wholly appropriate why is it selective? Why is it selective in the case of Mr Graeme Campbell, a Labor member of this parliament? Is the government going to fund him? I am not suggesting for one moment that the taxpayer should fund him, but at least he is a member of the same parliament.

Dr Lawrence was not a member of this parliament when the events in question occurred, and that needs to be remembered. The minister went on to say, `It should be remembered that it was the Court government of Western Australia which established this royal commission'. The minister is the one who should remember that. It is a Western Australian royal commission affecting the now minister for health when she was the state premier. She was running the show over there—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha!

—She was attempting to run the show. I acknowledge that giggle from Senator Patterson. Dr Lawrence was meant to be running the show. She was meant to know what was going on. Why, therefore, does the federal government suddenly decide to fund this out of the federal coffers? The minister went on to say, `If that responsibility is not met, then the Commonwealth has a duty to ensure that Dr Lawrence is appropriately represented'. That is the statement. Give us the facts. Give us the details. All we are saying is this: if the government believes that, then the taxpayer has a right to know why.

PARA.TAB: I would ask why Dr Lawrence has such a right when she was not a member of this parliament at the time. The government is dismissing the whole thing as a political attack on her fitness to be a Commonwealth minister. It has nothing to do with her fitness to be a Commonwealth minister in the eyes of the Court government, but it has everything to do with the way in which she acted as premier of the state of Western Australia.

The minister also made mention in his statement this morning of a whole range of other instances where funding had been provided. He mentioned that Mick Young had been funded for the Hope royal commission; that the Groom Liberal government had agreed to meet the legal expenses of former Premier Gray in the Rouse bribery royal commission; that the Fahey coalition government agreed to fund former Premier Nick Greiner, and so forth and so on. The one common denominator in those matters was that the funds were provided to people who were members of the parliament in the state holding the royal commission. That is the difference.

The government cannot possibly turn around and say that the funding of Dr Lawrence's legal fees out of the Commonwealth pot bears any relationship whatsoever to the other examples that have been provided. It is sheer and utter nonsense. The minister said today, `The opposition's state colleagues thought that the provision of legal assistance was appropriate in cases where corruption or maladministration was being alleged'. Yet those state members now have the hypocrisy, according to the minister, to claim that the government should not fund Dr Lawrence's legal costs when no such allegation is before the Western Australian royal commission.

Can the government not see the difference? Dr Lawrence was not a member of this parliament at that time. The people of Australia have a right to know why this is being done. We have a return to order which was set down for 9 o'clock this morning. The government agreed to provide the documents. The government should still be bound by the agreement to provide the documents instead of just providing a bunch full of nonsense that we have already read. There is virtually nothing in this bunch of documents that is not already on the public record.

How on earth can the government believe that this complies with the return to order that was agreed in the Senate yesterday for 9 o'clock this morning? This government has a responsibility to provide the documentation not only to the parliament but to the people of Australia. We are not for one moment talking about disclosing legal advice or the intricacies of it. That is the curtain behind which the government is hiding. It is false to suggest that we are trying to find out the legal ramifications and the legal intricacies of Dr Lawrence's defence.

What we are talking about is the details of why and how this Labor government reached its decision to spend Commonwealth taxpayers' money on defending a member of the federal parliament in an action which relates to Dr Lawrence's activities while she was a member of a state parliament. We can make it no clearer than that. The government has a responsibility to let this parliament know and to provide the supporting documents as to how that decision was reached. There are no ifs, no buts, and no maybes. That was the request. It has not been complied with. The government has a responsibility to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us make some things very clear. The Marks royal commission is not a Commonwealth commission or a Commonwealth inquiry. This is a Western Australian state matter and it involves issues and matters which relate to the actions or knowledge of Carmen Lawrence in a former incarnation as the Premier of Western Australia. It does not involve matters that in any way relate to her current role as the federal Minister for Health and Human Services. If it did, she would be covered by the guidelines for the provision of assistance to Commonwealth government ministers and parliamentary secretaries in relation to the defence of legal proceedings which were provided under Senator Vanstone's return to order.

PARA.TAB: For the second time in a month the government has used a very narrow definition of what it is required to table under a return to order to exclude any document which may be damaging to its cause. I suppose we should not be surprised by this action. However, the government should not be surprised that the Senate will take a very hard line in enforcing its return to order.

In a few minutes I will move an amendment to Senator Vanstone's motion, but I would like to make a brief comment on the response by the minister to the concerns raised by Senator Vanstone. The Greens looked very carefully at the terms of Senator Vanstone's return to order. If it had involved any of the aspects that the minister raised, we would not have supported it. We do not believe that it does request material that will require legal advice that should, quite properly, be covered by legal privilege. Neither do we believe that the public interest issue is one that can be used to justify failing to reveal the rationale for public funding expenditure.

We are not asking for legal information. That has not been the content of the request. If it had, we would have seriously considered not supporting it. The reason we agreed to support it was because we believed it was a very legitimate question that needed to be asked. We had an appalling response to the call to order and the reasons why the documentation was so inadequate. It does not represent fair and open government and it may well be argued that the Premier of Western Australia has been blatantly political or opportunistic in calling for the royal commission. I have a degree of sympathy with that argument.

However, the government is exposing itself to the exact accusation for entering into an agreement to use public money to fight against the legality of the royal commission. If it has the capacity to defend itself from that argument, it should be readily observable in the files which document the decision-making process that was followed. That has not been done. Therefore, I will move an amendment to Senator Vanstone's motion. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add "but the Senate is of the opinion that the Minister representing the Attorney-General is in contempt of the Senate by failing to comply with all the terms of the order for production of documents agreed to by the Senate on 28 June 1995 and orders that he purge his contempt by tabling all remaining documents by 6.00 p.m. this evening.".

I believe that this is a principle that this Senate needs to uphold. The government needs to demonstrate its accountability. If we have off-the-record government, as Senator Vanstone calls it, it is a real worry. It is a great worry that we cannot provide proper accountability and transparency by way of record to the community and to this parliament for the expenditure of public funds for an individual in a private capacity.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of issues involved in this return to order. I made known an amendment yesterday which resulted in the final shape of Senator Vanstone's first motion. In the event, it was actually moved by the government. In my suggested amendment I excised all those paragraphs in the original motion which appeared to pre-judge the issue, and left the bare bones of an order for the production of documents. It was strictly limited to that.

PARA.TAB: The documents requested were documents providing advice on whether or not Dr Lawrence, the Commonwealth Minister for Human Services and Health, should receive legal assistance through the Commonwealth. It did not ask for the production of documents which provided advice on the substantive issues of the legal position in which she found herself. It is very difficult to see why there could be any legal privilege attaching to documents which simply and exclusively deal with the question of whether or not Dr Lawrence should receive Commonwealth assistance.

In that particular area, the issue is whether the acts or omissions of Dr Lawrence, while she was premier of the state of Western Australia, continue to be relevant in her current position as the Commonwealth minister for health and whether the Commonwealth government, as a consequence of that, is entitled to use public funds to provide legal assistance.

As has been said by others, it is fairly clear that the actions of the Western Australian government are motivated by political considerations. It is also fairly clear that if Dr Lawrence was not the Commonwealth minister for health, it would be doubtful whether the Western Australian government would have instituted this particular inquiry. There is an argument which says that there could well be a reason why the Commonwealth government would be justified in providing that assistance. Against that, we have the very clear separation of functions. In the first instance, we have Dr Lawrence acting as the Premier of Western Australia. She is now the minister for health at a Commonwealth level. The inquiry to which she has been invited to respond is an inquiry into actions or omissions of hers while she was the Premier of Western Australia.

Therefore, the issues are not easy to resolve. It is the duty of the Senate, not just the right of the Senate, to examine these issues and to arrive at a reasonable conclusion. I believe that the Senate has the right to require the documents be placed before the Senate that were requested by the order for the production of documents which was passed yesterday. I sought to have it amended to be limited, very clearly and very narrowly, to documents which relate to the issue and advice as to whether or not Dr Lawrence should receive that legal assistance, not in any way to the substantive issue that is before the Western Australian inquiry. On that basis, the Australian Democrats continue the support that I announced yesterday for the production of the documents that were asked for and that the Senate has not yet received.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my view, the issue in this case is a very simple one: whether or not a part of parliament—not parliament—can properly attack executive privilege under section 61 of the constitution. There are times when parliament, as distinct from the Senate, can do so. Perhaps the best statement of that is the decision of the United States v. Richard M. Nixon, where the Supreme Court of America ordered the surrender of tapes. The unanimous—as I understand it—decision read by Chief Justice Burger reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Constitution—
I interpolate that the constitution of the United States provided the model for the constitution under which we operate—
does not contain any explicit reference to an executive privilege of confidentiality yet there is constitutional basis for this if it involves the effective discharge of the president's powers.
A criminal trial was involved and the need for fair administration of justice had to be balanced against the importance of the President's general privilege of confidentiality. It continued:
While taking note of the doctrine of separation of powers, the Court observed that there is no unqualified presidential privilege of immunity from judicial process under all circumstances.

The court was talking about judicial process. In this debate, we are talking about legislative process. It cannot be compared with the situation that might operate in England, which does not have a constitution to guide the way people go about their operations.

PARA.TAB: What the Senate is involved in—I said it before and I come back to it—is not the exercise of parliamentary power, but the exercise of Senate power. If the people who have spoken in this debate so far are so confident that they are right, why don't they get parliamentary direction? Why don't they get the House of Representatives to join with the Senate and get the assent of the Governor-General acting on behalf of the Queen—which is the process you have to go through—to talk about parliamentary exercise in this context? Why don't they go through that process?

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a properly elected chamber of parliament.

—Of course it is a properly elected chamber of parliament and you make out my case for me, Senator Vanstone, because you say, `It is a chamber of parliament.' But it is not parliament. The next point I want to make is that if there was a basis here for interfering with executive privilege, there might be merit in what you say, Senator Vanstone. I think there are cases where this chamber ought to exercise that power. In this case there is no need for it. It is all very patent; all the essential facts are known.

PARA.TAB: The essential facts in this matter are that there is a royal commission under the guidance of the former Supreme Court Justice of Victoria, Mr Marks; there is an inquiry into what Dr Lawrence may or may not have done; and there is a payment of a known sum by the executive of the Australian government. They are the essential facts. None of those are denied. All those facts are out in public and you can—as you have already—make very effective statements about that matter. You know all that you need to know to make your point. You have been making that point again and again in this chamber.

What you are on about, Senator Vanstone, must be the purported exercise of the Senate's power over the executive; an executive that comes from a party which is in the minority in this chamber, but in the majority in the House of Representatives. That is why it is not done in that chamber. It is not done there because members honestly believe it should not be done. It is done in this chamber because you are convinced it ought to be done. Have we asked ourselves why one chamber—where the Attorney-General is—does not even raise the issue whereas this chamber does?
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chamarette's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that Senator Vanstone's motion, as amended, be agreed to.
—The government does not support the motion, but we will not force it to a vote.

PARA.TAB: Motion, as amended, agreed to.
