TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee on the Family Law Reform Bill 1994 and the exposure draft of the Family Law Reform Bill (No. 2) 1994, and I seek leave to incorporate the response in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: OVERVIEW

The Family Law Reform Bill 1994 and the Exposure Family Law Reform Bill (No 2) 1994 were referred to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee for a second report to deal with a range of concerns which were expressed to the Committee in submissions at its hearing on 6 June 1995. The Government took note of the submissions made to the Committee and has given detailed consideration to the matters raised in the hearing before the Committee and in the report of the Committee.

Family law is an area of the law which touches the lives of so many Australians. The reforms proposed in the Bills aim to provide a means by which parents, when separating, can resolve matters between themselves with dignity, certainty and in the best interests of their children. When making arrangements for the future parenting of their children, parents should not resolve matters in their own interests but in the interests of their children.

The further hearing on the Bills enabled a detailed consideration of a number of important issues. The Government will be accepting all the Committee's recommendations for amendment to the Act and thanks the Committee for its second
report.
RESPONSE TO INDIVIDUAL RECOMMENDATIONS
Recommendation 1: The Committee recommends that specification of grandparents be considered as an amendment to section 69C of the Family Law Reform Bill 1994.
Government Response:

The Senate Committee has asked the Government to give consideration to the specification of grandparents in the Family Law Act, in particular in proposed section 69C. Over the period since the issue was raised with the Government by the Grandparents' Action Group of WA and, particularly since the Committee's hearing on 6 June 1995, this matter has been very carefully considered. The Government recognises the importance of the role which may be played by grandparents after separation and, in particular, the benefits that children may gain from continuing positive contact with grandparents.

Under the current provisions of the Family Law Act, any person who has an interest in the welfare of the child—including grandparents—may institute proceedings and seek orders. Where proceedings are on foot, the Court may grant leave to another person to intervene and has in fact done so to allow grandparents to be heard. The Bill continues this situation, allowing grandparents to make applications and to be heard in proceedings relating to children, but with one fundamental change. The Bill presents a consistent theme so that attitudes will shift away from self interest and centre upon the child's best interest.

The Government notes, in addition, that the Joint Select Committee on the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act concluded that it was not necessary to amend the Act to provide an express reference to grandparents, a view which has been supported by the Chief Justice of the Family Court.

The Government agrees that more should be done to encourage separating parents to consider the beneficial role that grandparents may play, and will address this issue in the educational campaign accompanying the reforms contained in the Bill. While recognising the valuable role that grandparents may play, the Government believes that the legislation needs to present a proper balance, consistent with the theme of the child's best interests, and not unduly limit the Court's consideration of the best interests of the child in an individual case. The Government is concerned that an amendment to the proposed section 69C might detract from that fundamental theme. The focus of the legislative reforms should therefore remain upon the child's best interests, and the arrangements or court orders which will best promote those interests.
Recommendation 2: The Committee recommends that the objects of Part III "Primary Dispute Resolution" be amended to include in paragraph 14 (a) of the clause words bolded along the following lines:

"(a) to encourage people to use primary dispute resolution mechanisms, that is counselling, mediation or arbitration or other means of conciliation or reconciliation, to resolve matters, provided such mechanisms are appropriate in the circumstances of the case and proper procedures are followed, in preference to litigation in which a court order might otherwise be made under this Act;"

Government response: The Government accepts this recommendation. In so doing, the Government notes the concerns expressed to the Senate Committee that there needs to be greater awareness that decisions to use primary dispute resolution should reflect a sensitivity and acknowledgment of issues in relation to family violence. The Government proposes to reflect this concern by amending the Objects provision to Part III to ensure that when the primary dispute resolution alternatives are used that regard be paid to the need for proper protection for individuals.

Recommendation 3: The Committee recommends that the Objects of Part VII "Children" be amended to include the words "except if it is contrary to the child's best interests" in paragraph (b) of the principles in subsection 60B (2).

Government response: The Government accepts this recommendation. The Senate Committee heard evidence that the second principle in the proposed section 60B (2) (b) of the Reform Bill should contain the words "except if it is contrary to the child's best interests" so that the Bill does not give the impression that the child's right of contact with both parents is unqualified. Notwithstanding that the Bill provides for decisions to be made in the best interests of the child through section 68F, the Government proposes to amend the Bill to include the words requested to make it clear that the child's right of contact is not unqualified.
This is also consistent with recommendation 2.6 in the Australian Law Reform Commission's Report No 73 "For the Sake of the Kids" tabled on 20 June 1995.

Recommendation 4: The Committee recommends that section 68K be redrafted to express in positive terms that the Family Court, when making an order, must have regard to safeguards in order to avoid exposure to family violence.

Government response: The Government accepts this recommendation. The concern expressed to the Senate Committee was that some provisions of the Bill did not have the right balance when considering contact between a child and others where there has been family violence or a family violence order has been made. Section 68K was mentioned in this regard. The Government therefore proposes that this concern be addressed by redrafting the provision in accordance with the recommendation to ensure the Court strikes the appropriate balance between protection of individuals and the right of the child to contact with both parents and significant others in accordance with Australia's obligations under the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. This, of course, would only occur in circumstances where it is not contrary to the child's best interests.

Recommendation 5: The Committee recommends that, as a matter of priority, an appropriate regulatory regime, specifying qualifications and standards, be developed for approved counsellors and mediators.

Government response: The Government accepts this recommendation. The Justice Statement released in May 1995 announced the establishment of a specialist Advisory Council to ensure high standards in alternative dispute resolution and to develop informed policy advice about the use and regulation of alternative dispute resolution. The Government proposes that the development of regulations be through a broadly based consultative arrangement including the proposed advisory council on ADR announced in the Justice Statement, the Family Law Council, the Family Law Section of the Law Council of Australia, the Family Services Council, the National Women's Justice Coalition and others who have an interest in the development of such a regime.
Additional Issues. There are two additional issues which the Committee has not recommended but which the Government believes should be changed:

PARA.TAB: A concern expressed to the Committee was that the name "special purpose orders" suggests that these matters would only be considered in circumstances which themselves are unusual or special. In cases of family violence, it has been argued that where such an order is required, it may be difficult to obtain. The Government believes this is not the case but to dispel any doubt, the Government proposes to change the name from "special purpose" to "specific issues order"; and'

SPEECH.PARA: Attention has been drawn by the Australian Law Reform Commission to proposed subparagraph 68F (2) (f) (ii) which is one of the factors that the Court must take into account in making an order in the best interests of the child. That factor requires the Court to consider the physical and psychological effects of violence in the presence of the child when deciding matters in the best interest of the child. Concern was raised by the Australian Law Reform Commission that this provision may unintentionally limit the Court's consideration of the effect of violence on the child's well-being. To dispel any doubt that this may limit other factors, which require that the effects of violence per se be considered, the Government will be amending the Bill in the terms recommended by the Australian Law Reform Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.
Debate (on motion by Senator Panizza) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled Checking the Cash: A report on the effectiveness of the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988, and I seek leave to incorporate the response in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
BACKGROUND

The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs (the Committee) conducted an inquiry into the operation and effectiveness of the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988 (the FTR Act).

2.The Committee received 66 written submissions and conducted public hearings in Sydney and Melbourne in June 1993. Written submissions were received from a variety of interested individuals and bodies. Many of those who made submissions also appeared before the Committee, including financial institution representative organisations, finance industry unions, state treasury and revenue officials, organisations representing the legal profession, three major banks, a major civil liberties organisation, and relevant Commonwealth agencies. The contributions of these individuals and bodies are gratefully acknowledged by the Government.

3.The Report of the Committee follows on from the Committee's earlier evaluation in 1988 of the Cash Transaction Reports Bill. That earlier Report recommended that if the Bill were enacted, its operation "be reviewed after a suitable period of time, preferably not longer than 3 years, and that the review include the economic, taxation, privacy and law enforcement implications of the Bill".
4.The Government would like to thank the Committee for the thoroughness of its report and its constructive suggestions for legislative amendment.
5.The Committee found the operation of the FTR Act to be cost effective.

6.The Government accepts in principle the majority of the Committee's recommendations, and will be taking action in the near future (including by amendment of the FTR Act) to implement those recommendations.
TERMS OF REFERENCE
7.The Committee's terms of reference were to inquire and report on the operation and effectiveness of the FTR Act with particular reference to:
(a)the scope and reach of the Act, the adequacy of its provisions and whether relevant international obligations to which Australia is subject have been met;
(b)the extent of public awareness of and support for the Act;
(c)the legal effectiveness of the Act, including relevant matters of law which have emerged or which may emerge;
(d)the extent to which the Act has achieved its objectives;
(e)the cost-effectiveness of the act, including the possibility or desirability of cost-recovery;
(f)any unforeseen or unintended effects of the Act; and
(g)any other matters relevant to the effective operation of the Act.
BACKGROUND TO THE FINANCIAL TRANSACTION REPORTS ACT 1988

8.The Costigan Royal Commission showed the importance of being able to trace financial transactions in the effort to curtail organised crime and reduce tax evasion. As well as "following the money trail" the Costigan Report also recommended tighter requirements for record-keeping by financial institutions, so as to provide a firmer basis for tracing transactions.

9.AUSTRAC, the Australian Transaction and Reports Analysis Centre, formerly the Cash Transaction Reports Agency, began operation in 1989. AUSTRAC receives reports on cash and other financial transactions as required by the Act, and analyses and disseminates to law enforcement agencies and the Australian Taxation Office, information relating to those reports.
10.The objects of the FTR Act are to facilitate the administration and enforcement of taxation and other laws.

11.The Act imposes a number of obligations on "cash dealers" and their customers in order to counter use of the financial system to facilitate or disguise criminal conduct. The term "cash dealers" includes not only banks, credit unions and building societies, but also securities dealers, futures brokers, bullion dealers, casinos, bookmakers and gambling houses.

12.The Committee examined the quantity of significant cash transaction reports, the cost of compliance and the method of delivery of data to AUSTRAC, and the acceptance of the erosion of banker-customer confidentiality. The Committee accepted that reporting of significant cash transactions should be retained generally in its present format, partly because it was not possible to form a concluded view on the forensic value of the information collected. The Committee also noted that efforts should be taken to contain the costs imposed on cash dealers.

13.One of the most controversial of the provisions of the Act has been the requirement that cash dealers verify the identity of persons opening new accounts. The Committee has noted that the account opening procedures were the subject of much comment in the evidence to the Committee, and that the number of changes made to the account opening procedures in just two years of operation is an indication that they are unsatisfactory. The Committee recommends that the account opening provisions be made much more flexible, and that AUSTRAC be given a wider auditing role to ensure that cash dealers comply with their obligations. The Government accepts this recommendation and will be working with representatives of the major cash dealers to establish satisfactory procedures.

14.During its inquiry the Committee was told of a suggested threat the FTR Act posed to the privacy and civil liberties of members of the community. The Committee noted that AUSTRAC has been very conscious of civil liberties issues and was impressed with AUSTRAC's consciousness of the need to secure the sensitive information which is provided to it. To better protect civil liberties and privacy, the Committee recommended that a person representative of civil liberties concerns be appointed to two key advisory committees, and that the Director of AUSTRAC have the power to delete information from the AUSTRAC database in appropriate circumstances. The Government accepts these recommendations.

15.After examining the way in which AUSTRAC stores and analyses the data reported to it and how AUSTRAC's clients use AUSTRAC's databases, and discussing AUSTRAC's participation in task forces, the Committee recommended that AUSTRAC engage only in activities that fall squarely within the confines of the FTR Act. The Government agrees that where there is any doubt about whether an action is allowed, legal advice will be obtained. The Committee endorsed AUSTRAC's analysis of data, "the moral distinction between collecting material obtained by force of law and without reference to its creator, and analysing it without the knowledge of its producer or supplier, is so narrow as to make it appropriate to treat both processes on the same basis. If it is reasonable for AUSTRAC to gather material, it is reasonable for it to order and deal with it in ways that show up pattens of behaviour and the pursuit of a particular course of conduct."

16.The Committee considered submissions made about the conduct of some members of the legal profession, but recommended that the definition of "cash dealer" not be altered to include solicitors. The Government proposes to require legal practitioners to take on some of the reporting obligations, and report to AUSTRAC transactions in cash (currency) of $10,000 and above with their clients, including in the report particulars of the identity of the client as known to them.

17.The Committee also recommended that the FTR Act be reviewed again in a further three years. The Government accepts that periodic review is appropriate, but considers a five year interval is more appropriate.
18.A number of the Committee's recommendations require amendments to the FTR Act. Briefly these are:

PARA.TAB: Recommendation 2, adjust the reporting threshold for significant cash transactions to maintain the threshold at or near the present amount in real terms;
Recommendation 5, prescribed account opening procedures not to be mandatory minimum; cash dealers to have discretion to depart from standards where warranted;
Recommendation 6, AUSTRAC to have power and resources to audit performance of cash dealers' compliance with duty to satisfy themselves of customers' identity;
Recommendation 7, ATO not to have access as of right to FTR data;
Recommendation 10, AUSTRAC Director have power to authorise the deletion of FTR information from AUSTRAC databases;
Recommendation 15, inclusion of a definition of `transaction' to make it clear that an uncompleted transaction falls within the reporting requirements;
Recommendation 16, legislative protection of the identity of tellers who initiate a suspect transaction report (retaining the possibility of the teller being called as a witness);
Recommendation 17, specifying the mental element required for the structuring offence in s31;
Recommendation 18, increasing the reporting threshold for import/export of currency; and define the point at which currency transferred by post or consignment is exported;
Recommendation 19, require the identification of customers in transactions for the sale and purchase of bullion through bullion dealers;
Recommendation 20, make administrative decisions under the FTR Act reviewable under the AD(JR) Act;
Recommendation 21, exempt FTR information from the FoI Act.

SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO INDIVIDUAL RECOMMENDATIONS

Recommendation 1: The Committee recommends that AUSTRAC should engage only in those activities which are clearly and unequivocally allowed under the relevant Act. Where there is doubt about an action it proposes to take it should seek the enactment of legislation that unquestionably supports it. For example, it should ensure it has legislative authority to participate in NCA task forces. (Para 3.25)
Response:

The Government agrees that AUSTRAC must engage only in activities allowed under the FTR Act. The Government does not accept that the inference can properly be drawn from the Committee's recommendation that AUSTRAC has acted ultra vires the powers conferred upon it by the FTR Act. Where there is any doubt whether an action is allowed, legal advice will be obtained. Advice has been obtained that AUSTRAC is able to participate in NCA task forces subject to it being made clear that AUSTRAC has no investigative role.

Recommendation 2: The Committee recommends that the reporting threshold for significant cash transaction reports should not be allowed to erode significantly through inflation. To achieve this the threshold should be adjusted periodically after consultation with cash dealers. The aim of the adjustment should be to maintain the threshold at, or near, the present amount in real terms. (Para 4.22)
Response:

The Government accepts the recommendation and, because of the current very low rate of inflation, notes that making a deposit of $10,000 in cash into an account is still a significant and unusual transaction (not only for an individual). As the Committee noted, adjusting the threshold would add to the costs of cash dealers, because of the need to rewrite computer software for electronic reporting. The situation will continue to be monitored. The Government accepts the Committee's counsel that efforts must be taken to contain the costs imposed upon cash dealers.

Recommendation 3: The Committee recommends that those cash dealers engaging in a sufficient number of significant cash transactions to warrant the measure should endeavour to provide the reports by electronic means. (Para 4.22)
Response:

The Government agrees with this recommendation. To their credit, banks and other financial institutions have voluntarily reported data electronically to AUSTRAC. This means that the cost of reporting, both for the cash dealers and for the Government has been much less over time than it would have been if paper reporting had been used. The data reported electronically is subjected to appropriate safeguards including encryption.

Recommendation 4: The Committee recommends that suspect reporting be retained in its present form. Privacy interests should be better protected than at present by adopting Recommendations 7-10 below. (Para 5.39)
Response:
The Government accepts this recommendation.

Recommendation 5: The Committee recommends that the present account opening requirements of the FTR Act should no longer be a mandatory minimum procedure. Instead the Act should impose upon cash dealers an obligation to take reasonable steps to satisfy themselves of the identity of signatories to an account. The present mandatory procedures should become standard procedures to apply in most cases. Cash dealers should have the discretion to depart from the standard procedures where the circumstances so warrant. The onus should be on the cash dealer to prove that the circumstances warranted a departure from the standard procedure and that in its opinion the customer's identity has been established. (Para 6.30)
Response:
The Government accepts Recommendation 5.

The Ministerial Advisory Committee has been asked to put forward proposals for procedures to give effect to this recommendation. Wide ranging consultations on the details of the proposals will be undertaken.

Recommendation 6: AUSTRAC should have the function, and the necessary resources, to audit the performance of cash dealers in complying with the statutory duty to satisfy themselves of the identity of their customers. (Para 6.30)
Response:
The Government accepts Recommendation 6, as flowing from Recommendation 5.

Recommendation 7: The Committee recommends that the FTR Act be amended so that ATO no longer has a right of access to FTR data but has access to FTR data on the same basis as law enforcement agencies, that is, on the basis of a Memorandum of Understanding entered into with the Director, AUSTRAC. (Para 7.28)
Response:

The Government acknowledges the important issues raised in the background to this recommendation and believes that privacy and secrecy arrangements already in place satisfy the thrust of the recommendation that the ATO not have an untrammelled right of access to FTR information. The ATO has agreed upon a Memorandum of Understanding with AUSTRAC and now accesses data on the same basis as Commonwealth law enforcement agencies.
Recommendation 8: The Committee recommends that a "civil liberties representative" be appointed to the Ministerial Advisory Committee on the FTR Act. (Para 7.32)
Response:
The Government accepts this recommendation. The Ministerial Advisory Committee has been asked to make a recommendation about an appropriate appointment.

Recommendation 9: The Committee recommends that the advice of the Privacy Commissioner be sought by the Director of AUSTRAC whether to appoint a civil liberties representative either to an existing AUSTRAC advisory committee, or to establish a separate advisory committee on privacy and civil liberties issues. (Para 7.32)
Response:
The Government accepts this recommendation.

Recommendation 10: The Committee recommends that the FTR Act be amended to give the Director of AUSTRAC power to authorise the deletion of FTR information from the AUSTRAC database in appropriate circumstances. (Para 7.35)
Response:

The Government accepts this recommendation and the persuasiveness of the Committee's reasons. Legislative amendment will be required to implement the recommendation. However, the Government believes that the deletion of FTR information should occur only in accordance with guidelines developed by the Director in consultation with appropriate parties including law enforcement agencies, revenue agencies and the Privacy Commissioner. The reporting requirements leading to the creation of FTR information have not been in existence long enough to establish pattens of usage and usefulness of FTR information. The Government has decided to defer implementation of the recommendation until a reasonable and practicable period for the usual use of FTR information has been clarified. The Government would expect the recommendation to be implemented gradually.
Recommendation 11: The Committee recommends that the Department of Social Security not be given access to FTR information. (Para 8.15)
Response:
The Government accepts this recommendation.

Recommendation 12: The Committee recommends that State and Territory revenue authorities be given access to FTR information on the basis of a Memorandum of Understanding to be entered into with the Director of AUSTRAC and subject to such conditions as the Director requires. The Director should ensure that access is permitted only to a small number of key officers of each authority. Access should be permitted only if the authority undertakes to comply with privacy safeguards equivalent to the IPPs and satisfies the Director of AUSTRAC that the FTR information will be rigorously protected by it. (Para 8.22)
Response:
The Government accepts this recommendation.
Recommendation 13: The Committee recommends that Commonwealth law enforcement agencies better utilise the AUSTRAC database to obtain maximum benefit in the pursuit of major crime. (Para 9.47)
Response:
The Government accepts that AUSTRAC's database should be fully utilised by Commonwealth law enforcement agencies in the pursuit of major crime.
Recommendation 14: The Committee notes the sparing use of the full range of AUSTRAC information by the ATO. The Committee recommends that the ATO review its application of resources to:

PARA.TAB: the training of ATO officers;
the further development of the relationship between AUSTRAC and ATO; and
the usage of AUSTRAC information by its officers

SPEECH.PARA: to maximise the benefit to the revenue from the use of AUSTRAC information. (Para 9.65)
Response:

The Government acknowledges the Committee's concern and accepts its recommendation. This issue is already being addressed by the ATO which is upgrading and evaluating systems and processes to make more efficient and effective use of FTR information.

Recommendation 15: The Committee recommends that a definition of `transaction' be inserted in the Act to make clear that an uncompleted transaction is caught by the reporting requirements of the Act. (Para 10. 17)
Response:
The Government accepts this recommendation. Legislation will be required to give effect to this recommendation.
Recommendation 16: The Committee recommends that the best way to deal with the protection of the identity of tellers as witnesses is:

PARA.TAB: agreements between AUSTRAC and law enforcement agencies be drawn up along the lines of the draft agreement with the AFP referred to at para 10.26;
the essence of such agreements be taken into account by the DPP;
State law enforcement agencies and prosecuting authorities should be encouraged to take the same approach;

at the same time legislative protection for the identity of the officer who initiates a suspect report should be provided in the FTR Act, but without excluding the possibility of calling the relevant officer in those few cases where it may prove to be necessary. (Para 10.28)

SPEECH.PARA: Response:
The Government accepts this recommendation. The Ministerial Advisory Committee has been asked for its views on how best to achieve protection of tellers.

Recommendation 17: The Committee considers that there should not be strict liability under section 31. It should be required that the prosecution establish that the defendant conducted the relevant transactions with the intent of evading the reporting requirements of the FTR Act. (Para 10.38)
Response:

The Government accepts that the creation of a strict liability offence may in certain circumstances infringe civil liberties. It is the Government's policy to legislate on the basis of strict liability only if this is justified by the inherent difficulty of proving the mental element in respect of the offence. Although the offence created by s3l is formulated without reference to a mental element, it has been established by the decision of the High Court in He Kaw Teh v The Queen (1985) 157 CLR 528 that where a statute defines an offence by reference only to external elements and does not refer to any mental state, there is a presumption that mens rea is an essential element of the offence. The presumption may be displaced by consideration of matters such as the subject matter of the offence and whether strict liability would facilitate enforcement. In so far as the offence of structuring created by s3l requires an objective assessment of the culpability of the alleged offender, taking into account any explanation for the manner or form of the transactions proffered by that person, the Government is of the view that the provision in its current form impliedly incorporates an element of mens rea. Accordingly, the Government does not consider the common law presumption to have been displaced in the case of this offence, and considers the current formulation of the provision to be the most appropriate formulation to achieve the objects of the legislation.
Recommendation 18: The Committee recommends that section 15 be amended:

PARA.TAB: to increase the reporting threshold for import or export of currency to $10,000, and
to define the point at which currency transferred by post or consignment should be deemed to have been exported. (Para 10.44)

SPEECH.PARA: Response:
The Government accepts the Committee's recommendation. Both matters will need to be addressed by legislation.

Recommendation 19: The Committee recommends that the FTR Act be amended to require the identification of customers in transactions for the sale and purchase of bullion through bullion dealers. (Para 10.50)
Response:

The Government accepts this recommendation. Consultation with the industry will be undertaken to determine the best means of implementation. Legislation will be required to give effect to this recommendation.

Recommendation 20: The Committee recommends that section 42 of the FTR Act be amended so that administrative decisions made under the Act are reviewable under the AD(JR) Act. The advice of the Administrative Review Council should be sought as to whether certain decisions should be included in Schedule 2 of the AD(JR) Act so that reasons for decisions may not be required. (Para 10.53)
Response:

The Government does not agree to this Recommendation. The existing arrangements regarding judicial review, including s42 of the FTR Act have been operating satisfactorily so that changes at this stage are not warranted.
Recommendation 21: The Committee recommends that FTR information be specifically exempted from FoI under section 38 of the FoI Act by appropriate amendment to the FTR Act. (Para 10.55)
Response:

The Government accepts the importance of protecting FTR material and has examined how best to do this without infringing basic FoI principles. It is proposed to protect FTR material in the manner adopted to protect material relating to the protection of witnesses by appropriate legislative amendment.
Recommendation 22: The Committee recommends that the definition of `cash dealer' in the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988 not be widened to include solicitors. (Para 11.25)
Response:

The Government notes that the reporting obligation on cash dealers is to report to AUSTRAC `suspect' transactions, `significant' transactions ($10,000 and above in cash) and international funds transfer instructions, and to verify the identity of account holders as well as to maintain various records. The Government accepts that it is not appropriate to require legal practitioners to report `suspect' transactions, (this would be difficult to reconcile with the responsibility of a solicitor to assert legal professional privilege), to verify the identity of their clients, or to report international funds transfer instructions. However, the Government proposes to require legal practitioners to report to AUSTRAC transactions in cash (currency) of $10,000 and above with their clients, including in the report particulars of the identity of the client as known to them. Such a report involves only objective facts and does not require legal practitioners to form opinions or suspicions about the affairs of their clients. Further, there will be no requirement for legal practitioners to go behind their clients' backs, as, in the unusual case where a transaction involves $10,000 in cash, the practitioner may, and can be expected to, advise the client of the requirement for the report.
Recommendation 23: The Committee recommends that the FTR Act be reviewed again in a further three years. (Para 11.27)
Response:
The Government accepts the principle of periodic review, but given the time needed to examine and implement recommendations made, considers that a five year interval is more appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee entitled Cashing in on the Sydney Olympics: Protecting the Sydney Olympic Games from ambush marketing, and I seek leave to incorporate the response in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: As well as providing $150 million towards the cost of staging the Sydney Games and up to $25 million toward the cost of the Paralympics, the Commonwealth Government will provide $140 million to sport in 1995-96. This includes $46 million to Olympic sport through the "Maintain the Momentum" program and the "Olympic Athlete" program ($135 million over six years) which is designed to ensure the best possible preparation of Australia's athletes for the Atlanta and Sydney Games. The Federal Government is making a substantial contribution to the preparation of Olympic and Paralympic athletes ($263 million in total) and therefore to the success of the Sydney Games.
1. Additional measures to be taken to secure commercial property rights for the Games organisers in the Olympic words and symbols.

Agreed. The Government will develop legislation aimed at preventing the unauthorised use of Sydney Games Indicia, in order to protect the sponsorship revenue of the Sydney Olympic and Paralympic Games. The rights in the Indicia will vest in the Games Organisers—the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games (SOCOG) in respect of the Olympics and the Sydney Paralympics Organising Committee (SPOC) in respect of the Paralympics.

2. A publicity campaign to inform the public including consumers and marketers of the additional and extraordinary measures which are to be taken to protect the Olympic words and symbols. The campaign should also assist the public to clearly identify Olympic sponsors so that if individuals wish to make a purchase to support the Olympic Games, they can do so with confidence.

The Commonwealth sees the announced response to the Senate inquiry and any publicity associated with the introduction and passage of legislation through Parliament as contributing toward this objective. Beyond that, the Government sees this as essentially the responsibility of the Games organisers. The Government considers that immediate and public exposure of Companies that are considered to be engaging in ambush marketing would be an effective deterrent to other companies considering similar conduct.

3. That specific purpose legislative measures be introduced to facilitate the Olympic organisers' ability to seek and obtain urgent injunctions to stop any contravention. The Canadian legislation provides a model for such a provision. The provision could provide a statutory presumption that [a breach of] the rights conferred upon the organisers would occasion immediate and irreparable damage to the organisers.

Agreed. The legislation that the Government proposes will provide the Games organisers and the official sponsors with the ability to seek and obtain urgent injunctions from the Federal Court. The Government also considers that it would be sensible to confer jurisdiction on State and Territory Supreme Courts and will consult with State and Territory Governments in the near future to this end.
4. That the Courts be able to make an order requiring an offender to place corrective advertisements.
Agreed. The legislation that the Government proposes will provide that the Courts will also be able to award damages.

5. The Committee supports the protection of a range of protected words, sounds and images along the lines proposed by the joint NSW and SOCOG submission. The Committee recommends that the following expressions be protected:

PARA.TAB: (a) the combination of the word "24th", "Twenty-Fourth" or "XXIVth" and the word "Olympic" or "Olympics" or "Games"; or
(b) the combination of the word "27th", "Twenty-Seventh" or "XXVII" and the word "Olympiad"; or
(c) the phrase "Share the Spirit"; or
(d) the combination of the word "Games" and the number "2000" or the words "Two Thousand"; or
(e) the phrase "Games City"; or
(f) the phrase "Summer Games"; or
(g) the phrase "Sydney Games"; or
(h) the phrase "Millennium Games".

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed. The legislation that the Government proposes will protect these expressions against unauthorised commercial use which is likely to convey a connection with the Sydney 2000 Olympics or Paralympics, their organisers and other associated parties.
6. The Committee recommends that the following words be protected (words in List A combined with words in List B):
OlympicBronze
OlympicsGames
OlympiadGold
OlympianGreen and Gold
ParalympicMedals
ParalympicsMillennium
ParalympianSilver

PARA.TAB: Spirit
Sponsor
Summer
Sydney

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed. The Government will protect these words against unauthorised commercial use which is likely to convey a connection with the Sydney 2000 Olympics or Paralympics, their organisers and other associated parties. The words "Two thousand" and "2000" will be added to List B, in order that the expressions such as "Two Thousand Olympics" or "Olympics 2000" are protected.
7. The Committee recommends the protection of Sydney Games images or sounds used in a context which would to the ordinary person represent a connection with the following:

PARA.TAB: (a) Sydney Games bodies;
(b) The Sydney 2000 Olympics;
(c) The Sydney 2000 Paralympics;
(d) Any activities arranged by or in connection with the Sydney Games bodies, the Sydney 2000 Olympics or the Sydney 2000 Paralympics; or
(e) Any Sydney Olympic Sites and Buildings.

SPEECH.PARA: "Sydney Games images or sounds" means any image or sound evoking the Sydney 2000 Games, Sydney 2000 Paralympic Games, teams attending the Sydney 2000 Games and Sydney 2000 Paralympic Games and any athletes who are members of such teams.
"Sydney Games Bodies" includes the SOCOG, IOC, AOC, City, the Government of New South Wales, IPC, SPOC.

The Government reserves its position on this recommendation. Such wide ranging protection would leave the discretion of who to target with the Games' organisers, with the potential for overzealous use and the pursuit of people for legitimate activities. It will also be necessary to take into account the rights acquired in images or sounds under present intellectual property laws, including the Copyright Act and the Trade Marks Act. The Government has therefore asked officials to consider whether it would be possible to frame legislation which addresses the Games organisers' concerns in this area, without having unintended application to acceptable activities. The New South Wales Government and Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games will be consulted in the development of the legislation and will be able to assist the Government in attempting to frame appropriate legislation. Should the Government decide to include a provision related to this recommendation, the Australian Paralympic Federation will be treated in the same manner as other "Sydney Games Bodies".
8. That the special measures recommended in Recommendations 5, 6 and 7 cease to have effect after 30 June 2001.

The Government agrees that the legislation should have a fixed term of effect. Official sponsors will be granted rights to indicia associated with the Games until 31 December 2000. As the intention of the legislation is to boost the sponsorship revenue by giving sponsors confidence that their rights are protected, the legislation becomes redundant when the sponsors cease to have those rights. The Government therefore intends that the legislation will cease to have effect on 31 December 2000.

9. Appropriately drafted exemptions be provided in any legislative measures to protect the Olympic words and symbols. Exemptions should permit the continued use of designations lawfully used prior to the enactment of the legislation, for press reportage and for dissemination of factual information relating to the services.

Agreed. There will also be an exemption to allow for "criticism and review" of the Games and provision for exemption for sporting organisations to be implemented if the SOCOG does not meet their reasonable needs for promotion and fundraising through the preparation of memoranda of understanding. Effective and targeted tourism and marketing activities that complement the activities of the SOCOG will play an important part in ensuring an effective Sydney Games. If further investigation shows that memoranda of understanding between tourism bodies and the SOCOG are appropriate, similar provision for the implementation of exemptions if the tourism bodies' reasonable needs are not met would be required. The terms of such memoranda (or exemption) will have to take account of the terms of the Host City Contract.

10. That the exemption for existing users of affected marks be lost if the marks are not used commercially for a period of 6 months to one year. That the exemption for existing users extend only to the use of the words and marks in the same class as the goods currently used.

Agreed in principle. The provisions should be consistent with the Trade Marks Act. The exemption for existing users should extend to the use of the affected marks in respect of the same goods or services as those currently traded under the mark, and in respect of goods or services similar to those currently traded under the mark. Users of affected marks will need to show cause why they should not lose the right to the affected mark if it has not been used commercially for three years. The exemption will apply only to where use commenced prior to 28 June 1995.

11. That the exemption provided for the dissemination of information by businesses advertising factual statements of services in connection with the Games but not so as to imply or give the impression of an official sponsorship connection where none exists.
Agreed.
12. That freedom of political communication be ensured.
Agreed.
13. That additional measures be taken under the Customs Act to seek to limit the possibility of the importation of goods which inappropriately seek to ambush market the Olympic Games.

Not agreed. Controls under the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations or the Customs Act, while to the commercial advantage of a limited number of licensed entrepreneurs, would be extremely intrusive to legitimate importers by retarding the movement of cargo, as well as being resource intensive and expensive to administer. The Government considers that appropriate new Customs measures based on comparable provisions in the trade marks and copyright legislation should be implemented in the proposed new legislation. The expressions proposed to be protected under this legislation consist of elements of trade marks and copyright matter and should be subject to similar controls.
14. That appropriate planning and training exercises be developed for Customs Officers and any relevant State Government agencies.

Agreed. Customs and other Commonwealth and State Government agencies must be provided with appropriate training once enforcement requirements have been identified. Responsibility for provision of the training should be determined at that time also.

15. The Committee recommends the amendment of the Olympic Insignia Protection Act to extend the protection of the proposed expanded list of protected words as requested by the AOC, but subject to appropriate exemptions for existing users.

Not agreed. The Government accepts the need to provide protection of certain words and symbols, in order to protect the revenue of the Sydney 2000 Olympics. It does not, however, consider it appropriate that there be any further extension of the protection available under that Act to protect names or abbreviations of the names International Olympic Committee (IOC) or Australian Olympic Committee (AOC). The Government will, however, consult further with the AOC and SOCOG regarding the protection of the words "Olympic", "Olympiad" and "Olympic Games" for the period up to the year 2000.
16. The Committee recommends that the SOCOG monitor applications for trade marks internationally to object to ones which breach the Games organisers' rights in the Olympic words and symbols.

The Government notes that this recommendation is directed at the SOCOG. Australian individuals and organisations would have no right to object to the application for trade marks under another country's legislation. Even if overseas companies were to obtain trade marks, none of the goods produced as a result could be imported into Australia if they breached the Australian legislation.

17. The Committee recommends that the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee monitor the implementation of the specific legislation once enacted. The Committee should consider whether the legislation is having any unintended consequences on business and whether additional measures should be introduced. The Committee should receive its reference two years before the Sydney Games.

The question of references to the Committee is a matter for the Senate. While the Government would have no objection to this proposal, it reserves the right to act earlier if the need becomes apparent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I should let the committee know that I will not be proceeding with all of the amendments circulated in my name. I will not be proceeding with items 1 to 8. They were consequential matters related to the sales tax on cars but, as that was not successful, they are no longer relevant. Therefore, I move:

PARA.TAB: Schedule 9, pages 12 to 14, omit the Schedule.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine made some excellent comments in the second reading debate about a taxpayer being able to seek redress through the common law. The government is claiming it wants to remove the right to seek sales tax refunds at common law. We believe that the right to seek refunds of tax is enshrined in the common law of Australia. It is a right that is not given or granted by government but is a right accepted by the people as being just. Taxpayers should only ever be required to pay the level of tax imposed by parliament. Taxpayers must always be able to enforce that right. The possibility of an action to recover moneys paid as tax where no tax was payable prevents the unjust enrichment of the revenue authorities. The possibility of the action is important to ensure that revenue authorities are only able to retain that which the parliament has determined they may collect. I ask the government: why is it moving this way, why now, and why sales tax only?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is opposing the amendment moved by Senator Gibson. I am not sure what the other parties in the chamber are doing about this but I hope they will see the merit of the government's position and, when it comes to the point, vote against the opposition's amendment.

PARA.TAB: The opposition proposes to remove the provision that would limit refunds to those grounds specified in the sales tax law. The need for the amendment which this legislation is proposing has arisen because several actions have been commenced seeking refunds of sales tax under the common law. The litigants who have commenced these actions have done so because they are unable to satisfy the normal conditions for obtaining a refund under the sales tax law, especially the passing-on rule.

A major factor in the decision to propose these amendments was to prevent windfall gains that could arise by litigants avoiding the passing-on rules. In situations where the taxpayer—that is, the manufacturer or wholesaler—otherwise would benefit at the expense of his or her customers, the government considers it preferable that the gains should be retained by the government to be applied for public purposes rather than contributing to the profit of the wholesaler or manufacturer.

The refund provisions are subject to certain conditions. One condition is that the passing-on rule has been satisfied—that is, that the cost of the tax has been borne by the taxpayer or claimant or, if it was recovered from the taxpayer's customers, has been refunded to them. This condition is a longstanding feature of the sales tax law. Without it, taxpayers claiming a refund could make a windfall gain since they could have recovered the tax once from their customers and again from the commissioner.

Another condition is that the applications for refunds must be made within three years of the overpayment. This condition corresponds to a similar restriction on the commissioner whereby he is generally unable to collect sales tax properly payable more than three years after it was due. This is to provide certainty for taxpayers that their past taxation obligations have been settled and certainty for the revenue.

It should be noted that the government's proposal does not alter any rights that consumers have against the government. The amendments remove the rights that sales taxpayers—that is, wholesalers and manufacturers—may have against the government, since they are the ones who are liable to pay sales tax.

Those are the reasons the government has advanced for these amendments to the legislation. I wanted those reasons to be clearly on the record. I apologise to Senator Gibson that I did not note all his questions. I may have answered some of them by making a more detailed explanation. I may not have; I suspect the latter is true. If it is, please ask your questions again.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to detail for the record the decision of the High Court in the Royal Insurance Australia case because it is an important matter, as the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) acknowledged. I made a number of points in principle in my speech this morning which go to the very heart of parliamentary democracy, the equality of rights of citizens under the law and the duty of parliament to uphold those rights against the Crown.

PARA.TAB: The background to this matter is that the High Court in the Royal Insurance Australia case has held that a taxing act confers no authority upon the commissioner to levy, demand or retain any moneys otherwise than in payment of duties and charges imposed by or pursuant to the act. This is plain commonsense. As I pointed out in my speech this morning, if it were otherwise, we would be back to the days of taxation by royal prerogative.

It is true that there is a statutory scheme for refunds of sales tax but this statutory scheme is subject to limitations, as honourable senators know. A major limitation is that the wholesale sales taxpayer must satisfy the commissioner that he either bore the overpaid tax or, if passed on to him by another, has refunded that tax. In other words, the sales taxpayer has no economic interest in most circumstances in challenging any wrongful decision of the Taxation Office. Who would go to the expense of litigation to get a refund for somebody else?

The legislation makes a choice as to who is the taxpayer, namely, the wholesaler. It does not prescribe a scheme for passing on tax, although the economic influences will usually, but not always, generate such a result. If the legislation does not prescribe such a scheme for passing on the tax, it seems curious that there would be a scheme for passing on refunds.

Consider what really happens in practice. The commissioner decides that something is no longer exempt or is now taxable at a different, higher classification. He then demands tax from wholesalers. They have two choices: they can accede to his demands and pay; or they can refuse to pay. If they refuse to pay, he can seize their cash flow by garnisheeing their debtors and send them bankrupt. This occurred in the Brayson Motors case—the Taxation Office sent them bankrupt. The commissioner can force them into liquidation before the courts have finally adjudicated on whether any sales tax is owing.

That is a very important point for honourable senators to focus upon: the taxation commissioner can force a company into liquidation before the courts have finally adjudicated on whether any sales tax is owing. In the Brayson Motors case, the taxpayer was put into liquidation and later on the High Court held that no tax was payable. The taxpayer had no legal right to compensation for the damage caused to his business because the commissioner had acted within his statutory powers in garnisheeing its cash flow.

Faced with the Brayson Motors precedent, few taxpayers would refuse to pay any sales tax demanded by the commissioner no matter how vigorously they disagreed with his interpretation of the law and no matter how wrong-headed the commissioner's opinion might be. From a commercial point of view, they would have no choice; they would cave in.

Having paid, they may litigate the matter. It may be years before the courts finally decide the matter and, if the courts decide in favour of the taxpayer, the commissioner will then seek to use the statutory scheme for refunds to deprive the taxpayer of any benefit from his challenge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why would anyone go into small business if they had to go through this? You would have to be a hero.

—Exactly. Many taxpayers will not be able to prove either that they bore the tax or that they passed on refunds. Anybody that has been in business, as Senator Boswell has, would know that elementary fact.

PARA.TAB: Thousands of transactions may have occurred and they are expected to set up an administrative apparatus to refund moneys to customers who may have gone out of business, moved on or been lost track of. Effectively, therefore, the sales tax payer, unlike the income tax payer, is placed in a position where it is virtually pointless to challenge a wrong decision by the Commissioner of Taxation. This means that in practice the Taxation Office can, to a large extent, impose taxation without parliamentary approval—and that is the nub of it—because nobody will challenge him.

The only cases where it is likely that somebody might challenge him could be where a wholesaler is a subsidiary of a large retailer. I raised a number of questions in the estimates committee about this matter and honourable senators may have had the opportunity of perusing the responses that came from the Commissioner of Taxation. In answer to these questions, the Taxation Office argued that the conditions on refunds do not allow the commissioner to be unjustly enriched. Rather they are designed to prevent the taxpayer from recovering the relevant tax twice: firstly, in the sales price; and, secondly, by way of unfettered refund from the Commonwealth. This answer clearly misses the point.

If no-one has an economic interest in challenging the commissioner and is thus deterred from doing so, the commissioner is unjustly enriched because he has taken money without parliamentary authority by levying an unlawful tax. If that is not unjust enrichment of the revenue, I don't know what is.

What is being ignored by the Taxation Office is that where a taxpayer recovers money under common law, that taxpayer is equally open to a claim by its customers for restitution in appropriate cases. That has been made clear by the High Court—the Taxation Office knows that. It is a matter between themselves and the fact that they may have rights between themselves is no excuse for the commissioner to avoid his liability to refund moneys unlawfully taken.

In any case, I note that we are dealing with trade practices in the competition policy bill. There is no reason why, in an appropriate case, the Trade Practices Commission in its expanded form could not take action to assist third parties to assert their claims to shares of refunds.

It lies ill in the mouth of someone who has extorted money unlawfully to argue that he should not have to give it back because, really, it belongs to somebody else. That is what the Commissioner of Taxation is saying. He has extorted the money and his argument is, `We are not going to give it back to the wholesaler because it belongs to somebody, or it might belong to somebody else.' That argument is not accepted in the case of ordinary theft and I see no reason why it should be any more acceptable here. If I cannot refuse to give back money when a mortgage repayment is demanded because the money really belongs to the depositors, why should the commissioner?

This is a very serious matter of principle and it is one in which the parliament itself is entitled to exercise its decision to ensure that the Commissioner of Taxation is not in effect permitted to retain taxes which are then seen to have been unlawfully garnered.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I may return to this matter, I congratulate Senator Harradine. I totally agree with the comments he made earlier today in the second reading on the principles involved. We also totally agree with the comments he made just now on the actual detail which he set out very clearly and logically. I do not need to say any more except that that is basically what the coalition is concerned about: we believe the availability of access to the common law should be retained.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —In commenting on what Senator Harradine said, I am not sure that these things may well persuade him to alter his view, but since he has had such an extensive intervention, it is appropriate for the government to reply, out of respect, to some of the points that he raised.
—It is hopefully more than out of respect.
—And because of the merit of the issue that is under debate.
—Intellectual rigour is the test you set in competition policy.
—I am being urged to look at various levels of why I should comment. Let me pick them all up and comment if I may be allowed to get to the commentary part.

PARA.TAB: The amendment before the committee is one to knock out schedule 9 of this bill. It is worthwhile looking at what schedule 9 does and what its removal would imply. As I read schedule 9 in relation to the rest of the bill, this relates to areas where the taxpayer has overpaid the amount of taxation due to him or her and wishes to seek recovery. We are talking about wholesale sales tax. So the taxpayer in this case is the wholesaler or the manufacturer and that wholesaler or manufacturer is working under a system of self-assessment. That is, they assess for themselves the right level of taxation and pay it. Usually, having done that, the standard practice is for them to pass on to their customers who are retailers the cost of taxation embedded in the final price of the product that they sell.

Where that has occurred, they have recovered the cost to them of paying, in this case, more tax than they ought to have paid. The question is, having recovered that, whether they should have the right of a further action to recover it again from the Commissioner of Taxation. The amendment says, in effect, that those who have recovered it once cannot recover it twice. On that basis, there would be general agreement that it cannot be recovered twice. That model of explanation sits reasonably. No-one would uphold the principle of double recovery. So far so good. No-one has nodded their head, but everybody is looking searchingly at me. I take that as leave to continue to the next stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is beside the point.
—It is the point of the amendment. That is why I am trying to make the point as clearly and succinctly as I can.

PARA.TAB: The next point is that, assuming the manufacturer or wholesaler has passed on a higher than necessary tax payment to the retailer, and assuming that the retailer has passed that to another manufacturer and it goes all the way through to the customer, is there a right of the individual customer to recover? That is more along the lines of what Senator Harradine is talking about. The assumption underpinning this argument is that there is fair transmittal through the process to the customer and the ultimate consumer and that the ultimate consumer picks up the full tab. I do not think in all honesty that argument can be sustained as being what happens in a working economy. I will give an example.

Automotive component manufacturers, as wholesalers, may sell their manufactured goods to General Motors, Toyota, Ford, Mitsubishi or another manufacturer of vehicles. They put the products into their motor vehicle and sell to retailers, who then sell to customers. How would one differentiate the right of the individual consumer to recover the cost? Can one assume that at each stage of the transmittal the full cost has been passed on?

This is interesting, and a worthwhile example for this reason. We have a contestable motor vehicle industry in Australia. The major four producers compete with one another over price, quality and after sales service. Price is an important part of that competition. No-one can be sure, for example, that General Motors has not absorbed part of the cost of the original componentry in its profit margin in order to win market share. One cannot at each stage track this perfectly or be sure what has been decided at each stage of the process. In the end, we cannot be sure of the consumer rights, if there is such a thing as consumer rights.

We have a contestable manufacturing market in Australia. Individual wholesalers or manufacturers are in a market in which they are contesting in their field with other individual wholesalers or manufacturers. The issue of price often concerns whether it is absorbed now or at the next stage of the process. I do not understand how anyone can be sure about identifying what the real cost in these circumstances might be and what the right of the individual consumer might be, if there is one, let alone how a bureaucracy is expected to divine this fact. All I can say, therefore, is that the fairest way of doing it is the way we have proposed to do it.

I tried to follow Senator Harradine's intervention in great detail. It was a considered intervention. He referred in part to a situation where there has been an underpayment of wholesale sales tax and an action by the tax officer to recover that underpayment. It is not for me to contend with him in terms of whether the Taxation Office sent someone under.

The first principle I would base my case on is that there is an obligation on all taxpayers, whosoever they are, to pay the full and correct amount of taxation. If someone has not and there is a claim, the normal process at the Taxation Office is to ask for 50 per cent of what is in contest, not the whole amount, while the argument is being resolved.

I understand that to be the normal process, which is a reasonable one, given that a fundamental obligation of the Taxation Office is that the Taxation Office should be seen like the statue we see on top of courts: it should be blindfolded, with a sword in one hand and a scale in the other. It should recover the full amount of tax fairly across the board from everybody and not make special exceptions. As soon as a special exception is made, all other taxpayers who are paying the full freight will ask, `If they can get away with it, why do we have to pay the full amount?' The whole principle of taxation then becomes unravelled.

I will come back to the point of Senator Harradine's intervention as I understood it. Where a taxpayer has underpaid, there is recovery afoot by the Commissioner of Taxation and there is a contest as to what the right amount might be, the habit of the Taxation Office is to ask for 50 per cent of that until the issue is settled. In some cases—

TALK.START.PARA: —But what if they are wrong?
—If they are wrong, it will be settled by a process in the end.
—After the business is bankrupted by the High Court case.

—With great respect, that suggests that the tax commissioner is driven by capricious motives and capriciously seeks to bring that about. There is an obligation on the taxpayer, particularly under self-assessment, to try to pay the right amount of tax. That is a fundamental obligation that we all have.

PARA.TAB: I know that the Taxation Office is not everyone's favourite cup of tea. I know that taxes are the one thing in life that are certain along with death and that everyone hates the day when they have to pay their tax. Nonetheless, the government has an obligation to have a system of payment which is fair and which applies equally to everybody. All I can say in answer is that there may be occasions on which people have miscalculated their tax and that, when they have to finally pay it, it affects their status in terms of their ability to continue trading.

It may also be that there are other good reasons in the marketplace why they cannot continue trading anyway. It should never be the case that they should be subsidised through the tax system. There might be an argument for them to be subsidised in some other way; that is perhaps a question of industry policy. There might be an argument that rescue packages should be put in place. However, there cannot be any argument that the tax system should be manipulated as a means of subsidy.

I have taken a lot of time; I apologise to the Senate for that. I have tried to explain the government's case as clearly and succinctly as I am able. I will differentiate this amendment from the argument that Senator Harradine has put. In terms of this amendment, where there has been an overpayment of tax, the principle here is that taxpayers who have overpaid and have had a recovery effected so that their overpayment is neutralised ought not be able to recover again and thus achieve two recoveries. Therefore, a wholesaler who has passed on the cost should not be able to recover against the Taxation Office.

A wholesaler who has passed on the cost and has then returned the extra cost passed on to customers so that the customer is not affected has a case to recover from the Taxation Office. Wholesalers who have not passed on their tax have a case to recover from the Taxation Office. But wholesalers who have passed on their tax and been rewarded ought not be able to recover. That is the issue that is being debated here. That is why the government sticks with its position.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Senator Harradine still has a number of statements to make. In view of the statements made by the minister, I ask: Has there been, to anybody's knowledge, a case so far when the common law remedies available in terms of overpayment of tax or unlawful taxing by the government or by the commissioner has resulted in the taxpayer gaining twice; in other words, double dipping? What is the rationale that common law will enable a taxpayer to double dip?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to Senator Margetts; I was speaking to the advisers on another point, but I understand her question, as relayed to me by those who were listening, to be: Has there been a court case in which the common law right referred to by Senator Harradine has been upheld concerning sales tax.

—Perhaps I can clarify. Has there been any court case resolved that has enabled a taxpayer to double dip on sales tax? If not, what is the legal basis upon which you are suggesting that the current common law remedies will enable a taxpayer to double dip on sales tax?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part is no, there has not been a court case which has upheld the right of anyone to double dip on sales tax.

PARA.TAB: As to the second part of the question, we want schedule 9 to remain in the bill to prevent that possibility in the future and to put the issue clearly and openly beyond doubt so that the Commissioner of Taxation can be sure that he or she collects the full amount of taxation and there is no double dipping.

Senator Harradine asked whether or not there is any common law right by an individual consumer. I have some notes which are worthwhile referring to. There is doubt as to whether the common law right that it is alleged we propose to take away does, in fact, exist. The amendment arises because of the government's desire to clarify the situation and to put it beyond doubt. By not taking away this right it might be, depending on whether the right actually exists, that the wholesaler can recover from the government.

Senator Harradine then argues that the retailer could recover from the wholesaler and then the consumer could recover from the retailer. This is untested at law. The only guarantee is that the consumer and retailer trying to exercise their rights will involve a lot of litigation. That is a fair enough observation. Litigation will increase as you go down the chain. If we consider how complex this chain might be, I am not sure that at any stage of that chain a court could reasonably make a judgement about what part is passed or what part is absorbed. My advisers inform me that there is doubt whether a common law right that has been referred to does exist.

TALK.START.PARA: —How could someone double dip under a common law right that does not exist?

—The contention being put is that there is a common law right. The person double dipping is not the consumer; the person double dipping—and to whom the legislation is directed—is the wholesaler or the manufacturer, not the consumer. That is the important principle to remember.

—May I pursue this matter with the minister, please. Regardless of the complications of the transactions involved, the facts are that if there has been an error and a refund is payable to the wholesaler, then he, in turn, is liable for the people that he deals with. That is the fundamental point. What you, the government, are assuming, is that that will never be effected and you want to remove the common law right of the wholesaler. We should not prejudge those people's actions. That is the fundamental thing. It is a very important principle that that right to go to law should be open to the wholesaler.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will pursue this matter a little further. I thought the minister's intervention was largely absolutely correct, with the exception of the last bit about there not being a common law right of the customer, whether that customer be the retailer or the end consumer.

PARA.TAB: But I just want to thank the minister for pointing out the obvious. First of all, the wholesaler, as the minister said, is the one that pays the sales tax. Not, as the minister said, in the manner of self-assessment, willy nilly, but it is assessment on the basis of what is regarded as his or her legal obligation. I will come to that again in a minute. So the wholesaler is liable to pay the tax.

What the minister is saying is, in this period of competition, particularly as we are entering a further period of competition, how can anyone know that that wholesaler has passed on to the retailer the full percentage of the taxation that that wholesaler has paid to the Taxation Commissioner? With respect, that is an argument for accepting the amendment moved by Senator Gibson. What the minister is saying now is that we should abolish the common law right of the wholesaler to claim a refund unless that wholesaler can prove that he has passed on, or will pass on, that amount to the retailer.

Clearly, what the minister is saying is that proof, in many cases, is going to be impossible because of the operation of the competitive nature of various businesses. But why, then, Minister, should the taxation department hang on to tax money that has been unlawfully garnered from the wholesaler? That is the point. I come back to what the High Court said in the Royal Insurance case, and we must really have regard to this because it is a major question of law and equality before the law. The High Court decision says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Tax Act confers no authority upon the Commissioner to levy, demand or retain any moneys otherwise than in payment of duties and charges imposed by or pursuant to the Act.

If the wholesaler has assessed his taxation liability to the tax office at a particular level and the Commissioner of Taxation later makes a determination that that is not the appropriate level, it should be a higher level and he should have been paying that higher level over a period of years, and if ultimately that is proved to be wrong, you are saying by this legislation that, although the court has determined that that was an unlawful enrichment of the tax office, the tax office can pocket that money and not refund it as it is required to do under the law as it exists.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in two minds about this amendment, for obvious reasons.
—Unusual for you, isn't it?

—It is very unusual for me. I usually do not come in here with my mind made up. I wait to hear the details, not like some other people. I understand the clash of principles. A lot of this difficulty arises out of the fact that so much tax legislation has to be announced by press release in the first instance. Senator Margetts has an excellent amendment which will deal with that.

PARA.TAB: We are getting a lot of phone calls at the moment about what is going to happen with the building sales tax. People ask whether they should take the advice of the tax office, because the tax office is still out there telling suppliers that the government is going to collect this tax from 1 July and they have to have the paperwork ready.

TALK.START.PARA: —People are buying up stock against the tax rise, too.

—Yes, people are buying up stock. The government might clarify that that is not happening. The same thing happened with the 1993 budget. It happens a lot. I am not a regular basher of the tax office but I wonder whether the tax office needs to factor in and monitor more closely the legislative progress and the politics. A lot of this goes back to that first announcement.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, the principle of access to common law for overpayment is an important principle. I recognise that common law claims for refunds could allow payers of wholesale sales tax, as the minister has said, to obtain a windfall. It is a terrible dilemma. I seriously wish the tax office would present to us some options which deal with this problem, because it has been an ongoing one.

I think the government is anticipating what some accountants have hinted they might be able to do. I made some comments about the culture of accountants in my previous remarks. Here we are again! It is like the diesel fuel rebate and other matters. We are having to put in something in anticipation of something that somebody else might do.

I think the amendment is going to pass. I think Senator Gibson's position will hold, irrespective of what we might do. I urge the tax office to come up with some serious options for dealing with this, rather than denying access to common law claims. Senator Margetts's amendment, which will come later, requires greater publicity of what we are doing here. Publicising the fact that this is a disallowable instrument will actually go a long way to alerting consumers of their rights and responsibilities. What the minister has said is very persuasive. Doing something in anticipation of what accountants might do, given my views on them, is a little dangerous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not rise simply to prolong this debate. Were the interventions of an extension kind I would not rise at all, but this is a serious discussion we are having. It behoves me to say a few things finally. I hope this is the last occasion.

PARA.TAB: I would like to answer one of the matters that Senator Kernot has referred to. It was the subject of a question by Senator Gibson to me at question time. What is happening out there because of the confusion created over the building materials tax—

TALK.START.PARA: —There was an announcement by Mr Willis this afternoon.

—I have just learned that. At question time I was defending vigorously that we would fight this on the beaches, in the trenches, we were not going to surrender one street in the city.
