I understand that, on mature reflection, the Treasurer (Mr Willis) has put out a press release that we will accept the Senate's amendments.
—Wasn't he talking to you?
—No. I reflect his state of mind at the time. At the time I reflected his state of mind, as it is my job to do so.
—The cumulative pressure.
—I am merely the messenger. I represent the Treasurer. I certainly reflected the Treasurer's state of mind as it was at question time.
—So the certainty is now there?

—It might be held that, on a political level, we should have stuck to our guns. The government recognises that there may be some confusion about this. In balancing the political issues against the merit of what affects the lives of people, we have opted—not surprisingly, since we are the Labor Party—for the people's view.
—As they are expressing it to you.

—That is my story. I now turn to the other part and make one last lunge. We are not here prejudging a right. For the information of honourable senators, I table the Treasurer's press release. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TAB.EMPHASIS: The press release read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: WHOLESALE SALES TAX ON CERTAIN BUILDING MATERIALS
The Government will accept the Senate's request to amend sales tax legislation to remove the extension of wholesale sales tax to certain building materials.
It is clear there is no possibility of this measure passing the Senate.
The Senate's action will reduce the Budget surplus by $215 million in 1995-96.
On this measure the minor parties have lined up with the hypocrites of the Coalition who are trying to wreck fiscal policy and stop the Government taking pressure off interest rates.
John Howard and Peter Costello say they support tighter fiscal policy, but they are taking every opportunity to prevent the tightening of fiscal policy.
The loss of the revenue from the rejection of this measure is a move in the wrong direction and will impede our efforts to take pressure off interest rates and reduce the current account deficit.
John Howard is trying to block revenue increases of more than $1 1/2 billion in 1995-96 and $2 1/2 billion in 1996-97.

Mr Howard's hypocrisy knows no bounds. He is also opposing spending cuts affecting non work related childcare and the diesel fuel rebate scheme. In the case of the diesel fuel rebate scheme he is seeking to extend its reach and to increase Government outlays. If he was successful in his dishonest campaign against Government spending reductions, the cost to taxpayers would be $400 million over four years.

Before the Budget, in the April edition of Australian Business Monthly, Mr Howard said: "I say to the Treasurer now, if you want to have substantial spending cuts in the May Budget, you won't have any opposition from us unless you stray into areas of ridiculous sensitivity."
Mr Howard's word is worthless.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to Senator Gibson that we are not trying to prejudge anything here. If all of us here were in business, we would be well-conducted business people and we would deal with these things responsibly. If we passed on the tax charge, we would then refund it to our customers and claim it back from the commissioner. We would be properly affected. If we did not pass it on, if we absorbed it and claimed it from the commissioner, we would get it. If we passed on part of it, we would claim back from the commissioner only that part we did not pass on. If we passed it on and got it back, none of us would go to the commissioner and reclaim it. Out in the wide world there may be some who would. They would double dip. This amendment prevents that. That is the clearest explanation I can give.

PARA.TAB: Senator Harradine referred to the case of the Victorian Government v. the Royal Assurance company. That case related to unjust enrichment. It was found against the Victorian Government that it had unjustly enriched itself at the expense of the Royal Assurance company. I have not read the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a stamp duty case.

—That is my point. It was a case about stamp duty. We are talking here about wholesale sales tax, which is a horse of a different colour. The difference makes for a difference in the argument, with great respect, which is the reason why I ask you to support the government's amendment to the bill.

—I do not see any difference in principle at all but I am not going to argue that. I have thought deeply about how the ultimate consumer will be better off. Clearly, the ultimate consumer is better off if the taxation department pays back money that it has unlawfully garnered from the wholesaler. The ultimate beneficiary must be the consumer in all circumstances in the event of a competitive industry.

PARA.TAB: You have said that very often it will not be known whether the wholesaler has absorbed the wholesale sales tax or whether some of it was absorbed by the retailer. Under those circumstances, you are cutting off the right of wholesalers to get back what has been stolen from them. In a competitive situation, wholesalers will build the tax into their businesses and, in competition with other wholesalers, will drop prices to the ultimate consumer.

You must admit that under those circumstances the ultimate consumer is better off than if the Commissioner of Taxation is pocketing the money. I have nothing at all against the Taxation Office. Many of my best friends work in the Taxation Office and they are very diligent and hardworking people.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have an unusual circle of friends. Many of your best friends?
—A number of them, yes. I just wanted to put those remarks on the record.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Gibson's) be agreed to:
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. After schedule 9, page 14, insert the following Schedule:
AMENDMENTS OF THE SALES TAX ASSESSMENT ACT 1992 RELATING TO INFORMATION FOR THE PROTECTION OF TAXPAYERS
1.After section 130:

PARA.TAB: Insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Information for the protection of taxpayers

SPEECH.PARA: "130B.Where a Minister makes a public statement which announces that it is the intention of the Government to introduce into a House of the Parliament a bill relating to a sales tax law to operate from a date before the enactment of the bill, the Commissioner must, within 7 days of that Minister making the statement, publish, for the information of taxpayers in each State and Territory, a public notice, in plain English, in at least 2 newspapers circulating generally in that State or Territory, as the case may be, which shall include the following:

PARA.TAB: (a)a statement of the intention of the Commonwealth Government to introduce the bill;
(b)details of what the bill will contain and how and when its provisions will be applied, if and when it comes into force;
(c)a warning that the bill is subject to enactment by both Houses of the Parliament and, if enacted, is to operate retrospectively from a date or dates specified in the bill;
(d)an explanation of why it is necessary that the bill be enacted retrospectively; and
(e)details of hotlines, addresses or other sources from which taxpayers may obtain further information.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Taxpayers protection not to be repealed except by express words

SPEECH.PARA: "130C. It is the intention of the Parliament that section 130B is not to be amended or repealed other than by the express words of an Act of the Parliament.".
2.Clause 2, page 1, at the end, add the following subclause:
"(3) Schedule 9A commences on the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent.".

I did not give detailed reasons for the way the Greens voted on the last amendment, so I will explain them now. It was a complex decision because obviously there were elements within the government's representations which were extremely attractive. It appeared that a major concern was for the protection of the taxpayer, and the ability to guard against at least one form of unjust enrichment—that is, on behalf the wholesaler in collecting, but not passing on, wholesales sales tax to the government. In the case where there was no lawful collection of sales tax, the attraction was in relation to avoiding some group in an unjust enrichment. That led us to look at why this might be the case and what might be one method by which this is less likely to be the case.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that, in the case of tax, knowledge is a very powerful thing. It is very important. One thing that has been missing in a lot of cases is people being able to find out exactly when taxes come in, to what degree they are liable, and where they can obtain information about their liability, or perhaps remedies, in the case of overpaid tax. That is why, on balance, our decision was to continue to support the current common law remedies until—and this may never happen—a case can be put to us at some stage that it is better to override the current common law remedy.

The rationale for this amendment arose from discussions with consumers and consumer groups and from letters from constituents concerning the difficulties in understanding the application of new sales tax changes, particularly when they have a retrospective commencement date. As a consequence, we are proposing an amendment to this bill that will require the Treasurer to publish information for taxpayers in major newspapers outlining: firstly, the intent of the government with respect to the law or change in law; secondly, details of the proposal and how and when it is to be applied; thirdly, whether the proposal is subject to enactment or disallowance; and, fourthly, the details of any hotlines or information sources.

I do not feel that this is an onerous requirement on the Treasurer, but it will assist the community at large—including consumers, retailers and wholesalers—in understanding these often complex issues that affect our daily lives. I look forward to support from all sides of parliament for this issue. It is unfortunate that the government has indicated that it is not prepared to support the legal requirement of provision of information to taxpayers on new sales tax. I would really like to know on what rationale the government could justify its not wishing to support a requirement that taxpayers be advised of new tax requirements, once they are announced.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said previously, the Australian Democrats think that these are excellent amendments. I think the Consumers Association would be really pleased to see this. Why would the government say that this could not be done? In an age of incredible complexity and requirements on citizens to comply with laws we are passing, it seems to me a very simple and basic thing to say, `Here is information which will assist you to comply with laws.' We spend so much money telling everybody about all the inquiries and committee hearings we are having and seeking submissions. This is an initiation of the process of saying, `Here is information which you need to use to fulfil other requirements.' I think it is an excellent idea.
—The coalition supports Senator Margetts's amendments; in fact, I am pleased to say that my office had a bit of a hand in rewording them. We are pleased to support them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be supporting the amendments moved by Senator Margetts; however, the government supports the principle of providing as much information as possible about the detail of a proposed change when it is announced. The government confirmed this in its reply to the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in its report entitled An assessment of tax, which was delivered on 8 August 1994.

PARA.TAB: The government has met its commitment in relation to sales tax; for example, all the legislation to support the sales tax changes announced in the budget on 9 May 1995 was introduced into the parliament the same night. In addition, there was a series of press releases which explained the changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not everybody listens to parliament.

—I am part-way through these dot points. From the following day, there was a hotline number which taxpayers or other interested people could call to get further details. This number is listed in the phone book. This goes on the Aristotelian scale of further upping the importance of each step. The tax office has since issued two detailed sales tax bulletins explaining how certain aspects of the changes would apply if passed by parliament. It turns out that, amongst all this activity, the government might not have adequately addressed all the needs of the consumers—at least that seems to be the view of the Greens. Having had this pointed out, we will address it in the normal course of our desire to get details out as soon as possible following announcements.

PARA.TAB: It is simply not appropriate to amend the law to place a requirement on the government relating to consumer information in this way. It will not be necessary in every case of a change for details to be widely advertised. To do so every time would impose unnecessary costs. I think that that is probably the main point of the government's position. There are a number of these changes, and if we had to advertise every change in several newspapers in every capital around Australia, it would impose an extra cost and an oversupply of information which dilutes the ability of the community to absorb. It is better that the tax office direct its bulletins to those people who are affected rather than broadcast more widely, because there are a number of these changes and the whole thing would be made a mockery of.

This proposed provision in the law does not provide the desirable flexibility, as different changes may demand different information. The provision will not necessarily provide the desired certainty, as the provision could be repealed. An important issue in relation to the drafting of the amendment is that the notice requirement will apply to all bills that are proposed to operate prior to the bills' enactment. There may be situations where a proposal is announced to operate from a future date and it turns out, due to the uncertainties of the parliamentary process—which is putting it nicely—that this date is before the bill's royal assent. In such a case, it would not be clear that such a proposal should fit into the proposed regime.

Also needing to be clarified is what details of the bill are necessary to be included. In cases where the proposed commencement is a future date, full details might not have been worked out. That is the summary of the government's position. It encodes in law a well-meaning principle, but then binds the law in an inflexible way which defeats the principle. It is far better, in our view, to target the particular groups who have an interest in this law rather than a broad brush encoding of legislation which works against better understanding and information. By doing it when the legislation is introduced does not mean to say that it will be the shape of the legislation when it is given royal assent. It creates confusion. The government opposes the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —To avoid cost increases all you have to do is avoid introducing retrospective legislation.

—There are some costs that obviously will not have to be added into this. The cost of the hotline has obviously already been provided for. Under (b) in the amendment it says `details of what the bill will contain and how and when its provisions will be applied if and when it comes into force'. I think the government can understand that.
—We understand, but we don't like it.
—With all due respect, Minister, you said what was required was not clear.

—I was trying to say it creates confusion. What is at the beginning of the process is not necessarily what comes out at the end of the process. So you tell people what you are going to do, but you will have to tell them again later. That creates a whole lot of confusion.

—Yes, you would need to tell them if there was a change. The minister's interjection is correct. Although so-called self-assessment with tax is the norm, the reality is that the government is more and more involved with enabling or allowing. The real information about tax liability is owned by very few. That is very elitist. We are trying to do something small to reverse that principle. The average person does not walk around with a copy of the tax act. Obviously `details of what the bill will contain' does not mean everything in the bill. Some of these bills are extremely long and complex.
—A digest.

—A digest, yes. That information is currently available only to those people using tax agents, accountants or lawyers. The tax agents are becoming richer and richer because of the lack of information available to people. The taxpack is deceptively simple, but information with regard to the taxpack is largely owned by fewer and fewer people. We are trying to reverse that trend to enable the changes to the sales tax legislation to be advised. It is a very good incentive for government to try and get it right. It means that there is a disincentive in putting something sloppily together, throwing it around and announcing it on budget night, without having thought through the consequences.

PARA.TAB: If there are major changes it would be necessary to do it again, but it is a very good incentive for governments to be their own house of review before they present a very badly formed tax proposal to the public. Governments should think through the ramifications before the bills are presented.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we should all note one thing that the minister said when we vote for this. He outlined an important principle concerning what we are doing in encoding this and requiring the tax office to perform according to the encoding. I still think it is worth a try. If it does not work we can bring it back.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As we are doing the same thing here, perhaps Senator Gibson will acknowledge that this is something similar to the audit bills where we had the same agenda.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 10, page 15, item 1, proposed definition of provisional tax uplift factor, paragraph (a), omit `8%', substitute `6%'.

I acknowledge that Senator Kernot and her party and the coalition have been critical of the eight per cent uplift factor and that we have both submitted amendments for moving it down to six per cent. The government has set the provisional uplift factor for next year at eight per cent. While this is an improvement on the current situation, the coalition does not believe that the government has gone far enough.

PARA.TAB: Provisional tax is calculated on the previous year's taxable income plus an uplift factor. The uplift factor is a major burden to small businesses as it detrimentally affects their cash flow, being a payment of tax in anticipation of future earnings. It is difficult to see any reason for the rate being set at eight per cent when the forecast for the CPI is less that half of that. What possible reason could there be for setting such a high uplift factor. I can perhaps supply an answer. I understand that for each one per cent increase in the uplift factor the government raises an extra $100 million. I think that is what it is all about. In the coalition's view eight per cent is unfair. We have proposed six per cent for next year.

I note in passing that the Institute of Chartered Accountants has surveyed 1,000 of its members representing 95,000-odd small business clients of whom a very high proportion—71,000—pay provisional tax. Ninety-six per cent of those surveyed believed that the uplift factor was unreasonable. That is not a marginal response; it is conclusive and it comes from those who should know.

I note from the report of the Senate Economics Reference Committee entitled A Question of balance that at recommendation 2.1 the committee recommends that the uplift factor should be set at a level no higher than the current or projected annual movement in the CPI. I believe that is a good principle. Nevertheless, for the immediate financial year starting on Saturday the coalition moves for six per cent.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I merely refer everybody to my extensive comments in the second reading speech. If this debate opens up I might be forced to revisit them.

—I would like to ask the minister what the government's response is to the fact that the Taxation Office acknowledges that the reality is that at an individual taxpayer level there will probably be a greater number of people who will be below the average and far fewer who will be in excess of the average of the uplift factor. In other words, it is a fact that rates at which the provisional uplift factor have been set since 1991 have resulted in the tax office never having lost any net provisional tax revenue. The tax office has had a considerable benefit from the uplift factor being far too high on the average of the past three years. Can the minister tell me why any benefits that accrue because of the setting of the tax uplift factor should go to the tax office rather than to individual Australians?

—The Greens are inclined to support a more realistic uplift factor; that is, six per cent rather than eight per cent. However, we are also inclined to provide some degree of certainty unless and until the point where the government can provide a good argument otherwise. There is some attraction in supporting six per cent but, by the same token, we believe that making this decision each year provides less certainty, unless there is some reason why there will be substantial changes from year to year that require that the uplift factor has to be decided each year.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that we are inclined to support the lowering of the uplift factor, but at the same time have some interest in waiting until the parliament decides next time. That means it is still possible for the parliament to change the rate next year if there was a circumstance that changed so much that it was necessary to change that uplift factor. To give some degree of certainty, it means that people do know what the level will be, at least until the parliament decides next time. We are inclined to support the lowering but at the same time are inclined to support that element of Senator Kernot's amendment which indicates that until further notice, that is what the uplift factor will be. To clarify that, if it is possible to support both, we will support the element of reducing the uplift factor; if the committee allows that amendment by Senator Kernot to be split later, perhaps we would support part (b).

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not support this amendment. I am not going to break my losing streak here because, given the expressions of view around the chamber, the government will be defeated on this. We will take it back to the House in due course and this time we will bring it back here. I am pretty sure of that. Like Senator Kernot, we referred to this matter in the debate on the second reading. I do not wish to canvass all the arguments again. The government is on the record as to why it sets the uplift factor as it does.

PARA.TAB: In answer to the question that I have from Senator Ferguson—this may well go to some of the arguments that have been put as well—we do not set the uplift factor in any sense on the basis of trying to give the tax office a windfall gain by artificially inflating the uplift factor in order to gain more revenue. The reason we set an uplift factor on the forecasts based by Treasury as to what the expected growth in business earnings will be is to pick the right point in the market. In no sense are we trying to manipulate a figure. The forecasting process is transparent and open, as it should be, and the issue is to get it right. The fact that when it is right, the opposition does not agree with it, is a point of argument. But the forecasting is fair and reasonable, transparent and open and based on all the matters that ought to be considered, and it is made by Treasury. The tax office then takes note of it and sets the uplift factor appropriately.

I repeat: we are not in the business of trying to soak taxpayers to make a windfall gain. We would not do that and we should not do that. If we were doing that, you would not let us do it, and nor should you. This is not a situation like that at all, although sometimes, for political purposes, it is argued that it is. In our heart of hearts we recognise that it is not. For those reasons, I oppose the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, your forecasting is wrong.
—That's your view.

—The department's forecasting has been wrong. For three years in a row the collections have been higher than they ought to be. The rate has been set at eight per cent for the past two years, so it is obvious that whatever method it is using for forecasting, it is wrong. I notice that one of the tax office submissions to the committee—I quoted it this morning—even uses long-range weather forecasting. I know lots of farmers who have tried to use long-range weather forecasting to try to accurately predict what their future incomes will be, and over the past three or four years they have not worked out too well. But the fact is that the forecasting is wrong.

PARA.TAB: Having been wrong in 1991-92, wrong the next year and wrong the next year by setting the rate too high, why does the government persist in setting it at the same level again this year, presuming that it is using the same economic indicators? The minister said that the government is not looking for a win-win situation against the taxpayer. In fact, for three years in a row it has been win, win, win. The people who have been paying provisional tax and paying the uplift factor in general terms have been paying more than they are required to.

I know that the uplift factor does not mean that at the end of the day anybody pays more tax than that person is actually liable for. At the end of the day you only ever pay the tax that you are actually liable for. It is all a matter of timing. That timing is impacting on small businesses—particularly a number of small businesses that have made approaches to us—very badly when they are in tough economic times. If they are paying more tax by way of provisional tax, which includes the uplift factor, than they are liable for, it is putting that added pressure on them and it means that somehow or other the forecasting is wrong.

I know that we can never get over this situation where, under the current system, some people who actually have a big increase in income from a variety of different industries—I know it happens because you are using one factor to cover a whole range of industries—have a windfall gain. Right now there are more people who are having losses than there are having gains.

Either the forecasting method is wrong or the government, on advice, is setting the rate at too high a level. I personally believe that even at six per cent the rate is too high, but I am aware of the impact that it has on government revenue. Even by bringing it down to six per cent this year, it will have a considerable impact on revenue. We as a coalition said last year that we could go along with an eight per cent uplift factor but that we would put the government on notice that it should consider it in the next year and that we would be prepared to vote in favour of lowering the uplift factor if all the facts and figures that were presented to us suggested that it had been too high.

I believe that we have had good enough evidence over the past two years to show that that eight per cent uplift factor—I think it was 10 per cent the year before; I may stand corrected—was too high. The indications are that it is still too high. I think that the Democrats and the coalition are being fair-minded in suggesting that we are signalling a decrease in the uplift factor. I do not think it is going as low as it should, but I think six per cent is what we would call a reasonable amount for the uplift factor to be decreased to in order that it does not have too great an impact on revenue and still has some sympathy for the predicament that small businesses and individuals who are actually paying provisional tax, including the uplift factor, find themselves in.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Gibson's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to amend my amendment so as to delete the existing (b) of schedule 10 and replace it with my (b) from amendment No. 1. In other words, it puts in place a fall back of six per cent instead of 10 per cent. I will repeat the arguments very briefly.

PARA.TAB: The 10 per cent rate represents the conditions of the 1980s, not 1995. The six per cent figure that I am proposing maintains a buffer between projected inflation and the uplift factor. It is slightly above the projected 5.5 to six per cent annual GDP per capita growth that has been, as I said, projected over the next four years. It is a more appropriate figure than the anachronistic 10 per cent.

Last year, one of the reasons the coalition gave for not being able to support our desire to reduce the figure to five per cent was that if it failed, the 10 per cent would automatically operate. I think it is more appropriate that we say, `We believe the Prime Minister's rhetoric about inflation never rising again. We believe him this time.' It means that inflation for the rest of this decade is going to be around three per cent.

That figure is included in Treasury projections published in the budget papers. I do not think even the most pessimistic economist—or anybody else—in Australia is predicting that we will return to eight to 10 per cent inflation. So 10 per cent is anachronistic; that is representative of the conditions of the 1980s. We are in 1995 and I think this is the most appropriate thing to do to give certainty. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Schedule 10, page 15, item 1, omit paragraph (b) of the definition of provisional tax uplift factor, substitute the following definition:

PARA.TAB: (b)in relation to a later year of income—means, until the Parliament otherwise provides, 6%".

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to indicate that while we are very sympathetic to the Democrats intention, we have decided to oppose the amendment at this time.
—And when it comes back from the other House, what is going to happen?
—We are simply opposing it now. There is currently a mix of economic growth and rate of inflation that is difficult to forecast. Therefore we are in favour of the—
—No-one is forecasting 10 per cent.

—I know that; and that is why it has to be adjusted each year. On the other hand, the Senate Economics References Committee has just put out its report recommending the CPI be applied. I think that needs to be considered and digested. For the moment, we are against locking in a particular number; so we are opposing the amendment.

—I would like to commend what my colleague Senator Gibson said. I have some sympathy for Senator Kernot's amendment in that it does put some certainty into things. What I do not have sympathy for is the fact that it really acknowledges an arbitrary figure which the uplift figure should be set at for a long time.
—So what is it going to be if you don't vote for this? It is an arbitrary figure that is set.

—What I am saying—and Senator Gibson recognised this—is that the economics committee has just brought down a report into the taxation treatment of small business. I heard the minister say today that the government would consider this committee report and then come back with a response and some recommendations.

PARA.TAB: As far as the provisional tax uplift factor is concerned, it is all to do with timing. I think perhaps the timing of your amendment is not quite right. I really think that this committee report ought to be considered at length because there are some other recommendations in the report, with regard to the uplift factor, which I think the government should have the opportunity to investigate.

I know that one recommendation is considered a rather radical suggestion. It talks about individual provisional uplift factors, but we have individual averaging for lots of others things with partnerships as well. It is a rather radical view but I think it is one worth investigating, because somehow at the end of the day we want to do what is best for the taxpayer; to make it simpler for him, so that there is some more surety. I am concerned about what is best for the taxpayer, what is best for small business and the impact this will have on small business.

It is not that I do not have some sympathy for the certainty, Senator Kernot, of having this level, which you say, is more in line with the inflation rate and CPI of the 1990s than is the 10 per cent of the 1980s; I just think that the timing is wrong. I think we ought to give the government a chance to respond to this committee report and some of the recommendations which are somewhat radical and different. Surely at some stage in the future we can then look at putting into place a mechanism which is far better than the current provisional tax uplift factor mechanism that we work under.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you are right, Senator Ferguson. Recently, I heard the expression `paralysis by analysis'. Last year, in response to the coalition's views on this, I initiated that inquiry because you said we couldn't do it last year.
—And we have done it.

—We have had the inquiry and received the recommendations. When you talk about timing, isn't it your side that is saying we won't be coming back? Aren't you saying, `We're getting ready for an election and we won't be coming back'? So what happens to this? Is it into the ether again?
—We'll be back.
—Oh, good!
—We'll be back at some stage.
—I am comforted that this—
—Don't believe them about an election; we actually call it.

—Of course it is reasonable for the government to have time to respond, but look how long this process is taking us and look at what small business is paying in the meantime. That is the point I want to make.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: No.1Schedule 10, page 15, after item 1, insert the following items:

PARA.TAB: Table 1:
(a)omit `$8000' (wherever occurring), substitute `$10,000';
(b)omit the heading `Instalment(s) due on first day of:', substitute:
Small: on first day of:
Medium: on last day of:'

SPEECH.PARA: (c)omit `month 18' (first occurring), substitute `month 21';
The amendment made by item 1A of this Schedule applies in relation to liability to pay instalments payable for the 1995-96 year of income and for all later years of income.".
No.2Schedule 10, page 15, item 2, omit "made by this Schedule", substitute "made by item 1 of this Schedule".

I canvassed some of these arguments in the second reading debate. I am concerned to ensure that, in moving to the higher company tax rate, the impact on smaller companies is done in the fairest possible way. We recognise that smaller companies face compliance costs that are much higher than those of big business, but we think that, while 36 per cent might be reasonable, we have to make sure that the way in which it is collected is as fair as possible.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Gibson pointed out in some of his comments, the original reduction in the company tax rate from 39 per cent to 33 per cent was funded by the bringing forward of company tax instalment times. Medium sized companies with a tax liability of $8,000 to $300,000 were moved to a quarterly payment system, with the first payment due brought forward from 28 September to 1 June. Then we had the last payment brought forward from 15 February to 1 February. Small companies balancing in June had until 15 February and then, after 1993, this was brought forward to 1 December.

I am proposing that it is time to review this payment timing schedule for small companies. I am proposing in item (c) that the payment time be put back from 1 December to 1 February. For medium companies, we propose in item (b) that the quarterly payments commence on 30 June rather than 1 June. As I said before, these amendments do not reduce at all the amount of tax payable, but give small business a little more time to get what can be chaotic affairs in order. In discussing these with the small business coalition, it certainly was of the view that they are not earth-shatteringly huge in their impact, but that they are helpful and they are a step forward.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Statement by the Acting Deputy President

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—By letter dated 29 June 1995 signed by the Chairman of the Select Committee on Unresolved Whistleblower Cases, Senator Murphy, the committee has raised under standing order 81 a matter of privilege. Evidence has been placed before the committee that a witness has been adversely treated as a result of giving evidence. Pursuant to Privilege Resolution 1(18), the committee has taken steps to ascertain the facts of the matter and has concluded that the witness may have been improperly treated in respect of evidence given to the committee. The committee has therefore recommended that the matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges. The committee has presented a report to the Senate on the matter.

This matter clearly meets the criteria which the President is required to take into account to determine whether a motion should have precedence to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee. I refer the Senate to past statements by the President's predecessor and by the President setting out the application of those criteria, in particular their application to matters relating to alleged interference with witnesses.

The President therefore determines that a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee may have precedence over other business. I table the letter from the committee. Senator Jones may now give notice of a motion, on behalf of Senator Murphy, to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Murphy, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, he will move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges:

SPEECH.PARA: Having regard to the report of the Select Committee on Unresolved Whistleblower cases on the alleged intimidation of a witness, whether there was any improper interference with a person who provided evidence to that committee on account of that evidence and, if so, whether any contempt was committed by that improper interference.

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Herron)—The committee is considering the Taxation Laws Amendment (Budget Measures) Bill 1995 and the Australian Democrats' amendments 2 and 3.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (BUDGET MEASURES) BILL 1995INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT BILL 1995

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was speaking to my amendment to change payment dates. I was speaking about the effect it would have on medium sized companies. The effect of this is to ensure that a medium sized company is not required to pay its first instalment until the last day of the financial year and that fact recognises that companies sort out their income on a very different basis from PAYE taxpayers. For small companies, we propose delaying the date of payment from 1 December to 1 February. If we look at what has happened already this year, we see that a lot of small businesses and their tax agents are saying that the new tax system has proved quite difficult for them.

PARA.TAB: The tax office has responded. It has agreed to put back the lodgment date of tax returns from 1 December to 1 February, but it still wants the money on 1 December. So it is a kind of Clayton's concession. That tax office action recognises that small companies are having difficulty meeting the earlier deadline, but the tax office is constrained from offering any further relief. So these amendments would do something the commissioner cannot do—that is, put back the date of payment to the date of lodgment of 1 February.

Secondly, in relation to the thresholds, item A of my amendment seeks to increase the threshold for small companies from a tax liability of $8,000 to a tax liability of $10,000—it used to be $20,000 under One Nation. As I have said previously, the fact that it was reduced to $8,000 was part of the bringing forward of repayment times needed to pay for the tax rate cut in 1993. I accept that it is too expensive to move back to $20,000 in one hit, but this is an affordable first step.

We are not talking about very big companies; we are talking about very small companies—$24,000 is not a big operation at all. The object of allowing for a small companies category is to allow companies with small incomes to make only one payment. That should suit the tax office in the same way it would suit the taxpayer.

In not doing this, though, we should be aware of one of the consequences—that is, around 5,000 companies are being forced to move from a single payment to a quarterly payment system. Their first payment would become due on 1 June rather than 1 December. That would be very inconvenient and add significantly to compliance costs. In general, we should be moving towards more reasonable thresholds. The measure would defer about $9 million of income from 1995-96 to 1996-97 and about $31,000 from 1996-97 to 1997-98, after which it would be revenue neutral.

I moved these amendments because I think they highlight the need for us to address some of these administrative problems of small business. I think the government spends a lot of time on big business. We always put small business in the too hard basket.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) will be supporting the measures Senator Kernot has proposed. All along, in relation to these bills, we have said we would look at ways to mitigate implications for small business.

PARA.TAB: In this particular case, in the manner of the adjustments on which the government will be likely to make a windfall just on a definitional change, we would certainly support maintaining the size of the business. Otherwise, it is a bit like bracket creep a la small business. Therefore, as indicated in my second reading speech, we will be supporting these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition is sympathetic to the two amendments moved by Senator Kernot. We are particularly sympathetic to the threshold question.

PARA.TAB: Minister, from the government's point of view, what is the problem with lifting the threshold from $8,000 to $10,000? Is it really going to help small and medium sized business? How was the $8,000 level set in the first place? Where did that come from? I could be persuaded that this is a worthwhile shift, and I am inclined that way. Depending on what you say, Minister, I will give serious consideration to that matter.

With regard to the timing, whilst sympathetic in principle to what Senator Kernot was saying, we are not really in favour of altering the timing, because the timing of tax is fairly well ingrained in the whole fabric of business.

TALK.START.PARA: —But people will be affected by what the tax office has done.

—I understand that but there is a regime which everyone knows and there is a good reason for staying by the dates that people know. We talked earlier about the difficulty of communicating through to all the small business in Australia, which is the essence of Senator Margetts's amendment that we all agreed with and passed here. We are in favour of less tax now rather than more tax later, so we are not in favour of changing the dates. But I will certainly listen to the threshold question.
—I have a letter from the Treasurer, if you need it, which sets out the government's answers. Do you need it?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some briefing notes which set out the government's answers.
—I thought I recognised what the Treasurer said in your second reading reply, actually.

—I thank Senator Kernot for assisting me but, as she pointed out, in my concluding speech to the second reading debate, I set out at some length the government arguments. Perhaps it is worth while, in view of the question, to canvass quite quickly but nonetheless in the necessary detail—I hope to be convincing and persuasive—the general comment.

PARA.TAB: I go to the briefing note. Firstly, the tax issues of greatest concern to small business have been the subject of an inquiry by the Senate economics references committee. The reference: improving the tax treatment of small business. The government is committed to responding to that report, therefore, it is appropriate to consider the committee's findings before deciding on any amendments to the taxation of small business.

Secondly, if the intention of the proposed amendments, as it seems to be, is to relieve small business of some of the costs of doing business, the proposed rescheduling may not be the best method of achieving that objective, because `small business', `small companies' and `companies paying small amounts of tax' are all different groups. Indeed, most small businesses, particularly those at the lower end of the total business income scale, are not incorporated and, therefore, would not benefit from special treatment for taxpaying companies. Furthermore, companies with small income tax liabilities may not be small businesses in terms of their accounting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, on a point of order: I need to save time. You are addressing the tax payment date, but Senator Gibson only asked for the threshold argument. So we could save time.

—Can I make one more point on this—and I will save time. Then you get into an argument about subsidiaries of large companies and the possibility of large companies organising their subsidiaries to qualify. That is another consideration.

PARA.TAB: On the threshold, the current $8,000 threshold was set to achieve the appropriate balance between efficiency and equity considerations favouring quarterly instalments and the desire to minimise compliance in administration costs involved in collecting relatively small amounts of tax. This balance is not affected by the fact that the increase in the company tax rate may change the classification of some companies from small to medium. Eight thousand is still a sufficiently large sum to warrant quarterly payments to spread the cost to the taxpayer of the tax liability. The same threshold applies for provisional tax quarterly instalments.

The government does not support the amendment because it would be most appropriate to judge the extent of small business interest in this proposal by considering the report from the inquiry of the economics committee and it would shift some $20 million of revenue collections from medium to small companies, some of which the first instalments otherwise payable by medium companies would be shifted from the 1995-96 financial year to the 1996-97 financial year.

The reason the government does not support the proposed amendment to 1A(b) is that it is estimated that $620 million would be shifted from the 1995-96 to the 1996-97 financial year. The franking credits for the payment of the first instalment for normal balancing medium companies may not arise until a subsequent franking year and companies would be unable to frank dividends in anticipation of payment of that instalment.

The proposed rescheduling would exacerbate the advantage of medium companies over provisional taxpayers, with similar tax liabilities, whose provisional tax may be due on 31 March of the current income year. This would undermine one of the reasons for the introduction of the company tax instalment regime which is to provide tax symmetry between incorporated and unincorporated businesses. This is of particular concern in relation to companies that are used as tax minimisation vehicles by wealthy individuals and families.

I now turn to the proposed amendment to paragraph 1A(c). This amendment would defer the payment of tax by small companies by three months. The government considers this amendment unnecessary and does not support it. The same argument applies. The proposed rescheduling would exacerbate the advantage of small companies over provisional taxpayers and it would undermine one of the reasons for the introduction of the company tax instalment regime. As I recall, under the proposal Senator Kernot has put forward, 30 June next year is a Sunday. That would mean that they would pay tax in the next financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —A financial year crossover.
—Yes, in terms of the shifting effect. I hope Senator Gibson can understand that. They are the reasons for the government's opposition.

—I guess it makes me more interested in the threshold matter. I am a bit concerned about the practicalities for established business of shifting the payment dates. I am very reluctant to shift on that issue. I would be interested to hear whether Senator Kernot has received evidence as to why we should shift from eight to 10? How many people are likely to be affected by this change?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Small Business Coalition indicated when talking to us that this is a small thing but it would help. I think we are talking about 5,000 companies that would be affected. I can hear what the minister is saying. I think he has raised some plausible arguments. Nevertheless, the issue of the threshold was very important in the superannuation debate.

PARA.TAB: Sometimes it is important to ask why the threshold is set where it is and how many people it will affect if it stays where it is in conjunction with other changes. When we changed the threshold in the superannuation guarantee charge debate the opposition made a lot of predictions about what it would do to employment and those predictions turned out to be easily disproved. Sometimes we accept thresholds without asking why they are there. When other circumstances change, I think we should ask why they are there. I think it was important to raise these issues because small business thought that they were small changes that would assist them. I think the financial year crossover is an important issue. The amount of money associated with the deferral is also important and I acknowledge that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate that answer.

—I registered that earlier on. In view of what I have heard today, I would be happy to commit the opposition to supporting your threshold issue, if that could be separated out, but we will not be supporting the timing issue. Mr Temporary Chairman, could you give us some guidance on separating them?

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Herron)—There is no difficulty in splitting the two amendments and having them voted on separately.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would Senator Kernot care to do that?
—I ask to have them separated and voted on separately.
—I will grant that wish. There is no difficulty with it.

PARA.TAB: Amendment 2(a) agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said no, but we are not dividing. I just want that recorded.

PARA.TAB: Amendment 2(b) negatived.
Amendment 2(c) negatived.
Amendment 3 agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on Taxation Laws Amendment (Budget Measures) Bill 1995 and to ask the Minister representing the Treasurer (Senator Cook) certain questions. In my speech in the second reading debate I referred to the removal of the tax exemption from EPROMs in this bill.

PARA.TAB: I pointed out to Senator Cook in that debate that that tax exemption will affect the only two phone companies remaining in Australia that manufacture and design in Australia. I also pointed out to him that the huge multi-million dollar market of mobile phones is being shared by Nokia, which is owned by the Finland government, and Motorola, which is an American company. I estimate that they would have something like 90 per cent of the market.

I also pointed out in that speech that the phones being sold at the moment are either subsidised by Optus and Telecom, which I cannot exactly prove, or perhaps dumped by Motorola and Nokia. I know that it would be almost impossible to get a phone on the market for around $200 and meet costs.

Both Optus and Telecom are not selling phones; they are selling access to the network. It is putting pressure on the smaller companies—the Australian companies—and excluding them from a very lucrative and vast Australian market.The exemption on sales tax on the EPROMs gave them an advantage that kept them in the market. As I said before, the minister is a very successful promoter of Australian industry. He comes in here and talks it up; that is his job. I know that everyone in the Senate wants to see Australia on the cutting edge of advancing technology.

I was in this industry for 20 years. Most of the products that I sold, which were ordinary manufactured products that went into a retail market, are now being imported from overseas. Virtually everything that I sold during those 20 years that I was in the industry—this was before I came into this place—has now been replaced by imports. The one area in which Australia can and must do well is high technology. By the removal of this sales tax exemption, the government has put at risk the development of the high-tech industry in Australia.

It is possible to buy a floppy disk which will have no sales tax on it. But the new technology—the EPROMs—which is the new age method of storing information, will now have tax on it. So the old way of doing things will be tax exempt and the new way of doing things will attract sales tax. In the minister's second reading speech, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The ministers—and I speak for Minister Lee and me in this—are committed to ensuring that a strategy is in place so that Australia is well placed to capture the emerging opportunities. A key element of that strategy will be working with Australian-owned companies to improve their quality and the applicability of their technology, and to encourage their ability to find niches and broader markets for their products.
I invite the minister to give the chamber some further information on how he and Minister Lee are going to stand by an industry that I believe needs their support at this particular time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the same question too, having been the mover of the original amendment and having acknowledged in the second reading debate the way in which it has been rorted in my view. So, while being willing to rescind it, I want some guarantee that you have paid serious attention to the effects of this on a particular telecommunications company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do acknowledge the representations made by Senator Kernot and Senator Boswell, and then Senator Boswell and Senator Kernot, and then Senator Kernot and Senator Boswell. It keeps going. I do acknowledge the assiduousness with which you have pursued this issue, and I congratulate you for it. I firstly refer to my remarks at the conclusion of my second reading address, in which I did set out in some detail actions that the government proposes to take of an industry policy nature to encourage the ability of this company called Voxson—I think Senator Boswell mentioned its name—to win greater contracts and establish itself more firmly in the portable phone market in Australia.
—I am talking NEC too.

—Yes. You have asked for further details. In the first instance, officers of my department visited this company last week and are in the process of preparing a further report for action by me and my department. In order that my office will be better acquainted with the circumstance of this company, one of my advisers, Mr Glenn Carlos, will be visiting this company too. He is an extension of me in this circumstance. I will be overseas doing a promotion of Australian automotive parts to Japan. But, at the same time, he will visit this company and report to me directly as to what actions we can take.

PARA.TAB: As to things that can be done and will be done, under our Ausindustry programs we have a series of programs designed to improve the efficiency of Australian manufacturing companies. We will work with those companies to access these programs and to increase their quality and efficiency of production. As I also said—I repeat it now—I have discussed this matter with the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Mr Lee. His department and mine will be working together cooperatively in a review of telecommunications purchasing policy—the 1997 review—and we will look to position Australian manufacturers to take advantage of what changes we make under that purchasing policy.

In relation to specific companies and purchases, I have before me a note to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Michael Lee, from Telecom, dated today, timed at 15.42 hours. It refers directly to this issue. I do not think it is appropriate for all of the things commented on to be read into the record but, in part, it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Telstra has previously purchased Voxon analogue phones . . .
It goes on to say why that is no longer the case. It continues:
More recently Voxon approached Telstra with a proposal to jointly develop telecommunication products. Telstra Mobiles considered the possibility of a joint venture to develop a digital mobile phone.
It goes on to talk in more detail about that and what arrangements would be necessary. It goes on:

Here we have a group of programs that can help to improve quality and the ability to win market share. We will slot those programs into this company. My department and the communications department are actively involved in assisting. My office is directly engaged. The market for this company, Telecom Australia, from the comments I have just read into the record, is disposed to purchasing Australian made goods for its operational network. I hope that is sufficient to encourage you to see that this is an action oriented agenda aimed at promoting the Australian flag on Australian made products for use in Australia and for export.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you, Minister, for those comments. They are very helpful and I know they will be well received by the management of the two Australian companies that are trying to retain some market share. There is not a lot more that I can say. It will give these two phone companies an added incentive to break into the digital market.

PARA.TAB: One is presently developing a digital phone which will be one of only four or five of its kind in the world. If that development can progress and get into the market, the company will be able to produce a first-class product. I have used its analogue phone and I have always found it to be a first-class product. It has never given me any trouble.

TAB.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Herron)—The committee is considering the Competition Policy Reform Bill 1995 and amendment Nos 2, 4 to 18 and 20 to 24, moved together, by leave, by Senator Kernot for the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
Motion (by Senator Cook) proposed:
That this bill be now read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make some final comments with regard to the Competition Policy Reform Bill. I believe that what has been done in this legislation is shameful and will not benefit the community, the general public, at all. I believe the objective of this bill is to cut up power, water and other utilities and force the states to sell them off according to a federal agenda to sell off large airports, increase costs for remote communities, and eventually close down or lead to a reduction of airports, post office agencies, train stations, medical services and schools.

PARA.TAB: Part of the agenda is deregulation, where regulation is so-called anti-competitive. The Industry Commission called for all sorts of deregulation, all the way to cutting out requirements for minimum width for footpaths. You tell me what kind of competitive barrier regulations on footpath width represent. Yet the Industry Commission identifies this as an area for reform.

I think we will see a lot of this sort of thing, without consultation and with very little consideration and probably without much sense but a lot of dry right bureaucrats will be busy. Of more concern are the perennial targets. I am sure regulations on trading hours will be the first to go. We will encourage the United States style shopping with a few big chains opening 24 hours a day, employing juniors to keep costs down. You can bet such a push will be accompanied by pressure to eliminate any overtime regulations based on unsociable hours. You can bet it will put a lot of family businesses, corner delis and such out of business. Their major niche was the after-hours trade. So much for competition.

Coles, Woolworths and maybe a franchise deli chain like 7-Eleven will survive. It could mean death to thousands of small businesses. Competition is about survival of the fittest: the biggest with the most economic muscle. The name `competition policy' is misleading. This is not about consumer choice but about privatisation and deregulation. Concerns about privatisation and the potential impact on consumers, the community and the environment are being overruled.

Privatisation will lead to private sector monopolies or oligopolies with consequent higher prices for many people and a reduction in the ability to pursue issues in the public interest. Yet we are told that the Trade Practices Act will allow anti-competitive private sector business behaviour to be taken to court.

This does not correspond with the general view of the current actions of the Trade Practices Act in relation to the private sector. For example, the oil companies have for some time been recognised as being an effective oligopoly that engages in price fixing and generally recognises the market share of other players. The pricing of CDs in Australia has also been noted as being significantly higher than in other countries for no apparent reason. Monopoly arrangements on book supplies have also attracted criticism for decades: in part because of the substantially higher prices that result and in part because of issues of simple availability.

Recently, government went so far as to join with other governments to re-establish the effective cartel of aluminium companies. This has been broken by the introduction of Russian aluminium. The government has established a minimum price for the protection of industries. These are industries assumed to take risks and, as a consequence, all profits from this intergovernmental action flow to the industries and their stockholders—not to the public and not to the governments concerned. The companies are not taking risks. Governments are helping them to form cartels to increase prices and guarantee them higher profits. There is no doubt that the move results in higher consumer prices on a global basis. It affects inputs in a range of industries and they will also end up raising their prices.

This is not competition that government seems to be interested in. It is the use of so-called competition policy to justify a range of social cutbacks in the name of economic efficiency. It has been used to drive dismemberment of public sector activities and a radical change in federal-state powers.

I would like to call the attention of honourable senators to the proposed operation of section 51(1) which used to create exemptions from trade practices for activities specified by law or regulation. Any authorised legislation is still exempt, but to be authorised under section 51(1B)(a) a law must explicitly refer to the Competition Policy Reform Act. This effectively means that we start out with no legislation or regulation exempt. Any attempt to create exempt legislation must be approved by the commission and the minister. Government amendment No. 5 will further extend this to conduct under licenses. These are mentioned and are now subject to section 51(1B)(a) and they must refer to the Competition Policy Reform Act to be exempt, and are therefore not exempt.

I would like it noted that in the whole process it appears that the minister has absolute veto. The state ministers can inform the commission, and the commission, with the council, holds an investigation and reaches a conclusion. This is passed on to the minister who considers the issue and decides. If she or he decides in contradiction to the commission, the commission accepts it. This is the chain of power. Read the act carefully.

This bill will create an organisation of considerable power; a vehicle to examine almost any aspect of government at almost any level—federal, state or local; a vehicle which can accept or reject decisions of parliament; a vehicle which will examine and approve or reject laws; a vehicle which will examine the private sector, the public sector and the service or community sectors; a vehicle which can effectively pass judgment on the department stores and businesses of this country; and a vehicle which can create offences by regulation and prosecute them through its own tribunal. It can examine prices and it can set prices.

We are asked to create this immensely powerful vehicle for executive action; action which makes parliaments subsidiary and sets itself above them in judgment. It is a far more radical arrangement of power than almost any suggestion on constitutional change in relation to the republic debate.

We will set up this very powerful vehicle operating in relative autonomy but answerable to a minister. As Senator Boswell pointed out, it is a vehicle that will act by regulation. It is the ultimate vehicle that acts by regulation. It comes with its own think-tank, its own tribunal. It need not ever converse with parliamentarians. It will communicate by edict—by acceptance or rejection of the efforts of poor representative democracy. It is the wave of the future.

State government has been told to write an agenda for reform and, as an afterthought, to include what they will do for safeguards. It can bring this back in a year. By this time, the ACCC should be up and can pass judgment on what the states have put forward. I hope that makes the situation clear. The states' agenda is conditional. The final agenda will be decided by the commission. It will then be approved by the federal minister. All those access agreements must pass the least restrictive to competition test. This is the sort of thing the World Trade Organisation applied in relation to various regulations.

Government makes decisions to protect and maximise its revenue. So we have it moving to a coordinated buying policy which will see virtually a third of computer goods bought from single sources. What is competitive about this? Nothing. Government does not pursue competition. It pursues short-term budget balancing and cost cutting. The point of privatisation is to generate short-term revenue. It is one-off revenue. At the same time, it eliminates income streams and the efficiency of potential integration of objectives and cooperation between departments. It will entail a massive regulatory effort to replace the natural oversight of a government agency. Either that, or there will not be regulation or consumer protection.

In competition, people cut corners. This might save costs, but there are prices to pay. They usually do not come due until those that have made the cuts have gone. It is possible to cut corners by doing things like putting in lower standard steel piping for water mains. The savings or profits are made immediately. The cost does not appear for over a decade, but by then the cost is considerable. Another form of efficiency is gained when a water provider does not need to be concerned about downstream issues or long-term management. All the record keeping, labour and expertise becomes unnecessary. Lots of money is saved when the activities stop, but no management generally means mismanagement with a cost later. Of course, that cost is considered a natural disaster and a social cost.

These types of approaches might provide short-term, narrow focus economic gains, but they are not efficient socially or from the perspective of overall economics or outcomes. Efficiency properly means doing more with less. The thing those keen on competition seem certain we need less of is labour. While there may be inefficiencies in some hypothetical instances, what often seems to have occurred in the last 10 years is that retrenchments have meant doing less with less.

We see moves for efficiency in hospitals. When an economist sees a worker in an emergency ward who is not busy stitching up someone, that economist sees inefficiency: obviously there are too many staff. The ideal situation from an economics standpoint is when the staff are always flat out. They are flat out on a calm night, they will have people waiting for urgent treatment on an average night and people waiting longer on a heavy night. They will be stressed and rushing like competing track stars. Is it efficient?

When a medical administrator sees an emergency room without enough staff to cope with a normal heavy night in a timely way, she or he sees a different sort of inefficiency—one that might lead to death or permanent injury—rather than a large outlay figure. Efficiency in medical terms is having enough staff to deal with the injured in a timely way on most normal nights, whether they are heavy nights, average nights or calm nights. This means that if you have enough to cope on a heavy night, you might be less than flat out on an average night. You may be able to relax a bit on a calm night. The test of efficiency is in the functional outcome—whether people get the treatment they need.

People tend to see hospital services like the hospital administrator does. They see having to wait as inefficient. They call for efficiency and the economists step in and cut staff. Services are theoretically cheaper, although you might die waiting for them, or be in a lot of pain, and the cheaper treatment usually takes the form of less government outlay rather than actual savings for consumers.

Is this paranoid fantasy? Not long ago an administrator at Woden hospital complained of exactly this, stating that he was quitting and that staff levels could not cope with an average night. He outlined the consequences of a real emergency, a bus crash or similar accident. Yet this is what we are told is efficient medical treatment.

Is it efficient to eliminate rural clinics and centralise resources in big hospitals? Is it efficient for all the people who have further—sometimes very much further—to go, often for quite basic treatment? Is it economically efficient? Does it lower your hospital bills? No. It probably increases the cost of transport and time lost. But the argument is that it lowers the government hospital bills and Medicare payments. Of course, the ultimate in efficiency is where government has no costs and people pay for all the services they use themselves. It is very efficient because it reduces demand. It reduces demand because many people cannot afford treatment.

A less horrific example of doing less with less—one that makes a different but related point—is of public transport. If a route is not frequently used and the bus is not fully loaded, it is less efficient. The economists would argue that you should reduce the number of times the bus passes. Loading per trip will be greater, but the less frequently the bus comes by, the less efficient it is for the users and the more they will look for other options. If bus use continues to be poor, an alternative is to increase charges to recover costs. Those people living in Western Australia would probably recall that when the new train service was put on for the northern rail line there were twice as many trains to cope with the northern service. In fact, the payback time became much faster than was expected because more people wanted to use the service.

The ultimate result of economic efficiency measures designed to reduce expenditure is that a bus may run only once a day and a ticket costs twice or three times the cost of petrol for a private car. Only those who are entirely dependent on public transport are likely to use the bus at this stage. This happens far more often than it should and there are bus routes in Perth in exactly this state. Virtually everyone who can has given up and gone by car. At this point the transport company is liable to cut out the service altogether as unnecessary.

When a response to service costs is to cut services, at some point services are cut to such a degree that they become pointless. What exactly is the point of having security guards in Parliament House where senators can reach under a desk and push a distress button, then ask the same senators to walk around the building alone in the dark at midnight? Anyone wanting to attack a senator—gosh, who would?—would only have to wait outside in a car, jump out and drive away. So what is the point? When services are cut back far enough, there is little point in having them at all. It is reductio ad absurdum in practice.

The Greens (WA) would not oppose competition. It has its place, but it is not the supreme place, and certainly not the only place. This bill is a formula to hand over public functions to a handful of big players who are pursuing their own profit with little concern for the public. I see nothing in this bill that leads me to think that this bill provides provision for public welfare or well-being. When the agendas and safeguards and CSOs are in and spelled out, I might change my mind. But they are not, and we are passing this without them. The Greens (WA), therefore, completely oppose and condemn this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak very briefly on the third reading of the Competition Policy Reform Bill 1995 to point out to the chamber that the day before yesterday I asked about the conflict between private property rights and the requirements that infrastructure be made available to all comers. I noted that the day before yesterday the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) said that there would be no contingent liability on the Commonwealth to pay compensation for orders enforcing third party access to state or privately owned infrastructure.

PARA.TAB: I would point out that this scenario fits in with some Industry Commission work which has been done on charities. I raised questions about this matter in December of last year—in fact, it was on 8 December last year. In particular, I raised the issue of indirect taxes on charities in relation to the Industry Commission report on charitable organisations.

The commission's draft report recommended abolition of so-called input tax concessions for charities. That means, imposing payroll tax, sales tax, rates and land tax on every school, hospital, church or social welfare organisation in Australia. The commission also cast an unfriendly eye on concessions to charities for water, sewerage and electricity charges. I understand that the commission's final report is either with or about to be delivered to the Treasurer (Mr Willis). Through the minister, I ask the government to release the report immediately it has been received, so that we can see how the Industry Commission proposes that user charges be levied on charities and the social infrastructure of this country.

There is an enormous amount of interest within the community on this whole question. If the report is not released swiftly, some people might well be entitled to conclude it as being probable that the removal of water, sewerage and electricity concessions for charities is on the agenda, and that part of a hidden agenda for raising revenue in this country is likely to embrace imposing full cost recovery user charges and indirect taxes on the non-profit community sector.

I do hope that the Industry Commission report will be rapidly released after having been received. I do not intend to go over all the points I made during the second reading debate in opposition to this piece of legislation. I simply refer honourable senators to the comments that I made then and at the committee stage of the debate. I thank the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995CUSTOMS, EXCISE AND BOUNTY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 8 June, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will address the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill and Senator Parer will address the detail of the bounty bill. Over the last three or four days there has been an enormous amount of work done to get the bill to this position. While being very critical of the bill the government put in its initial form, I do want to acknowledge the amount of work that the department officers have done.

PARA.TAB: The legislation we have before us is incredibly important because it addresses a fundamental point of principle. It is one of the few areas in which both sides of this chamber are consistent, whereby a tax is rebated when it is applied to the cost of doing business in the industries of agriculture, mining, fishing and forestry. To the coalition, a fundamental policy in principle which is not shared by the government is that we would prefer to see all taxes on all business inputs progressively removed.
