By addressing this as a fundamental policy thrust, we believe that virtually every industry or business will be able to compete with any other country in the world. It will also have the dramatic impact of reducing unemployment and the evils that go with it.

This legislation is split into four fundamental areas. The first one is retrospectivity; the second is the abolition of the category of residential premises; the third is the narrowing of the definition of minerals; and the fourth is the tightening of the definitions of agriculture and mining operations. The original bill was just 9 1/2 pages. It was so badly put together in the stated policy position of the government on budget night—or was it? One must ask: was it a deliberate misrepresentation of the government's intention? There are seven pages of government amendments to a bill of 9 1/2 pages; and there are five from the opposition. I am not sure as yet how many there are from the Democrats and the Greens, but certainly there are a number of amendments from them.

The first issue which I want to cover is retrospectivity. In doing so, it is interesting to note that, on 16 December 1993, the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht, in dealing with a bill at that particular time with regard to retrospectivity, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, once it is through, it is through. No-one will be able to do much with it because no-one is going to come back in here in nine months time and try retrospectively to legislate, in view of the workload of the Senate and in view of the fact that a lot of people in the Senate, including myself, are a little careful about retrospective legislation. I want to make that point to the committee.

In dealing with this bill we will see just how far this government has gone in terms of retrospectivity. We will be moving amendments to remove all aspects of retrospectivity, every single bit of it. We will also be moving to have the old act in place up until budget night and the new bill commencing from budget night.

PARA.TAB: It must be noted that, from a public policy point of view—and Senator Schacht has said this many times—it is the government's intent to bring this scheme back to its original position. What is happening in practice is that the government has left itself wide open to all sorts of claims and applications, which we will see start to flood in once the legislation goes through, because the legislation fails to have the new laws operate from the night of announcement. I quote from the second reading speech to highlight the particular situation we have before us now and the changes that are being introduced:

SPEECH.PARA: During the last year in particular, as a result of a series of legal challenges, eligibility definitions in the Scheme have been subjected to considerable expansion. This has pointed to ambiguities in the interpretation of these definitions, which demand urgent remedial attention so as to prevent the exploitation of the Scheme and a consequential drain on the public purse.

The reason there are these claims is that the customs department itself was interpreting the act wrongly. It was not until such time as these cases were taken before the courts in this land, initially the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, that we found there was a wrong interpretation of the position of the customs department. That is worth bearing in mind.

PARA.TAB: We cannot condone, nor can we support, a unilateral action which dissolves people's rights in law by the stroke of a pen in this parliament. In this particular case, to be going back to 1986 is beyond belief. The government, which has been in power all this time, has had plenty of time to fix up its own mess. It is now complaining about what it terms `mickey mouse claims' because of a problem that it created and a problem that it allowed to perpetuate.

These amendments also create an enormous challenge to the Australian Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine. Are they going to stand up and be counted with regard to protecting people's rights in law or are they going to collapse and go with the government? They will be judged either very kindly if they stand up for the fundamental principles or very harshly if they do not. We will find out in due course what their position will be.

It is not surprising that the government has chosen this route, because it has always been about interfering with the rights of the individual; whereas we believe that the right of the individual is paramount. I would also add that I have not heard the government in this place claiming that there were fundamental flaws in the diesel fuel rebate and that the scheme needed changing to this extent.

The second category I raised is the matter of residential premises. Our position is quite simple and clear on that: it is purely a matter of equity. We will be moving amendments so that people who do not have access to alternative sources of power will be eligible for the diesel fuel rebate for their residential premises.

The third matter of principle is the narrowing of the definition of minerals. We once again will be opposing this measure because, in essence, we do not differentiate between the digging and processing of iron ore, for example, and the digging and processing of clay to make house bricks and tiles. It is fairly difficult to draw a distinction between those processes and the follow-up process in a manufacturing operation.

Fourthly, there is the narrowing of the definition of mining and agriculture. I have referred to the enormous number of amendments before the chamber for this legislation. Despite assurances given by the government, I believe that the intent of the bill was to greatly reduce the areas that were claimable under the previous scheme in law, practice and custom.

If in fact the government intent with agriculture, for example, was to remove amenity agriculture, that would involve a very simple amendment which clearly stated that only bone fide commercial agricultural or pastoral activities qualified. I think this is a classic example where KISS—that is, keep it simple, stupid—principles should have been applied. We now have an unbelievable list of activities, for both mining and agriculture, from the government, ourselves, the Greens and the Democrats.

The government has opened up a hornets' nest, I believe, which will live in the courts. We will be dealing in detail with various amendments in the committee stage, so at this time I will deal with only one: the amendment we are putting forward with regard to soil conservation work carried out in designated catchment areas through an approved catchment plan. I am absolutely amazed that the government has not picked up this particular amendment we put forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have picked up part of it, Senator.

—I am absolutely amazed you have not picked up this amendment. It is now custom and practice, in terms of development in soil conservation district areas and catchment plans, that members start at one end of a catchment area with an agreement between the people involved, and the voluntary work is carried out on an organized basis throughout the year. It seemed to me to be a very legitimate component in terms of what has developed in recent years as far as soil and water conservation is concerned in various areas of the landcare operation in Australia.

PARA.TAB: As far as the overall legislation is concerned, unless the matters concerning retrospectivity—we will go into that on a clause by clause basis in a moment or two—are dealt with appropriately, we will oppose this legislation. We are putting forward a considerable number of amendments which I believe will make the legislation better. It will reflect what has been the practice in the past in terms of the operation of the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1995. The diesel fuel rebate scheme is, I believe, one of the worst examples of public policy making legislation and implementation on the Commonwealth parliamentary record. Thirteen years ago a coalition government changed from a system in which all off-road users of diesel were exempt from excise to a system where an arbitrary selection of off-road users of diesel were entitled to a rebate, and so the diesel fuel rebate scheme was born.

PARA.TAB: The government of the day failed to define any policy objectives for the scheme. They were imprecise in the statement of policy intent; the wording of the act was vague, allowing a range of interpretations as to where the boundaries of the scheme lay; and the then government certainly did not provide a convincing justification as to why it had chosen to smile upon some groups, such as farmers and miners, while excluding from the scheme other major contributors to the Australian economy, such as our railways, our manufacturers, our marine tourist operators and many others.

At the time, Australian Democrat Senator John Siddons asked the simple question: who will be worse off in the new scheme? The government failed to answer. Failing to provide a simple, clear answer as to who was and was not supposed to be covered by the scheme condemned the Commonwealth government of the day to 13 years of incessant legislation.

The scheme is riddled with anomalies. If you mine ore, transport it to the processing site and then process it and sell it you can claim a rebate for the transportation. If you mine ore, process it and then transport it and sell it you cannot claim for the transportation. Where is the sense in that? Consider two identical boats off the coast of Queensland, one fishing, the other one carrying tourists, both earning valuable export dollars for Australia. The fishing boat gets the rebate, the identical tour boat does not.

The original excise was meant to make diesel-using vehicles contribute towards road costs, but the exclusion of rail from the scheme pushes more traffic back on to the roads, adding to those very same costs. The scheme is supposed to help farmers and miners, but pushing up rail costs means it slugs those same farmers and miners every time they send their goods to market.

There are three different rates of rebate for different sorts of activities. Do they bear any relation to any stated policy objectives? Mining uranium for export to France gets a 92 per cent rebate. Powering hospitals and aged care facilities gets a 76 per cent rebate. I wonder if the minister can confirm that this is an accurate reflection of this government's priorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a reflection of what we inherited, Senator.

—You had a number of years, Minister, to rectify those anomalies and it is now only after some 13 years that you are attempting it—and you are not attempting that particular one, I might say. That will be an amendment that the Democrats will move, and I trust you will support it. For 13 years these anomalies have been brought to government attention again and again. For 13 years claims for rebate have been the subject of dispute, appeal and counter appeal.

PARA.TAB: The Australian National Audit Office told the government to define some objectives for the scheme. What was the outcome? Nothing. The Industry Commission told the government that the scheme was discriminatory and needed fixing. What was the outcome? Nothing. John Button, former minister for industry, was going to undertake a review of the scheme and all its anomalies. What happened? Nothing. Finally, in 1995, this government is taking action. But does it take action to fix this botched up mess of a scheme? No. The only reason it takes action is that it is desperate for revenue in order to maintain its fiction of a budget surplus.

The government has approached the diesel fuel rebate scheme as some sort of a vast, misshapen piggy bank to be smashed open and raided for whatever pennies could be scraped out. Only because it needs money and only because 13 years of failure to fix this mess have finally caught up with the government through a series of unexpected court room losses has the government chosen to act.

Even in taking this action to smash open the diesel fuel rebate piggy bank the government has taken little or no care. It has not consulted adequately with affected groups and it has given no consideration to simple fairness. In attempting to abolish the residential category, a change for which there is not even an attempt at justification in the minister's second reading speech, the government did not consider the huge slug on pensioners, who cannot afford to convert their old diesel heaters. The Australian Democrats call on the government to introduce a scheme to assist people to convert to more efficient forms of domestic heating.

The government also failed to consider the impacts on people living in remote areas, not to mention the sudden cost increase being imposed on remote area tourist operators, remote area roadhouses or coastal shipping. I foreshadow that I will be moving an amendment to ensure that those living and working in remote areas of Australia who are currently entitled to the rebate are protected from unfair and unavoidable rises in the cost of energy.

The cost of this measure would be minor but let me state further that the Australian Democrats would support any attempt by the government to recoup the cost through a very minor adjustment to rebate rates. In other words, we do not mind if we get an adjustment of fairness in the way in which the scheme impacts by aiding people living and working in remote areas and decreasing the rebate to pay for that of those people, miners in particular, who currently are on a good wicket. We are, I repeat, a fiscally responsible party. I wonder whether the government will be prepared to accept that particular challenge.

In an associated budget measure, the government announced a mammoth 380 per cent increase in the rate of excise on light fuel. While there is some sense behind this decision in terms of stopping substitution of diesel for a less efficient fuel—and that is generally acknowledged—the government has once again failed to consult and failed to consider the impacts of such a massive immediate tax rise. The impact on rail costs will be a hidden slug for the very miners and farmers that the diesel rebate scheme is supposedly designed to help—not to mention the fact that rail transport is by far the most environmentally benign and efficient that this country can offer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most passenger trains are electric trains today in Australia.

—Some are left on diesel and I think you should have considered them. In addition, marine tourist operators—who are part of an important major Australian export industry—have to quote prices up to two years in advance to be included in the brochures and packages of tourist agents around the world. This sudden 380 per cent belt would, if not fixed up, ensure that many of these operators spend the next two years running at a loss. The Australian Democrats call on the government to give serious consideration to phasing in this massive tax hit over a more reasonable period.

PARA.TAB: In summary, this very poorly designed scheme which has been neglected for 13 years is being raided by the government for funds—an action taken without consultation and without taking simple and social economic justice into account. The Australian Democrats believe that this entire wretched scheme requires an immediate and total overhaul. This bill certainly does not achieve that. The minister is smiling, and I hope he will put his efforts into this overhaul.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want to extend this at one moment and then reduce it the next.

—I know it is a massive task, but I also believe that your undoubted capacities and qualities are equal to the task. The Democrats are looking forward to your efforts in this direction. It is time taxpayers' money was directed towards activities which are of economic and social value to the community as a whole, and are not determined by the historical accident of which groups in the community had the ear of government in 1982.

PARA.TAB: To start the ball rolling, I foreshadow that the Australian Democrats will move an amendment to remove the eligibility for rebate of diesel used in the mining of uranium. That is the amendment I mentioned before, and the minister appeared to give me some encouragement for that. I hope he can maintain his spirit of encouragement as that amendment goes through the committee stages.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you consult the uranium miners?

—The Australian Democrats are interested in the benefits to the community as a whole—not just the miners and not just ministers who cannot get up quite enough courage to stand up to the French. It is bad enough that we dig the stuff up. It is appalling that we export it. You must admit that it is criminal that we sell it to the French. Why on earth should the Australian taxpayer—in addition to all of that—subsidise this dreadful activity?

PARA.TAB: We have all been very critical of our government's attitude towards the French in the last couple of weeks. We have been saying that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) should have taken a much harder stance towards the French. In fact, that has toughened the backbone of our foreign minister, and we now have a stronger position yet the Australian taxpayers continue to subsidise the mining of uranium and its sale to the French. I really commend that amendment to the attention of the government.

There are two other issues I would like to deal with. The first is the claim in some quarters that exclusion of clay for bricks and limestone for cement from the rebate scheme, the only two quarried home building materials that currently get the rebate, will add huge amounts to the cost of a new home. That is garbage. I worked in the building industry for a number of years. I have compared my own calculations with those of the housing industry. We both agree that the maximum impact on the cost of building a new home would be less than $50—hardly a sum to be taken into account. To pursue the argument that the digging up of clay and limestone in this context is equal to the extraction of minerals in the definition of mining is just ludicrous.

I would like to deal with the great furphy of the so-called retrospectivity of this bill. With regard to this so-called retrospectivity, a view has been put to the Australian Democrats by the Minerals Council, formerly AMIC. I should point out that this body is a representative industry body whose members include Boral, CSR and Pioneer, the three major groups which feel they are being hurt by so-called retrospectivity.

The view put to us by the Minerals Council is that this bill is not about retrospectivity but about the clarification of the intent of the diesel fuel rebate scheme. This is not like a retrospective tax; this is not like going back to 1986 and saying, `Oh, we forgot to charge some tax, pay it up now.' This is about taxpayers' money which was never intended to be handed out for the activities for which it is now being claimed. It was never intended to be a rebate for lawn mowing. It was never intended to finance drilling for water or supplying electricity to a grid. It was never intended to count dredging sand or exploding stones out of a quarry as mining.

Let us look at the cases that we are dealing with. In the so-called Nunawading case, Customs won in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against the claim which the Nunawading Council made that lawn mowing was agriculture. Who in their right mind would class lawn mowing of nature strips, parks and gardens of a local council as agriculture? Nunawading appealed to the Federal Court. That is where the case now stands—hardly a settled law of the day. But if Nunawading's claim at some future date and against all available evidence should be successful, the Australian taxpayer would be up for $40 million on what can only be described as a furphy—a stupid claim that lawn mowing is part of agriculture.

Let us turn to mining for minerals, the extraction of minerals, the quarrying and dredging of sand. In this bill the government excludes the mining of sand, sandstone, soil, slate, clay, basalt, granite, limestone and water. That, I believe, is a fair enough start. In the Neumann Sands case, the claim was made that the dredging of sand for concrete and as bedding sand should be classed as mining. In the 1987 Neumann case that claim was rejected—and, I believe, rightly so. In the 1995 Neumann Sands case the arguments that were used by the court to justify that judgment were apparently overturned. That case is now on appeal to the Federal Court. If the government lost the case, the Australian taxpayer would be up for $91 million.

We have a related case which uses some of the arguments we used in the Neumann's case—that is, the water authority of WA. It was claimed that the pumping of water was rebatable under the mining heading. There is another case, under the sweeper clauses, on agriculture and mining—that is, the Cowell Electric supply case. It was held that, if some of the electricity supply to towns was used for agriculture, it could properly be applied under the category of agriculture to qualify for the rebate. Here the Australian taxpayer would be up for $30 million.

We do not have a settled area of law here that is being changed retrospectively; we have a series of decisions which are palpably not intended by the definitions of the original legislation. Admittedly that legislation was ill defined. Admittedly it should have been changed by previous governments and by this government, but it has not been done.

Why on earth would we now fall for the trick of somebody calling for clarification on commonsense and legal grounds? Why would we call clarification retrospectivity? Why would we fall for that trick because somebody was clever to use the word `retrospectivity'? It is something that will cost the taxpayer between $160 million and $190 million. The Australian Democrats are not going to fall for that particular trick. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to confine my remarks in the main to the Customs, Excise and Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill, which really is non-controversial. I should address it, though, in view of the Conroy report and everything that went before it. However, the bill could pale into insignificance compared with the other legislation before us.

PARA.TAB: The diesel fuel rebate is an absolute mess. It has moved right away from its original intent. I even think the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) would agree with that. I see him nodding. We have before us a situation where the diesel fuel rebate applies to mining, agriculture, fishing boats and ferries but does not apply to things like tourist boats. There is a 380 per cent increase in respect of light fuel oil. This is a grave injustice because the two categories perform similar functions. One is a service, I know, and the other is producing minerals, goods or whatever. It is something that must be addressed. If it is not addressed by this government, it will be addressed by the coalition government after the next election.

It is a pity Senator Spindler is not here. It is amazing how he can twist words. I think even the government and the minister could not help but agree that, whatever you call this legislation, it is retrospective. It applies to a law that has been in existence for some time. The Democrats became politically correct and said, `It's not retrospective; it's clarification.' They were the words used by the Democrats.

The Customs, Excise and Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill is of considerable importance to Customs. The bill contains amendments to six pieces of legislation, namely the Customs Act 1901, the Customs Administration Act 1985, the Excise Act 1901, the Distillation Act 1901, the Spirits Act 1906 and the Bounty (Fuel Ethanol) Act 1994.

The most significant purpose of the bill, I believe, is to implement the recommendations of the Conroy review. This review was commissioned by the government in May 1993 in response to the parliamentary inquiry into the controversial Midford Paramount case. The principal inquiry was that conducted by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts which delivered its final report in December 1992. The JCPA report called into question the competence and judgment of the Australian Customs Service.

The review offered a series of recommendations. These recommendations were to eliminate the possibility of any future impropriety and to infuse the Customs Service with a culture of professionalism and accountability. The turning point—as the Conroy report was entitled—recommended changes that would overcome deficiencies in the Customs Service in the field of policies, priorities and organisational structure.

The tenor of the Customs Service, before its reformation, was brought to light in the Midford Paramount case. The ACS was geared towards revenue collection and law enforcement. These two drives had overshadowed the priorities of trade facilitation and the protection of civil liberties. This bill seeks to amend these deficiencies, and it has the support of the coalition.

The search and seizure provisions of the Customs Act have been amended by this bill in order to protect the individual rights and liberties of individuals in respect to privacy and security without disempowering Customs officers in their role of protecting national interests and national security.

Under the provisions of the bill, all warrants will require the bringing to bear of an independent mind to weigh up the circumstances of the case and to sanction the issue of a search warrant. This `independent mind' will necessarily be an independent judicial officer.

Under the previous legislation, any Customs or police officer who had a writ of assistance or a customs warrant could enter and search a house at any time and break open any chests or trunks and take away records and goods. These warrants were granted on application by the minister or Comptroller of Customs for a state or territory, by a state or territory supreme court.

As the Conroy review identified, under this regime, Customs officers were assuming too much authority without an independent opinion as to whether or not reasonable grounds had been established so as to justify the granting of a search warrant. This abuse of power came to a head in the Midford Paramount case in which Customs officers made executive decisions on raids, search and seizure at the whim of their own prejudgment without any mechanism of accountability.

In accordance with the Conroy review's identification of these problems, the coalition supports the amendment that will transfer the power to grant a search warrant from the comptroller to a judicial officer. This bringing to bear of an independent mind is a commendable measure that breaks the executive power of the Australian Customs Service that was not found to be in the best interests of the community. This is the cardinal change to the search and seizure provisions.

The statutory provisions of this bill governing the issue of search warrants will allow a measure of protection to those interests espoused by common law, in particular those interests upheld by the writ of trespass that maintain the privacy of the individual.

The Attorney-General's Department sees the bill as an improvement to personal liberty and privacy under the threat of a search and seizure operation and the department is satisfied that the bill meets the requirements of the Crimes Act.

The second major amendment in this bill to the Customs Act applies to the role of the head of the Australian Customs Service and their role in the reformed ACS. Apparently, his name is to be changed to the chief executive officer and this substitution will be concomitant with the new provision of ministerial power to issue policy directives to the CEO in the administration of Customs. That is fairly similar to a lot of other legislation that has been brought in on these sorts of authorities and GBEs.

The coalition supports these amendments because they are an appropriate reform of the service in the wake of Midford Paramount that exposed problems in the functioning and structure of the organisation. We are also supporting the amendments because it is in accordance with the coalition's philosophy. This is the philosophy which protects the rights and interests of the individual and the philosophy that champions unfettered business practice. The amendments to search and seizure and the role of the head of the Australian Customs Service reflect both of these aspirations.

The financial impact statement contained in this bill is not entirely correct in its assertion that there is no financial impact. This statement disregards the ramifications of the changes to the search and seizure provisions of the bill. The ramification arises in the delegation of the sanctioning of search warrants to judicial officers. This is the bringing to bear of the independent mind. It may not involve any Commonwealth expenditure; however it does transfer some expense to the states.

After the Midford Paramount case, the government was faced with the task of bringing the Comptroller-General to account. Denis Ives, the Public Service Commissioner, under the Public Service Act, issued a special pay decision allowing the previous Comptroller-General to maintain his $126,760 salary. Even Senator Cook said at the time that if it was not for this novel determination by the Public Service Commissioner, he would have been dropped to deputy secretary.

The Conroy review was an intelligent response to the Midford Paramount case, but the golden handshake given to the Comptroller-General who had the responsibility of overseeing this case was not. His actions were looked on with a lot of distaste by those on this side of the chamber and I think by the general public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The position of the Greens (WA) in relation to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill can be put fairly succinctly. We have problems with cutting out specifically the electric generation portion of the residential rebate without seeing a clear package of compensation. There are a number of issues, but they have not been examined or resolved. We would support a review and modification of that rebate, with the exclusion of heating, cooking and other items, but that is not an option now. We certainly do not have the time to try to do this unilaterally or to propose extensive amendments. We have some amendments that we will move, but if they should fail we will vote to retain the current residential rebate scheme.

PARA.TAB: We support the attempt to exclude so-called amenity agriculture. We support the exclusion of water from the definition of `mineral' for the purpose of the mining rebate and we will agree to them being excluded retrospectively. We will also look carefully at the sweeper clauses. We think the court was right about the Cowell case, but agree that the definition of `associated with agriculture or mining' is too open and should be more restrictive. How to make it restrictive without cutting out a range of important things is a difficult issue, and one we have all wrestled with. The plethora of the amendments—pages of them—is testimony of this.

In relation to quarrying generally, we would agree to exclude them in the future but not retrospectively. We think that water and amenity agriculture can be seen as a fairly clear cut issue in terms of the act. They should not be, and never have been, considered as mining or agriculture. The amount of agonising about quarrying is good evidence that there is no such clarity about this issue. In such a case, parliament should not abuse its power by overriding the judicial system.

This has always been our basic position. It has not changed or shifted, as a member of Senator Schacht's staff claimed. The only thing that has shifted and changed has been the government's position. It has changed in relation to its labyrinthine attempts to cobble together some sort of deal to give it what it wants.

We do not think the elimination of residential rebates, which are basically for rural people, should occur without a clear understanding of who will be affected and how the effects can be reduced. The government has tried to make a few concessions by including residential power generation within the definition of mining and agriculture. It has been announced that there will be a compensation package for Aboriginal communities, but there are other users who would be affected. This measure will effect people from remote communities and rural users. We should also include the in port aspect of coastal shipping where diesel is used to generate residential power for the residential requirements of the crew.

In short, there are a number of anomalies and inequities and there is no clear plan to remedy them. When there is, we may support this measure, but until then we will support the elimination of the residential rebate. Our preference is for a modified residential rebate that exclusively covers electricity generation. This could address several of our concerns. Some cost increases could be ameliorated by transferring the rebate for residential power generation under the mining rebate, which is about 30c a litre, or the agricultural rebate, which is about 32c per litre, to the residential rebate, which is paid at 24c. Governments will save between 6c and 8c per litre on all residential use by mining and agriculture, which is by far the bulk of residential diesel electricity use.

I will state on the record that the Greens (WA) do not favour diesel power generation. We believe that there are viable, often less expensive alternatives. The problem is the capital cost. If the government can come up with a program to support conversion through providing loan funds, tax rebates or through other means or a combination of means, we would happily support a move to decrease or eliminate the residential rebate. The program run by Illawarra Power is, in our opinion, a good start and possibly a good model.

I will now deal with diesel fuel rebates and retrospectivity. The issue is generally not about the classification or rebate but about the nature of the retrospectivity to 1986. There certainly are cases where legislation has included extension backwards in time. There was the case of the Chinese rifle imports or the Volvo claim. These certainly arise where a loophole in legislation that escaped parliamentary notice is discovered or a court makes a ruling on law which may be contrary to everyone's perception of what the intention of the law is. This can occur, and courts can and do rule on points of law, even if the court recognises that the ruling contradicts the sense of law.

An example is the recent finding of the court in relation to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Such a ruling casts all actions under such a law into question. The only option parliament has to preserve the intention of the law and the former actions under the law is to legislate to correct the problem and apply that legislation backwards. Such cases are rare. When they occur, there is generally a clear perception that this is an exceptionable case and so falls outside the normal definition of retrospectivity. The Senate has and does act in such cases. The question here is whether the matters brought before us in this legislation fit into this category. I will go through our interpretations.

I will now deal with amenity agriculture. If the law and other documents, the position of the customs office and rulings of the court consistently found that an area was excluded from rebate—there has not been any finding to the contrary—a backdated claim is not retrospective; it is clarification. The fact that a matter may still be before the court is not grounds against such clarification. Such a progression of claims may mean that the issue is always before the court. The fact that an issue is consistently raised is prima facie grounds to consider that the area in question is not clear and requires reclarification. In relation to amenity agriculture, this principle applies.

I will now deal with the notion of water as a mineral. If the law and other documents, the position of the customs office and the rulings of the court consistently found that an area was excluded from rebate or the area was not raised previously and now only an unexpected and unprecedented judgment was handed down in the court, there is a strong argument that the court is making a ruling on law. The Volvo case is such an example. To close a loophole opened by such an unexpected and inconsistent court ruling is not retrospective in that sense.

The finding that water is a mineral under the meaning of the mining rebate is, in our opinion, such an instance. I doubt if anyone in the Senate could honestly state that they think the intent of the mining rebate is to give a rebate to water extraction. In one famous case, Coca-Cola claimed that Coca-Cola was nutritious because it included water, and water is a nutrient. Water comes under many different headings. In this sense, obviously, that is not what we mean when we are talking about nutritious, and it is certainly not what a lot of people would mean when they mean mining.

I certainly do not believe that any average person would easily accept that water extraction is mining or that water is a mining product. I cannot seriously believe that the court would believe for a moment that it was the intention of the Customs Act to include water as a mineral for the purpose of the act. The Greens (WA) therefore believe that the finding was in relation to an unclarity in the act and that by accident it allowed water to fall under the definition of mining. In such a case I believe that it is proper to clarify the situation backwards as well as forwards.

Quarrying is a different matter. Customs initially granted rebates to quarrying under the law. This is evidence that the law itself appears to include quarrying, and Customs itself held this to be the case. The change in policy by customs was pursued through a loophole interpretation in which Customs believed it could claim it was not required to give rebates for quarrying. In spite of a level of unclarity that led Customs to give rebates for quarrying, Customs did not seek to clarify the issue through legislation.

Subsequently, the definition of mining was re-extended to cover quarrying operations. The courts found that the quarrying of limestone, granite and other materials for dressed building blocks was mining. Still Customs did not act. When Customs continued to insist that other forms of quarrying were not included, it could hardly claim that further extensions of the definition of mining to cover quarrying were unexpected. A key finding of the Auditor-General's report No. 27 of 1990-91 into the diesel rebate scheme was as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The criteria for eligibility under the scheme are complex and ill-defined. This combination has had the effect of broadening the scope of the scheme, increasing the likelihood of incorrect rebate payments being made and adding to the costs of administering the scheme.

This seems a fairly clear warning that a better definition is needed, and quarrying is certainly one of the most dubious areas of definition. In its lobbying to us, Customs gave us a document that on page 3 provides a definition of mining as `obtaining a mineral or minerals embedded in the material that was to be extracted'. This would be great from our perspective because we think it could be used to knock out rebates on coalmining. I note that this is not the definition that the government has proposed. Instead it seeks to exclude the products of quarrying. That is at least clearer. I give this definition only to illustrate the lack of clarity even with what the government was arguing in discussions with us.

PARA.TAB: The point is that the Greens (WA) would love to exclude quarrying. We are not anxious to include any more benefits to mining. We think the benefits are too great already, and we have consistently argued for a reduction of the mining rebate, which is rapidly expanding towards a cost of $1 billion each year. We certainly do not want to give any free kicks to the mining industry. We are happy to legislate to explicitly exclude quarrying, including those areas where claims are of longer standing such as limestone and granite, in the future.

The issue for us is that to legislate backwards in this case cannot be interpreted as anything other than overruling the decision of the courts in our minds. If the Greens, who would love to knock out the mining rebate, cannot accept the government arguments that it is not retrospective, I cannot see how anyone else can.

This area is anything but clear. Customs has not been clear. Certainly the situation and the right of the many conflicting claims have not been clear to many of us in the Senate. The current definition is incredibly contentious. Problems have been evident for many years. Customs has failed to clarify them. What we are now being asked to do is to overrule the court, which cannot be seen as finding on a point of law; to go against the court which has found that the intention of the law does include quarrying, and to legislate retrospectively. This seems to us a violation of the legal system by the legislature and an abuse of the principle that we will not legislate retrospectively. It has none of the qualities of our decision on water.

We cannot ethically support what we can only see as a ham-fisted attempt to remedy Customs inaction. The fact that we do not want quarrying to claim is not a good enough argument for the Senate to overrule the courts. The fact that the government might lose money is also not a good enough argument for the Senate to overrule the courts. The Greens cannot vote for that.

In relation to the sweeper clauses, where Customs has sought to exclude certain activities and the courts have found against it, parliament may agree with the courts. The judgment may be entirely logical and consistent with the law. It appears that positive finding for claims on use of diesel for power generation based on the portion that goes to farmers is such a case. It is entirely consistent with the granting of a rebate to stand-alone power in the same situation. To override the court would be to create a disincentive to grid connected diesel power for the same user in the same circumstance. It may not create that disincentive under the current situation of power provided at a flat rate to all users, but it may make a difference to rural communities when the competition policy bites and rural users and rural power stations face a situation of cost recovery instead of cross-subsidy. It is worth noting that small rural power stations are almost the only users of diesel power.

If rural power stations could claim a rebate for the portion of power provided to users who would be eligible for rebate for stand-alone diesel power, then the cost attributable to rural users would be less. In a cost recovery situation, rural users would pay lower power bills. We think this is a good idea, although we would prefer a program to convert rural power to sustainable sources. It is possible that, if the government were liable for such a rebate, it may consider such conversion more urgently.

We will be putting up an amendment to support the decision in the Cowell case and to extend the residential rebate to the generation of electricity with diesel other than at a premises as long as there is no other form of commercial energy available. The only other way we can protect that decision is to knock out the definition of agriculture, which leaves claims under the sweeper clauses and amenity agriculture open.Otherwise, we basically support the definitions of agriculture and mining that the government has put up, with some amendments made by various parties. We will get to the finer details in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —At such a late hour of the night I believe that when debating a second reading we should just stick to basics. The finer points of these bills have already been addressed by Senator Crane and, to some extent, by Senator Parer. However, I would like to put on the record some of the history of this scheme.

PARA.TAB: I heard Senator Spindler of the Australian Democrats and Senator Schacht, by interjection, say that the previous government left no direction on the diesel fuel rebate scheme, which was introduced in 1982. I beg to differ. I would like to read from the second reading speech delivered by the then Minister for the Capital Territory and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Michael Hodgman, on 17 August 1982 on the Diesel Fuel Tax Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1982. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill amends the Diesel Fuel Tax Act (No. 1) 1957 to terminate the operation of that Act on and from 8 o'clock tonight. The Bill forms part of a package of measures designed to terminate the diesel fuel certificate scheme...

which had operated since 1957. Diesel trucks were not a high percentage of the trucks on the roads at that time. They paid their fair share of road taxes by paying a certain amount per gallon of diesel fuel but certificates were issued for trucks used off road. He continued:

. . . and introduce a new rebate scheme for diesel fuel as foreshadowed by my colleague the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in his Budget Speech earlier tonight. From 8 o'clock this evening all diesel fuel will be required to be duty paid but rebates will be available to certain categories of users on condition that they use the fuel that they have purchased for open `off-road' purposes.

PARA.TAB: The provisions of the Diesel Fuel Tax Act (No. 1), however, will continue to apply in respect of diesel fuel entered for home consumption before 8 o'clock tonight. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: In the second reading speech on the Diesel Fuel Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982, delivered by Mr Hodgman that same night, he said:

On and from 8 o'clock tonight the existing diesel fuel certificate scheme, wherein certificates were issued to purchasers of diesel fuel for `off road' use to obtain the fuel at duty free prices, will be terminated. In its place this Bill will introduce a new rebate system which will require all purchases of diesel fuel to be made at the duty paid price with rebates payable to persons in certain categories for their `off road' use. I have already revoked the relevant Customs and excise by-laws which provided the authority for the issuance of diesel fuel certificates under the previous scheme.
He went on to say:
Any purchases of diesel fuel for `off road' use made at duty free rates under the certificate scheme up to 8 o'clock this evening...
would be on the same basis. I go now to question time on 19 August 1982, when Mr Kerin asked Mr Howard this question:

Is the Government imposing extra costs on drought stricken primary producers by changing the diesel fuel excise exemption to a rebate? Does the Government know that fuel costs represent a high proportion of farm cash costs, for example, 13 per cent for wheat growers? Will farmers have to fill in a form to get the rebate? How long will rebate applications take to process? Will the rebate not be repaid until taxation returns are processed at the end of the year? Who was making $176m out of the previous farm exemption system?
Mr Howard simply replied:
The changes that I announced on Tuesday night do not represent by any stretch of the imagination discrimination against primary producers.
In his speech in the second reading debate Mr Kerin said:

PARA.TAB: The Opposition—

SPEECH.PARA: that was the Labor Party at that time—
does not oppose these Bills. Their purpose is to introduce a system of rebates on duty paid on diesel fuel used off-road . . .
He later said:

PARA.TAB: We do not oppose the Bills because they are Budget Bills, but it is impossible to be other than highly critical . . .

SPEECH.PARA: He claimed that having a rebate would disadvantage some industries. However, soon after all of that had been put into place the coalition went out of government. It was very precisely put down in August 1982 that the diesel fuel rebate scheme was basically to be used for off-road circumstances. That was the position in 1982.

PARA.TAB: What has happened since then? The rebate has not blown out of proportion as much as we were told last week at the legislation committee. I believe that the rebate at present is somewhere in line with the expansion of farming and mining in Australia. I do not think it has blown out, except in relation to Senator Schacht's fear of what courts may do.

Since March 1983, when this government came to power, if the government had any problems—Senator Button tried to do this—it should have been sorting them out gradually as time went on. Unfortunately, the government did not do anything about the problems and tried to fix them up a bit here and a bit there. For instance, the government took 4c off the mining industry in the budget of two years ago. It went to the AAT with this and that; it might have won this and lost that—that sort of thing. The government did not do a real reworking of the whole situation. That is why it is in trouble now. If it were not for the AAT appeals the government lost, we might not have this bill here now.

On the night that budget came down, we did not know how wide ranging these effects were, but we soon found out. Fortunately, we had a debate some time ago in this parliament which brought all those problems out. As a result of the legislation committee last week, the government has about three pages of amendments. Without going through them, I believe we have reached a reasonable situation with those three pages of amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seven pages.

—There were only three pages last Friday. Whether there are three pages or seven pages, we have a heap of government amendments which I believe will bring the scheme back to where it should be. Basically, primary industries, such as the mining industry and the fishing industry, are the main beneficiaries of it. The government has gradually put the rebate back for off-road use in those industries. Do not blame the coalition for that, because what it left in 1983 was quite clear. I believe we are going somewhere down the line.

PARA.TAB: I heard Senator Spindler mention that the mining council is made up of three big companies, as though that were some reason to have provisions in this bill that would act against big mining companies. I heard Senator Margetts say something about mining companies, too. As much as that lot dislike mining companies, they all welcome the export income they bring to Australia. I believe big mining companies should have big profits and more taxes. If they did, then all Australians would benefit.

There are a couple of other areas that I would like to address. Senator Spindler mentioned the effect on diesel fuel in relation to the quarrying of clay for the making of bricks. To me, quarrying is quarrying. If the legislation is not clear, by all means rule it out and set up a new definition. Whatever ore comes out of the ground it is still mining. Mining is mining and quarrying is quarrying.

I abhor retrospective legislation and I do not think it is the way that Australia should be going. I have no sympathy for golf clubs claiming the diesel fuel rebate for mowing golf courses. The water authority in Western Australia has put in a claim for pumping water. I have no sympathy for that authority. The authority would have charged its rates from 1986 onwards and the ratepayers would have paid. If the authority won a big claim it might pass it on to ratepayers. However, retrospective legislation is retrospective legislation.

The Greens call it clarification or something, but it is still retrospective legislation. If the government has such a good case it should let the matter go to the highest court in the land and have it sorted out. I believe it is time for the government to get back to square one on the diesel fuel rebate and sort out exactly what it wants. The government has not touched the matter legislatively since 1982 and that is why it now has this problem.

In our business we claim the diesel fuel rebates, so I had better declare my interest. I believed that there was a regulation that the rebate had to be claimed within 12 months. I was always under that impression. In our business we made sure that we claimed at least every three or four months. If the government had introduced this legislation two or three years ago we would not have had a problem with retrospectivity back to 1986. I have had it in the back of my mind so the government must have at least spoken about it at some stage.

I will now come to the issue of light crude oil. This legislation will change the way that light crude oil is treated. You can get some pretty good light crude oil now. It can be used on high performing diesels and in road vehicles without changing filters or fuel pumps or adjusting injectors. However, I have no sympathy for transporters who are getting away with not paying the levy because they should compete on the same level as everyone else. Once the levy is in place those people will go back to using diesel. I believe it is wrong to change the treatment for off-road vehicles. Light crude oil is used off road and I do not believe that it should be levied on power generation.

I have here a chart that was submitted to the committee last Friday. I have shown it to the minister. It features an old 44-gallon drum, which is now called a 200-litre drum. This chart shows the possible yield from a barrel of crude oil. Roughly 50 per cent comes off as gasoline. Prior to 1957 it had a levy on it for road usage. Forty-four per cent is distillate, or diesel fuel in everyman's language. That has had a levy on it since 1957, but it changed in 1982 to the rebate scheme. Then there is a narrow band of crude oil, or light cycle oil.

After those things are taken into account, little is left—six per cent, which is furnace oil, bitumen, et cetera—which is not taxed. I presume the government will be looking at that six per cent. It has not got far to go to be taxing the whole lot. The government has taxed fuel to the hilt. It has turned it into a broad based taxation system. It might as well have looked at a broad based consumption tax, which Mr Keating suggested in 1983. The point I make is that the government does not have much of that barrel of oil left to tax. Of course, it could start on the container. There is probably already sales tax on the container. I seek leave to incorporate this chart in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The graph read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: [GRAPH OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 2234]

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the government has gone beyond all reason with this bill. As I said before, it is time it got back to rewriting the whole lot and setting different parameters. As far as retrospectivity is concerned, we should forget about that and let the courts sort it out.

—Some time ago when we were debating diesel fuel rebates, I indicated that I had an interest in certain outcomes arising from this legislation. At the time it was principally in the area of primary production. I mentioned contracting and others. I note that the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) has put a number of amendments through which will tend to clarify those positions.

PARA.TAB: When Senator Panizza was speaking, the question of retrospectivity came through. A number of companies will benefit from, in a sense, retrospective benefits. I suppose, in a true sense, they are not retrospective in the sense of taking away cash or something that was previously there. Nevertheless, there is a principle there that our party will be voting against.

I am a small shareholder in a number of companies. I have shared in several dozens of companies amongst which principal beneficiaries, which are probably obvious at the moment, would be CSR, Boral and maybe Pioneer. There could be others but, as a small shareholder, my holding in terms of the total would be insignificant. I just wanted to make clear to the Senate that I have always tried to declare an interest, even though it be a very small interest, whether it be in pharmacy where my wife has been a salaried pharmacist, wool or whatever it might be.

The purpose of my rising tonight was just to indicate that, for the record, I do have a small interest in what might be the outcome. I wish to indicate that in no way does that affect my vote or the position I have taken on this. As an overall result, the effect would be perhaps minuscule in terms of the relatively small holding I might have or I might hold jointly with my wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just as Senator Watson has got it off his chest, I also state that I have shareholdings in companies that would use diesel. They would not amount to a lot of money and they are certainly not going to influence my vote on this matter.

PARA.TAB: The Senate today is debating the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill. The bill will amend various provisions of the Customs Act and will modify the eligibility criteria for diesel fuel rebate scheme recipients, as foreshadowed in this year's budget.

The present form of the diesel fuel rebate scheme dates from 1 August 1986 and provides eligible primary producers undertaking off-road activities with a 100 per cent rebate on diesel fuel excise, which currently stands at 32.5c a litre. The government is always telling us that we would have put sales tax on everything. I think we ought to put it on the record that the excise would have been 15c a litre instead of 32c. The mining companies will receive a rebate of 31c per litre.

Other eligible users, including hospitals, aged homes, nursing homes and residential will receive a rebate of 24.8c per litre. In 1994-95 the diesel fuel rebate granted to primary producers will be $515 million, rising to $543 million in 1995-96. The rebate to the mining industry for 1994-95 will be $632 million and $691 million in 1995-96. To put these figures in context, the government anticipates raising $3.9 billion from diesel excise in 1995-96, up from $3.6 billion in 1994.

There are four main sections of the customs and excise bill. They include, firstly, the exclusion of the agriculture category for rebate eligibility from 1 August 1996, with estimated savings of $15 million in 1995-96 and retrospective savings of around $40 million. Secondly, the bill will abolish the residential premises category from the rebate eligibility from July 1995, with estimated savings of $13.6 million in 1995-96, offset by $1.8 million in compensation. Thirdly, the bill will narrow the definition of minerals to exclude from rebate eligibility mining operations that involve the extraction of sand, sandstone, clay, granite and water from 1 August 1996. We are really going to the bottom of the barrel to make that differentiation between mining and extraction. But I suppose that desperate needs demand desperate measures, and the government wanted to get that budget into surplus.

TALK.START.PARA: —So did you, senator.
—Of course we did but—
—Where else would you cut expenditure?
—You certainly would not make a differentiation between mining and extraction.
—It all adds up.

—Yes. There will be estimated savings of $5 million in 1995-96, with a retrospective saving of at least $16 million. Fourthly, the bill will tighten the definition of agricultural and mining operations by removing the broad sweeper clause and replacing it with the prescribed list of activities that entitle rebate eligibility. The estimated savings will be $7 million in 1994-95, with retrospective savings of at least $30 million. That is despite government assertions that the purpose of these amendments was to restore the scope of the diesel fuel rebate scheme to that introduced in 1986.

PARA.TAB: Considerable concern was raised by various industry groups that the proposed changes in the bill went much further than those announced in the budget. That is correct. We did not get a lot of flak when the budget came out, but when people did investigate it, a huge amount of concern was raised. As a result of that concern, the bill was referred to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and the Senate Economics Legislation Committee for review. Nineteen submissions were received from industry groups, farming and mining organisations, including the NFF, WA Farmers, AMEC, MIM and the Tourism Task Force, amongst others.

I will touch briefly on some of the main concerns raised about this deeply flawed bill. The retrospective element of the bill, reaching back nine years to 1986, have been roundly condemned. As stated in the Senate committee report, the retrospective elements of the bill fail to overturn all decisions handed down by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court to the financial disadvantage of the claimants and abort other decisions in the process. The government's rationale for introducing these retrospective measures is that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and Federal Court judgments have resulted in broadening the scope of eligible rebate activities beyond the original intention of the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

This did nothing to allay the concerns of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. That committee found that the bill clearly trespasses on the basic rights of those who are subject to the law, who are entitled to be treated according to what the law means and, at the same time, as declared by the courts. The Law Council of Australia submitted that the amendments offend against proper principles in a number of areas, including constitutional concerns that the right to obtain a rebate—which has existed since at least 1986—is to be removed, without allowing any just terms as required by section 51, and the proposal to introduce retrospectivity without compensation.

The coalition, rightly, is opposing the retrospective elements contained in this bill. The amendment dealing with the tightening of the definition of `agricultural and mining operations' raised a great deal of disquiet at the Senate committee. The NFF stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the prescribed lists inevitably lacked detail, suffered definitional problems, overlooked needs of circumstances in small industries and failed to keep pace with the changing industry practice . . .
AMEC submitted that the new definitions in the bill are vague and incomplete, and that the operation of the scheme would depend upon subjective decisions by the Customs Service.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane has led this debate for the coalition and he has done an excellent job in running these amendments to ground. He and I deplore the fact that the government remains adamant, even after the Senate committee hearing, that primary producers carting grain and stock from storage areas to the front gate, as well as subcontractors carting off road, will not be eligible in this tightening category. To categorically exclude such activities as extraction of sand, sandstone, soil, clay and water, where the materials are not being recovered with their inherent mineral qualities, would have the effect, as stated by the shadow resource minister, Peter McGauran—

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!—a good man.

—He is a great man, Senator. It would have the effect of setting up an artificial distinction between mining and quarrying and disadvantaging the latter. Boral, Pioneer and CRS, which comprise 75 per cent of the quarrying industry, have submitted that this measure will cost them heavily and would result in increases to the costs of building material. And yet that would have been another increase in the cost of a home to be borne by newly married couples if the coalition were not forever vigilant and watched for these increases in tax. Of course, we will be voting against it. We will oppose those amendments.

PARA.TAB: The amendment to abolish the `residential' category from the rebate eligibility has serious implications for residents in remote areas. It is a callous action by the government. Once again, that action demonstrates its indifference to people living in rural and regional areas—although I suppose I can understand the government's problem: it is not going to spend money where it does not get votes. But it should not persecute the people; they are Australians too.

As the shadow minister stated, the customs figures show that there were 14,500 claims received under the residential category in 1992-93 of which 13,500 were individuals, the remainder being hospitals, nursing homes, medical institutions and aged care homes. If Australians living in rural and remote areas are forced to use diesel fuel as a result of lacking access to an electricity grid or any other energy source, then they fully deserve to continue to receive a rebate—and the coalition will be moving such an amendment. I cannot understand, Senator Schacht, how you could possibly put a tax on fuel that runs the plants that generates the lighting on properties of people who have no access to an electricity grid. What do you expect them to do—use a hurricane lamp?

TALK.START.PARA: —A candle.
—Or perhaps a candle? That is very callous—to tax someone's ability to light their property.
—You misunderstand the whole category.
—No, I do not. What surprises me, too, is that you came off a farm and yet you would do this to farmers.
—Yes, and that is why I know all about it; as a result I know every trick in the book.

—We are going to move an amendment to ensure that people in remote areas who lack access to that sort of energy source are not going to be disadvantaged. Through this bill, the government seeks to retrospectively recoup past revenue lost as a result of far-reaching decisions made by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court. I thank Senator Crane for his very good work on this bill and the coalition amendments. I think most of those amendments will be supported by the Democrats and the Greens. Senator Schacht, you have been done again.
—You never know your luck in a big city.

—That is right, and I have not canvassed which way the Democrats and Greens are going to vote; but I would be very surprised and disappointed if they support amendments to take away the rights of farmers who do not have the ability to be connected to an electricity grid and are forced to generate their power with diesel. I would be very surprised if anyone in the Senate would support that sort of amendment. I am sure they will all vote against it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill proposes to amend the Customs Act 1901 and remove the eligibility for the payment of rebate of customs duty in respect of the use of diesel fuel at residential premises; remove the definition of `minerals' materials that are more valuable for use in their own right, rather than for their inherent mineral worth; ensure that a rebate of custom and excise is payable only where the diesel fuel is for use in an activity embedded in the definition of agriculture; and, remove the clause conferring rebate on activities connected with mining operation and primary productions, and insert a clear list of eligible activities.

PARA.TAB: I note that the government has supplied amendments nos 1 to 28 in relation to some aspects of clarification and some specific activities which relate to this. In the Alert Digest No. 7 of this year, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee noted that subclause 2(2) items 4, 7, 8 and 10 of schedule 1 will have effect retrospectively from 1986. These items propose amendments to the definition of agriculture, minerals and mining operations in subsection 164(7) of the Customs Act 1901. They set out some of the uses of diesel fuel which will attract rebate.

Originally, it was intended that only miners and farmers would have the benefit of such rebate. I note the comments made by Senator Spindler earlier in this regard, that there was a question of intention. Parliament may well have intended that certain aspects flow from the legislation which it enacted some time ago—but did the people of Australia understand that? There is nothing unusual in legislation having a progressive interpretation by the courts over a period of time.

It appears that, in this instance, courts and tribunals had a varying interpretation over time in relation to the diesel fuel rebate scheme. Government would not be responsible if it did not respond to the various interpretations placed on legislation, especially if there was some sort of loophole. But what responsible government does is act when that loophole comes to light—and it acts prospectively, not retrospectively. There may well be a loophole which needs attention.

Mention was made earlier that rebates are available in relation to mowing golf courses, lawns and the like. I think the case involving Nunawading City Council was mentioned. But, in this instance, I believe the government has been on notice for some time that there have been problems in relation to this area, and it should have acted earlier. I think earlier speakers—including Senator Crane, Senator Margetts and Senator Spindler—touched on this very point.

The government should have acted at that time and should have legislated prospectively. It was with the aspect of retrospectivity in mind that the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills drew to the attention of the Senate the fact that these provisions unduly trespass upon the basic rights of individuals. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . those subject to the law are entitled to be treated according to what the law says at the relevant time and according to what the law means at that time as declared by the courts.
That is a basic principle of law, a basic tenet of our legal system. In this instance, it is not a question of clarification; it is a question of retrospectivity.

PARA.TAB: In some instances, the legislature accommodates retrospective legislation. We sometimes have legislation by press release. That is, the minister makes a press release and subsequently there is legislation. People are placed on notice that legislation is being brought in which will have some effect, if not total effect, from the date of the press release and, normally, the time lapse between the press release and the passing of the legislation is not too great. But one also has to look at any question of prejudice that might be suffered by individuals and, of course, the extent of the retrospectivity. In this case, we have a period of time which goes back to 1986.

I believe the question of prejudice has some application to those who have court cases pending. I notice that there is some mention in the bill of applications or proceedings which are pending in the Federal Court. I note that, in the Cowell Electric Supply Co. case, special leave is being sought to appeal to the High Court.

If there are any pending proceedings, you have the situation where the ground rules are changed in the course of those proceedings, and that is prejudicial to the person who is bringing that action. That happened in some refugee cases in relation to another piece of legislation dealing with migration, and that too was abhorrent for that reason.

It is for those reasons that I say that the provisions here do offend the principle of retrospectivity. For that reason, I believe the coalition should oppose these provisions, and is doing so. To treat them merely as clarification is not quite appropriate here because the government is enacting legislation which will go back some time and will have wide effect.

If the legislation were prospective, then it could be clarification. But I do not believe you can clarify the law in the past. I believe that clarification can only act prospectively. You cannot clarify what people thought yesterday, because what they thought yesterday has been and gone. You can only clarify what people will think in the future, how people will approach a matter and how they will understand it. With great respect to Senator Spindler, I cannot accept his argument as to clarification in this instance.

I might just point to the question of the definitions of `minerals' and `agriculture' and contrast that with the amendments which have been lately brought before the Senate. There are a number of clarifications for which I applaud the government, but I believe this demonstrates how the government has approached this matter in a somewhat ad hoc fashion. I do not wish to criticise the government for perhaps being alive to some issues and thereby remedying it. But I believe that the number of amendments, and the way they have been brought before the Senate, indicates that perhaps there could have been some forethought on this matter.

I notice that, for instance, there is a clearer definition of `earthworks' and a clearer accommodation of the planting of trees on agricultural property. It is available for rebate as long as the planting of trees is not for the purpose of felling. I think that is laudable, but the government has to be very careful that, in including so many specifics in the legislation, it still does not leave unaddressed other aspects, other activities, which could well attract a legitimate rebate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was the problem with the existing scheme.

—In that case an amendment should be brought in. What I am saying is that the problem with legislating retrospectively is that we unleash a can of worms. It is a shame that these definitions and the clarifications were not addressed earlier. I believe this matter was brought to the government's attention some time ago. That, I believe, rests squarely at the door of the government. Nonetheless, for the base reason of retrospectivity, I believe these provisions have to be opposed. The prospective ones rest in somewhat of a different category. As I say, I am pleased to see there has been some clarification in that regard. I remind the Senate of the Alert Digest as put out by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and the attention that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee draws to the aspect of undue trespassing on individual rights and liberties.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the time we have available—we are under a great deal of time pressure—it would be impossible to respond to all the comments made in various contributions by senators. First of all, Senator Parer talked about an aspect of these two bills: the changes to the seizure powers of Customs. He indicated his strong support for the changes which came out of the Conroy review. I welcome his support and note there is no opposition to it.

PARA.TAB: For the record, these are significant and major changes to the operational processes of Customs—the most significant since federation, when Customs was one of the first departments established. From now on, inside the border of Australia, Customs will not be able to seize goods for any reason unless it has a judicial warrant. Until now, even in a commercial dispute Customs could seize commercial goods without a warrant. I think this led to a culture within Customs that was out of kilter with the provisions of what we would accept as community standards in this area of legal process in the latter part of the 20th century.

These changes are a major achievement for the reform process within Customs. I pay tribute to the officers of Customs who have helped me draft these amendments, which are significant and major. I also pay tribute, now 15 to 16 months on from the announcement of the Conroy review recommendations, to Customs for performing magnificently in the restructuring of its department. It has made structural and operational changes. As Senator Parer said quite rightly, those changes have been significant. I appreciate his support. I also place on record my appreciation to all the staff at Customs for their work in this area. These are major changes for the better. They will make the service a better service for the Australian people.

I now turn to the real debate on these bills, which is the diesel fuel rebate scheme. Senator Spindler and some other senators have in one form or another criticised the government for not making changes to this scheme earlier than 1995. They said this government has now been in office for some 13 years. We inherited the scheme from the Fraser government in August 1982. Most of the problems we are dealing with in this scheme have come to light over the last three, four or maybe five years. An attempt was made in the 1993 budget to deal with some of these issues. That was my first attempt. I was not very successful, in view of opposition in the Senate. In this budget we have attempted to deal with the problems of the scheme.

In my second reading speech and in debates here on urgency motions I have pointed out to the Senate that this scheme was introduced to help the mining, farming, forestry and fisheries industries in the off-road use of diesel. That was always the policy intent of the Fraser government and it was the policy intent of this government. We intend that this scheme, if it is to survive, should maintain that focus. Every attempt to expand and extend the definition ultimately means that the whole scheme itself will come into question when you see a scheme that cost $150 million or thereabouts in 1982 now costing $1,200 million. At the present growth rate, even with these restrictions and the new clarifications, it is still going to grow significantly.

Senator Spindler made some very damning remarks and descriptions about the whole scheme, basically implying that it should be abolished and that we should start again or do something else. Many sectors in our community would be up in arms at such a suggestion. Those sectors that have an advantage from the scheme ought to be very supportive of what we are doing here tonight to make sure that the scheme maintains its substance and its direction. I have only been in the portfolio two and a half years and since I have been there I have made genuine attempts to address these issues.

Senator Spindler is right to point out the Auditor-General's previous comments about the running of this scheme. It is impossible to guarantee the policy intent of the scheme, that the money being spent is actually being spent as we want it for the scheme, because it is overwhelmingly self-assessment. There are 250,000 applications for diesel fuel rebate every year. We have 140 officers in Customs administering the scheme, and they do a mighty job with the resources they have. They cannot guarantee that every litre of diesel that is claimed for rebate is actually eligible. So we always get criticism.
