The Auditor-General has announced another review of the scheme by the end of this year, and I will bet two bob to Sydney Harbour Bridge that he will criticise aspects of the administration of the scheme—although not the individual officers, because it is impossible for them to carry out and guarantee absolutely the intent of the scheme, even with the clarifications we are now making for it.

I say to the mining and agricultural industries of Australia: if you want this scheme to continue for a long time into the future you ought to support this government's changes made here tonight because they ensure the integrity of the scheme as far as that is humanly possible. That is an important issue.

I want to deal with the sweeper clauses, to give them their nickname—the new clarifications and definitions. They were put into this bill so that there would be less opportunity for people to win some arcane argument in an AAT court or anywhere else to extend the nature of the scheme, and instead of having broad definitions open to argument and interpretation, and clever lawyers and QCs arguing where it could be extended. We have the ridiculous example of only a few weeks ago that pumping water out of the ground is the equivalent of mining. Under any commonsense definition that is absurd, but the AAT said that, the way they make the definition, that is a mining process. No ordinary Australian would claim that that process is equivalent to mining in the common use of the word. So we have problems with the broad definitions being interpreted by the court. Therefore, the government's view was that we define much more clearly who is eligible.

The sweeper clauses that were put before you in the budget were aimed at ensuring that those people who were eligible within the original definitions continued to get the rebate. I accepted from the absolute beginning—and I told my officers this—that there was no doubt that senators and people with legitimate interests in this area would come forward with suggestions for further clarification and description of the definitions. I said, `We will have open discussion and bend over backwards to accept those definitions to ensure that all of those who had been getting the rebate scheme would continue to get it.' One thing we would not do is give new definitions to extend the scope of the scheme beyond what had already been operating for some 13 years. We made that very clear.

We have had long discussions with Senator Crane and other senators. I pay a compliment again—as Senator Crane did—to the work of my officers. They looked at all those definitions to make sure they were feasible, operational, manageable and administrable; they did that very well.

It is no embarrassment to me that there are many pages of further amendments. I always said to my officers, `I don't care how many more pages of amendments we have to take, so long as the scheme is clear and understandable,' and we have achieved that through the sweeper clauses. But we reject the amendments to the sweeper clauses that extend the scope of the scheme into new areas, and we will vote against them. A number of the amendments that the opposition and the Greens have put forward clearly extend the scheme beyond its original operating capacity. We reject that.

We find it difficult to believe the opposition when it claims that we should reduce the outlays. It is now putting forward suggestions that we increase the outlays, thereby increasing government expenditure. The opposition told us that we had to reduce expenditure everywhere in the budget. We did not reduce it in this area; we just made sure that those who should get it, got it. The opposition has put up amendments that extend the scope of the scheme and which will cost the community and the taxpayers many tens of millions of dollars. That goes on the outlays. It is an increase in expenditure, and the government finds that unacceptable.

TALK.START.PARA: —It all depends on how you go in the courts.

—But you are putting forward definitions in the sweeper clauses—irrespective of a court decision—which extend the eligibility into new areas. That is what the opposition is doing, and it is certainly what the Greens are doing. We reject that.

PARA.TAB: Now we turn to the issue of retrospectivity. I understand that, quite rightly, a lot of people on both sides of the parliament are always very cautious about looking at issues of retrospectivity. We have put forward some proposals and, although some senators opposite are calling them `retrospective', in the normal sense of the word they are not retrospective—we are not going back to claim money off people retrospectively. What we are trying to do is ensure that, if we lose all the appeals, the money that the Fraser government and our government envisaged cannot be accessed.

I will tell you why. If we lose all the cases, between $160 million and $200 million will go off the budget. That is an increase in the outlays. Again, the opposition tells us that it is so concerned about reducing outlays and getting the expenditure down, but it is supporting retrospectivity. It is not retrospectivity covering $3 million or $4 million; it is covering between $160 million and $200 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't alter the principle.

—Well, let us turn to the operation of the principle of retrospectivity. In the lobbying that has been going on ever since the budget was announced last month, three major Australian companies have come to see me. They have been openly and publicly campaigning to have the retrospectivity—as you call it—rejected by the Senate. If it is rejected by the Senate and those three companies win the final appeals, at our best estimate they will have a windfall of $70 million plus—and that may be a conservative estimate. That is $70 million for three companies, and that amount goes right back to 1986 transactions.

PARA.TAB: Remember this: regardless of whether those companies—CSR, Boral and Pioneer, and they have openly identified themselves—win in the courts and you defeat the bill in this area, they have already charged their customers at the full cost of the diesel they used in making that product.

Have they announced that if they are successful in getting this money, this windfall gain, they are going to redistribute it back to their customers whom they have already charged? Of course not. They have made no announcement to that effect. If they had announced, `If we win this all the way through and the Senate rejects the government's legislation, we will then reduce our prices for two years by 10 per cent so that the $70 million plus that we will get is redistributed to our customers,' they would have a bit better argument, in my view.

They want the taxpayer to give them a windfall gain. That is unacceptable to the government. They only put forward these claims in the last couple of years and have gone through the court. For several years they willingly paid the full excise on diesel. A number of consultants started going to them, saying, `If we win the case for you we'll have a success fee.' I understand the usual fee is about 25 per cent. So there is a pretty substantial consultants industry at work here, living off the fact that they can redistribute taxpayers' money retrospectively to their clients.

As a result of the fact that these companies have openly claimed they want this amendment defeated and because of the large amounts of money involved, I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that there are senators listed in the pecuniary interests document as having shares in CSR, Pioneer and Boral.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your people who are members of unions? Do you vote on industrial relations bills? Come on; you should be consistent.

—Senator, this goes beyond that. Three companies have specifically campaigned to get this retrospective legislation, as you call it, defeated so that they get a windfall gain of $70 million after they have already charged their customers. I think it would only be appropriate for senators to declare their interests. Senator Watson, always a man of ethics, has already declared his interest—that he has shares in these companies. There are other opposition senators who have shares in these companies. I refer to the pecuniary interests document under the standing orders—the register of senators' interests. The fifth paragraph of the introduction is headed `Declaration of interests in debate in other proceedings'. I believe, as Senator Watson has already done, quite correctly, that those senators ought to declare their interests.

PARA.TAB: If these companies distribute the windfall profit, if they end up getting it all, and then distribute it as profits to the shareholders, in view of that conflict of interest there is a very good case to be made that those senators should abstain from the vote on this clause. In this case we are dealing with three companies which will take over $70 million of taxpayers' money and are not going to distribute it back to their clients. So I draw the attention of the Senate to the pecuniary interests document under the standing orders. As Senator Watson has already declared his interest, I think it is only appropriate that the other senators do so.

I also point out that there are Labor senators and members who have shares in these companies. Of course, they will be voting, against their own interests, to reduce the chance of that money being paid. So they are certainly not voting to improve their financial interest.

From time to time bills pass through this place which may advantage all senators, as members of the community, in an indirect way. But in this case we are dealing with three companies which have publicly campaigned that they want this money. Those who have shares in those companies should declare them. It is a bit strange to us that the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, claims he wants a new set of ethical standards of behaviour for parliamentarians. Here is an example where the opposition can stand up and so declare those interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Some of us may have interests in these companies. I have, as is disclosed in my declaration of interests. I have been sitting here for the last hour or so intending to make a declaration. To save time, I did not put my name on the speakers list to make a speech; I intended to say something at the end. Senator Schacht, you are taking so long that it will be 11 o'clock in a few minutes and I will have sat here for more than an hour waiting to do that, and will then be cut off altogether. The standing orders state quite clearly what is required. I am not doing this because you said so; I know what the rules are and I have been waiting a long time to do it. I interrupt you to do it now because of the way you are carrying on, wasting the time of the Senate and not getting the matter completed. These bills could have been finished tonight.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—Order! There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on another point of order. Under procedural order No. 17(5)(b), a senator, as soon as practicable after a division is called for in the Senate, can make a declaration. It is most unfair of the minister to accuse us of sitting on our interests, if you like. I, too, came down here to make a declaration because I am a small shareholder of two of the companies mentioned. Probably more importantly, my home is heated with diesel oil. For those very reasons I have not taken part in any of the deliberations of the coalition, even though I am the parliamentary secretary to Peter Costello. I have avoided all the deliberations. I have not taken part in this debate or in the coalition debate, even though I had a right to do so. It is most unfair of you, Minister, and absolutely pathetic that you put out a press release which has already been boxed to this effect.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Of course I put out a press release, because I wanted to draw attention to this issue—it is a special issue—so senators clearly understood they had a chance to declare their interests.
—The time to do it has not arisen.
—You are sleazy. You are telling lies.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. The word that is being used across the chamber has been ruled on many occasions to be unparliamentary. I think it should be withdrawn.
—Yes; Senator Crane, will you withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw that. Mr Acting Deputy President, while I am on my feet I raise a point of order relating to the imputation that was made against these people sitting here, in terms of their position, by what Senator Schacht just said. I ask you to ask him to withdraw any reflection against any of my colleagues sitting on this side of the chamber.
—Order! There is no point of order. There was no imputation.
—Due to the fact that the time for government business is about to run out—
—You put out a press release before the time had arrived.
—Of course, and I have drawn it to your attention, and given the opportunity for senators to declare their interests.
—You did not have to do that. You put it out before the opportunity was presented to us.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, in view of the time, I will conclude my remarks. I urge the Senate to support these bills at the second reading stage and the committee stage. I make the point that if the amendments moved by the opposition and the Greens are proceeded with and carried, $200 million-plus of government outlays will be extended. That makes a real mockery of the opposition's position of saying we should reduce government expenditure.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—Order! It being 11 p.m., I propose the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today some papers came across my desk—some with good news and some with bad news. It is the content of those that I want to address tonight in the short time available to me rather than, as I would like to, talk about Governor-Generals, state governors or such matters which are near and dear to my heart. The two that I particularly refer to came in on the Australian Associated Press, the wire service that goes through parliamentarians' offices. This is not the one that contains the pornographic material that others, I understand, are interested in getting access to.

PARA.TAB: The good news story actually came in second. It informed the Australian public that a group of 45 people had been returned to China today by aircraft, bringing to a total of 173 the number of people who, initially, entered this country illegally by boat without any papers whatsoever and that now a further 45 of them have today been returned to their country. That is indeed very good news. It is certainly good news for the taxpayers of Australia. Since their arrival in around December of last year, it has cost the Australian taxpayer quite a deal of money to keep those people together in body and soul.

The other bit of bad news that arrived two minutes earlier to this on the same wire service told the Australian public, and the Western Australian public in particular, about a rooftop demonstration taking place at the Port Hedland Detention Centre by a group of some 40 people who arrived in Australia on the boat Jabiru on Christmas Day last year, 25 December. The article said that there was concern by immigration department staff for the welfare of the people and, in particular, some five children that have been brought onto the rooftop in Port Hedland. The protesters have brought with them blankets, mattresses, food and water onto the roof. The demand, I am told, is that they want the boat in which they arrived illegally on our shores returned to them. Unfortunately, that will not be possible because the boat, as I am informed, has been destroyed.
The other bit of news that came across my desk today was a newsletter from the Australian Catholic Refugee Office entitled `Journeys' End June 1995 No. 6'. The first paragraph states:
At a `summit' conference held in Canberra at Parliament House during refugee week,—

SPEECH.PARA: which was last week—

the Minister for Immigration stated that the boat peoples' cases were being handled with increased expediency with only about 50 having been held in detention for more than 12 months. Sadly, some of these 50 have been held for more than five years. Since the Minister has discretion to give bridging visas to those held in long term detention, not doing so continues to give the impression that lengthy detention is a punishment for seeking redress in the courts for perceived injustices in the refugee determination process.

The author, whom I believe to be Father Larry Reitmeyer from the Australian Catholic Refugee Office, is incorrect in that—certainly incorrect as it relates to two of the people who have been in detention now for more than five years.

PARA.TAB: I spoke with one of them when I was in Port Hedland on 10 June this year, just three weeks ago. That particular individual is not waiting for the outcome of a court case. The individual is actually waiting for a hearing of an application before the Refugee Review Tribunal. I understand that that hearing would have been held by now. The individual was not waiting on the courts, he was waiting for the due administrative processes.

I do not know how many applications this particular individual had made either for primary application or for review of rejected applications. But I do know that he, like many of his country people who previously arrived in Australia by boat and who subsequently did return to their home country of Cambodia, has the ability at any time of his choosing to return to Cambodia. His confinement at the Port Hedland Detention Centre is in fact his own doing.

I had the good fortune to talk to Father Larry at the refugee seminar in Canberra last week. He gave me a recipe to help ease the pain that I am feeling in my back. He was in the news recently when he was in Derby, which is a town in the north of Western Australia, my home state. He was there just prior to the time when 100 boat people, who were being held in a detention centre, decided that they did not want to remain there and knocked over the fence and walked out. According to newspaper reports, they remained at large for 5 hours. Father Larry had earlier addressed the people in the Curtin Detention Centre at Derby.

In speaking about this issue tonight, the point I want to make is that there seems to be an increasing tendency towards violence against the people who are detained in these two detention centres in the north west of my state. I am concerned about the protection of the individuals in those centres. Women and children are held in those centres and they may be vulnerable if there is violence. I am also concerned because there have been a number of escapes from the Curtin Detention Centre and the Port Hedland Detention Centre and the tighter security facility at Perth airport. I have grave fears that legal citizens of Australia might be hurt by these people who might feel desperate from time to time.

In yesterday's West Australian there was an article entitled `Injuries in detainee lunch brawl'. This article told of an argument at the Port Hedland Detention Centre where people, including officers from the Australian Protective Services, were hurt. These are law abiding citizens who are trying to earn a quid by maintaining peace and security at that facility. It is not fair on them or their families that, in earning a living, they have to face the threat of violence.

Thankfully, the violence is at a very low level in Australia, but it is not at other detention centres in other parts of the region in which we live. We have seen spectacular coverage on television in recent months of 4,000 people breaking out of a camp in Kuala Lumpur. We have again seen further spectacular scenes of law enforcement officers at the Whitehead detention camp in Hong Kong who had to resort to the use of tear gas in order to control people who were rioting.

Not only the Australian authorities but also the international community have done an enormous amount to help these very unfortunate people. Those who have been found to be fleeing persecution have been granted refugee status. Australia has done more than its share to alleviate the problems facing those people, particularly those from Vietnam. I think it has to stop.

While the facilities we have at the moment are low security, if the current trend towards violence continues—such as the sit in that is taking place, as I understand it, at Port Hedland at the moment—then, unfortunately, there will be great demands on the community to increase the security at those facilities and make them more secure and make them more like prisons. They should not be designed to be like that. I would not like to see what happened at Whitehead repeated at Port Hedland or Derby.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today the collapse in the level of sports funding shown in the current budget was demonstrated by my colleague Senator Campbell, when he pointed out that the forward estimates show a slashing of sports funding by something like $34.4 million, or more than a 30 per cent cut. The response from the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) clearly indicated that there will be some lollies held out and promised in the next election campaign. That was the import of Senator Faulkner's response. He said that it will be looked after next time.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, this is just a set-up for another election promise from the Labor Party. The people of Australia know how to deal with Labor Party election promises. These increased sporting grants will be l-a-w. As we know, l-a-w turns into l-i-e non-appearance.

What Senator Campbell was pointing out was quite generous. He understated the volume of fall in sports funding that has taken place. He was particularly generous to the government. I am not critical of Senator Campbell for being so generous—it shows an ability of spirit—but the fact is that in 1994-95, which ends tomorrow, total sport and recreation funding of $116 million will in 1996-97 be only $61.2 million, according to the forward estimates. That is a fall of $50 million.

When I raised this matter in the Senate estimates, I was told that basically the major reason for that additional fall on top of the forward estimates fall which emerges from the end of the four-year program, as Senator Faulkner rather uncharitably pointed out today, was the end of several schemes. One of them that is of great interest to us is the community, sporting, recreation and cultural program.

TALK.START.PARA: —More commonly known as—?
—The whiteboard fund.
—The sports—
—Rorts.

—I thank Senator Campbell and Senator Troeth; they are quite right. It was the end of the sports rorts gimmick. That is why that funding fell. Even this government recognised that it was totally indefensible. It was a shonky scheme run by a minister who eventually got run out of town because of the disgraceful way she handled this money, which, as the Auditor-General pointed out, was directed overwhelmingly to marginal Labor seats.

PARA.TAB: I am raising this not just to score a couple of points. It is to demonstrate that the dishonesty involved in the sports rorts affair is still alive and well and living in the Labor Party.

I have here today a copy of a letter sent by Mr Stephen Martin MP, the Speaker of the House of Representatives. One would expect a certain standard from a member who holds that high office. Yet this is what he says to the secretary of the Wollongong Amateur Swimming Club in explaining why the swimming club will not be able to get any funding from the federal government:

SPEECH.PARA: You will be aware that throughout the entire time I have been an elected representative I have vigorously and consistently supported the improvement, establishment and development of sporting facilities.
As a Government Member I promoted the establishment and continued existence of the Community, Sporting, Recreation and Cultural Program as a funding source for regional sporting activities.

I am interested to see that Mr Martin is a strong supporter of the sports rorts. I suppose that anyone in the Labor Party would tend to adopt that approach, particularly those from the right wing of the Labor Party in New South Wales, because it was a shonky deal. Get this bit:
Unfortunately, due to the basic and crass politics of the Liberal Party over the so called "White Board Affair", this valuable funding program simply does not exist at the Federal Government Level.
Why not? This government cancelled it. This member very sensibly recognised that it was a shonky deal, and so it has ended. Mr Martin goes on:
There are many projects such as your proposal which deserve funding and would be important additions to our sporting infrastructure.
Sadly, because of the bloody-minded attitude of the Liberal Party at the Federal Level it will have to fall to the State Government to fund a project of this nature.

Let me tell Mr Martin this: according to the secretary, the club has been trying to get funding for the last 40 years. The local members have made promises going back as far as 1954. In other words, the Labor government has had since 1983 to fund this project, but it decided it did not want to. Mr Martin's government took the view that, despite the fact that it was spending $62 million on this shonky deal, the Wollongong Amateur Swimming Club did not deserve any money whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: For Mr Martin to pretend that the Liberal Party had anything to do with that decision not to fund the Wollongong Amateur Swimming Club when the Labor Party was handing out the money is simply uncomplicated, dishonest politicking of the worst kind, but we have learnt to expect this from the Labor Party.

The simple fact is that all that money was being spent on marginal seats, and Wollongong is not a marginal seat. Sure, by accident it did get some funding for a few things. There is no doubt about that. But the great bulk of the money went to marginal seats because it was a political stunt. It is about time Mr Martin faced up to the facts and stopped trying to blame the Liberal Party. For heavens sake, he is trying to blame us for Labor's shonky community, sporting, recreation and cultural program. The Labor Party got caught out with its fingers in the till. Up to $62 million was allocated on a whiteboard by a minister who pretended she did not know she was breaking the rules. She broke even their rules, and their rules are pretty ordinary.

Here we have a situation where a Labor member of parliament, the Speaker of the lower house, is prepared to put out this kind of deceptive and dishonest letter to try to win a few votes. It is not even as if he is in a marginal seat. I do not know why he need try. But the fact is that he is prepared to do anything. I think the rest of the Senate should be aware of the tactics that Labor people are using in this dishonest way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that all senators would endorse my belief that a fundamental tenet of our Western legal system—whether it is Australia, Britain or the United States—is access to legal representation and advice in an equitable way. Recent events in New South Wales, however, raise serious questions about the power of large corporations such as Telstra to limit the access to legal services by the community. This issue is of such grave implication that it should be investigated by the Trade Practices Commission or at least the Attorney-General's Department. The story starts with the New South Wales Public Interest Advocacy Centre, which is a clearing house for public interest legal matters. The PIAC Bulletin No. 5 of May-June 1995 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: In seeking to assist one public interest, the Clearing House has been beset by obstacles which deserve investigation in the public interest.

A resident group concerned about the health implications of a telecommunications development in their area sought assistance to challenge the development, which is adjacent to a kindergarten, baby health centre and residential premises. The CSIRO has released a report substantiating some of the health concerns raised by the residents.

Attempts by the Clearing House to secure legal advice for the group were met with rejection from 12 member firms. According to the firms, the corporation in question has an arrangement with 43 law firms whereby the firms undertake not to act against it in any matter in return for receiving some part of its legal budget.
The result: any person attempting to obtain redress against an activity of the corporation which appears to offend the public interest, is denied access to lawyers with relevant experience.
As I suggested, this raises the serious issue of the power of corporations to affect the access to legal services by the community.

PARA.TAB: My office contacted the Public Interest Advocacy Centre on 23 June and, after receiving permission from their client, the Harbord Residents Group, was told that the corporation in question was Telstra and that the offending development was a mobile phone base station, a transmitting tower. What is Telstra so worried about? Is it just a few local community groups opposing the siting of a few transmitting towers? Or does it have more serious concerns?

It has recently been reported that the Warringah council has received a $20,000 contribution from Optus after it did not object to the company building a telecommunications base station at the Forestville War Memorial Playing Fields. In November last year I tabled in this chamber a draft report on problems associated with electromagnetic radiation. That report referred to the research into the health effects of electromagnetic radiation from a variety of sources, including video display units, fluorescent lights and electrical transmission lines.

A follow-up report, to be released soon, refers to the increasing litigation that is occurring against cellular telephone manufacturers. Overseas, brain tumour claims are `popping up everywhere now', according to attorney Bruce Goodhart of Holstein, Mack and Klein from Chicago in the United States, as quoted in the Microwave News of November-December 1994. According to the cover story, entitled `Why electromagnetic field litigation could be the next asbestos', in the January 1994 Journal of the American Bar Association:

SPEECH.PARA: Presently, more studies exist that appear to link EMF exposure to an increased risk of cancer than existed linking asbestos exposure to an increased risk of cancer at a similar embryonic stage of asbestos litigation.

Telstra and other carriers are not ignorant of these events taking place in the US and they have a valid right to be concerned about possible litigation. But to attempt to redress this threat by limiting the access to legal services by the community is an horrendous action and we should be very much aware of it.

PARA.TAB: If this practice is allowed to continue, we can expect other industrial groups to copy the strategy. I can well imagine that suppliers and manufacturers of agricultural chemicals, for example, may find it advantageous to jump on the bandwagon as well, attempting to limit the public's access to the opportunity to seek legal redress. This practice needs to be well aired in this chamber. The debate needs to be seriously considered. The practice needs careful scrutiny by this chamber and any other forum in which it can be exposed.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity to correct a statement I made today in the debate on the demand for certain executive council documents by the Senate. During that debate I said that the payment to be made to the Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Lawrence, is a known sum. Senator Vanstone brought my notice to the fact that it is not a known sum and thought I should correct that statement, which I now do. I am taking this process on the advice of the Deputy Clerk—that great parliamentarian, Anne Lynch—who told me how to do it. So I correct that statement: it is not a known sum.
—And she is a Collingwood supporter.

—And a Collingwood supporter. I have often heard you speak in glowing terms of both her and Collingwood, Senator Robert Ray. I take Senator Vanstone's point. It is not a known sum. When you are wrong, you have to say you are wrong.

PARA.TAB: The thrust of what I was saying is this: there is a variety of privileges and rights that have to, at times, be balanced against each other. Clearly, the way the constitution is established, the division of chapters flowing from the constitution of the United States of America, means that one branch of government should not readily intrude on another. That has been made most clear by the judiciary in a series of cases—for example, the boilermakers case and, more recently, the Brandy case.

Logically, there must be a division of powers between the executive and the legislature. When demanding documents, the legislature has to be mindful of executive privilege and should not lightly set that aside. In other words, it should only do so for good reason. The point I was making today in respect of Dr Lawrence was that all the facts that are needed for this chamber to take such actions as it will against the minister are already known; namely, a royal commission is inquiring into her alleged conduct in the past when she was a member of the Western Australian legislature, and the government has decided to finance her legal costs, as I understand it, not only for the royal commission but also in respect of any challenge she may make through the processes of the court.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean the government or the taxpayer?

—The government has to expend money and spend it responsibly in the interests of everybody in the country. Senator Campbell's comment makes it quite clear that my point is valid. He knows all the details there are to know to make the point that taxpayers' money has been expended by this government on legal costs that might be incurred by Dr Lawrence. He knows that. He and other people have interjected on other occasions. All of those interjections indicate that they know all there is to know about this matter.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, why do they want to pursue the documents that are involved in this matter? The only apparent reason is that they want to go on a fishing expedition, not to protect taxpayers' funds, because they know all there is to know about that, but to embarrass the government. If you are going to go on in a party political way, you must expect a party political answer. Senator Campbell has made the case for me. He made a political interjection—that this is a political exercise. That is the whole thrust of the interjection he made. In conclusion—

TALK.START.PARA: —Go on; I'm enjoying this.
—If he said it all, you do not have to go on.

—Senator Troeth is absolutely right. Senator Campbell has summed it all up. Senator Troeth has saved some minutes of the Senate's time by having made that point. I do not resile from the confession I have made about using the phrase `known sum' when I should not have used it. Having said that, I cannot use the expression `known sum' because nobody knows what the sum will be.
—The lawyers can guess.
—As you say, Senator Campbell, nobody ever quite knows what the lawyers might charge and how long this might go on for.

PARA.TAB: All that can be known about the fees is known to the government and everybody else. In other words, as Senator Campbell has said, the sum can only be ascertained at the end of the process. It is no good searching amongst the documents that the government might have to find out what the sum will be. All lawyers being worthy of their hire are properly paid for the hard work they do on behalf of Dr Lawrence and on behalf of the various courts and commissions that they will also help come to their conclusions.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of justice.
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some comments tonight on the accreditation of child-care centres. It is important to note that after Friday, 30 June, those centres that have not registered for accreditation will begin to lose their fee relief. In this chamber we have discussed at length the problems associated with accreditation and the forced adherence to the arbitrary and ridiculous guidelines which centres must follow in order to receive a standard to guarantee accreditation.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, has prevaricated on the question of cost: sometimes saying that accreditation would cost no more than 88c per child per week and later suggesting that she did not know in fact how much accreditation was likely to cost.

The government has had a study done by Coopers and Lybrand, the results of which were released today. This study has borne out coalition concerns about the additional time and money which the system requires. Getting parents to become involved in the process, the extra paperwork, the pressure on staff, and the hurdle of getting started were noted as difficulties contained within the system. The subjectivity of the principles which determine accreditation and the background of reviewers were also highlighted as other subjects of concern to centres.

Throughout this process the coalition has expressed a great deal of concern about the draconian nature of this legislation. The big stick approach, whereby parents and children will lose fee relief if the centre owner does not register for accreditation, is totally abhorrent. The minister quotes that 94 per cent of centres have been accredited, and has also said on occasion that centres are cheerfully embracing accreditation as an attractive and constructive process. I ask the minister how many centres have not happily and cheerfully embraced accreditation.

Of course the number of accredited centres is high: the government is threatening child-care proprietors with the loss of their livelihood if they do not become accredited. Under similar circumstances most people would submit to such measures irrespective of whether they support them. I have had many letters from child-care proprietors and I would like to read to the Senate a letter I received from the director of the Jolly Frog Kindergarten in New South Wales, Ms Eileen Byrnes. She is writing to Quentin Bryce who is the chairman of the National Childcare Accreditation Council. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Quentin
In response to your phone call 27-6-95, please find enclosed registration form, cheque for $100.00 and self study report in the name of the Jolly Frog Kindergarten.
We are registering under protest.
We understand and object strenuously to the fact that we are forced to take part in this process to protect our children's parent's income related subsidy.
We are registering at the very last minute also as a form of protest.

We request that our long standing opposition to the link to C.C.A. through this process be brought to the attention of the Commonwealth Minister for Family Services, Senator Rosemary Crowley once again.
We do not feel that it is appropriate that the parent's of our attending children should be threatened with losing the Child Care Assistance if our centre is not complying.
We believe it is disgraceful and immoral that our compliance or noncompliance will have a direct effect on our client's income.

Our centre has a long standing reputation for high quality care and education. We find it irritating, to say the least, that some bureaucrat will come into our centre once every one, two or three years to tell us we are good bad, or indifferent. One wonders why we bother to do any training
We feel we no longer run, own or direct a private centre. We have become a government run institution.
Move over big brother!

We wish our opposition to the cost of this program to be registered also. We believe the Minister has wasted taxpayer's funds on a totally useless exercise that will not make one jot of difference to centres not supplying quality care and has increased paper work, stress and expense for those that are.

We also object to the fact that the rules of entry for children are being changed at the whim of government officials and we put this government on notice that if they continue to discriminate against children because of their parent's employment situation they will have a fight on their hands.
I request that this letter be read in both houses of parliament.
Yours faithfully
Eileen Byrnes
Director.

This letter is representative of a large number of child-care centre owners in Australia. I received earlier today a letter from a Mr Bruce Lizotte, expressing the same sentiments. Concern for the parents is prompting some child-care centre owners to register for accreditation. Centre owners feel very uncertain about the whole process. I have had representation from other centres who, up to a few weeks ago, had not received responses to queries about the cut-off date and likely ramifications. The head of the National Child-care Accreditation Council, Ms Quentin Bryce, has been calling child-care centre proprietors around the country trying to heavy-hand them into registration.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I state that the coalition is not opposed to the concept of quality assurance and standards of care, per se. On the contrary, the coalition is completely cognisant of the importance of high standards of care for children. What we are opposed to, however, is the coercion of child-care centre proprietors to register for accreditation through the removal of child-care assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the President, upon notice, on 8 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the adoption of an information pricing policy by the Government and its impact on the Parliamentary Library:
(1) Has the annual budget for the Parliamentary Library been increased to take account of the change in pricing policy.

(2) On an annual basis since the introduction of this policy, what is the specific budgetary allocation made to the Parliamentary Library to enable it to purchase information from those Government and semi-Government bodies which have adopted this pricing policy.

(3) In each year since the introduction of the pricing policy how much has been expended by the Parliamentary Library purchasing information from the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Attorney-General's Department.
(4) In each year since the introduction of the pricing policy, how much has been expended by the Parliamentary Library purchasing information from all Government and semi-Government bodies.
(5) Are there any instances where the work of the Parliamentary Library is hampered or affected in any way because of budgetary constraints having an impact on the capacity to purchase information.

(6) Is there any supplementation by the Department of Finance for the purchasing of information; if so, does it apply to all departments and agencies from which the Parliamentary Library might wish to purchase information; if not, what specific section of the library budget is used for this purpose, and has there been any negative impact from this usage.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: 1. The Parliamentary Library's collection comprises a range of information sources and media. In addition to obtaining monographs and serials in hard copy form, the Parliamentary Library obtains data and information on computer tape, CD-Rom,

PARA.TAB: The budget for development of this collection is based on a total figure established by a special formula agreed with the Department of Finance (DoF). This is designed to cover all pricing changes impacting the purchase of collection material, including the effects of currency exchange movements and individual price movements.

2. The budgetary allocation to the Parliamentary Library for collection development purposes is at the overall collection level. Budget allocations agreed with DoF, after the impact of the efficiency dividend and price movements, are:

The Parliamentary Library makes a number of purchases each year from government agencies, including the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Attorney-General's Department. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian National Gallery: High Court of Australia

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Regional Development, upon notice, on 29 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What changes are proposed for the entry to the Australian National Gallery and the High Court of Australia.
(2) What costs will this entail in design, documentation, implementation and any other costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) A detailed site master plan, a framework for development and management of the National Gallery and High Court precinct, is being finalised by the National Capital Planning Authority. It provides a strategy for improving traffic circulation, parking, pedestrian access and amenity and the future development of buildings and landscape. An order of costs and works is included in the plan.
The changes proposed to the entry of the National Gallery of Australia and the High Court are:
rationalisation of the two vehicle entry/exit points on King Edward Terrace to one central entry/exit for the precinct;
removal of the gravel car park in front of the High Court and relocating the parking space to a less obvious area;

creation of two forecourts on King Edward Terrace, one directly in front of each institution, which will be the principle address points for pedestrians. The forecourts will be paved and furnished with flagpoles, bollards, signs and sculptures to reflect the character of each institution;
between these forecourts is the proposed single vehicle entry point which will be marked by a grove of Eucalypts; and,

removal of approximately ten plane trees to make way for the establishment of the courts and vehicle entry. The feasibility of relocating these trees elsewhere along King Edward Terrace is currently being investigated.

Section 5 of the Parliament Act 1974 requires that all works associated with the project be approved by both Houses of Parliament. Parliamentary approval will be sought when detailed design drawings and documentation are complete.

(2) The 1993/94 Budget allocated $1.6m over three years to the National Capital Planning Authority for improvements to the precinct and the precinct entry. The development of the Site Master Plan cost $125,175.
The costs for the improvements to the entry are:
Detail Design, Documentation and construction oversight fees—$167,800.00 which includes Landscape Architects, Surveyors, Engineers, Quantity Surveyors and Graphic Design Consultants;

The Construction budget for the entry works is $1.32 million which includes roadworks, parking, paving, signage, planting, irrigation, lighting, architectural elements such as walls etc and siting of sculpture.
